The High Court Division while not accepting the finding as regard possession of the land in suit is quite silent as to that the said finding of fact arrived at by courts of fact either was not based on evidence or the finding was made on non-consideration or mis-reading of evidence as regard the said fact. The that state of the matter High Court Division- was in error in embarking upon for fresh assessment of evidence on the point uniformly decided by the courts below.

 

Sufia Khatun Vs. Amin Hossain Mondal & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 164.

 

Section -115(1)

 

Suit for a decree of Specific Performance of Contract -In the instant case out of Tk. 16,537.50 only an amount of Tk. 2,000.00 was paid by the plaintiff an earnest money to get the Bainapatra. As per the Bainapatra the plaintiff supposed to pay further amount of Tk. 14,537.50 within next six months, otherwise the Bainapatra would be unenforceable. Apparently the plaintiff failed to make such payment within the stipulated time though after expiry of that time the defendant No.l allowed him further seven days. In such situation I hold the view that for execution of Bainapatra a seller can not wait for unlimited time to sell the land to the person on whose behalf she or he executed the Bainapatra. The seller used to sell the land for his/her necessity. Waiting for unlimited time will never meet such necessity. In the instant case the defendant No.l executed the bainapatra to sell her property to meet up the expense of constructing her dwelling huts which was not possible by Taka 2,000.00 only and as such for meeting her necessity she sold her other properties. In such circumstances the plaintiff is not entitled to get any discretionary relief like the decree in such suit for specific performance of contract.

 

Srimati Dipti Rani Das Vs Muzaffar Ahmed & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 475.

 

Section -115(1)

 

On perusal of record it appears to me that the courts below did not exercise their discretion in judicial manner. In deciding the suit the Courts below failed to find that the plaintiff did not approach the Court with clean hand rather he approached the Court with some false concocted story which was disbelieved. When the Courts below disbelieved such story they committed illegality in decreeing the suit.

 

Srimati Dipti Rani Das Vs Muzaffar Ahmed & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 475.

 

Section-115(l)

 

It appears that the appellate court and the High Court Division concurrently held that the plaintiffs could not prove his right of easement of the pathway and dismissed the suit of the plaintiff petitioner. The solenama purported to have been filed in criminal case does not contain any schedule of the pathway and such a solenama has been rightly held not to be a conclusive proof of the plaintiffs right of easement on the land of the respondents. The case has been correctly decided by the courts below on proper assessment of evidence on record causing no failure of justice.

 

Giyash Uddin Vs. Martuza Bibi & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 316.

 

Section 115(1) Not a proper Judgment of reversal

 

It appears that all the issues involved in suit have rightly been framed, considered and decided by trial court with reference to evidence and materials on record but the impugned judgment and decree of the court of appeal below is not a proper judgment of reversal as it failed to consider the evidence orally and documentary on record and as such the court of appeal below committed an error of law resulting in an erroneous decision occasioning failure of justice.

 

Abdul Khaleque Vs. Khorshed Alain & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 46.

 

Section-llS(l) Whether revisional application, as preferred by the defendant-respondent-petitioner assailing the judgment and decree passed in appeal without preferring any appeal against the judgment and decree passed by the trial Court

 

To address the point of non-preferring of Appeal by the defendant-respondent-petitioner against the preliminary decree, it will be sufficient to state that the Revisional jurisdiction of this Court empowers it to interefere with the Subordinate Courts Judgment if it appears to this Court that the Subordinate Court's have committed error of law in passing decree or order occasioning failure of justice and in that case this Court is empowered to make such order in the Suit or proceeding as it things fit. Therefore, any error committed by the Subordinate Courts either at the trial stage or at the appellate stage is amenable to the jurisdiction of this court, irrespective of parties failure to take up any appeal to the higher Court.

 

Hashen Ali & Ors Vs Suruj Ali & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 295.

 

Section-115(l)

 

It is a settled principles of law that concurrent finding of facts arrived at by the Courts below should not be disturbed by the High Court Division in its revisional jurisdiction under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure unless it can be shown that the finding is based on gross mis-reading or non-consideration of evidence or founded on misconception or misapplication of law or misinterpretation of any document or otherwise it is perverse.

Md. Kobbat Ali Sikder Vs Dayal Chandra Biswas & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 305.

 

Section-115(l) Motive behind the benami transaction

 

From the evidence I do not find any reason to believe that the defendant No.l purchased the suit land himself either by his own money or money provided by his grand mother. Rather on evidence it is established that the plaintiff purchased the suit land on 21.6.1974 and 5.10.1974 vide exhibits-7 and 8 in the benami of his minor son, the defendant No.l out of his money. -Held; Considering the decisions mentioned herein before settled by the Appellate Division, I am of the considered view that the plaintiff proved the motive behind the purchase of the suit land in the benami of his minor son, the defendant No.l by his own money and that he had, been possessing the suit land by adducing cogent and reliable evidence, both oral and documentary -Both the Courts below rightly and legally found concurrently that the plaintiff could prove his title to and possession over the suit land by adducing cogent and reliable evidence and thereby did not commit any error of 1 aw resulting in an error occasioning failure of justice.

 

Abdur Rashid Gazi Vs Nur Ali Gazi & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 315.

 

Section-115(l) Concurrent  finding   of facts   based   upon contrary to evidence.

 

It is a settled proposition of law settled by the Apex Court that the concurrent finding or lacts arrived at by the Courts below should not be disturbed by the High Court Division in revisional jurisdiction under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure unless it can be shown that those are based upon misreading or non-consideration of evidence or founded on misconception or misapplication of law or on misinterpretation of any material document or otherwise perverse being contrary to evidence on record, law and materials on record.

 

Abdur Rashid Gazi Vs Nur Alt Gazi & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 315.

 

Section-115(1)

 

Whether the suit in which ex-parte decree was obtained by the Respondent was barred under the provision of the Forest Act and that the High Court Division was in error in setting aside the finding of the last Court of fact that the decree in Title Suit No.860 of 1981 was obtained by fraud and collusion between the plaintiff of the said suit and the government functionaries.

 

The finding of the appellate Court that the decree in the Title Suit No.860 of 1981 was obtained by fraud was also based on misconception of law enunciated in the cases mentioned hereinabove and that the said finding was made upon the view that the documents on the basis of which the plaintiff of the previous suit claimed his title in the land were not genuine, although the question of genuineness of the claim on the basis of the said documents was not the subject matter of the suit filed by the appellants. The appellants were required to establish for getting the ex-parle decree set aside on the ground of fraud that summons of the previous suit was not served on them and thereby they were prevented from placing their case before the Court or that the Court was misled in passing the ex-parte decree upon the representation that the summons of the suit was duly served on the defendants. As already stated hereinbefore that the summons of the previous suit was served on the defendant and that although the plaintiff-appellants filed the suit alleging fraud on the ground of non-service of summons but at the trial of the suit they proceeded taking the stand that the claim of the plaintiff of the previous suit as regard the land in suit was based on non-genuine documents or in other words defendant-Respondent in the previous suit obtained the ex-parte decree on the basis of perjured evidence, but as has already been mentioned that setting aside of the ex-parte decree on the ground of obtaining the same on the basis of perjured evidence was never accepted by the Court as the ground for setting aside the ex-parte decree.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Osimuddin 19 BLT (AD) 119.

 

Section-115(l) Judgment of reversal

 

The claim of the defendant Madrassa is that the plaintiff along with his uncle Sirajuddin executed a deed of gift in favour of the Madrassa and the defendant has acquired right, title and interest on the disputed land on the basis of the said deed and also by way of adverse possession for over 12 years -Held; On perusal of the Exhibit-'Ka' it appears that the plaintiff was a minor at the time of execution of the said deed for which the sub-registrar refused to register that deed. As such the same cannot be a deed in the eye of law and it has no value in the eye of law. So, the defendant could not claim that he has acquired any right, title and possession in the suit land.

 

Panchalipara Ebtedaya Madrassa Vs. Abdul Kader 19 BLT (AD) 12.

 

Section-115(l) Irregularity and not an Illegality

 

It is true in passing the impugned order the Court below did not, in so many words, discuss the reasons which led him to pass an order and the trial Court below passed the impugned order stating all along <rtft in place of fel^t and f^l^t in place of ^t. But from the materials on record, it appears that the materials on record and law justify the order. It is well settled that mere omission to assign reasons in the impugned order is not fatal if in law the order is sustainable. So, it is mere irregularity and not an illegality and the impugned order cannot be knocked down on that count. We, therefore, are not inclined to disturbed the impugned order.

 

United Traders Ltd Vs. Motorola Technology. 19 BLT (HCD) 396.

 

Section - 115(1) Whether the finding of facts be erroneous

 

Assessment and evaluation of the evidence on record is the primary duty of the trial court as well as the appellate court as a last court of fact and more so when a judgment of the trial court is reversed by the appellate court, it is incumbent upon the appellate court to assess and evaluate the evidence by himself or itself and in the absence of such evaluation the judgment of reversal on the basis of finding of facts can not but be erroneous.

 

Ganendra Nath Mondal Vs. Kalipada Mondal & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 424.

 

Section-115(l) Concurrent finding of facts

 

It appears that the findings arrived at by the Courts below having been rested upon consideration and discussion of legal evidence and materials on record and also on a correct and proper analysis of the legal aspects involved in the case and the findings being findings of fact are not liable to be disturbed by the High Court Division in exercise of power under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Abdul Awal & Ors Vs. Abdul Hai & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 596.

 

Section-115(1)

 

Admittedly that the defendant-petitioner Nos.l and 2 are ejmali owners of the suit land and that the agreement was signed by the defendant No.l - The High Court Division held that the defendant No.l entered into an agreement for sale of the disputed tank with the plaintiff at Tk.49,000.00 on receipt of earnest money to execute and register the deed of sale within one month after arrival of the defendant No.l from India. The aforesaid agreement for sale is only binding upon defendant-petitioner No.l but not upon the defendant No.2 who is not a party to the agreement. It appears that the High Court Division found that learned Subordinate Judge committed an error of law in passing the impugned judgment and decree allowing the appeal in full which has resulted in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.

 

Sree Gonga Narayan Shaha & Anr Vs. Sankar Mondal & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 50.

 

Section-115(l) Without taking step for representing the minors

 

The learned Advocate-on-Record submitted that the High Court Division was in error in concurring with the finding of the lower appellate Court as to presumption of jointness of the family in Muslim Law. It is seen from the judgment of the lower appellate Court that the said Court on consideration of the evidence on record held that on the death of the father of the plaintiffs and the defendant No.l, the defendant No.l being elder brother of the minor plaintiffs were looking after the members of the family of Faizuddin Sheikh i.e. father of the plaintiffs and the defendant No.l and it is also seen from the materials on record that while the defendant No.l was actually managing the property left by the father of plaintiffs and the defendant No.l, some of the properties left by the father of the plaintiffs and defendant No. 1 were put to auction and the same were purchased in the name of the wife of the defendant No. 1. It has already been mentioned the auction was held without taking any step for representing the minors and also without impleading the co-sharers and in that background of the matter the appellate Court held that the auction was not genuine, rather the defendant No.l purchased the property in the name of his wife to deprive the co-sharers.

 

Tarn Miah Sheikh & Ors Vs. Alek Sheikh & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 173.

 

Section 115(1) Whether Judgment of reversal is proper one

 

A judgment reversing the decree of the trial court without adverting to the evidence on which the trial court relied is not a proper judgment of reversal and is liable to be set aside.

 

Md. Samsur Rahman & Ors Vs. Md. Sukur All Khan & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 388.

 

Section 115(1)

 

Suit was instituted by the lessees The judgment and order dated 16.3.1998 passed by a Single Bench of this Court in Civil Revision No.8052 of 1991 annexed with the supplementary affidavit filed by the opposite parties arising out of Other Class Suit No. 12 of 1989 instituted by the present petitioners, the lessees, under the defendant No.l for cancellation of the registered deed No.4398 dated 20.5.1989. On perusal of the said judgment and order it appears that the suit was instituted by the lessees under the Government who had no locus standi to challenge the registered deed No.4398 dated 20.5.1989 of the plaintiff and the Court rightly held that the suit was not maintainable. Further in the said judgment no decision was given as to the validity of the deed in question. In the case in hand the Government represented by the defendant No.l passed the impugned order dated 26.7.1993 for cancellation of the Genuineness Certificate dated 29.4.1989 and registered deed of transfer dated 20.5.1989. Thus the judgment and order dated I 16.3.1989 passed by this Court in Civil Revision No.8052 of 1991 in the facts and) circumstances of the present case can not be a bar in the disposal of the instant Suit.

 

Jhaiya Barman & Ors Vs. Md. Khondoker Syedul Islam & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 344.

 

Section 115(1)

 

Whether the Revision Application is maintainable as the petitioner was neither a party in appeal nor in the original pre-emption case.

 

The petitioner's case is that petitioner having I acquired the case property by way of an exchange deed, mutated his name and has been enjoying the said land by erecting a 2 (two) storied building thereon. The petitioner was not aware about the pre-emption case as well as the Miscellaneous Appeal No.27 of 1998 who on 29.05.2002 for the first time on getting a notice issued by Mowchak Police Sub-station, Kaliakor came to know that the opposite party no. 1 herein as pre-emptor obtained a Pre-emption order in Miscellaneous Appeal No.27 of 1998 against the predecessor in interest of the petitioner namely Md. Abdul Hakim Talukder, who is opposite party No.2 herein. The said Pre­emption order dated 30.08.2001 passed in Miscellaneous Appeal No.27 of 1998 has adversely affected the right, title and interest of the petitioner and as such the petitioner has filed this Revisional Application challenging the Pre-emotion order dated 30.08.2001 though, the petitioner was neither party in the pre-emption case nor he was made party in the pre-emption Misc. Appeal. - Impugned judgment and order of pre-emption dated 30.08.2001 passed in Miscellaneous Appeal No.27 of 1998 has adversely affected the right, title and interest of the petitioner though; the petitioner was neither party in the original pre-emption case nor in the pre-emption Misc. Appeal. Therefore in the facts and circumstances of the case, I have no hesitation to hold that the instant Revisional application is well maintainable. Beside, on top of that the Revisional power of the High Court Division is supervisory power which may also be exercised suo motu. - Relied on 1984 PLD (SC) 166 and 21 DLR (SC) 50.

 

Md. Ismail Hossain Vs. Shaklrina & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 194.

 

Section 115(1) Presumption-consummation of marriage

 

The evidence of PW1 furnished corroboration with the evidence of his uncle P.W.2 Md. Rahmatullh. On appraisal of the evidence of aforesaid witnesses, it transpires to me that the evidence of these PWs are consistent, uniform and corroborative with each other particularly, in respect of leading conjugal life by both of them for about three/four months. There is absolutely no reason to disbelieve the consistent and corroborative evidence of those competent witnesses having no reason whatsoever to depose falsely against the defendant. The defendant however cross-examined them extensively, but nothing could be elicited to shake their credibility in nay manner whatsoever. So the same are invulnerable to the credibility. In view of such evidence it is legitimate presumption that the marriage between plaintiff and defendant was consummated in due course of lading conjugal life. - The findings arrived at by the Court of appeal below having been rested upon consideration and discussions of legal evidence and materials on record and also on a correct and proper analysis of the legal aspects involved in the case and the findings being a finding of facts are not liable to be disturbed by the High Court Division in exercising of the power under Section 115( 1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Md. Wahed Ali Vs. Ms. Moslema Khatun 20 BLT (HCD) 222.

 

Section 115(1) Whether judgment of the Court of appeal is a proper judgment of reversal

 

Suit for declaration of title and recovery of possession - From evidences together with the exhibited documents produced by the plaintiff-opposite party No.l, it transpires that the plaintiff-opposite party No.l purchased the suit land from PW-3 by Ext. 1 and all the PWs. in their respective testimony categorically testified in one voice that the plaintiff-opposite party No.l was dispossessed by the defendant-petitioners from the suit land and thereafter, the defendants erected a hut thereon. Therefore, the finding of the trial Court below that the plaintiff has failed to prove his title as well as possession and dispossession appears to-be based misreading and non-consideration of the material evidence on record. - It is true in passing the impugned judgment the Court of appeal below did not, in so many words, discuss the reasons which led him to decree the suit. But from the materials on record it appears that the materials on record justify the ultimate decision of the Court of appeal below. It is now well settled that omission to assign reasons in the impugned judgment is not fatal, if in law the judgment and decree is sustainable. So, it is a mere irregularity not an illegality and the impugned judgment cannot be knocked down on that count. Therefore, I am not inclined to disturb with the impugned judgment.

 

Saidur Rahman & Anr Vs.  Haji Ameer All & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 568.

 

Section -115(1)

 

No where in the college record admittedly there exist any such resolution that the suit land have been possessed forcibly and the witness also admits that there can not be any principle, rule or system of such acquisition of land forcibly. Both the Courts below in this context were quite justified that the educational institution must have to maintain some sanctity and ethics and none should support that an institution can acquire or retain possession of any land forcibly. This sort of illegal immoral act is not at all expected from an educational institution. Be that as it may; the Court of law must not protect such misdeed. Both the Courts below concurrently found in their judgment and decisions that the plaintiff-opposite-parties successfully discharged the onus of proving their respective case and the appellate Court being the final Court of facts decided that there was in fact an oral awaj between the parties by virtue of which the^ disputed land was handed over to the plaintiffs and they do possess the same. -Consulting the relevant papers on record it is evident that the learned appellate Court below during disposal of the appeal on proper appreciation of evidence opined that the plaintiffs have successfully proved their case and the Court of appeal below being the final Court with regard to determination of fact in issue that findings cannot be interfered with.

 

Barguna University College Vs. Sree Citta Ranjan & 7 Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 197.

 

Section -151(1)

 

Not a proper judgment of reversal The Defendant-Opposite Parties during trial was not able to discharge their onus that the plaintiff-petitioner has lost his citizenship by adducing competent cogent evidence to establish their case but the learned Appellate Court without proper assessment of evidence and appreciation of law decided the merit of the appeal against the respondent and in favour of the appellant. Apart from this the learned Appellate Court misread and misconstrued the evidence on record and also misinterpreted the connected papers on record specially the exhibited documents which were taken into consideration by the trial court at the time of disposal of the suit on merit after vivid discussions and findings on evidence adduced therein.

 

Jnanendra Nath Barai Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 03.

 

Section-115 (1) Error in the decision in passing the impugned order

 

Held; The subject matter of the Miscellaneous appeal was whether the learned Assistant Judge was justified in passing the impugned order in the Title Suit. But it is very astonishing to note here that he pronounced the judgment as if he sat as an appellate Court against the judgment and decree passed in the Title suit although the appellate Court below had no any scope to consider the merit of that suit which was not the subject matter of the miscellaneous appeal placed before him -the appellate Court below committed serious error of law resulted in an error in the decision in passing the impugned order.

 

Putul Biswas -Vs- Krishnapada Mondal & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 564.

 

Section-115(l)

 

Not a proper judgment of reversal Held; The trial Court after a detailed discussion of the evidence of the plaintiff and defendants and attending circumstances borne out by records held that the plaintiff failed to prove their predecessor's/ vendor's exclusive title and possession in the suit land. The Court of appeal below reversed the findings of the trial Court by the impugned judgment stating that if Boudi and Syed AH as heirs of Safar Ali got the land of Safar Ali, the daughters of Safar Ali obviously be entitled to get their shaham as a legal heirs of Safar Ali according to the personal law and hence, the transfer in question by registered deed dated 4.11.1982 in favour of Haji Abu Bakkar was a valid transfer and, on this finding the learned Additional District Judge, 3rd Court, Sylhet decreed the suit. In the facts and circumstance of the case this finding of the lower appellate Court is not based on correct evaluation of the facts and materials of the case nor on proper appreciation of the evidence on record. It is very surprising that the learned judge of the lower appellate Court enunciated a wrong proposition of law by giving a go-by to the material evidence on record. This is not only illegal but also not a proper exercise of jurisdiction vested in the Court.

 

Ibrahim Ali Vs Alhaj Md. Nazim Uddin Akhter & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 276.

 

Section 115(1)

 

Rights of the transferee Pendente lite-Addition of party

 

The facts in the instant Case of themselves necessitated in this Court's view the addition of the Opposite Party No. 1 at the very least as the proper party, as rightly found by the learned Joint District Judge, in the interest of ensuring a fair outcome of the pending litigation filed against the backdrop of highly contested and divisive claims to the Suit land of both the Plaintiff-Petitioner and the now deceased Defendant No. 1-vendor as the predecessor-in-interest of the Opposite Party No.l. Indeed, the Opposite Party No.l, we note, having claimed interest though the Defendant No.l vendor will not get any better right than the deceased Defendant No.l-vendor. But that does not detract from the fact that his coming on board as an Added party will indeed ensure his rights and interests to be properly addressed by the Court and, thereby, contribute to the more effectual and complete adjudication of the dispute at hand. It is this Court's view, therefore, that the learned Joint District Judge aptly and duly appreciated the somewhat compelling circumstances in this Case that reasonably merited the Application under Order 1 Rule 10(2) to be allowed in the manner that was done. Having, therefore, not erred in law in any manner and having not contributed to the failure of justice in any sense, the impugned order merits no interference by this Court as otherwise prayed for.

 

Md. Abdul Bari Chowdhury Vs Md. Moklisur Rahman 21 BLT (HCD) 356.

 

Section-115(l) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1990; Section -96 Pre-emption case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act -transaction is an exchange

 

The trial court on consideration of the pleadings, materials and evidence had held that the transaction is not a sale but an exchange. The Appellate Court as it appears has adverted to the materials on record and Held In view of such evidence on record I have found the courts below correctly held that the transaction is an exchange but not an out an out a sale and in arriving at such findings considering the pleadings and evidence of the parties committed no error of law in drawing the conclusion. The case has been concluded by concurrent findings of facts which do not warrant interference in revision.

 

Md. Lokman AH Kazi & Anr Vs Md. Mozammel Hague Mridha & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 552.

 

Section 115(1) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 Section 42 Annulment ofNim-Howla interest

 

In the instant case, suit land was belonged to Wasek Patwari. Plaintiffs claim that they purchased the land from successive heirs of Wasek Patwari and thereby exercising their right title and possession in suit land. The contesting defendants disowned such facts. They claim that suit land was auctioned in 1949-50 which was purchased by government, therefore howla right of original landlord Wasek Patwari was annulled, and plaintiffs by admitting auction approached for settlement to Government -plaintiffs title was clouded before institution of instant suit. So, in my view without seeking any relief against auction, the suit for declaration of title simplicitor is not at all maintainable.

 

Abdul Khaleque Vs. Khorshed Alain & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 46.

 

Section 115(1) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 Section 42 read with Principles of Hindu Law

Debuttar documents were never acted upon -Proper Judgment of reversal

 

Illusory endowments - Held; The Appellate Court has held relying upon mainly on the S.A. Khatian exhibit 2-2(43), exhibit 7 and order dated 5.1.1959 in rent suit no.44 of 1958 and also on the basis of the order passed in Rent appeal No. 16 of 1959 that the plaintiff has been able to prove that during the life time of said Ramoni Mohan, he did not diveste himself from the properties rather he mutated his name and realized rent. The Appellate Court also held that the plaintiff is admittedly the grand son of Ramoni Mohan and the title and possession naturally had vested in him. He also found that the deities were not kept in the Debuttar properties but allegedly preserved in the custody of the Secretary of the committee in his personal house and also found that alleged application made by Ramoni Mohan contained no schedule of the properly and as such, recording of names in S.A. Khatian remained unchallenged and I am of the view that the Appellate Court has decided the matter to its true perspective considering the evidence both oral and documentary and law. The original maker of the deed i.e. Ramoni Mohan had recorded his name in S.A. Khatian during his life time and Braja Bala tried to establish herself as the Shebait by filing rent suit but the Munsif, 1st Court, Sylhet in rent suit no.44 of 1958 which had clearly held that the deeds were not acted upon and such findings were affirmed by the Appellate Court. It is in evidence that the deities are not being maintained in the land of the Debuttar property but kept in a private house of the Secretary and as such, the very purpose of dedication as it appears to have lost and as such, I am of the opinion that the plaintiff has been able to prove that the Endowments had been made were "Illusory endowments and "Illusory endowments" are sham endowments. In such endowment the donor does not completely divest himself of all beneficial interest in the property given in endowment.

 

Deities Vs. Biresh Ranjan Dhar & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 51.

 

Section -115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section-96

 

Judgment of reversal

 

The Trial Court dismissed the miscellaneous pre-emption case only on the score that it was barred by limitation whereas the appellate court considering the evidence in detailed discussions reversed the said finding and found that the said pre-emption case is not barred by limitation. Held; Considering the statements of the pre-emptor particularly the words "f^t srffi ^" the appellate court has given the analogy of the fact that the knowledge of transfer of pre-emption was "after" three months of the execution of the deed i.e. in between second week of the month of March and the second week of April, 1999 and that being so since the pre-emptor case has been filed within the required period of four months from the said date of knowledge i.e. on 26.7.1999 the pre­emption case is not barred by law. The appellate court being the last court of fact and its finding as to limitation having not been tamted by any misreading of non-consideration of material evidence no interference is called for by this court exercising revisional jurisdiction under section 115( 1) of the Code of Civil Procedure

 

Md. Saidur Rahman Vs Md. Afsar Ali Dewan & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 23.

 

Section-115(l) read with Order-9 Rule-13 Failed to show any sufficient Cause

 

From the impugned judgment in appears that the learned judge of the appellate Court after assessing the evidence properly came to a definite finding that the petitioner filed the instant Miscellaneous Case at the instance of Ruhul Amin Molla. The learned Judge also found that the original suit was decreed on contest against Ruhul Amin Molla who also lost in appeal against which no second Appeal was preferred by him before this Court. The learned Judge also observed that this petitioner being brother-in-law of the said Ruhal Amin Molla and in order to frustrate the decree passed in Title suit no. 193 of 1974 had filed the miscellaneous Case through his brother-in-law, Kobbat Ali Shikder, the present petitioner who was defendant no. 2 in the suit and though he being a minor was represented by the Court guardian.-Held; I am of the view that the concurrent finding of facts arrived at by the Courts below do not suffer from any infirmity or illegality and hence do not call for interference by this court in its revisional jurisdiction.

 

Md. Kobbat Ali Sikder Vs Dayal Chandra Biswas & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 305.

 

Section-115(l) read with Order 41 Rule 31

 

The provision of law is that the learned appellate Court must consider each of the findings of the trial Court then to give his own independent finding on the basis of the material on record, but in the present case, it appears, the learned appellate Court only considered the question of hotch potch and came to the finding that the plaintiff should be given a chance to amend the plaint by inclusion of the rest 3 plots namely plot No.296, 297 and 300 in hotch potch and as such, in my opinion, the impugned judgment and decrees passed by the learned appellate Court are not sustainable in law. \

 

Mst. Saleha Begum & Anr Vs Md. Mizanur Rahman & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 123.

 

Section 115(1) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 Section 42

 

Not maintainable-Plaintiffs took lease of the disputed property from the Vested Property Authority and subsequently as per decision of the government release the said property from the list of Vested Property and the plaintiffs as lessee preferred the suit.

 

Held; Since the alleged lease had not been renewed the plaintiffs have no right to file this revision. Moreover, in case of such order of release from the list of vested property by the government the so called lessee have got no right or locus standi under any law of the land to challenge.

 

Md. Mohiruddin Sonar & Ors Vs. Pijush Kanti Bhattacharya & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 541.

 

Section-115(l) read with Limitation Act, 1908 ArticIe-36

 

Money Suit being No. 14 of 1986 which was filed beyond the two years -barred by Law of Limitation

 

Money Suit, which was filed on 6.7.86 for the recovery of an alleged loss caused by misfeasance, malfeasance or nonfeasance in the year 1981-82 and discovered on 26.10.82, was well beyond the 2 (two) years limitation period, prescribed by Article 36 of the Limitation Act, 1908. Therefore, in the facts and circumstances of the case vis-a-vis the provisions of Article 36 of the Limitation Act, 1908, we are of the view that the suit is barred by law of limitation -both the Courts below erred in law in passing the impugned judgments without properly applying its judicial mind into the facts and circumstances of the case and law bearing on the subject and the same has resulted   in   an   error   in   the   impugned decisions occasioning failure of justice.

 

Md. Azizul Haque Vs Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd 19 BLT (HCD) 306.

 

Section-115(l) read with Order 41 Rule-31

 

Learned Additional District Judge as Last and Final Judge of fact, also, duly considered pleadings, evidence of parties, provisions of Law embodied in The Act of 1948 and other materials on record came in full agreement with the decisions reached at by Learned Assistant Judge and maintained those Decisions. Decisions rendered by Learned Assistant Judge and Learned Additional District Judge are well founded, well grounded and well reasoned and those do not suffer from any illegality and legal infirmity and those do not warrant any interference by this Court in its Civil Revisional Jurisdiction under Section 115 (1) of The Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Bangladesh Railway Vs. Md. Sujaruddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 363.

 

Section 115(1) read with Order 39 Rule 1

 

In the instant Civil Revision, the Rule arising out of the judgment and order passed in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 151 of 2004 refusing the prayer for temporary injunction or status quo. - Held; In the facts of the case, both the parties are directed to maintain status quo in respect of their possession in the suit land till disposal of Miscellaneous Appeal No. 151 of 2004 now pending in the Court of the learned District Judge, Khulna.

 

Shyamol Kumar Singha Roy Vs. Sarder Haider Ali & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 482.

 

Section 115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section 96(1)(B) Not a proper judgment of reversal

 

The trial Court below upon hearing both the sides and on considering the materials on record disallowed the pre-emption case mainly on 2(two) counts that (i) the pre-emptor opposite party No.l having failed to prove that the deed in question was out and out sale deed and (ii) it has been decided earlier in Title Suit No.63 of 1996 that the deed in question was a deed of exchange not a sale deed. - On an overall consideration of the entire materials on record, I am of the view that the Court of appeal below without applying its judicial mind into the facts and circumstances of the case and law bearing on the subject erroneously held that the trial Court below committed wrong in rejecting the prayer for pre-emption holding that the pre-emption application is not maintainable as per provisions of Section 96 (1)(B) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.

 

Md. Ismail Hossain Vs. Shakhina & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 194.

 

Section 115(1) read with Order 7 Rule ll(c)

 

Held; I find that the plaintiff sought for 3 reliefs in the plaint but the plaintiff has paid court fee of Tk.200 for one relief. In this respect the law is very much clear and there is no ambiguity in the provision of law as contained under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure where it is clearly described that the plaint shall be rejected where the relief claimed in the plaint though properly valued but insufficiently stamped and the plaintiff being required by the court to pay requisite court fee in this respect it is very much clear that the plaintiff in his suit though prayed for 3 reliefs but paid court fee for only one relief, so in this count also the plaint is not properly stamped and the same is liable to be rejected on the ground of insufficient stamp and as such provision of law as contained in Order 7 Rule 11 Sub rule C of the Code of Civil Procedure is very much applicable in the instant case as such the learned Trial Court has committed a serious error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice in not rejecting the plaint of the suit under Order 7 Rule 11 Sub rule (c) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Md. Ayub AH & Anr Vs. Md. Sirjul Islam & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 217.

 

Section 115(1) read with Order 39 Rule 1 read with Section 151 Revision against the Order issued only 'show cause notice' by the trial Court

 

The suit for declaration and for mandatory injunction was filed on 18.8.2010, application for injunction was filed on that date, the Court issued only show cause notice on 23.8.2010 - Plaintiff having apprehension that defendant Nos.l to 3 might have change the nature and character of the suit by selling it to the 3'd party, moved before this court and obtained rule on 26.8.2010. This Court at the time of issuance of rule, directed the defendant-opposite party Nos.l to 3 to maintain statuesque in respect of selling transferring mortgaging or in any way handing over the apartments as fully described in the schedule to the application to any body else. - The order status quo granted earlier by this Court shall continue till disposal of injunction matter.

 

M.N.H. Khan Manju Vs. Comprehensive

1491

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Part-3)

Citation: 20 BLT (HCD) 237, 20 BLT (HCD) 368, 20 BLT (HCD) 465, 20 BLT (HCD) 554, 21 BLT (HCD) 123, 21 BLT (HCD ) 273, 21 BLT (AD) 168, 21 BLT (HCD) 386, 21 BLT (HCD) 520, 21 BLT (HCD) 84, 20 BLT (AD) 272, 18 BLT (HCD) 36, 18 BLT (HCD) 413, 18 BLT (HCD) 86, 18 BLT

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Code of Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-07-09

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

 

Section - 115(1) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 Section - 42

 

Product of misreading and non considering the material evidence on record

 

Suit for declaration of title of the suit land; regarding last R.S operation the suit land was wrongly recorded as Khas land - The plaintiffs in support of their claim proved as many as 4 (four) vital documents namely; (i) Pattan dated 4.4.1939 (Ext.l), (ii) 5(five) rent receipts (Ext.2-2Gha), (iii) S.A. Khatian (Ext. 3) and (iv) rent receipt under S.A. Khatian (Ext.4) but both the courts below mere on surmise and conjecture mechanically held that the plaintiffs could not prove their pattan as well as right, title and possession in the suit land by educing evidence - Held; The plaintiff-petitioners in order to prove their right, title and possession in the suit property produced so many important documents namely, pattan dated 4.4.1939 (Ext.l), 5(five) rent receipt (Ext.-2-2 Gha), S.A Kantian (Ext.3) and rent receipt under S.A. Khatian (Ext. 4). The Court of appeal below by the impugned judgment affirmed the decision In the given facts and circumstances of the case and the uniform decisions of the highest Court, I have no hesitation to hold that the above quoted finding of the Court of appeal below is product of misreading and non considering the material evidence on record inasmuch as in this case the plaintiffs had produced their kabala, S. A. Khatian and rent receipt in the trial Court to show their continuous possession but the Courts below did not consider the same. - I am inclined to hold that both the Courts below erred in law in passing the judgments under challenge without following the correct principle relating to the appreciation of the evidence and materials on record and the same has resulted in an error in the impugned decisions occasioning failure of justice.

 

Md. Alauddin Kazi & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 237.

 

Section - 115(1) read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003; Section– 44 Jurisdiction-the petitioners have challenged the orders passed by the Artha Rin Adalat directing to detain the respective petitioners as per section 34 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003.

 

The revisional applications under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is not at all maintainable as no revision lies against any interlocutory order passed by the Adalat exercising the power conferred by the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 as contended by the learned Counsel for the opposite party bank. - Held; The provisions of Section 44 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003, on interlocutory order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat under Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 is appeal able or revisable - In view of the above facts and circumstances, the provision of law as contained in section 44(2) of the Ain of 2003, as well as the decisions of our Apex Court and this Court as referred to above, we have no other option but to hold that the impugned    orders     in     these    revisional applications passed by the executing Court are interlocutory orders, and as such revision under  section   115   of  the   Code   is   not maintainable.

 

Md. Bodiuzzaman Milan Vs. Bangladesh Commerce Bank Ltd. & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 368.

 

Section - 115(1) read with Order 41 Rule 33

 

Proper judgment of reversal Record of right is not a document of title and it does not create or extinguish title to land as contended by  the  learned  Counsel for the plaintiff-opposite parties

 

It is true that the names of Izzatunnessa and Lazzatunnessa were not recorded in C.S., S.A. and R.S. Khatians but from the oral evidence as well as documentary evidence, their existence was proved they are co-sharer by inheritance in the suit property. - It is now settled position of law when the court below gives decision on the basis of documents and evidence that is a question of fact and this court ordinarily should not interfere with the question of fact arrived at by a court unless it appears that the court below patently committed illegality and took a wrong view of law.

 

Md. Omar Khan & Ors Vs. Md. Shatnsul Haque Mia & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 465.

 

Section - 115(1) read with Evidence Act, 1872; Section -102 Suit for partition - 'Onus'

 

Whether the photo state copies which are copies made from the original by mechanical process are admissible in the evidence. The deposition of DW.2 Hasina Begum and Exhibits 'Ka' and 'Ka-(l)' by which it is evident that Pi Mahmud had no daughters in the name of Izzatunnessa and Lazzatunnessa. Trial Court relied upon the deposition of D.W.2 to prove that Pi Mahmud had no daughters. The D.W.2 U.P Member Hasina Begum produced Ext.-'Ka', application for heir certificate and identified her signature therein as Exhibit-'Ka-l'. Both Exhibits-'Ka' and 'Ka-1' are Photostat copies. The writing therein are also Photostat copies. No explanation was offered regarding original copy of the Exhibit 'Ka' and 'Ka-1'. - After perusing the exhibit 'Ka' and 'Ka-(l)' the appellate court below arrived at a finding that those exhibits arouses suspicion to its genuinity. -Court of appeal below has not committed any error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.

 

Md. Omar Khan & Ors Vs. Md. Shamsul Haque Mia & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 465.

 

Section -115(1) read with Evidence Act, 1872; Section – 102 Affirming judgment - Non-consideration and misconstrued

 

It appears that "will" was executed on 9.10.1963 by Surendara Nath Sarder, by dint of "will" the executor of the will obtained the probate and letter of administration on 4.11.1967 from the competent Court, Thereafter one Dejendra legal heirs of Surendra filed case for canceling the probate which was also compromised and solenama was filed in Court which was accepted by the Court and till day all these Court orders neither challenged by the heirs of the testator nor by the authority of custodian of enemy property. In the mean time plaintiffs sold some lands to the third party who was added in the present suit as added defendant. In order to protect his property he was examined as D.W1. He also mutated his name and paid rent. The added defendant produced all the documents and materials as exhibits. On the above documentary evidence it appears that before promulgation of the enemy property Ordinance the right, title and possession of the Surendara was extinguished in the year 1963 and 1967 and the plaintiffs and added defendant by dint of legal and valid documents acquired the right, title and possession over the suit land. In such view of matter I do not find any reason to disbelieved oral evidence of P.Ws regarding the possession of the plaintiff. -The property as described in the schedule of the plaint is not enemy or vested and Non­resident Property.

 

Anil Krishna Roy & Ors Vs. Sub-divisional Officer, Khulna, & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 554.

 

Section -115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section - 96 read with Land Reforms Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No.X of 1984) Section – 6 Judgment of reversal

 

The learned Judge of lower appellate Court after hearing the parties without considering the evidence on record and the land Reforms Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No.X of 1984), wrongly allowed the Miscellaneous Appeal reversing the judgment and order passed by the learned Judge of trial Court and wrongly sent back the case on remand to ascertain the development cost of the case land. The learned Judge of the trial Court after hearing the parties rightly dis-allowed the Pre­emption Miscellaneous Case No.27 of 1997. The pre-emptee purchaser after purchase the case land erected homestead and lives with his family members thereon.

 

Nazrul Islam Khan Vs. Hatem Ali Sarder & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 123

 

Section 115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, (As Amended); Section -96(3)(c) Whether the trial Court was not justified in not staying the further proceeding of the Pre­emption case till registration of the sale deed under section 60 of the Registration Act.

 

In the instant Case, the sale deed has been presented before the Sub-Registrar, Keranigonj on 5.08.2007 and the petitioner filed miscellaneous case on 6.08.2008 after : one year. But till then the registration of the deed was not completed under section 60 of the Registration Act, that is, the deed has not entered into volume - Before amendment of the section 96 of the S.A.&T. Act there was provision only to deposit an amount of Tk. 10% together with the consideration money along with the application for pre-emption. But by the amendment, provision has been made for depositing Tk. 25% as compensation together with the consideration money plus 8% interest upon the consideration money from the date of "execution1 of the sale deed to till filing of the application for pre­emption. If the petitioner is to wait for filing the pre-emption case after registration of the deed as per provision of section 60 of Registration Act then he will have to pay more Tk.4/5 lac as additional interest -The law cannot compel a person who comes before the Court for establishing his statutory right to bring the said application with compensatory interest as provided by section 96(3)(c) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act and that is also not the intention of the legislature -In such circumstance, the trial Court was not justified in not staying the further proceeding of the preemption case.

 

Md. Abdul Motaleb Vs Md. Enamul Hoque 21 BLT (HCD )273.

 

Section-115(1) read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section 40 and 42

Whether the judgment and order passed in the Artha Rin Miscellaneous Appeal amenable in revision jurisdiction

 

The provisions of Appeal and revision of the Code such as Sections 96, 104, Order XLI and Section 115 respectively have been made applicable in respect of an appeal and a revision, if filed under the Ain, 2003 subject to the provisions of the said Ain. -Reading Section 42 along with Section 40 of the Ain, 2003, it further appears to us that the provisions of the Code will be applicable so far as the procedure in filing the revision application and the grounds on which revisional Court would interfere in revision with the judgment or the decree passed by the Appellate Court in an Artha Rin Appeal.

 

Md. Gokar Hossain, Adv. Vs. Janata Bank 21 BLT (AD) 168.

 

Section-115(l) read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section-102 Legal necessity under Hindu law—onus

 

The onus of establishing legal necessity is on the transferees. Again if the transactions are impeached the burden lies on the transferees to prove either that there was legal necessity in fact or that proper and bonafide enquiries were made by the transferees as to the existence of necessity and they did all that was reasonable to satisfy themselves as to the existence of the necessity. Thus it is seen that the transferees must establish both, but that may always prove one of these two alternatives. So it can not be argued that if the transferees failed to establish the first alternative, had happened here, it was incumbent on the court to investigate into the other alternative. The two considerations being alternative, in my opinion, one exclude the other. Here the first alternative has been found not to have been established and that was quite sufficient, and so there was no necessity to enquire into the other alternative. —It appears from the depositions of the recipient of the deed that it was not a deed covered with minimum legal necessity as defendant sold for maintaining of her day to day affairs of family. It appears that Chinta Haran Debnath died on 30th Magh, 1372 B.S. and the impugned deed of sale was registered on 17.04.1969 i.e. in early part of 1374 B.S. It is also on evidence that out of 5 of the daughters of Chinta Haran Debnath, 4 has already been given marriage and for the remaining daughter, Chinta Haran Debnath has made sufficient arrangement. It appears from the depositions of defendant's witnesses that none speaks for selling of the property to defendant No.l for legal necessity. The woman necessity means a kind of pressure which the lawdescribe as serious and sufficient. As such on an over all consideration of the Hindu Law it appears that defendant failed to prove the requirement of legal necessity for transferring the suit land as such we find substance in the rule.

 

Had Md. Nazim Hossain & Ors Vs Hafiz Ullah & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Section 115(1) read with Order VI Rule 17 Whether an amendment of the pleadings can allow in revision stage

 

It appears that the plaintiffs instituted the suit for recovery of possession on evicting defendants as they are possessing the suit land on permission - advertently plaintiff did not pray for declaration of title as contended by the counsel for plaintiffs -held; We have gone through the submissions of the learned Advocate for the plaintiff petitioner and of the view that on the pleading of the parties we find suit has been brought against wrong recording not for declaration of title which by amendment of the pleading plaintiffs wanted to implead which in fact did not change the nature and character of the suit as on fact of the given case declaration of title to the suit is required. We find substance in the rule.

 

Afqjuddin Dewan & Ors -Vs- Salema Begum & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 520.

 

Section -115(1) read with Evidence Act, 1872 Sections -101,102 & 103

 

In R.S. Khatian the suit property has been recorded in the name of plaintiff deity, but in remark column of the R.S. Khatian it has been noted as 'Vested Property'.

 

Both the courts below were totally failed to assess the evidence on record properly and appreciate the actual position of law. There is no sifting of evidence in the true perspective of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. The appellate court during disposal of the appeal misread and misconstrued the evidence on records and misinterpreted the material evidence specially the exhibited documents which is an apparent error in law on the face of the papers.

 

Sree Sree Radha Ballav Deb Thakur & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 84.

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (as Amended) Section -115 (1) read with Order 22 Rule 4

 

The appellate Court below rejected the pre­emption case as bad for defect of parties on the finding that the heirs of deceased-opposite party No.4 Khaitun Bibi have not been substituted by the petitioner, this finding of the appellate Court below is erroneous and contrary to the amended provision of Order 22, Rule 4 of the Code.

 

Alhaj Abdul Awal Ratan & Anr Vs. Abdul Mannan Mia & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 272.

 

Section 115(2) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877; Section 9 Proper Judgment of reversal

 

From the averments of the plaint it appears that the plaintiff's cause of action to institute the suit arose when he was dispossessed from the suit land on last part of Falgoon, 1379 B.S., that is, first part of March, 1973. The suit was instituted on 22.08.1973, that is, within 6(six) months of dispossession and the trail Court decided the issue No. 2, that plaintiff instituted the suit within 6(six) months of his dispossession from the suit land. On examination of evidence of the plaintiffs witnesses it appears that all the 4 P.Ws have categorically stated that the plaintiff from the time of his father was in possession in the suit land till dispossession in the last part of Falgoon, 1379 B.S. Trial court found the issue No.2 as to dispossession in favour of the plaintiff which clearly indicates that prior to dispossession the plaintiff was in possession of the suit land. So, I find that the plaintiff could well prove his possession in and dispossession from the suit land. The trial Court committed error of law in dismissing the suit occasioning failure of justice. The Rivisional Court assessing the evidence available on record rightly allowed the revision and decreed the suit by the impugned judgment and order. The District Judge or the Additional District Judge as rivisional Court in exercise of power conferred by section 115(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure, amended by the Law Reforms Ordinance, 1978, could rectify any illegality committed by the inferior Court even if such defect is not pointed out by either party. I find that trial Court dismissed the suit without assessing the evidence on record but the rivisional Court rightly and legally interfered within setting aside the judgment and decree passed by the trail Court.

 

Nannu Mia Vs. Mohan Basi Bhoumik & Ors. 18 BLT (HCD) 36.

 

Section-115(2) read with Order 18 Rule-17

 

On going to materials on record it transpires that still the pre-emption proceedings is pending. The pre-emptor sought to prove some documents which in my view are necessary for the purpose determining the real question of controversy between the parties. It is absolutely the option of pre-emptor which document he will prove for the purpose of his own success and the pre-emptee has ample opportunity to discard those documents in his cross examination. Therefore, I find that the application for re­calling P.W-1 cannot be denoted as belated stage, so the courts below after appreciating the materials on record by allowing the application committed no error of law.

 

Md. Abdul Mazid Miah Vs Sree Shuvendu Sekhor 18 BLT (HCD) 413.

 

Section -115(4)

 

Allowing the Revision application Summarily without giving any opportunity of being heard of Petitioners

 

 It is well settled that disposal of revisional application without any notice being served upon the opposite parties for appearing in the case when the matter is taken up for hearing is illegal.

 

Sekandar AH & Ors Vs Emran Chowdhury & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 86.

 

Section -115(4)

 

Suit for declaration that the non confirmation of the appointment and termination of employment by the defendant is illegal and not binding and that the plaintiff is entitled to reinstatement to her post and subsequently the plaint was amended to include a prayer for mandatory injunction directing the defendants to pay her emolument and revalued the suit for mandatory injunction at Tk. 10007- and paid court fees accordingly. The defendant opposes the revaluation of the suit on the plea that there is objective standard of valuation for the relief and the plaintiff is required to pay advalorem court fees on the basis of her salaries. -High Court Division held that there is no objective standard of valuation of the suit having regard to the nature of the prayer sought by way of amendment to the plaint seeking relief for recovery of arrear salaries by way of mandatory injunction. -Held; the High Court Division upon correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

World Bank Vs. Ismat Zerin Khan 18 BLT (AD) 01.

 

Section—115(4)

 

Whether an interim Order can set aside

 

Since the District Judge is in seisin of the matter under section 115(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure, the defendants ought to have completed the hearing of the said revisional application but the defendants without exhausting the said forum preferred a civil revision under section 115(4) of the Code of Civil Procedure before the High Court Division and the High Court Division issued rule and also passed an interim order—Held; let the interim order dated 16.01.2011 passed by the High Court Division at the time of issuance of the Rule in Civil Revision No. 83 of 2011, be sefaside.

 

Saiful Alain Vs. Md. Kamal Uddin Sabuj & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 102.

 

Section-115(4)

 

A Civil Revision under section 115 (2) of the Code of Civil Procedure is pending before the learned District Judge and fixed the stay petition on 18.01.2011 for hearing—Held; It appears that the learned District Judge is in seisin of the matter— Let the District Judge, Dhaka, be diirected to decide the matter by 31st January, 2011. In the meantime, the parties are directed to maintain status-quo till that date.

 

Saiful Alain Vs. Md. Kamal Uddin Sabuj & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 102.

 

Section-115 (4) Whether an order passed in miscellaneous case was under provision of Order 41 Rule 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure is revisional.

 

Held; It is apparent from the face of the papers that the Miscellaneous Case being No. 10 of 2003 arising out of an application filed under Order XLI Rule 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure which was fixed for hearing on 19.09.2005. On the very date the petitioners filed an adjournment application and the learned Additional District Judge, 8lh Court, Dhaka rejected the same. Subsequently by the self same order the learned court dismissed the case for default. Therefore, obviously the impugned order was passed on an application filed under Order XLI Rule 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure which is an appealable order under the ambit of Order XLIII Rule l(t) of the Code of Civil Procedure. Hence; obviously I'm constrained to hold that the revisional application in the form of Civil Revision is not tenable in the eye of law.

 

Bangladesh Railway & Anr Vs. Mahfuzur Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 420.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (As Amended) Section-115(4)

 

The learned Judge while disposing the revisional application under section 115(2) has considered certain orders which were not impugned before the revisional Court.

 

From impugned order it reveals that the learned Judge also allowed an application for amendment dated 10.04.2003 filed by the defendant which was not the subject matter of the revision and from the order it clearly indicates that the learned District Judge exercised the jurisdiction beyond the scope of subject matter which is not expected from a Senior Judicial Officer like District Judge, Dhaka and it further reveals from the impugned order that the learned District Judge has not reversed the findings of the Trial court in as much as the Trial court recorded clear findings that the statement made in application for better statement does not relate to the suit property and in such circumstances, I find substance in the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioner and therefore, I consider that an important question of law has been raised before this court and in the facts and circumstances of the case and in view of my discussion the impugned order is not sustainable in law.

 

Md. Nazimuddin & Anr Vs Abdul Khaleque 17 BLT (HCD) 313.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (As Amended) Section-115(4)

 

After the submission of the commissioner's report, the plaintiffs have come up with a new ca^e of encroachment of one decimal of lands by the defendants from their saham, although they have not made such allegation at any stage of the proceedings. The trial Court also did not pass any such a direction to give saham to the plaintiffs out of the lands in possession of the defendants. In that view of the matter, the learned Joint District Judge without applying his judicial mind has drawn up the final decree in pursuance of the Advocate Commissioner's report which has been submitted not in conformity with the preliminary decree. This defect can be detected on the face of the record and in that view of the matter, the Courts below have committed error of law in not amending the final decree. On consideration of the facts and circumstances of the matter. I find substance in the contention of the learned Advocate for the petitioners that the Courts below on a superficial consideration of the Advocate commissioner's report rejected the defendants application for amendment of the final decree which has been apparently drawn up beyond the preliminary decree. Accordingly, I find substance in this rule.

 

Najib Chowdhury & Ors Vs. Moazzem Hossain Chowdhury & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 14.

 

Code of Civil Procedure (Third Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No.XL of 2003) Section 115(4)

 

Rejecting the plaint on the ground that suit is barred by law of res-judicata

 

The suit is barred by res-judicata, which is a question of fact and law, normally in such type suit's plaint cannot be rejected but in this case it is clearly found that over the self same suit land and in between same parties the defendant-petitioner earlier got decree in Title Suit No.448 of 1975 and the said decree was upheld by the High Court Division in Civil Revision No.4573 of 1995 vide judgment and order dated 18.02.2002 and under such facts and circumstances the trial Court below committed no wrong in holding that the suit is clearly barred by principle of res-judicata.

 

Anarul Islam Vs. Govl. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 206.

 

Section 115(4) read with The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Sections-96(3)(a)(b) read with The State Acquisition and Tenancy (amendment) Act 2006; Section 96(3)(4)(5)

 

Before and after the amendment of section 96 of the Act, the provisions for "holding an enquiry regarding deposition and giving all the parties an opportunity of being heard" remained same. It is pertinent to point out that the pre emptor at his own instance deposited the deficit compensation money with interest. The court of Revision below without complying the provisions of sections 96(4) (5) of the Act reversed the order of trial court. On this count the impugned order cannot be sustained.

 

Md. Aftab Uddin Pramanik Vs Md. Bulbul Shakidar & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 328.

 

Section -115(4) read with Order -21, Rule -29

 

It is admitted facts that plaintiffs are in possession in the suit land. If the Title Execution Case No.Ol of 2005 arose out of exparte decree dated 10.11.2004 of Title Suit No.267 of 2003 is allowed to continue, then certainly the plaintiffs will be evicted from suit premises, therefore the purpose of the suit and revision before District Judge will be frustrated -It transpires from the impugned order that at the time of admission, the learned judge of revisional Court below by staying the order dated 06.02.2008, virtually granted the whole relief and in my view nothing left for further adjudication at the time of final hearing of revision before the District Judge. Therefore, I hold that the impugned order so far it relates to stay operation of the order dated 06.02.2008 of the Trial Court is not only illegal but militates against common sense and natural justice. So the same cannot be sustained in the eye of law.

 

Swapan Kumer Das & Ors Vs Md. Reaz & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 556.

 

Section 115(4) read with Order VI Rule 17

 

Whether in Civil Revision, an application for amendment of the plaint is maintainable

 

High Court Division rejected the application for amendment of the plaint on the view that the amendment, if allowed, would totally change the nature and character of the suit. -Held; it is clear that by the proposed amendment the plaintiffs did not seek any change as to the form of the suit from one of redemption of mortgaged to any other form and thus the suit remains as it was, i.e. one for redemption of the mortgaged property along with the other prayers. Mere omission/deletions and insertion of some new facts as indicated herein before in no way can be construed to change the nature and character of the plaint or the suit. It further appears to us that the amendment sought for it necessary to decide the core question involved in the suit as to whether the plaintiffs are entitled to redeem the mortgaged property being the heirs of late Sirajul Islam Khan who was the Managing Director of Plaintiff No.l company. In rejecting the prayer for amendment of the plaint the learned Judges have not at all spelt out as to how the amendments sought for would change the nature and character of the suit. The learned Judges in a very casual manner observed  that  the  amendment if allowed would totally change the nature and | character of the suit. In conclusion, we hold that the learned Judges of the High Court Division erred in law in rejecting the prayer for amendment of the plaint and we are inclined to allow the prayer.

 

Salahuddin Khan & Ors Vs. Md. Abdul Hai Bahar & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 137.

 

Section 151

Whether the trial Court committed illegality in entertaining an application under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for vacating its previous order for local investigation

 

Held; the learned Senior Assistant Judge acted illegally in setting aside its previous order purporting to act in the exercise of inherent power of the Court while the plaintiffs could not make out any case that the Court inadvertently by mistake passed an order causing some injustice to a party.

 

Md. Abdus Sattar & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank & ors 20 BLT (HCD )82.

 

Section -151 and Section 152

 

The writ petitioner respondent filed Mortgage Suit No. 33 of 1991 in the Court of learned 1st Artha Rin Adalat, Chittagong against the petitioner and others for realization of Tk.73,63,612.50 which was subsequently made an amount of Tk.67,90,120.06 as per banks subsequent account statement submitted and a preliminary decree was passed on condition for re-accounting and re-calculation of simple interest at the rate of 18% per annum with specific direction that the amount ascertained on such re- calculation and after adjustment of payment made by the petitioner to the respondent during pendency of the said matter the petitioner shall pay rest of the amount (if any) within one year in different installments enjoying waver of interest during the pendency of the Mortgage Suit No,33 of 1991 -but on practicing fraud upon the court and also suppressing the terms, conditions and observations of the preliminary decree regarding re-calculation of interest and adjustment of the payment made by the petitioner during pendency of the Mortgage suit obtained the final decree dated 23.10.1994 contrary to the provisions provided in the preliminary decree dated 29.11.1992 and started decree execution case -the petitioner for ensuring justice by way of legal rectification of errors committed in the final decree and also Mortgage Decree Execution Case due to practice of fraud upon the writ petitioner Bank, the petitioner company preferred a petition under Sections 151/152 of the Code of Civil Procedure praying for setting aside the final decree and also staying the execution proceeding and on hearing both the parties Artha Rin Adalat passed the order (impugned order dated 21.01.1996) setting aside the final decree dated 23.10.1994 and also directed the writ petitioner Bank to submit a current statement on the re­calculation of interest @ 18% per annum in the light of preliminary decree by 27.02.1996. -High Court Division made the Rule absolute and set aside the judgment and order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat setting aside the final decree. -Held; Section 151 cannot be invoked when specific provision is there in Code of Civil Procedure or any other law against the decree and Section 152 is only meant for correcting arithmetical errors or clerical mistakes and was wrongly invoked in this case by the trial court which has been rightly corrected by the High Court Division.

 

M/S. S. Rahman & Com. Ltd. & Anr Vs. United Commercial Bank Ltd & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 51.

 

Section -151 read with Order 39 Rule-1

 

The Order to maintain Statusquo convert into an order of ad-interim injunction.

 

High Court Division by order dated 15.1.2008 passed an order to maintain status quo in respect of possession but with ill motive the opposite parties tried to dispossess the petitioner from the suit land on 26.6.2008 and assaulted the men of this petitioner and threatened to dispossess from the suit land and again GD Entry dated 26.6.2008 was lodged with Charfession Police Station. In the similar way it is alleged that the present petitioner was threatened on several times with dispossession with the help of local musclemen and land grabbers and terrorist and the alleged history of torture of a Hindu family appeared in the daily news paper, paper cuttings of the daily shahnama and Daily Dakhin Anchal have been annexed in the application -Held; Considering the facts and circumstances of the case, I do not find any legal bar to convert the order dated 15.1.2008 into an order of ad-interim injunction restraining the opposite parties from threatening the present petitioner Profulla Kumar Das with dispossession.

 

Prafulla Kumar Das Vs Md. Abul Bashar & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 27.

 

Section-152

 

Whether the Court can amend and/or rejecting the final decree if decree is not in confirming with the preliminary decree.

 

In the instant case, the final decree was drawn up on 30lh November, 2005 and the application for amendment of the decree was filed on 20lh March, 2006, as soon as the defendants came to know that the final decree was drawn up not inconformity with the preliminary decree. In that view of the matter, the Court is not power less to correct and/or amend the decree if the said decree is apparently contrary to the preliminary decree.

 

Najib Chowdhury & Ors Vs. Moazzem Hossain Chowdhury & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 14

 

Order -1 Rule -9 & Order-1 Rule-13 Question of non-joinder of Party

 

Law requires that the objection as to non-impleading of party is to be taken "at the earliest possible opportunity". From the defendant' side neither at the trial nor in the appeal any objection as to non-joinder of party was raised. Also in the revisional application no ground relating to non-joinder of the party was raised. It appears for the first time in the course of hearing of the Rule question of non­joinder of the party was raised. -The settled principle of law is that a suit shall not fail for reason of mis-joinder or non-joinder of the parlies. This Division in the case of Safaruddin and others Vs. Fazlul Huq and others reported in 49 DLR(AD) 151 has held, "no suit can fail by reason merely of non­joinder of parties. Order 1, Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure makes this legal position clear". The High Court Division was in error in entertaining submission as to the matter of non-joinder of the parties made for the first time in the course of argument before it inspite of not taking any ground in the revisional application. Since the defendants in the background of the material as relied upon before the High Court Division had the opportunity before the trial Court as well as in the appeal it; take the plea that the suit was bad for delect of parties and they having had not done so before the courts below they thereby in fact waived the objection as regard the non­joinder of parties, (Order 1, Rule 13 of the Code of C i v i 1 Proced ure)

 

Sufia Khatun Vs. Amin Hossain Mondal & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 164.

 

Order 1 Rule 10

 

Whether an application under Order 1 Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure for adding as parties filed in Civil Revision and brought completely a new fact other than the facts on which the courts below disposed of the suit is maintainable.

 

Held; It appears that the added opposite parties brought completely a new fact other than the facts on which both the courts below disposed of the suit. Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is concerned with an error of law committed by the trial court and appellate court below. The revisional court cannot decide a contested question of fact raised for the first time in revision. Since it is stated in the supplementary affidavit that the added opposite parties have been ppssessing their respective shares, they can file a suit for partition or declaration of title or otherwise if they are so advised.

 

Most. Rafida Bewa Vs. Md. Abdul Gani & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 407.

 

Order 1, Rule 10(2)

 

Whether any transferee pendents lite is capacitated in law to seek any recourse to the provisions of Order 1 Rule 10(2) to be impleaded or added on as a party to such a Suit

 

Held; first and foremost it reflects a judicial discretion that has to be exercised with regard to impleading a party or not in view of the fact and circumstances of each individual case. It is equally to be borne in mind that any applicant under order 1, Rule 10(2) may either qualify as a necessary and/or a proper party. Hence, should the facts and circumstances merit identifying an applicant as one or the other kind of party then that would merit a favourable exercise of judicial discretion - the Doctrine of Us Pendens does not make a transaction pendent lite invalid, the court in the Anil Ranjan Ghosh Case ruled that a purchaser assignee of suit land being interested in the result of the suit can indeed be added as a party given his presence is necessary in the suit.

 

Md. Abdul Bari Chowdhury Vs Md. Moklisur Rahman  21 BLT (HCD) 356.

 

Order 1 Rule 10(2) Read with Transfer of Property Act, 1882

 

Section- 52 & Section- 53 Purchased the land during continuation of the suit whether purchaser is necessary party in the suit

 

In the instant case, while the suit was at preemptory hearing stage, the petitioner sought to be added as party in the suit, either co-plaintiff or defendant - trial Court rejected the prayer on the ground that during continuation of the trial the suit land having been transferred they are not necessary party in the suit. Held- The facts upon which the third party petitioners want to be added is that after purchase they have inducted into possession, they are enjoying the suit property and took different connections from the different authorities as such if there be any decree in the instant suit as such unless the petitioners be made a party, the decree cannot be executed for which further litigation will be required. Moreover, the decision of 50 DLR spelt the apprehension of 3' party which cannot be brush aside as if the plaintiffs do not take any interest in the suit as they sold the property, in that case third party petitioners will have to go for further litigation for protecting their property. - We are of the view that third party petitioners be added as defendants, not as co-plaintiffs.

 

Begum Kohinur Alain & Ors Vs. Md. Yousuf Sikder & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 97.

 

Order 1 Rule 10(2) Application for addition of party in interlocutory matter

 

In the instant Rule the application for addition of party arising out of interlocutory matter, not from the decision of the suit. Unless a party be added in suit, he cannot be a party to the appeal arising out of interlocutory matter. The applicant should approach the trial Court and should be a party in the original suit as unless the applicant be added in the suit he has no right to be added in a proceeding arising out of the suit, as such the applicant should move before the learned Joint District Judge for being added an a party in the suit.

 

Dhaka City Corporation Vs. M.R. Trading Co. & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 383.

 

Order 1 Rule 12(1) Whether only one plaintiff on behalf of others deposed is irregular

 

In the instant suit as I have come-across that only one plaintiff on behalf of others deposed before the trial Court and the learned Court below find it nothing irregular which is reflected in the decision of our Appellate Division reported in 12 MLR (AD) 248, in the case of Kazi Md. Abdul Quddus & another -Vs- Mst. Karimon Bewa and others. Order 1 Rule 12(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure is very much clear in this regard.
