There exist no confusion that all the plaintiffs of the original suit have got common interest and they became aggrieved while the order of termination was issued against them on dated 19.09.1981.

 

Md. Mosharraf Ali Khan Vs. A.G.M Sonali Bank, & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 51.

 

Order-2 Rule-2

 

We have considered the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioners. His only contention is whether Panchu Moral is the son of Danu Moral as alleged hv hip defendants or son of Hache Bepari as alleged by the plaintiffs. This question has been dissolved on the evidence on P.W.2, who is aged about 90 years and saw both Danu Moral and Panchu Moral and deposed that Panchu Moral is not son of Danu Moral. In consideration of the evidence on record, the learned Single of the High Court Division correctly held that in Title Suit No.413 of 1966 Jongal Moral failed to prove his relationship with Danu Moral, who is admittedly the son of Panchu Moral and as such neither Panchu Moral nor his son Jongal Moral is entitled to inherit the properties left by Danu Moral described in the schedule of the plaint. The learned Single Judge of the High Court Division having passed the impugned judgment on due consideration of the evidence and materials on record we find no reason to disturb the same. -We are also of the opinion that the said Jongal Moral being unsuccessful in Title Suit No.413 of 1966 the defendant-petitioner are precluded by Rule 2 Order 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure from claiming the share of Jongal Moral.

 

Sakat Ali Gazi & ors Vs. Mr. Abdur Razzaque & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 219.

 

Order-2, RuIe-2

 

Title Suit No. 134 of 1964 is barred under the provisions of Order 2, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure and that the cause of action of both the suits aroses at the same time and as such the subsequent suit namely Title Suit No. 134 of 1964 is barred under the aforesaid Rules as contended by the learned Counsel for the appellants - in reply the learned Counsel for the respondent submits that the suit holdings being different, the provisions of Order 2, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure are not applicable in the present case - Held; The contention so made by the learned Counsel of the respondent appears to be of merit.

 

Khandoker Ansar Ahmed & Ors Vs. A.T.M. Monsur Ali Mallik & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 129.

 

Order 2(2) read with Order 2(14) Distinction between 'decree' and an 'order'

 

The essential elements of a decree are (1) formal expression of an adjudication in a suit (11) adjudication of the rights of the parties with regards to all or any of the matters in controversy and (111) conclusive determination of the rights. On the hand order as defined in section 2( 14) of the code though generally has the essential attributes of a decree is not a decree as it arises out of proceeding not being a suit. Thus, an order allowing or rejecting the pre-emption case under section 96 of the said Act is not a decree.

 

Md. Afazuddin Fakir Vs. M. H. Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 407.

 

Order-5 Rule-12 Service of Notice

 

Notice of the Title Suit No.59 of 1988 was sent through registered post and defendant Kazi Sultan received that on 18.8.1988 by putting his own signature and the normal notice was received by his brother Joynal Abedin as the said defendant was out side and his brother agreed to receive that and then it was served upon him on 28.8.1988 resulting service of notice upon the said defendant, the instant plaintiff of the suit and the notice was received by the full brother of the plaintiff who stay in the same house and mess with the plaintiff - Thus I am of the view that the notice of Title Suit No.59 of 1988 was duly served upon the plaintiff in Title Suit No.36 of 1996.

 

Kazi Md. Sultan Ahmed Vs. Titama Bibi & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 17.

 

Order-6 Rule-17

 

Held; we have carefully examined the terms of the proposed amendment as well as the depositions of the witnesses. It appears to us that just to fill up the lacuna, plaintiff brought such amendments. There is no legal mandate to bring such amendment at the belated stage which will certainly change the nature and character of the suit. It is pertinent to point out that the proposed amendment is not merely a formal addition of certain facts rather it has direct bearing on the nature and character of the suit and it will have the effect of making out a new case for the plaintiff which will materially affect the merit of the case, such amendment should not be allowed under Order VI Rule 17 of the Code. Moreso, a story of dispossession having a remarkable departure from the stand taken in the plaint and evidence will seriously prejudice the defendants in suit. On this count also the application for amendment cannot be allowed.

 

Abdul Mutaleb Khan & Anr Vs Md. Kabir @ Mostak Ahmed & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 159.

 

Order-VI Rule-17

 

Incorporation of new face It appears that the plaintiffs incorporated new facts by the amendment but incorporation of new fact cannot in any way change the nature and character of the suit. The suit still be named as a suit for declaration of plaintiffs' easement right. The finding of the High Court Division that the nature and character of the suit would be changed by the amendment without elaboration of its finding cannot sustain in law. Amendment is always necessary to determine the real question of controversy between the parties otherwise there is likelihood of croping-up of multifarious litigations.

 

Md. Akram Ali Pk. & Ors Vs. Md. Yasin All & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 175.

 

Order -6 Rule-17

 

Amendment of the pleading of the Written Statement —Civil Revision under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure

 

Held; The learned Subordinate Judge at the time of disposal of the application for amendment of the written statement ought to have taken into consideration that after filing the application for amendment of the written statement by defendant No.5 i.e. the petitioner herein the defendant did not raise any objection against the proposed amendment of the written statement. So I find that the proposed amendment of the written statement will not destroy any right of the litigant parties and also the nature and character of the suit will not change. The learned Subordinate Judge fell into a gross error in not taking into consideration that if the amendment is allowed, the concerned party will be at liberty to file additional written statement or in the alternative to file an application for amendment of the written statement. In the aforesaid facts and circumstances of the case, I find that the impugned order of the learned Subordinate Judge in rejecting the application for amendment by Order No. 19 dated 02.10.1997 suffers from gross miscarriage of justice resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice and as such the same deserves my interference under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Tapash Kumar Majumder Vs. Nirmal Krishna & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 446.

 

Order VI Rule 17 read with Local Government (Union Parishad) Election Rules, 2010; Section 61(3) Whether amendment gives retrospective effect to the proceeding relating to the trial of an election petition

 

On careful scrutiny over the related papers along with the order of the learned Election Tribunal it is apparent from the face of the papers that the amendment as sought for by the plaintiff-opposite party has been given a retrospective effect from the date of filing of the election petition and as such I am constrained to hold such a view that the said amendment has no doubt the effect of filing a fresh election petition. Such amendment can not be entertained but the learned Election Tribunal illegally allowed the application for amendment which is not sustainable in law.

 

Haji Mohammad Nurul Hague Vs. Rafik Ahammad 21 BLT (HCD) 120.

 

Order 7 Rule-3 read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 ; Section-42

 

Order 7 Rule 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that the description of the suit land must be specific and if necessary the specific boundary should be given. The present suit is a suit for declaration of title as well as the 4 deeds arc void. So it is a suit for declaration simplicitor in which specification of the suit land is a must.

 

Most. Alom Taj begum & Ors Vs Sree Nimal Chandra Roy 18 BLT (HCD) 196.

 

Order-7 Rule-4 read with Evidence Act, 1872; Section-102

 

Suit for realization of the government Money-Impugned judgment and decree is perverse being contrary to the Nitimala of the Government dated 28.11.1994 vide its memo No. ms-mg/wewa-l/Gm-2/94 (Ask-2)-241(200). as contended by the counsel far the defendant appellant.

 

Held; The proposition of law is well settled that the burden lies on the plaintiff to prove his case and he must succeed on his own strength only and not at the weakness of the defendant. Therefore, we are led to hold that the learned Subordinate Judge erred in law in passing the impugned judgment and decree without applying his judicial mind into the facts and circumstance of the case and law bearing on the subject and the same has resulted in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice.

 

G. M. Abu Hena Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 616.

 

Order VII Rule-11

 

Four conditions arc necessary far rejection plaint: Firstly, if it does not disclose any cause of action. Secondly, the relief claimed is undervalued. Thirdly, if the plaint is written upon paper insufficiently stamped or Fourthly, if from the statement of the plaint, the suit is barred by law.

 

Abdul Aziz Vs Md. Anisur Rahman Babul & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 80.

 

Order 7 Rule 11

 

Whether the plaint in Admiralty Suit cannot be rejected under the provisions of Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure

 

Held; The application under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is not maintainable to reject a plaint in Admiralty suit, but the Court can invoke its inherent jurisdiction to reject the plaint if it appears that the suit is barred by law relied on 35 DLR(AD) 188.

 

Penta Marine Services Ltd. Vs Niko Resources (Bangladesh) Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 294.

 

Order 7 RuIe-ll

 

Whether an application under Order 39 Rule 2(3) of the Code of Civil Procedure is a plaint

 

The application under order 39, Rule 2(3) of the Code of Civil Procedure can never be termed as a plaint. No. application under Order VII, Rule 11 CPC lies in violation Miscellaneous case under order 39, Rule 2(3) of the Code of Civil Procedure. kbdur

 

Rouf Khan & Anr Vs. Jobbar Ali Howlader  21 BLT (HCD) 482.

 

Order 7 Rule- 11

 

Proceeding under section 96 of the SAT Act, 1950

 

Held; we are of the firm view that the proceeding started under Section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is not a suit, it is an application which does not come within the purview of the plaint according to Order 7, rule 1 of the Code. The plaint has been explained and codified in Order-VIl of the said Code. On the other hand the application for pre-emption under section 96 of the Act is mere a proceeding which cannot be denoted as plaint within the ambit of Order vii, of the said Code although it has got all the Trappings of a plaint - a proceeding under section 96 of the said Act pending before a civil court not being a plaint applicability of Order-vii Rulel 1 of the Code would not be available to reject the same.

 

Md. Afazuddin Fakir Vs. M. H. Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 407.

 

Order -7 Rule -11 read with Trade Marks Act, 1940 Section -21, 22 & 25

 

It is on record that the defendant's trade mark was registered on 18.07.1988 for the shoes as Samrat Shoes with the flying Eagle and the defendant has been using the same trade mark since registration of the trade mark. It is also on record that the application for trade mark registration of plaintiff was acknowledged by the Registrar, Trade Marks by letter dated 02.11.1994 treating the application of the plaintiff as trade mark application No.42095 class 25. Thus it is clear that the defendant's trade mark was registered in the year 1988 whereas the receipt of the application of the plaintiff for trade mark registration was acknowledged by the authority on 02.11.1994. Therefore, the plaintiff has no cause of action to file the suit. The High Court Division rightly held that the plaintiff had no cause of action for the suit and accordingly rejected the plaint under order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for want of cause of action.

 

MIS. Samrat Shoes Ltd. Vs. Md. Zahirul Islam 17 BLT (AD) 75.

 

Order -7 Rule -11 read with Bangladesh Rin Shalishi Ain, 1989 Section -6 Disclosure of Wrong Cause of Action

 

It appears from the plaint that the plaintiff respondents subscribed the cause of action to have arisen on 15.06.1997 but it is not denied that they filed the case before the Board under Section 6 of the Ain on 28.08.1990 and as such the submission made on behalf of the appellants that there being disclosure of wrong cause of action the plaint was liable to be rejected is not bereft of substance. - The plaint of Title Suit No. 152 of 1997 of the Court of the Senior Assistant Judge, Rajbari stands rejected.

 

Md. Akkas All Biswas & Ors Vs. Ashit Kr. Mojumder & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 92.

 

Order 7 Rule 11 read with Limitation Act, 1905; Article 137

 

Whether a plaint in a suit can be rejected on the ground of barred by limitation

 

The question of limitation is hybrid question of law and fact and question whether the suit is barred by limitation can only be decided upon getting evidence on the point and as of the Pourashava is appointed only to receive postal documents and summons on behalf of the Pourashava. Evidence shows he received the same on 15.06.1983 and it to the concerned authority. -Whether the suit is maintainable or not due to non complying the mandatory provision of section 152 of the pourashava Ordinance, 1977 is a matter relating to maintainability of the suit itself and deserves no consideration in disposing either the application filed under Order 9 Rule 13 of the code of Civil Procedure or the instant petition.

 

Chairman, Mymensingh Pourashava Vs. Kasimonnessa Bewa & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 206.

 

Order -9 Rule-13

 

I have examined the order sheet of the Trial Court which has been referred by the learned Advocates and found that the order No.9 dated 16.1.1980 as quoted above, the process server submitted report to have served the notice and the same is also reflected from the annexure-A, report of the process server but by subsequent order dated 28.6.1982,  the court asked the plaintiffs to put in fresh requisites in respect of defendant nos. 2,3,8 and 7-20 (order No. 30) and by the subsequent order no.35 dated 16.3.1983,  the court found non compliance of the order and further asked the plaintiff to comply with the order dated 28.6.1982 and from the said order No.61, it appears that subsequently    notices    were    served    on defendant nos. 4-7 and substituted heirs of defendant nos.  1(0,  l(m), l(a),  11 (a), 12, 1 (c), 1 (h), (j) but we do not find any order to have passed on 10.8.1986 as referred by the learned Trial court in his judgment which has been quoted by the learned Advocate for the plaintiff opposite parties in paragraph 5 of the counter affidavits and we also do not find any service of summons upon defendant nos. 2, 3 and 8 and on the face of such materials on record, I have drawn the attention of the learned Advocate for the plaintiff opposite parties to such facts who finds difficulty to trace any order as to have passed on 10.8.1986 by the Trial Court and also any order as to service of summons on defendant nos. 2,3 and 8. -The application under order 9 Rule 13 is allowed and the partition suit no. 1317/1985 is restored.

 

Md. Abdul Wahab Sarker & Ors Vs Md. Shahid Sarker & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 94.

 

Order-9 Rule-13

 

Sufficient Cause

 

It is pertinent to point out that admittedly one Assistant Government Pleader named Muslem Uddin entered appearance on behalf of defendants without furnishing vokalatnama duly signed and executed by them. From the materials on record it shows that the concerned Assistant Government Pleader could not take any step to collect the information to respond the plaint and there is no materials that result of the exparte decree was duly communicated to them by the learned A.G.P. In view of such facts 1 hold that mare appearance of the Government Pleader without furnishing Vokalatnama duly signed by the concerned authority of the Government and without their instruction it cannot be treated as proper appearance in suit by the Government where there is an allegation that summons were shown to have been served upon them.

 

Md. Osman Gani Vs Deputy Commissioner & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 311.

 

Order IX Rule-13

 

Held; In view of provisions of law only the defendant of the suit can file Miscellaneous Case under Order 9, Rule 13 of CPC with a prayer for setting aside the exparte decree. Stranger or any 3'd party has no locus standi to institute or maintain Miscellaneous Case under Order 9, Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside the exparte decree passed.

 

Md. Salamat Hossain Vs. Abdur Razzak Mahmud Chowdhury & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 427.

 

Order-9 Rule-13 read with Order-7 Rule-11

 

The application under Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure being not a plaint, application under  Order 7 Rule   11 of the  Code  of  Civil procedure shall not apply.

 

Haflzuddin & Ors Vs Md. Idris Mia & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 308.

 

Order-9 Rule-13 read with Evidence Act, 1872 ; Section-102

 

Regarding service of summons upon the non contesting defendants the onus lies upon the plaintiff who obtained exparte decree to prove that summons upon the defendants were duly served. When it is established to the satisfaction of the Court that summons upon defendants were not served and the defendants were not so long aware of the suit, the exparte decree is set aside, upon an application under Order IX rule 13 of the Code.

 

Md. Osinan Gani Vs Deputy Commissioner Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 311.

 

Order IX Rule 13 read with President's Order No.142 of 1972 Section 6

 

'satisfaction' - P.O. No.142 of 1972, before amendment government was Impleaded as proforma defendant but after amendment, government became necessary party

 

Held; In the application under Order IX Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure it is stated that Government having been made proforma defendant did not take proper attention to the summons which was served on the Government, as such, government did not take proper care and step in the proceeding of the suit. - Rule 13 Order IX speaks 'satisfaction' and this 'satisfaction' is satisfaction of the Court. From the facts of the case it appears that Government satisfactorily explained its non appearance when the suit was decreed against Government.

 

Jamuna Builders Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 36.

 

Order 13 Rule 3

 

It appears that all the exhibits produced by the plaintiff received back by the plaintiff-opposite parties, although from this Court once again reminders were issued to produce the wanting exhibit documents before this Court but they failed to do so. Therefore, this court has no scope, chance or occasion to perused and consider the same.

 

Soleman Biswas Vs. Abdul Khaleque & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 374.

1492

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Part-4)

Citation: 1 7 BLT (AD) 187, 17 BLT (HCD) 450, 21 BLT (AD) 137, 19 BLT (HCD) 310, 17 BLT (AD) 150, 17 BLT (HCD) 364, 20 BLT (HCD) 29, 21 BLT (HCD) 427, 21 BLT (HCD) 284, 20 BLT (HCD) 519, 18 BLT (HCD) 86, 20 BLT (AD) 105, 20 BLT (AD) 107, 19 BLT (AD) 52, 17 BLT (AD

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Code of Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-07-09

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

 

(as Amended) Order-15 Rule-3 read with Order 14 Rule-2 Issue of Law —Issue touching maintainability of Suit.

 

Learned advocate for the Petitioner submits that the learned Judges of the High Court Division erred in law in not considering the facts and circumstances of the case that the trial court framed the issues on 18.9.1997 and subsequently the suit was posted for peremtory hearing but the suit was Suo Moto withdrawn from the peremtory hearing without giving effect to the applications under Order 11 Rule 14 and Order 11 Rule 21 of the Code of Civil Procedure filed by the plaintiff petitioner and also without considering the ( )rder dated 10.8.2002 wherein it is noted " Benefit the learned Courts below committed error of law in passing the impugned judgment which is against the principle of natural justice and as such the same is liable to be set aside. -We do not find any substance in the points raised. The High Court Division upon correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision. We therefore find no reason to interfere with the same.

 

Saiful Hoque Vs. Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation  1 7 BLT (AD) 187.

 

Order -20 Rule -4

It appears from the order sheet that 3 PWs. were examined but the appellant failed to cross-examine them. On 09.03.1991 the opposite party appellant appeared and filed application for re-calling, the witnesses for cross-examination which was allowed on 10.04.1991. On 15.08.1991 they cross-examined the PWs.l and 2. On 06.11.1991, the applicant respondents filed an application to exonerate them to produce any witness and from cross examination of P.w.3 but no order was passed on that application. It further appears from the order dated 11.02.1992 that an application was filed by this appellant and the court fixed the matter on 10.03.1992 for order. On that day, this appellant failed to appear and the Court allowed the case exparte. In the exparte order the learned District Judge observed Held the judgment and order dated 10.03.1992. as passed by the learned District judge, Bogra, is hereby set aside and the learned District judge, Bogra, is directed to proceed with the Case allowing the parties to adduce evidence, if they are so advised.

 

Kanchan Bala Rani Vs Sreemati Gita Rani Sarker & Anr  17 BLT (HCD) 450.

 

Order XX Rule 5

 

In the instant case, the suit was filed on 14.08.1996 and the pro-forma defendant No.9 filed the application for rejection of the plaint on 29.06.2005, the date fixed for preemptory hearing of the suit though long before the said date issues were framed including the issue of maintainability. - the learned Joint District Judge rejecting the application and observed that an issue as to the maintainability having already been framed, 'he same shall be decided along with other issues; in revision the learned District Judge rightly affirmed the said view of the learned Joint District Judge, but the learned Judges of the High Court Division totally failed to consider the above discussed factual and legal aspect of the case as well as observations of the Courts below. - Since the learned Judges of the High Court Division rejected the plaint taking the application filed by the defendants as one under Order VII, rule 11 of the Code which we have not approved, we do not consider it necessary to dwell upon the point of deciding the issue of maintainability of the suit at the stage of preemptory hearing in the light of the provisions of Order XX, rule 5 of the Code as that will be mere academic. However, we approved the decision given by the learned Joint District Judge in this regard as discussed hereinbefore.

 

Salahuddin Khan & Ors Vs. Md. Abdul Hai Bahar & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 137.

 

Order 20 rule 15 read with Partnership Act, 1932 (IX of 1932) Section 69(3)(a)

 

When a decree a nullity

 

In the instant case the partnership business on the basis of an unregistered document is admitted by both the parties. In view of the said admission, the plaintiff is entitled to get a preliminary decree for a declaration that he is a partner in the business in question and for dissolution of partnership business - But in passing the impugned judgment and decree the learned Joint District Judge without passing any preliminary decree and taking account straight way relying on a procured audit report by the plaintiff, exhibit-2, has determined the profit of the business and the share of the respective parties and decreed for an amount of taka 10,96,0177- in favour of the plaintiff - Held ; We have no hesitation to hold that the impugned judgment and decree is passed beyond the scope of order 20, Rule 15 of the Code of Civil Procedure and same is without jurisdiction and a nullity in the eye of law.

 

Tushar Kanti Bhattacharjee & Anr Vs Bijoy Lai Karmaker 19 BLT (HCD) 310.

 

Order -21 Rule -29

 

Staying the Execution case at the instance of third Party It appears that the appellant already obtained a decree in his Title Suit No.404 of 1984 in which the respondent Nos.l and 2 were not parties. Under the facts and circumstances and in view of materials on record, we are of the view the respondents have no locus-standi to file the so called applications for staying the execution proceeding.

 

Mozharul Islam Chowdhury, Advocate Vs. Dilip Kumar Roy & Ors. 17 BLT (AD) 150.

 

Order -21 Rule-29

 

It appears that the Miscellaneous Case praying for setting aside the ex-parte decree dated 28.8.1996 was filed on 24.8.1997 and the execution case was filed on 21.7.1997. It appears that both the cases were filed long ago but the miscellaneous case filed under Order IX rule 13 will be infructuous if the execution case proceeds. In that view of the matter, we are of the opinion that the interest of justice will be met if we direct the concerned court to dispose of the miscellaneous case within a period of 6(six) months from the date of receipt of this order.

 

Masumul Huda & Ors Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 364.

 

Order-21 Rule-29

The Title Suit No. 367 of 2002 and Title Suit No. 40 of 2004 are pending before the joint District Judge, First Court, Dhaka and the Arbitral Awards sought to be enforced by the District Judge has been passed by the International Court of Arbitration which is different from the Court before whom the aforesaid suits are pending. Moreover, in order to invoke Order 21 Rule 29 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the existence of a decree is required any admittedly, the Arbitral Award sought to be enforced is neither a decree nor the same has been deemed to be a decree by any law. Smith Co-Generation (Bangladesh) Pvt. Ltd. Vs Bangladesh & Anr 18 BLT (HCD) 261.

 

Order XXI rule 83

 

The legislative intent of rule 83 is to facilitate, and not to obstruct, the satisfaction of the decree through private initiative of the judgment debtor instead of the court process. The rational is, such a course would not affect the interest of the decree holder, and rather it is likely to pave the way for better satisfaction of the amount of the decree.

 

Major (Retd.) Rafiq Hasan Faruq Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 29.

 

Order XXII Rule-4(4)

 

Held; It is on record that the principal defendant No. 1, Sheikh Bashir Ali after filing written statement finally did not contest the suit. Provision of Order XXII, Rule 4(4) CPC provides that the heirs of non contesting defendant need not be substituted.

 

Md. Salamat Hossain Vs. Abdur Razzak Mahmud Chowdhury & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 427.

 

Order 22 Rule-9(2)(3)

 

Substituted in miscellaneous case under Order 9 Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Plaintiff's suit was dismissed for default and thereafter the suit was restored to its file and number by judgment and order passed in Miscellaneous case under Order 9 Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure -In the said Miscellaneous Case plaintiff filed an application on 24.09.2009 praying for recording the names of the heirs of the defendant Nos. 1 to 3 in the suit as they had already been substituted in Miscellaneous Case No. 58 of 2005. The plaintiff (petitioner herein) also filed another application on the same day, that is on 24.09.2009, praying for substitution of the heirs of the substituted defendant No. 2(Ka), late Abul Kalam Azad who died on 02.07.2009. The learned Judge of the trial Court, after hearing both the parties by his order No. 80 dated 15.10.2009 was pleased to reject to the applications for recording abatement dated 16.09.2009 and allowed both the applications for substitution -In Revision Learned District Judge reversed the order -Held; On perusal of the documents submitted with the petition it is found that the deceased defendant Nos. 1 to 3 were duly substituted in course of time in the miscellaneous case filed under Order IX, rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure on 14.02.2006, as such, the impugned judgment and order passed by the learned District Judge, Narail dated 28.04.2011 thereby reversing the judgment and order dated 15.10.2009 passed by the learned Senior Assistant Judge, Lohagara, Narail in Title Suit No. 85 of 2001 is found to be unjustified and therefore the Rule attracts merit.

 

Jobeda Begum & Monjuri Bibi Vs Titu Munshi & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 284.

 

Order -22 Rule 9(3) read with Limitation Act, 1908; Article 177

 

Whether the appeal arising out of the judgment and decree passed in Artha Rin Suit stood abated as a whole on account of .failure to substitute the heirs of sole respondent

 

Held; There is 9 years 5 months 5 days delay has been occurred in the instant application for substitution. The reason for causing delay is unsatisfactory and not covered by any hypothetication. The conduct of the filing lawyer is not reasonable and not covered by any norms of practice as the delay is absolutely inordinate. The appellant may sue the filing conducting lawyer for the loss but on such application which does not disclose the particulars even to the date of knowledge of the date of death of the deceased, respondent No.l, for unexplained unknown reason according to the broad principle of law of limitation, the vested right accrued to the other side after prescribed period of limitation cannot be wiped out. On such type of application unusual long delay of 9 years 5 months 5 days can not be condoned. - Since the rule for substitution of the heirs of sole respondent after setting aside abatement has been discharged, the appeal has no leg to stand.

 

Sonali Bank Vs. Sheikh Anis Uddin Ahmed 20 BLT (HCD) 519.

 

Order-22 Rule-10

 

Held; On going to materials on record it transpires that the suit is pending for pre-emptory hearing. The opposite party no.l prayed to be impleaded as plaintiff because interest to other plaintiffs was devolved in favour of him. The trial Court rejected the same holding that his interest will be protected by other plaintiffs and mean while plaintiff no. 6 was already examined as P.w-1. So the trial Court rightly rejected the application but the Court of revision below allowed the rejection -I am of the view that the impugned judgment and order suffers from legal infirmities.

 

Sekandar Ali & Ors Vs Emran Chowdhury & Ors  18 BLT (HCD) 86.

 

Order 23, Rule 1

 

Application filed in Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal praying for granting permission to withdraw the suit

 

Held; We are not inclined to give permission to the petitioners to withdraw the suit with liberty to institute fresh suit, but however, the petitioners may withdraw the suit in terms of Order 23, Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure subject to payment of Cost ofTk.5,000/-

 

Md. Ibrahim Hossain Shah & Ors Vs. Md. Abdul Aziz & Anr 20 BLT (AD) 105.

 

Order 23, Rule 1

 

Application is allowed, for withdrawal of the suit with liberty to sue afresh, if not otherwise barred by law.

 

Forhad Hossain Mondal & Ors Vs. Md. Badsha Sahansa Alam 20 BLT (AD) 107.

 

Order-26 Rule-1

 

Extraordinary power

 

The power of the Court to issue a commission to examine a witness, is an exceptional one and should be used carefully and only after being fully satisfied that there is no other way to examine the said witness whose evidence is necessary for proper disposal of the suit. An occasional illness or temporary infirmity is not enough to allow a commission in exercise of such an extraordinary power.

 

Sonali Bank Ltd. Ors Vs. M/s. Fair Chemicals Pvt. & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 52.

 

Order-26 Rule-9

 

In title execution case

 

It appears from the record that the suit land was specifically mentioned in the plaintiff of the suit and there was no uncertainty or vagueness in the land which has been decreed by the Court of Appeal below and maintained upto this Division. It further appears that the subject matter of the suit including the description of the property, as described in the schedule to the plaint, is sufficient to identify the suit land and the executing Court cannot go beyond the decree by allowing a local investigation to ascertain the suit land. During trial of the suit the contesting defendants could have raised the plea of identity of the suit land and could have made a prayer for local investigation but such prayer cannot be entertainable by the executing Court, as the executing Court cannot go behind the decree.

 

Md. Nurul Alain Miah & Ors Vs. Md. Idris Ali 17 BLT (AD) 296.

 

Order -26 Rule -9 Suit for Permanent injunction

 

The instant suit was for a decree of permanent injunction. In such suit the suit land must be specific and well identified as provided in Order VII Rule 3 of the Code. From the schedule appended to the plaint it appears the suit land measuring 11.50 decimals has been based on C.S. and S.A. Plot covering 6.46 acres of land situated within Dhaka City which has been devided into several plots and recorded in the Dhaka City survey khatians. Since the suit land covered by C.S. and S.A. Plots have not been identified by the R.S. and Dhaka City Survey khatians in the schedule of the plaint it is hardly possible to determine and ascertain the identity of the suit plot on the basis of oral and documentary evidence without holding local investigation by a survey knowing Advocate Commissioner. -It appears from the schedule of the plaint that the suit land has not been properly described and depicted and the same is not identifiable in the locality. Hence local investigation was essentially required for ascertaining the identity and location of the suit land by a survey knowing advocate Commissioner, otherwise the decree passed by the trial court would be infractous.

 

Order -26 Rule -9

 

Appointment of Advocate Commissioner -Available in appeal

 

A legal right for appointment of Advocate Commissioner for holding local investigation under Order XXVI Rule 9 of the Code available in a suit is also available in an appeal in appropriate case since the appeal is the continuation of the original suit. The appellate court having all the powers and trappings of the original court has discretion either to allow or disallow appointment of Advocate Commissioner for holding local investigation but the discretion should be exercised judiciously.

 

Md. Babul Islam Vs Md. Nasiruddin Sarder 17 BLT (HCD) 510.

 

Order 26 Rule -9

 

The Advocate Commissioner could not accomplish his duty as per direction in the Writ as contended by the learned counsel for the petitioner.

 

It is well settled now that the Court is not at all precluded from considering the report of the Commissioner afresh again in the light of such fresh materials as may be legally brought on the record by the parties. The Commissioner report is to be evaluated in the facts of the case on the evidence adduced and the Court has wide discretion in such matter. Mere acceptance of the report by the Court therefore, did not cause any error in the decision which requires to be interfered by this Court.

 

Abdul Halim & Anr Vs. Sheikh Abdullah & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 280.

 

Order 26 Rule 9

 

Application for local inspection filed at belated stage as the suit is in the final stage

 

Without local inspection only by adducing oral evidence it is not at all possible to arrive at a correct finding over the matter in dispute as contended by the learned Counsel for the defendant-petitioners. - Learned trial Court below rejected the same on the ground that the defendant did not pray local inspection earlier as such the application for local inspection is not considered at this belated stage as the suit is in the final stage. - Held; The impugned order of the learned trial Court below suffers from serious miscarriage of Justice which has resulted an error in the decision occasioning in failure of Justice. - the learned Trial Court is hereby directed to dispose of the application under Order XXVI Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure on merit giving opportunity to both sides and dispose of the same preferably within 2 (two) months and the learned Advocate Commissioner if so appointed by the learned Trial Court is hereby directed to submit his report within l(one) month.

 

Tofazzal Hossain & Ors Vs. Govt of Bangladesh 20 BLT (HCD) 309.

 

Order-26 Rule-9 read with The Hindu Gains of learning Act 1930 Section-3

 

It appears from the impugned judgment that the learned Joint District Judge rejected the Advocate Commissioner's report mainly on the ground that the valuation of goodwill was not included in the preliminary decree, but such observation is totally misconceived. It is evident that the value of the movable property and the value of goodwill have been described in the schedule properly and the preliminary decree was passed in accordance with the schedules of the plaint.

 

Chinmoy Chowdhury Vs. Mridul Chowdhury & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 140.

 

Order-26 Rule-10 Without Jurisdiction—Advocate Commissioner

 

Held;—Writ was issued for examining Nuruzzaman but the learned Advocate commissioner also examined -one Shirin Akter which is beyond the writ. The learned Advocate Commissioner, as we see did not act judicially as such the report cannot be accepted legally.

 

Azam Ali & Anr Vs Akram All & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 192.

 

Order XXVI Rule 10(2)

 

The report of the Advocate Commissioner shall go into evidence even if the Commissioner is not examined in Court and that the evidentiary value of the report of the Advocate Commissioner may vary depending upon the facts and circumstances of a particular case. The Advocate Commissioner's report is not sacrosanct but it is only a piece of evidence which is to be considered along with other evidence. The Court may or may not rely on such evidence notwithstanding the fact that it has been admitted in evidence.

 

Abdun Noor & Ors Vs. Aziruddin & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 161.

 

Order XXVI Rule 10(2)

 

Whether the law laid down on the construction of Order XXVI Rule 10(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure in the case of Abdus Sattar (Md.) and others Vs. Lalon Mazar Sharif and Seba Sadan Committee and others (2004) 56 DLR (AD) 180 is the correct statement of law.

 

Held; Having gone through the entire judgment it appears that the Sub-rule (2) of Rule 10 of Order XXVI was not brought to the notice of this Division in which it is stated that the report of the Advocate Commissioner and the evidence taken by him shall be evidence in the suit and shall form part of the record and that the Court on any of the parties with the permission of the Court may examine the Commissioner in open Court touching all the matter relating to his report. Had the provision of Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 of Order XXVI of the Code of Civil Procedure been brought to the notice of this Division, the aforesaid finding would not have been made.

 

Abdun Noor & Ors Vs. Aziruddin & Ors 21 BLT(AD)161.

 

Order -32 Rule- 6 &7 read with Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article - 7, 8 and Article-10

 

Concept of Social Justice Held; On a close scrutiny of the mandate laid down in our constitution we find that the great people of this country through its constitution intended to lead our society to a welfare state and the concept of social justice would remain in oblivion unless social justice is dispensed. Dispensation of social justice and achieving the goals set forth in the Constitution are not possible without the active concerted and dynamic efforts made by the persons concerned with the justice dispensation system. Therefore, we are also of the considered opinion that without being confined to the four corners of the Code of civil Procedure and other laws relevant for the purpose, we must promote the concept of social justice so that life of the people living in a sovereign Nation become meaningful he or she be able to live with human dignity. We are also of the view that the concept of social justice is not fettered by any chain or shackles in order to do justice to the downtrodden in the society. Under the said concept the court must award appropriate relief to rehabilitate the person/person s in distress in proper social spectrum.

 

Tarik Hossain & Ors Vs. Dulari Begum & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 521

 

Order-32 RuIe-7

 

Court Jurisdiction -to ensure social justice During pendency of the appeal when the matter was brought in the list for hearing at that stage an application for compromise was filed apparently on behalf of both the parties

 

The situation arose and reflected before the court brought its entire atmosphere under a thick cover of painful silence unmistakably indicating that the compromise is nothing but an aggression by the mighty man like the defendant appellant No.l upon the downtrodden two respondents but according to their  mother  they  are  helpless  ladies, therefore, we are of the firm belief that the alleged compromise is a pointer to a device to deprive the weak section of the society by the mighty ones as is going unbridled around us in our present day scenario, therefore, we are of the considered opinion that the compromise is neither lawful nor satisfactory to this court rather it is a device to deprive the downtrodden by the mighty one, therefore, having discarded the application for compromise we have asked the learned Advocates for the parties to place the appeal on merit -we find that this court is oath bound to do something for those who have been looked down upon by another group of people living in the same society particularly in view of the mandate of the Constitution. Therefore, we are of the firm belief that this is a- fit case where the concept of social justice must be invoked as a device to ensure human life to be meaningful and liveable with human dignity -Appeal is Dismissed. The learned District Judge is also directed to attach  the  property   left  by  Badsha  Miah described in the schedule Ka,Ga,Gha of the plaint    of   Title    Suit    No. 168    of    1991 appointing   Deputy   Commissioner,   Dhaka and the collector as receiver thereof for the purpose  of protecting  and  preserving the property and its income derived from the attached property with a view to distribute the same amongst the heirs of Badsha Miah after ascertainment of their respective shares on the final disposal of the partition suit. The receiver   be also directed to maintain possession of that part of the property where the parties are holding for their respective dwelling purposes but the remaining properties which   are  being  held  by   tenants  or  for business purpose shall be brought under the control and management of the Receiver. The Deputy Commissioner and collector of Dhaka shall however be at liberty to engage any other suitable person for carrying out the directions of this court but the ultimate responsibility shall lie with the collector and the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka.

 

Tarik Hossain & Ors Vs. Dulari Begum & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 521.

 

Order 33 Rule 1

 

On perusal of the order of the trial Court it appears that the trial Court came to the findings in as much as, an admitted fact is that the petitioner has a provident fund account where he has Tk.l 1,5337- as balance and that necessarily shows that the plaintiff is owner of the property worth more than Tk.l,0007- and as such he cannot be considered a pauper as contemplated under Order 33 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court Division appreciating the order of the trial Court and submissions of the learned Advocate of the parties has affirmed the judgment of the trial Court holding that the trial Court committed no illegality in coming to the findings that the petitioner has got Tk.l 1,5337- in his provident fund as well as owner of the landed property measuring about 0.70 decimals and as such, the petitioner is not entitled to claim him as a pauper as contemplated under the provision of the Order 33 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure. - In drawing such conclusions and affirming the order of the trial Court we find the High Court Division committed no error of law warranting interference by this Division.

 

Md. Abdul Khaleque Vs. Uttara Bank Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 94.

 

Order 33 Rule 1

 

Refusing to accord permission to institute the suit as being pauper

 

Held; On perusal of the order of the trial Court it appears that the trial Court came to the findings in as much as, an admitted fact is that the petitioner has a provident fund account where he has Tk. 11,5337- as balance and that necessarily shows that the plaintiff is owner of the property worth more than Tk.l,0007- and as such he cannot be considered a pauper as contemplated under Order 33 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court Division appreciating the order of the trial Court and submissions of the learned Advocate of the parties has affirmed the judgment of the trial Court holding that the trial Court committed no illegality in coming to the findings that the petitioner has got Tk.l 1,5337- in his provident fund as well as owner of the landed property measuring about 0.70 decimals and as such, the petitioner is not entitled to claim him as a pauper as contemplated under the provision of the Order 33 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure. - In drawing such conclusions and affirming the order of the trial Court we find the High Court Division committed no error of law warranting interference by this Division.

 

Md. Abdul Khaleque Vs. Uttara Bank Limited & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 256.

 

Order 34 Rule-2 & 11

 

Held; the pendente lite interest is in the discretion of the Court which may not grant interest at the contractual rate and reduce it when under the circumstances it is excessive and unfair, but cannot refuse it altogether. In any decree passed in a suit for forclosoure, sale or redemption, where interest is legally recoverable, the Court can  not refuse to allow any pendente lite interest.

 

Uttara Bank Ltd Vs. M/S. Gazi Naziin Uddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 577.

 

Order-39 Rule-l

Counsel's oral agreement

It appears that since there was nothing in writing before the trial Court about the fact that learned engaged Advocate for defendant Nos. 1 and 2 agreed to the passing of the status-quo order on both sides, the defendant Nos. 1 and 2 had legal scope to deny the said fact afterwards, The learned District Judge correctly observed that there was nothing before the Court about the fact that he orally agreed to the passing of status-quo order before the trial Court. Accordingly, the learned District Judge allowed Miscellaneous Appeal setting aside status-quo order dated 01.03.2006 passed by the trial Court.

 

Mozibur Rahman Vs. Al-haj Nazrul Karim & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 189.

 

Order -39 rule -1

In a case where national interest out weighs personal interest/gain or profit or in other words where national loss because of an order of injunction would out weigh the individual loss, the prayer for injunction is certainly merit less. In the instant case the prayer of the plaintiffs for an order of injunction was merit less in the background of national interest, loss to the people of the area out weighed loss, if any, to the plaintiffs and because of absence of prima facie title to the land in suit.

 

Water Development Board, & Anr Vs. Md. Moktaruddin & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 137.

 

Order -39 rule-1 Circular vide Memo No. Committee/30/ Laksmi/ 319 dated 14.5.07 read with circular vide Memo No.ShaSha No./Sha:ll/13(IDA)- 3/2003 11620 dated 13.11.06 issued by the government.

 

It appears from the impugned judgment that the learned District Judge found that the petitioner is a elected chairman of the governing body and the said election held, long after the said circular was published ans as such the said circular is not applicable to the instant case of the petitioner and thus the impugned memo through which the plaintiff was removed and U.N.O. was appointed as a chairman of the Managing Committee is per-se illegal and thus found a prima facie case of the plaintiff and passed an order of injunction in his favour. Considering the aforesaid memo, I found the learned District Judge committed no illegality in passing the impugned order. Since the plaintiff has got a prima facie case the learned District Judge has rightly granted temporary injunction in this favour.

 

Inspector of Schools Vs Nazrul Islam Litton & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 361.

 

Order 39 Rule-1

 

It appears that a partition suit is pending. It further appears that the High Court Division found that the apprehension that the defendant will transfer the suit land to others and will change the nature of character of the suit land is well founded. It appears that the finding of the High Court Division is based on correct appreciation of fact calling for no interference by this Court.

 

Nargis Majid & Ors Vs. Kamol Ram Pashi & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 220.

 

Order 39 Rule 1

 

An abrupt finding by the concerned Judge

 

The sole ground for rejection of the temporary injunction, petitioner appears to be that since 11 members of the Executive Committee out of the 12 including the, plaintiffs resigned from their office, they had no prima-facie and arguable case to get temporary injunction, rather such an order, even if passed, would be in fructuous. It appears that the plaintiffs had strongly denied about tendering resignation by swearing affidavit and they not only filed original suit to get protection of their membership but also filed temporary injunction petition in assertion of their original intention of retaining membership of the Executive Committee. In such a situation, the learned Judge of the Trial Court appears to have passed his sweeping remark in a very undesirable manner and it is certainly unbecoming of a judicial officer. Such a controversial issue of the suit should not have been answered in such a way and made the only basis for rejection of the application for temporary injunction in the manner he passed the impugned judgment and order. The disputed issue regarding the resignation of the plaintiffs from the memberships of the Executive Committee is necessarily a matter to be decided in the suit by taking evidence at the time of holding trial. Due such an abrupt finding by the concerned Judge, the suit of the plaintiffs had become non maintainable and in fructuous, which is not legally acceptable. As we do not find any other ground for rejection of injunction prayer, certainly such an order cannot be given affirmation in this appeal.

 

Md. Anowar Hossain Vs. Divisional Co­operative Office & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 333

 

Order 39 Rule 1

 

Plaintiff-petitioner is the purchaser of the suit property - the balance of convenience and inconvenience

 

Admittedly the respondent No.l purchased the suit property through Court by registered kabala dated 23rd June, 2009 in Artha Rin Execution Case No.340 of 2005 and got delivery of possession through the process of the Court. The High Court Division in the backdrop of the matter held that the plaintiff could not claim any right or interest in the suit property since the disputed property in question was sold in auction in favour of the respondent No.l through the process of the Court before the plaintiff had acquired any right or interest thereon and that the balance of convenience is not in its favour. - To maintain the judgment of the High Court Division.

 

Ayat Steel Ltd. Vs. Mohammad Ali & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 123

 

Order-39 Rule-1

 

Whether in an Urban area a co-sharer should not be restrained by an Order of injunction from making construction at his own risk.

 

Trial Court below on considering the fact's and circumstances of the case granted statuesque -Courts of appeal did not at all advert the findings of the trial Court -Held; On perusal of the materials on record including exparte order dated 13.05.2009 passed by the Mayor, Kabirhat Pourashava and Advocate Commissioner's report as evidenced by "Annexure-D and Annexure-E, I am led to hold that the plaintiff-petitioner having a good prima-facie arguable case and since both the parties are claiming their possession in the suit land the trial Court rightly passed an order directing the parties to maintain status-quo which need to be maintained. The findings of the Court of appeal below in the facts and circumstances are totally unsatisfactory and misconceived inasmuch as the plaintiff-petitioner filed Other Class Suit No.252 of 2009 challenging the exparte order passed by the Kabirhat Pourashava Mayor in Arbitration Case No.02 of 2006 deciding title in favour of the opposite parties during pendency of Title Appeal No.95 of 2010 arising out of 'Partition Suit No. 17 of 1997 in between the self-same parties with regard to the same property. The defendants have placed nothing on record to prima-facie prove that they have actual exclusive physical possession in the suit land. The Court of appeal below ought to have considered all these vital aspects of the case and in not doing so committed an error of law resulting in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice.

 

Nurul Hague Vs. Mohammad Shamsul Hague & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 456.

 

Order 39 Rule-1 read with Section-115 Order of Mandatory injunction

 

Possession is the prime consideration for disposing an application for temporary injunction when the plaintiff filed papers of his purchase of possession of the Suit premises and when the defendants admit giving possession of the office to the plaintiff, the plaintiff is entitled to get an order of temporary injunction. Trial Court erroneously rejected his application on wrong finding that he filed no papers in support of his possession and on misreading the statement of made in their written objection as aforesaid. I, therefore, find no reasons to hold that the Court of Appeal below erred in law in allowing the appeal allowing the application and setting aside the finding of the Trial Court. I also find from the plaint as well as from the application enclosed with the revisional application that the plaintiff clearly and specifically described the unit premises giving measurement and other particulars in both the schedule and there is no ambiguity and vagueness in the schedule of the suit premises. Appellate Court below in consideration of the facts and documents filed before the Trial Court found good prima facie case and balance of convenience and inconvenience in favour of the plaintiff and granted injunction finding that the plaintiff will suffer irreparable loss and injury if the application for injunction is not allowed.

 

Md. Mahfuzul Hague & Anr Vs Sajibul Islam & Anr 17 BLT (HCD) 310.

 

Order XXXIX Rule 1 read with Motor Vehicles Ordinance, 1983 Section 51

 

Plaintiff instituted the suit for a decree of permanent injunction and filed an application for an order of temporary injunction against the defendants - learned trial Court rejected the application and on Miscellaneous Appeal, the learned Appellate Court allowed the said application - The High Court Division held that the defendant-petitioners have no route permit for running the "Maxi Service" in the concerned Highway and section 51 of the Motor Vehicles Ordinance, 1983 clearly prohibits plying of such vehicles on the road without route permit. Accordingly, the High Court Division discharged the Rule -Held; In the circumstances we do not find any cogent reason to interfere with the judgment of the High Court Division.

 

Masud Miah & Ors Vs. Kishorgonj Zila Auto Tempo & Taxi Malik Samity 20 BLT (AD) 73.

 

Order 39 Rule 1 read with Order 43 Rule l(r)

 

An order of Statusquo passed in respect of the suit land without entry First Miscellaneous Appeal

 

In the instant F.M.A.T., upon going through the materials placed that the order dated 02.04.12 was passed mainly on the ground that the suit land was not specified properly rather it was vague but on a perusal of the application for injunction we find that the petitioner has given a full specification of the suit land where he prayed for injunction with boundaries, therefore, in our opinion, ends of justice would be met, if this appeal is disposed of with an appropriate direction without admitting the same with a view to avoid spoiling time unnecessarily. - Pending disposal of the said application the parties are hereby directed to maintain status quo in respect of the suit land.

 

Mst. Salma Khatun Vs. Sayed Hossain & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 398.

 

Order-40 Rule-l

 

Appointment of a receiver in Petition Suit

 

In a suit for partition not merely the interest of the plaintiffs but also the interest of all the parties to the suit need be protected. The power to appoint a receiver as conferred by Order 40, rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, therefore, should, therefore, be sparingly used. The provisions for the appointment of a receiver is to be considered as one of the harshest remedies for the enforcement of rights to property.

 

Most. Umme Shaheda Akhter Rina & Ors Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 180.

 

Order 41 Rule 11

 

Whether the delay reflect the callousness, negligence, slothful manner and indolent attitude in tendering the appeal should not be condoned

 

Court of Wards Bhawal Raj Estate tiled a suit for a declaration of title, with further declaration for delivering possession after removing the stricture irom mere defendants - Defendants filed two application, one, under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejection of the plaint as it is barred by law and another, under Order XIV Rule 2 of the Code for framing issued to that effect. The learned Judge framed issue as to the maintainability of the suit and after hearing both the sides rejected the plaint on the ground of maintainability - Plaintiff filed appeal with Court Fee of more than Tk.40,000/-, out of time of by 191 days-Held; it appears that plaintiff has no subsisting interest in instituting the suit. The impugned Gazette notification was published under Section 3 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act with reference to particular estates, taluks, tenures, holding and tenancies and in respect of all rent receivers whose properties were under the management of court of wards Act, 1878. Sub-Section (2a) was enacted and introduced Section 3 of the Act by Ordinance No.l 11 of 1956. It is after this amendment general notification dated 2nd April, 1956 was issued district wise in regard to all rent receiving interest which thereafter vested in the government with effect from 14.04.56 in terms of those notifications. As such, after 14.04.56 the plaintiff has no right take interest or possession in itself, whatever it has, has under the Government, not of it in any individual from to initiate any proceeding. A title less person has no legal character to initiate any proceeding as such no effective result would be available to the appellant in appeal be admitted on condonation of delay.

 

Court of Wards Bhawal Raj Estate Vs Eastern Housing Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 286.

 

Order-41 Rule-19

 

Whether appeal can be readmitted on setting aside the decree

 

Application for re-admission of appeal under Rule 19 is applicable till decree is not drawn up as the order of dismissal of the appeal till then did not reached its finality but once a decree is drawn up and sealed and signed it can not be re-opened or re­admitted merely on application as it reached its finality.

 

Mohi Ahmed Chow. Vs Kashipur Tea Estate Company Ltd. & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 415.

 

Order-41 Rule-19

 

Non-Payment of C.P. Cost -no scope for restoration of the Appeal

 

It appears that the High Court Division considered that although the learned District Judge extended time the plaintiff petitioner failed repeatedly to deposit cost as directed by him and in that event the learned District Judge rightly dismissed the Miscellaneous Case, in default, of payment of C.P. cost. -We do not find that either the learned District Judge or the High Court Division committed any illegality or error of law in rejecting the prayer of the petitioner.

 

Amena Begum & Amena & Ors Vs. Upazilla/ Thana Nirbahi Officer & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 73.

 

Order-41 Rule-19

 

It is stated in the application that the learned counsel for the appellant could not appear in the court when the appeal was called on for hearing as he left the court premises to see his ailing mother but the court below without considering the sufficient cause and only considering the previous conduct of the appellant rejected the Misc. case. It is well settled that the previous conduct of the appellant maybe reprehensible but the matter (restoration of the appeal) cannot be decided on the ground of mere previous conduct. Whether he was prevented by sufficient cause from appearing when the appeal was called on for hearing will determine the out come of the proceeding under order 41 rule 19 of the Code. On this count the impugned order cannot be sustained. More so the grounds taken in the application for re-admission of the appeal clearly indicate that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause not to appeal-when the matter was called on for hearing.

 

Shaheen Akhter Vs Shakila Amin. & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 76.

 

Order 41 Rule 19

 

Sufficient cause

 

We find that learned Judge dismissed miscellaneous case on the ground that there is wrong mentioning of the date of knowledge whether it was on 28.2.1999 or some other date, as in the body of the application it was written that litigant appellant-petitioners could know on 05.07.1999 and filed application on 10.7.1999. It is true that learned Advocate mistakenly written as 28.2.1999 in place of 5.7.1999. It appears that the application was filed for readmission of the appeal on 10.7.1999. If it is calculated from 28.2.1999 even then it was not so late for which learned Judge deber the litigant from placing their case and also none suited them. It appears from the record of the appeal that before this Court plaintiffs-appellant-petitioners took some step relating for making the appeal ready for hearing and also filed substitution application for the deceased respondent showing their intention for prosecuting the appeal. Considering all these aspects of the case we are of the view that the appeal has merit.

 

Kazi Zahidul Islam & Ors Vs. Mustafa Khan 20 BLT (HCD) 275.

 

Order 41 Rule 19

 

Whether Miscellaneous Case under Order 41 Me 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure arising out of judgment and order passed in Miscellaneous (Pre-emption) Appeal is maintainable

 

Held; On perusal of Order 43 Rule l(t) read with Section   104   of the   Code  of Civil Procedure, I am of the clear view that the instant first miscellaneous  appeal  is  well maintainable.

 

Mst. Nahida Sultana Vs. Md. Bazlur Rahman Khan & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 32.

 

Order 41 Rule 19 read with Civil Rules and Orders

 

Sufficient cause

 

From the order sheet it appears that the appeal was dismissed at 1 p.m. It is settled by the Supreme Court that default order should not be passed at 1 p.m., it ought to be passed at the end of the day, as, it may be I that, for some other reason, litigant may be busy or their Advocates may busy at any other Court. It may be the litigant or learned Advocate may appear before raising of the Court.

 

Kazi Zahidul Islam & Ors Vs. Mustafa Khan 20 BLT (HCD) 275.

 

Order 41 rule 21

 

Notice of transfer was not served

 

Appeal was transferred to the Court of the Joint District Judge for disposal. Notice of transfer of the appeal was not served upon the plaintiff-respondent or upon his Counsel - Held; Learned Judge did not at all satisfies as to whether notice of transfer of the appeal to his Court was served upon the plaintiff or upon the learned Advocate for the respondents. Judge who hurried in disposing of cases are not sound in mind. Justice hurried Justice buried. It is to be borne in mind court is to render Justice and that too, not only done but act impartially so that it can be shown so that trust, faith and believe of the litigant may not be disturbed – appeal allowed.

 

Sorekha Begum Vs. AH Ahmed & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 546.

 

Order -41 Rule-23

 

Learned Appellate Court in his judgment made observation and remark that contesting defendant no.2 Momtaz Uddin in spite of getting original kabala of his vendor Samchia from her, he (defendant no.2) did not produce said original kabala dated 10.5.68 in Trial Court to be marked Ext, rather defendant no.2 produced C.C of said kabala dated 10.5.68 in the Trial Court and the same was marked Ext. cha. Due to above anomaly such as non tendering in evidence of defendant no.3 to be marked C.C of the death certificate of Birbol although it was filed by firisti on 10.11.96 in O.C suit no. 197/94 and n on producing of original kabala dated 10.5.68 in Court at the final hearing by defendant no. 2 to be marked Ext. learned Appellate Court clearly observed that those documents as pointed above must be produced at the Trial Court giving chance to the contesting parties for cross examination to establish the truth of exact date of death of Birbol as well as to establish the truth and genuineness of kabala dated 10.5.68 and accordingly learned Appellate Court set aside judgment of Trial Court by allowing the appeal and sent the suit on remand to the Trial Court for proper decision according to law Learned Appellate Court rightly observed that Trial Court would be the competent forum for further evidence as above on the disputed points for appropriate legal and correct decision -This Court is of the view that Trial Court will be more competent to do procedural modified in above regard. Having considered above facts and circumstances this Court does not see any merit in the Rule which must fail.

 

Md. Momtaz Uddin Vs Sreernoti Bimala Rani Roy & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 01.

 

Order-41 Rule-23

 

Not a fit case for remand

 

Since the plaintiffs by adducing cogent and reliable evidence could establish their prima facie title and possession in the suit land, the learned Judge of the trial Court rightly and legally decreed the suit. The defendant No.l after closer of evidence of the plaintiffs did not adduce either oral or documentary evidence but participated in the hearing of argument. As the defendant No.l was negligent in proceeding with the suit diligently he should not be allowed to adduce evidence after delivery of the judgment and decree passed by the trial Court inasmuch as that will give him an indulgence to fill up the lacuna.

 

Azam All & Anr Vs Akram AH & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 273.

 

Order 41 rule 23

 

In the instant case partnership business is admitted and in view of the provision of section 69 and sub-section 3(a) of the Partnership Act the present suit for dissolution of partnership is maintainable as conceded by the learned Advocate of the defendant-appellants relying on the decision reported in 7 PLR Dacca, Page-23. On the other hand learned Advocate of the plaintiff respondent has also conceded that a proper accounting as per provision of Order XX rule 15 of the Code of Civil Procedure is required to be prepared - We send the case back on remand to the trial Court to pass a preliminary decree on the basis of the evidence available on the record in the light of the provision of Order xx, rule 15 of the Code of Civil Procedure determining the date on which the partnership shall stand dissolve or deem to be dissolved and thereafter by appointing an accountant knowing person, preferably an agreed person by the parties, direct to prepare accounts and on the basis of such accounts final decree be passed.

 

Tushar Kanti Bhattacharjee & Anr Vs Bijoy Lal Karmaker 19 BLT (HCD) 310.

 

Order -41 Rule-23

 

The defendant-appellant got ample opportunity to adduce evidence before both the Courts below and since the deeds of the plaintiffs were proved' in accordance with law and both the Courts below after detail discussions of the entire evidence on record decreed the suit and when evidence on all material points are there on record, it would not be justified sitting under reivisional jurisdiction to send the suit back on remand to have the, genuineness of the said deeds proved in accordance with law. -Held; In view of the long line of judicial decision is to the effect that the remand order should be avoided as far as possible, we are unable to accept the submission of the learned Deputy Attorney General that to send back the case on remand to the trial Court below for fresh trial since both oral and documentary evidence having been available on record to decide the case on merit.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs Syed Rashid Ahmed Ehsan & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 162.

 

Order-41 Rule-23

 

Since the revisional application has not been disposed of on merits it appears to me that justice will be met if the case is send back on remand to the revisional court to dispose of the revisional application on merits.

 

Md. Aminul Haque Vs. Md. Abdul Quddus Mollah & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 422.

 

Order-41 Rule-23 read with Civil Rules and Oeder

 

Rule-774(8)

 

The High Court Division held that there is a gross illegality for not registering the petition filed by the appellant under Order XXI rule 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure as Miscellaneous Judicial Case as per rule 774(8) of the Civil Rules and Order and thus, the impugned order complained of is not sustainable in law. But the High Court Division found no other alternative but to send the case back on remand to the executing Court for removing the illegalities and to register the petition filed by the appellant bank under Order XXI rule 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure as a Miscellaneous Judicial Case and to give opportunity to the opposite party to file written objection, if any and after hearing both the parties to dispose of the same in accordance with law -The petition is dismissed.

 

Jan-E-Alam Vs. Rupali Bank Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 80.

 

Order 41 Rule-27

 

Held; we noticed that the plaintiffs had filed the deed of endowment in course of trial of the suit but they did not mark it as exhibit. In this Court they filed an application for recording additional evidence for exhibiting the deed of endowment. We have allowed the prayer and marked it as ext. 3.

 

Paresh Chandra Biswas Vs. Sree Sree Shmashan Kalimata Idol &Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 474.

 

Order 41 Rule 27

 

Whether in Civil Revision an application under Order 41 Rule 27 is maintainable.

 

Held; It is stated in the application that father of this applicant late Rafiqul Hoque as defendant witness No.l made his deposition before the trial court and at the time he handed over the rent receipts of Khatian No.64 to his learned Advocate for submitting in the court but the learned Advocate inadvertently did not submit the documents in the court for which the rent receipts has not been marked as Exhibits in the case record. It is stated in the application that the learned Advocate inadvertently did not submit the rent receipts in the trial court but it appears that the defendant-petitioners did not take any step to file the rent receipts in the appellate court below though they had ample opportunity to produce the same before the appellate court below. The provisions of order 41 rule 27 are clearly not intended to allow a litigant who has been unsuccessful in the lower court to patch up the weak parts of his case and fill up the omissions in the revisional court and as such the application for additional evidence is not necessary at this point of time to pronounce judgment.

 

Most. Rafida Bewa Vs. Md. Abdul Gani & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 407.

 

Order-41 Rule-27 read with Order 18 Rule-17

 

Additional evidence by recalling PW  in appeal

 

There is no materials to show that the plaintiffs had ever approached to the trial Court for admitting the plaint of pre­emption case in evidence and the same was refused by the trial Court. So, in view of the Provisions laid down in Order XLI Rule 27 of the Code of Civil Procedure, that document cannot be admitted in evidence by re-calling P.W.I.

 

Mvi. Abdul Khair Mollah & Ors Vs Golafernessa & Ors 17 BLT  (HCD) 571.

 

Order -41 Rule -31

 

Finding based on facts It appears from the exhibit-2 that after the death of Balaram a succession case was filed in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Kishoregonj and the plaintiff claimed the ownership that whatever was earned by Balarma was earned from the income of joint family. This document esxhibit-2 is supported by the application of compromise. Both the P.W.'s 2 and 3 are signatories to the exhibit-3. They testified in support of the settlement of the dispute between the plaintiff and the defenciants. It also appears that the trial Court believed exhibit Nos. 1- 2 and deposition of the witnesses and came to •a finding that both late Balaram and Krishna Bank were in joint mess and their property was never partitioned and Balaram was the Karta of the family and the share of Modan was purchased by both brothers by exhibit-'Ka' out of the income of the joint property. These findings of the trial Court are based on evidence and cxhibit-2, exhibit-'Ka', 'Kha, and 'Kha(l). The High Court Division as well on consideration of the material evidence including the Exhibits concurred with the finding of the trial Court.

 

Ujjal Rani Banik & Ors Vs. Sree Krishna Chandra Banik & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 303.

 

Order 41 Rule 31

 

Proper Judgment of reversal

 

It is apparent from the evidence on record that the alleged deed of gift dated 16.01.1917 was not marked and exhibited in the suit. Father more, the learned Subordinate Judge, as a last Court of fact recorded his suspicion relating to existence of the original deed of gift and even after assessing photocopy of the said deed of gift arrived at a finding that the photocopy is manufactured for the purpose of the suit. If the deed of gift is not proved, then question of ROR in the name of the predecessor of the defendant does not arise. -On perusal of both the judgment passed by the trial Court as well as the appellate Court below it appears that the Court of appeal below after assessing the evidence on record independently reversed the judgment and decree passed by the trial Court in compliance of Order 41 Rule 31 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Nidhuram Mondal Vs. Sumitra Mondal & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 31.

 

Order-41 Rule-31

 

Defendants have admitted the banks liability -Suit for sale of the mortgaged property in the event of defendant's failure to repay the decreetal amount.

 

Section 58(f) of the Transfer of Property Act was amended with effect from 26 March, 1971 by the Bangladesh Law (Revision and Declaration Act, 1973 and in section 58(f), the towns of Dhaka, Narayangonj and j Chittagong have been added. The position stands now is that the provision for equitable i mortgage by depositing title deeds had been made applicable at Dhaka and Narayangonj with effect from March, 1971 and before that date there was no provision of equitable mortgage by deposit of title deeds. The transaction between the plaintiff and the defendant No.l was entered in 1968, when there was no provision for creating equitable mortgage of lands in Dhaka district.

 

Agrani Bank Ltd. Vs Habib Oil Mills (Bangladesh) Limited & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 01.

 

Order 41 Rule 31

 

Order 41   Rule 31   of the Code of Civil Procedure is a mandatory provision of law to be followed by the appellate court, in this regard, which mandates that in the event of reversal of the judgment by the appellate court in that case it is incumbent upon the appellate court to arrive at a finding upon proper assessment and evaluation of the evidence on record and then advert to the findings of the trial Court and in the absence of proper assessment and evaluation of the evidence on record mere reversal of the finding of fact will not do. The reversal of the finding of facts on the basis of proper assessment and evaluation of the evidence on record while reversing the judgment of the trial court, is the mandate of Order 41 Rule 31 of the Code of Civil Procedure which must be followed by the appellate court which is the last court of fact.

 

Ganendra Nath Mondal Vs. Kalipada Mondal &Anr. 19 BLT (HCD) 424.

 

Order-41 Rule-31

On assessment of the entire materials on record we find nothing wrong on the part of the defendant-appellant inasmuch as who after death of his wife Monowara Begum as legal successor applied for pension benefit of her deceased wife and thereupon, the concerned authority of the Government after thorough scrutiny over the matter allowed the defendant appellant to withdraw the pension benefit of her deceased wife -Appeal must succeed.

 

G. M. Abu Hena Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 616.

 

Order 41 Rule 31

 

It appears that no issue has been framed regarding exchange of land as per pleadings of the defendants by the learned trial Court as well as appellate Court below -the appellate court below without discussing the

case of the plaintiff allowed the appeal based on the defendants case and deposition of D.Ws. In nowhere of the judgment passed by the appellate court below arrived at a finding whether the plaintiff has been able to prove his case. Without framing an issue the appellate court below made a general point for determination whether the judgment and decree under appeal is sustainable or not. The appellate Court below though arrived at a findings that the suit of the plaintiff succeeds but did not assign any reason how the plaintiff succeed to prove his case without discussing their case and perusing evidence produced by the plaintiff. Under the facts and circumstances of the case I am of the opinion that the learned Subordinate Judge passed the impugned judgment and decree without following the provisions of order 41 rule 31 of the Code of Civil Procedure and as such has committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice in passing the impugned judgment and decree.

 

Md. Samsur Rahman & Ors Vs. Md. Sukur All Khan & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 388.

 

Order 41 Rule 31 read with Specific Relief Act, 1877; Section -42 read with Evidence Act, 1872

Section -102

 

Judgment of affirmence - onus of proof

 

The plaintiff appellant instituted the suit for a declaration that the deed of lease executed between the parties was a void and fraudulent document and not binding upon the plaintiff on the assertion that the aforesaid deed has been executed not on the basis of original draft agreed upon between the parties and some clauses of the previously agreed draft being altered, the deed has been registered and thus fraud has been practiced - Held; it appears that the draft agreement purported to have been made has not been produced before any courts. The plaintiff further asserted that after the fraud was detected the plaintiff called the defendant respondent and after discussion with the consent of the defendant a "(MWra Tifsffi" was made but the said "CSTW113 Tffi^T" was also not produced before any court.
