Further more, it appears that the plaintiff cancelled the lease and did not deliver the possession of the land in favour of the defendant. In such view of the matter we are unable to understand what prompted the plaintiff to file the suit for cancellation of the deed of lease on the face of "c^Ntt^ra T^R" between the parties - we do not find any substance in this appeal.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh Vs. Mega Fisheries Ltd, Dhaka 20 BLT (AD) 25.

 

Order 41, Rule 31 read with Specific Relief Act, 1877; Section - 42

 

Held; In the instant case, learned Joint District Judge decreed the suit in part on a gratuitous finding to the effect that the plaintiffs have acquired title over the suit land on the basis of adverse possession. Adverse possession was neither pleaded nor any evidence was lend by the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs have made a prayer to have a declaration of their title in the suit land by virtue of purchase deeds but adverse possession was neither pleaded nor proved, therefore, findings arrived at by the trial court is no doubt a gratuitous, one which is not at all sustainable in law.

 

Nazir Ahmed & Ors Vs. Md. Fajal Ahmed & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 118.

 

Order-43 Rule-I(r)

 

Whether Appellate Court had any scope to consider the merit of the original suit in miscellaneous appeal arising out of an order whereby rejected the prayer for temporary injunction

 

Held; The subject matter of the miscellaneous appeal was whether the learned Assistant Judge was justified in rejecting the prayer for temporary injunction in original title suit -the Appellate court below had no any scope to consider the merit of that suit which was not the subject matter of the miscellaneous appeal placed before him.

 

Putul Biswas -Vs- Krishnapada Mondal & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 564.

 

Order 43 Rule l(r) read with Order 39 Rule 1

Locus-standi

 

Admittedly, the plaintiffs were elected members of the concerned Executive Committee for a term of 3 years and in order to protect their right as elected members of the said Executive Committee they had filed the suit. Ultimately they obtained the rule 1 and injunction order after filling the instant First Misc. Appeal and continued to work as elected members of the Executive Committee till today, though their tenure in office of the Executive Committee had already been expired on 7.8.11. The plaintiffs also prayed for protection of their right by filling temporary injunction petition. But after expiry of the tenure of the office they cannot have any locus-standi to continue as members of the Executive Committee and as such neither they are in a position to maintain the original suit for declaration nor the instant First Misc. Appeal and connected Rule. It is therefore, immaterial to adjudicate as to whether the plaintiffs had tendered resignation or any such resignation letter was obtained by force by or by resorting forgery as alleged by the plaintiffs.

 

Md. Anowar Hossain Vs. Divisional Co­operative Office & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 333

 

Order - 47 Rule -1

 

The questions of genuineness of the decree

 

The application for review was not legally well conceived one since the facts alleging which review was sought were very much, in the background of the averments made about those facts in the written statement of the respondent filed in Title Suit No.634 of 1970, within the knowledge of the respondent. It also may be mentioned that there was specific plea in the written statement Sreenath Chatterjee died on July 24, 1947 but the respondent did not take any step to establish the said fact. From the averments made in the written statement it is seen that the respondent was in possession of the materials in support of alleged death of Sreenath Chatterjee on July 24, 1947 and in that view of the matter for re-agitating the said fact upon resorting to review was not legally competent. The contention, as stated hereinbefore, upon making which leave was obtained, in our view, in the background of the materials on record appears to be of merit, primarily question of genuineness of the decree obtained in Title Suit No. 198 of 1970 was not an issue in Title Suit No.634 of 1970 out of which Title Appeal No. 166 of 1973 arose, second issue as to genuineness of the decree in Title Suit No. 198 of 1970 could only be the subject matter of a suit seeking declaration about the said decree i.e. decree in Title Suit No. 198 of 1970 and in no way can be the matter for adjudication within the scope of Title Suit No.634 of 1970 as framed and the review as sought. We have already mentioned herein before that the ground upon which review was sought as in no way conform to the requirement of the provision of law as in Order 47 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure for maintaining an application for review or entitling a person to seek review against a decree, the order of the High Court Division affirming the order of the appellate Court passed in Miscellaneous Case No.5 of 1980 allowing the application filed seeking review for re-hearing of the appeal was not maintainable.

 

 

Shahjada Hossain Mallik & Ors Vs. Assistant Custodian of E.P.  20 BLT (AD) 242

 

Order 47 Rule 1

 

New ground - without registered as Civil Review - there is no specific date mentioned in the application for addition of party when the Ad-hoq Committee was formed.

 

Held; On going through the application it appears that it is admitted that no date was mentioned in the earlier application under Order 1 Rule 10(2) of the Code as to the formation of ad-hoq Committee. Now the applicant filed the instant review application annexing a memo issued by Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Board on 2.3.2011 for formation of Ad-hoq Committee of the School namely The order dated 8.10.2012 is recalled. The application for addition of party under Order 1 Rule 10(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure is allowed.

 

Md. Hazrat Ali Vs. Chairman, Education Board Dhaka & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 566

 

Order 47 Rule 1

 

Whether the Court re-consider its earlier interlocutory order - similar prayer which was rejected earlier, against which, did not file any revision

 

We are of the view that this will not debar the plaintiff from renewing the prayer since the earlier order being an interlocutory order, the question of res-judicata normally does not arise, since the Court may reconsider its earlier interlocutory order on new facts if a proper application is filed. Accordingly, we treat the second application of the plaintiff as one of reviewing its earlier order rejecting his prayer for examination of the disputed thumb impression by expert.

 

Kabir Ahmed Vs. Korban AH & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 130.

 

Code of Civil Procedure (Amendment) Ordinance, 1983

 

Section 6 read with General Clauses Act, 1879 Section 6

 

Whether the Additional District Judge was justified in disposing the Civil Revision after repeal of Section 115(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure by the Ordinance, 1983.

 

In the instant case trial Court dismissed the suit by the judgment and decree dated 25.6.1980 and since the suit was for recovery of possession of the suit land under section 9 of the Specific Relief Act, the decree passed in the suit was not appeallable but revisable under amended section 115(2) of the Code by the District Judge - Section 115 of the Code was amended by Law Reforms Ordinance, 1978 (Ordinance No. XLIX of 1978) published on 5.12.1978 and came into force on 1.6.1979 by S.R.O. 113-L/79/3 "0"-30/79-Law/252 dated 25.4.1979. -During pendency of the said Civil Revision section 115 of the Code was again amended by the Code of Civil Procedure (Amendment) Ordinance, 1983 (Ordinance No.XLVIII of 1983) published on 5.9.1983. By section 4(b) of the Ordinance, sub-section (2) and (3) of section 115 was omitted. Thereby the rivisional jurisdiction of the District Judge was withdrawn on and from 5.9.1983 -From section 4(b) of the Ordinance, 1983 it appears that sub-section (2) and (3) of section 115 of the Code was repealed /omitted. Section 6 of the said Ordinance provides that the pending proceedings shall be continued and disposed of as if the Ordinance, 1983 had not come into force, besides saving clause provided in section 6 of the Ordinance, 1983, section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1879 also protects the aforementioned civil revision in its continuation and disposal by the Additional District Judge under the repealed section 115(2) of the Code as if the same was not repealed.

 

Nannu Mia Vs. Mohan Basi Bhoumik & Ors. 18 BLT (HCD) 36.

1493

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Part-I)

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 206, 18 BLT (AD )277, 21 BLT (HCD) 51, 21 BLT (HCD) 107, 21 BLT (HCD ) 376, 18 BLT (AD) 501, 19 BLT (HCD) 244, 19 BLT (HCD) 363, 19 BLT (HCD) 474, Anr 20 BLT(HCD) 440 , 21 BLT (HCD) 76, 21 BLT (HCD) 03, 19 BLT (AD) 119, 19 BLT (HCD) 602, 18

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Code of Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

 

Section 2(2) Rejection of plaint under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure comes within the definition of 'decree'

 

The learned Joint District Judge (trial Court) allowing the defendant's application under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure on the finding that suit is barred by law of res-judicata - the Revisional Court below appears to have committed illegality in entertaining the Revisional application under Section 115(2) Code of Civil Procedure against the order of rejection of plaint inasmuch as order of rejection of plaint is appealable.

 

Anarul Islam Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 206.

 

Section-9

 

Jurisdiction in the Civil Court In view of the findings of the High Court Division that the legality of the certificate proceeding settled in a revenue forum cannot be agitated before the Civil Court, is a correct   finding which calls for no interference by this Court.

 

Altaf Sarder & Ors Vs. Md. Mobarak Ali Gazi & Ors 18 BLT (AD )277.

 

Section – 9

 

Whether suit is maintainable as per Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act  since the plaintiffs admittedly took part in the illegal strike and were involved in the trade union activities they were sacked legally by the appropriate competent authority on compliance of all legal formalities. - Maintainability.

 

As regard the maintainability of the suit in its present form under the ambit of Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 it is concurrently observed by both the Courts that the suit is maintainable and the Civil Court have got every legal authority and jurisdiction to try the suit and that it was not barred by any law.

 

Md. Mosharraf Alt Khan Vs. A.G.M Sonali Bank, & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 51.

 

Section – 9: The law is that if any body is dissatisfied with the decision of the allotment committee of Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industrial Corporation, he can file appeal before the Chairman of BSCIC -Jurisdiction of the Civil Court

 

It is the case of the plaintiff that allotment letter of the plaintiff was cancelled whimsically, capriciously without giving any notice to the plaintiff. But, law is otherwise, if any allotment be cancelled even illegally then the allottee under the lease deed has remedy in appeal - We are of the view that plaintiff got the allotment letter from defendant Nos.1-3 as per the terms and conditions which totally debar plaintiff to institute of file any suit.

 

Noor Jahan Begum Vs. Bd. Small & Cottage Ind. Corp. & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 107

 

Section-9: Suit being filed on behalf of alien citizen

 

Held; Neither the executants nor any attesting witness appears to prove exhibit-6 power of attorney infact such power of Attorney exhibit-6 has no validity in the eye of law - It appears that both the courts below rightly held that the suit property was never in the management of Evacuee on management committee as under East Bengal Evacuee (Administration of Immovable property) Act 1951 and the suit being filed by so-called Attorney on behalf of alien citizens is not maintainable and the so called Attorney has no locus-standi to file the instant suit.

 

Sree Haripada Das & Ors Vs Md. Fazlul Hoque Mridha & Ors 21 BLT (HCD ) 376.

 

Section-9 read with Building Construction Act, 1952 Section-14 read with Town Improvement Act, 1953; Section-169

 

Ouster of Jurisdiction of the Civil Court The plaintiff appellant instituted Title Suit No.99 of 1999 for declaration that the suit property is his personal property and that the suit property is not a play ground or an open field or a water reservior/river and also for declaring memo dated 06.04.1999 issued by the defendant No. 1 Rajdhani Unnayan Katripakhya in short RAJUK as illegal, without jurisdiction and not binding upon the plaintiff. -Held; This Act has provided an ouster of jurisdiction of the Civil Court under the provision of Section 14 of the Building Construction Act, which is bar to maintain any suit against the order passed by RAJUK under the Act providing provision for an appeal therein. In the instant case the appellant has not availed the said provision of appeal instead filed the suit which is not maintainable as the special provision provides a special remedy for the purpose and the person being the satisfied with any order of RAJUK could prefer appeal in the special forum for the purpose.

 

Shahabuddin Chisti Vs. RAJUK & Anr 18 BLT (AD) 501.

 

Section 9 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 Section 6 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003; Section 20: Whether the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain a suit challenging the judgment and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat

 

The instant suit was filed by the opposite party No.l as plaintiff, prayed for two fold declaration first is that the exparte decree obtained in Title Suit No.54 of 1998 is not binding upon him and a declaration that the registered Power of Attorney and Memo of Deposit of Title Deeds were forged, fabricated and false ones. - Held; Majority view Mr. Sheikh Abdul Awal, J. delivering the majority judgment and Mr. Nozrul Islam Chowdhury, J. concurring with him.

 

Per Mr. Sheikh Abdul Awal, J : Except the provisions of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, no question shall be raised before any court or authority about any pending proceeding in the Artha Rin Adalat, or its order, judgment or decree, and if any relief is claimed or prayer before any Court or authority ignoring the provisions of this Act, no Court or authority shall accept any such prayer, the judgment or decree of the Artha Rin Adalat is final and the same cannot be questioned in any other Court under any separate proceeding. - Therefore, I am led to hold that the suit filed by the plaintiff-opposite party No.l challenging the judgment and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat and some mortgaged deeds as produced/ used in the suit before the Artha Rin Adalat was impliedly barred by specific provisions of both old and new Artha Rin Adalat Ain. So, the suit is not maintainable.

 

Per Mr. Nozrul Islam Chowdhury, J : Section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 or for that matter Section 20 of the Ain, 2003 create a bar in proceeding with a subsequent suit making a prayer for setting aside an ex-parte decree even on the ground of fraud or. even with a prayer for another declaration for the Power of Attorney and Memorandum of Deposit of Title Documents as forged, fabricated and false rather the only remedy available for the opposite party No.l was to go for an application under Order IX Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure or an appeal under Section 7 or Section 41 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and 2003 respectively, therefore, I find that the submissions made by the learned Advocate for the petitioner has got substance, as such accepted. Minority view.

 

Per Mr. M. Moazzam Husain, J: In the instant suit, in particular, no less an issue than one involving allegation of making the plaintiff a third party mortgagor by fraud and forgery has to be tried which, if proved, would render the decree against him a nullity and no decree in the eye of law. The issues cannot be decided except on evidence taken in a full fledged trial before a competent civil court. Since law does not intend any person to suffer for no fault of himself the opposite party No.l cannot be made to suffer the stringent conditions and procedure of special statute, even if available, for no fault of him and his property be taken away as is sought to be done by a decree of the Adalat. It follows, therefore, that the suit filed by the opposite party No.l is fairly maintainable.

 

Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd. Vs Md. Salauddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 244.

 

Section 9 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain,2003 Section 18(3)

 

The person who is not a borrower or one not in any way concerned with the same as mortgagor or guarantor is not contemplated in the special statute to be sued for loan or if once sued by accident or design shall be precluded from protecting his property under the ordinary law of the land by reason merely of the ouster clause provided in the statute. This is a proposition that can hardly, if ever, be conceived as is intended by the law makers while enacting the legislation. -The Artha Rin Adalat is a court of limited jurisdiction created for the particular purposes of speedy trial of the suits involving loan granted by the financial institutions. This is not a full fledged civil court competent to try all the intricate issues of civil nature. The present and many other collateral issues may arise from a loan transaction against which remedy lies only in the civil court.

 

Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd.Vs Md. Salauddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 244.

 

Section-9 read with (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948 Section-14A

 

On a plain reading of Provision contained in Section 14A of The Act of 1948 it is manifestly clear that Civil Court shall not entertain any Suit or application against any Order passed or any action taken under the Act and all Suits and Appeals pending in any such Court against any order passed or any action taken under the Act shall abate with effect from coming into force of (Emergency) Requisition of Property (Amendment) Ordinance, 1963. Since Plaintiff-Opposite Party No.l did not challenge any order passed or any action taken under The Act of i948. Plaintiff filed the Suit for Decree of Permanent Injunction under Section 54 of The Specific Relief Act. The Plea taken from the side of Defendant-Petitioner that the Suit is hit under Section 14A of The Act of J948 is not tenable in law, and, as such, the plea stand rejected. In this context it can be conveniently said that even if Jurisdiction of Civil Court is excluded, still Civil Court got the Jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provision of The Act have not been complied with or the Statutory Tribunal has not acted in conformity with Fundamental Principles of Judicial Procedure.

 

Bangladesh Railway Vs. Md. Sujaruddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 363.

 

Section-9 read with Religious Endowment Act, 1863 (As Amendment Act XXI of 1925) Section-14 and 15: Whether an interested person or a worshipper can maintain a suit for protecting the deity's property

 

Section 14 lays down an important provision under which any person interested in the religious establishment may institute suit against the trustees for any misfeasance and empowers the Court to direct specific performance of act or remove the trustee. The nature of the interest entitling a person to institute such suit is described in section 15. It need not be a pecuniary or immediate interest or such an interest as would entitle the person receiving it to take part in the management. Any person having a right of attendance or partaking in the benefit of any distribution of along shall be a person interested within the meaning of the section. Under section 18 such suits could be instituted only after obtaining leave from the court. Section 18 further provides that if the Court is satisfied that the suit has been for the benefit of the trust and no party to the suit was to blame, it may direct the whole or any portion of the costs to be paid. Section 14 creates- a special jurisdiction in civil courts for the puipose of deciding matters relating to republic religious trusts and to that extent the jurisdiction is exclusive.

 

Paresh Chandra Biswas Vs. Sree Sree Shmashan Kalimata Idol & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 474.

 

Section 9 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (As amended by P.O. No.88 of 1972)

Section 95A

 

Held; Once mortgaged, it shall always be deemed to be a mortgage. So, the doctrine of past and closed transactions are not applicable after insertion of the definition of "complete usufructuary mortgage" in the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. It further be noted here that in the present case, both the Courts below considered the event of the present case as a sale without considering the exact legal proposition of laws as quoted and discussed hereinabove, for which, they came to a wrong decision, and as such, erred in law. The defendant respondent opposite party earlier filed the suit for declaration that the order passed by the then Sub Divisional Officer is null and void; and with regard to permanent injunction but it transpires from the facts and laws as discussed above that legality and propriety of any order passed by Sub Division Officer is not amenable under section 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, as after the expiry of 7(seven) years the property mortgaged in question deemed to be realized automatically, and as such, the proceeding started by the Sub Divisional officer not to determine the validity of law or mortgage but it was, in fact for only to pass necessary order. If the mortgagee failed or refused to hand over the possession of the property, if, not, handed over in the meantime, and in that case, the Sub Divisional Officer is authorized to pass order for redemption and also to hand over the possession of the property to the mortgagor.

 

Jagadish Chandra Bose & Ors Vs. Ajnacharan Biswas & Anr 20 BLT(HCD) 440 Section - 9 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 Section 147(c)

 

In the instant case, plaintiffs filed the suit showing cause of action as :- "The cause of action for the suit on 25.05.2004, 13.07.2005 and 26.12.2005 as the plaintiff did not get justified order in their favour before A/C land Kotwali, A.D.C. (Rev.) Dhaka and Additional Divisional Commissioner, Dhaka respectively which still exists in Mouza Wari under Police Station Sutrapur, District Dhaka, which is the jurisdiction of this learned Court." - Held; It appears that suit was filed without exhausting the procedure as laid down in Section 147(c), as such the suit is not maintainable.

 

Md. Faizur Rahman & Anr Vs. Halima Khatun & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 76.

 

Section - 9 read with Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article - 135(2)(iii) read with Government Servant (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1976 Rule 22: Jurisdiction - In the instant case, the plaintiff instituted a Title Suit being No.455 of 1978 for declaration that the order dated 12.04.1978 passed by the defendant No.l vide Memo No.74-ll/4D-l/77 dated 12.04.1978 is illegal, without jurisdiction, ineffective and not binding upon the plaintiff and also for a direction to the defendant to reinstate the plaintiff in his service and post with all arrear salaries, seniority, facilities and benefit in accordance with law. - It is the positive case of the plaintiff that he was neither given any show cause notice nor any opportunity of being heard in person.

 

Held; the termination order vide 'exhibit-11' was not given in the interest of the security of the State. Therefore, Article 135 Sub-Article (2) (iii) of the Constitution of Bangladesh do not attract the case of the plaintiff-petitioner and it is not the case of the Government that the plaintiff did any act which could be a threat for the security of the State or could be a threat for discipline or that the plaintiff did any act subversive of the State.

 

Jnanendra Nath Barai Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 03.

 

Section-11: Whether the suit was barred by Principle of resjudicata in view of the exparte decree in previous suit.

 

The suit was filed seeking declaration that the ex-parte decree dated 28.11.1981 obtained in Title Suit No.860 of 1981 was void, collusive and fraudulent and that the plaintiff of the said suit i.e. defendant in the instant suit (Title Suit No.22 of 1987) had no right, title and interest in the land of the said suit i.e. Title Suit No.860 of 1981 -the defendant in the previous suit had no knowledge about the ex-parte decree and that appellants came to know about the ex-parte decree in 1983 and thereupon filed Miscellaneous Case No.26 of 1983 but the same was dismissed on 28.3.1984. Thereafter the appellants filed the Title Suit No.22 of 1987 —The other ground on which leave was obtained was that the High Court Division was in error in holding that the Title Suit No.22 of 1987 was barred on the ground of principle of res-judicata in view of the exparte decree in the Title Suit No.860 of 1981 appears to be not well conceived one in that so long the ex-parte decree is not set aside the same being remaining the legal one the subsequent suit between the same parties, in respect of the matter which was the subject matter of the previous suit, may not be the position of the parties in the later suit similar to the earlier suit relating to the subject matter of the previous suit and as to which a competent Court has passed the decree, the later suit is certainly barred by the principle of res­judicata.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Osimuddin 19 BLT (AD) 119.

 

Section 15 read with Order 37 Rule 1: Whether Joint District Judge is competent to try the case contained in Order XXXVII Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Learned Joint District Judge allowed the application under Order 37 Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure in money suit -Held; Order XXXVII is under heading 'Summary Procedure on Negotiable Instruments' and Rule 1 is 'This order shall apply to the High Court Division and to the District Court.' Scheme of this order is summary and departure from the procedure provided for ordinary suit. Although High Court Division and District Court are competent to try suits on negotiable instrument through summary procedure but as per provision of Section 15 of the Code of Civil Procedure the plaint is to be presented before the court of lower jurisdiction. The order passed by learned Joint District Judge is therefore suffers from lack of jurisdiction and not maintainable or sustainable in law.

 

Mrs. Aleya Begum Vs. Allegiance Consortium Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 602.

 

Section-20 Appropriate court having jurisdiction

 

Section-20 C.P.C. provides the Provisions for institution of the suit, it clearly specified that where a person has a permanent dwelling at one place and also a temporary residence at another place, he shall be deemed to reside at both places in respect of any cause of action arising at the place where he has such temporary residence and a Corporation shall be deemed to carry on business at its sole or principal office in Bangladesh or, in respect of any cause of action arising at any place where it has also a subordinate office, at such place. It is pertinent to point out that plaintiff instituted the suit showing his permanent address in Rajshahi and defendant business concern is also extended to Rajshahi which is within the local limits of District Judgeship of Rajshahi. So, institution of suit in the Sadar Court of Assistant Judge, Rajshahi, is competent.

 

Jesmin Ara Vs Md. Abdul Karim 18 BLT (HCD) 255.

 

Section -20 clauses (a) and (b) read with explanation- II

 

The appellant in his suit filed in the 5th Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhaka impugned the proceedings of the suit decreed by the Court at Rangpur and also the proceedings of the execution case was taken out -on the basis of the aforesaid decree in the Court at Rangpur and the property of the appellant was put into auction sale located at Rangpur and was purchased by the Respondent No.3 who resides at Rangpur. In such a situation we are of the view the appellant taking recourse to the provision of section 20 (a) CPC read with Explanation II to said section is not competent to file the suit in Dhaka, which is in fact the off-shoot of the suit which was decreed at Rangpur, since for the purpose of establishing that the decree in Artha Rin Adalat Case No.55 of 1990 was legally passed and that execution case taken out on the basis of the decree obtained in the Artha Rin Adalat Case and that property of the appellant sold in the execution case were legally done are to be established by the Respondent No.2 through the evidence, both oral and documentary, from Rangpur. So considering the convenience of the Respondent No.2 in a situation like the instant one we are of the view the appellant is not competent to file the suit as filed in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhaka impleading the Respondent No.l whose Head Office is at Dhaka and carries on business through its branches in Rangpur and other places -relied on AIR 1992 SC 1514

 

Md. Habibur Rahman Vs. M/s Uttara Bank Ltd. & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 170.

 

Section-24

 

It transpires that nature of both the suits are identical. The conflict arose between plaintiff and defendant who are mother and sons respectively over execution of heba deeds. The petitioner is defendant in both the suits and opposite party no.l is the plaintiff. It further transpires that conflict erupted between mother and son over self same plots, only difference is the quantum of land. So, in my view to avoid conflicting decision both the suits should be tried simultaneously. With that end in view, suits of this nature may be transferred. Evidence should be taken separately and each suit should be disposed of by separate judgment by the same court.

 

Golam Haider Chowdhury Vs Amena Begum & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 238

 

Section-24 The ground for transfer: To sum up the grounds for transfer are:

 

(i)                 Reasonable apprehension in the mind of the litigant that he may not get justice in the Court where the suit is pending;

 

(ii)               Where the judge is interested to one party;

 

(iii)              Where the judge is prejudiced against the party;

 

(iv)             To avoid multiplicity of proceedings or conflicting decisions;

 

(v)               Where two persons have filed suits against each other on the same cause of action in different courts;

 

(vi)             Where common questions of law and fact arise in two suits;

 

(vii)           Where considerable section of public is interested in the litigation;

 

(viii)         Where     balance     of     convenience requires     considering     where     the witnesses   resides,   or   the   account books are kept.

 

 

Md. Enamul Hague Vs. Md. Ekramul Hague & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 383

 

Section-24

 

Conduct of the Presiding Judge It appears on reference to annexure C and also to the order dated 11.8.2010 i.e. Order No.8 we find that learned Judge after passing the impugned order of which the certified copy has been annexed (Annexure C) in the rule petition interpolated or add further line after ' ' (dari) as which has been made so cleverly, so minutely and so masterly that it is very difficult to notice or find the addition. We find that '4' of >*H° has been mischievously added with the ' ' (dari) which only not been heinous, contemptous but a misconduct on the part of the presiding judge and specifically open his mind that he is interested in disposing of this matter even at the expense of the defendant which cannot be allowed.

 

Md. Enamul Haque Vs. Md. Ekramul Hague & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 383.

 

Section-24 On the ground of convenience and inconvenience

 

It appears that the defendant-petitioner (defendant No.l) did not appear in the suit nor raised any objection as to jurisdiction of ' the Court of Khulna but after two and half years from the date of institution of the suit, the petitioner filed this application before the Court under section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure for transfer of the suit from Khulna to Dhaka for the convenience of the parties. It is also found that the cause of action of the suit arose well within the jurisdiction of the District Judge, Khulna and address of the plaintiff and defendant No. 2, as given in the plaint are at Khulna— In the facts of the case and for the reasons stated above, we are clearly of the opinion that the defendant-petitioner could not make out any case for transfer of the suit to this Court on the ground of convenience and inconvenience. Therefore, we find no substance in either of the contentions as raised by the learned Advocate for the petitioner.

 

Bangladesh National Ins. Co. Ltd.Vs. Modhumati Salt Ind.(Pvt) Ltd. & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 450.

 

Section 24 read with Section 115(1) Requirement of transfer and withdrawal

 

It appears that Title Suit No. 145 of 1997 is a suit for permanent injunction and the parties of the suit are different and other two suits are not of the same stage. It further appears from the evidence on record that title Suit No.240 of 1997 is a suit for declaration of title and Title Suit No. 145 of 1997 is a suit for permanent injunction and SCC Suit No.20 of 1998 is a suit for eviction of tenants and thus the nature of all three suits are different. Thus from the facts and circumstances of the case, it appears that the learned District Judge committed wrong in directing to try these three suits simultaneously without taking into consideration that Title Suit No.240 of 1997 and SCC Suit No.20 of 1998 at preliminary stage and it will take long time to reach at the hearing stage for disposal along with Title Suit No. 145 of 1997 and as such the order No. 10 dated 27.09.2000 passed by the learned District Judge is not legal and thus he has committed an error of law in passing the impugned order.

 

Ashrafunnessa & Ors Vs Sree Sree Bimsankar, Shiba Bigraha & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 303.

 

Section 24A(2)

 

As per provision of Section 24A(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure I do not find from the order sheets that order of transfer was made on a date when the case was fixed for appearance. Such requirement of law would have been duly complied with if the transferee court would informed the parties of the transfer. But on record there is nothing to show that petitioners were informed about the transfer of the case either by the transferor Court or by the transferee Court. Further, the transferee court did not pass any order indicating or showing that the petitioners were duly informed about the transfer. As per provision of Section 24A(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure I do not find from the order sheets transferee Court after receiving the record informed the parties to the case. So these orders passed by the Courts below are bad on this count.

 

Mrs. Rezia Sultan & Anr Vs. Md. Haroon Malik &Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 339.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (As Amended) Section -44A District Court and District Judge -execution of a foreign decree.

 

There is a difference between District Court and District Judge. District Court means the principal civil court of a district and District Judge means the Judge of a principal civil court, not to any one inferior. When execution of a foreign decree is required, it must file before the District Judge, not to any other Judge. Here, we may refer to the decision of Sonali Bank-Vs- Abidur Rahman wherein it is held as 'The District Court' mentioned in Section 44A(I) of the Code means only the court of District Judge. In other words, the certified copy of decree under Section 44A(I) of the Code must be filed in the court of District Judge."

 

Nirman International Ltd. & Anr Vs. Janata Bank 20 BLT (HCD) 449.

 

Section-46 read with Arbitration Act, 2001 Section- 45: Whether a foreign Award executable in Bangladesh -Application under Order 21 rule 54(1) read with Sections 46 and 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Held; We are of the view that the learned District Judge, Dhaka, who started the execution proceeding to execute a foreign Award is not a Court of transferee, rather, within the purview of Section 45 of the Arbitration Act, 2001 the learned District Judge, Dhaka itself ought to have assumed the Award in question is a decree of his own. However, refusing to accept the foreign Award as the decree of the Court below a clear misconception of law.

 

Goenka Impex Vs. Tallu Spinning Mills Ltd. 21 BLT (HCD) 212.

 

Section-89A(5)

 

(i)                 Held; In the present case on perusal of the mediators report it is apparent that the Mediator has failed to compromise the dispute under reference. Accordingly he did not file any decision in the form of

 

agreement as referred in sub- section (5) of the section 89A of the Code rather, he filed a lengthy statement stating the plaintiff's and defendants' case discussing the merit of case of the both sides giving 'saham' in favour of the plaintiff, as if the reference was made not to Mediate the dispute or disputies amongst the parties but to decide the controversy between the party and pronounce the verdict in either way. Mediators in his statement not only passed the verdict but also he categorically directed to pass an order or a decree in terms of his statement. From the contentions of his statement it appears that the Mediator neither able to compromise the matter nor he submit his report stating failureness of the parties to compromise the suit in reference of Mediation. The Court below passed the impugned order stating that according to report since the parties failed to compromise the disputes and Mediator did not comply the procedure to compromise the suit in accordance with ADR system hence, comes to fail -we are of the view that the report of the Mediator does not reflect any terms of compromise, rather, it is a complete exparte adjudication of the suit by the Mediator in spite of mediation. Therefore, we are of the view that the opinion formed by the Court below in the impugned order does not suffer from any legal infirmity or perversity justifying interference by this Court.

 

Amitosh Das Vs Animesh Das & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 344.

 

Section-92

 

This section applies to public trust and provides that a suit against a trustee for the relief mentioned in the section could be instituted only in the manner provided therein. Where members of the public as persons interested in the endowment to enforce the right of the idol as against the trustee and claimed relieves mentioned in the section, the suit must be brought inconformity with that section and a suit under the general law is barred.

 

Paresh Chandra Biswas Vs. Sree Sree Shmashan Kalimata Idol & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 474.

 

Section 96 read with Limitation Act, 1908 Section – 5 An application for condonation of delay of 599 days in filing F.A. T. No.602 of 2002

 

The opposite party (plaintiff) obtained the decree in 2002 and should not be deprived of the fruit of the decree in the absence of cogent and satisfactory explanation for the delay in obtaining the certified copy of the impugned judgment and decree. A vested right accrued in favour of the plaintiff which can not be any taken away on the basis of the application for condonation of delay which does not contain each days delay. -The First Appeal arose out of a suit for declaration of title in respect of the suit property which was declared vested property in V.P. Case No.14 of 1977 on 8.1.1986. This declaration of vested was made at a time when there was no existing law in respect of vested and non-resident property, which was repealed in 1974. In view of such legal position, we do not find that the petitioner shall suffer any loss if the unexplained inordinate delay is not condoned.

 

A.D.C. (Rev.) Dhaka Vs. Sree Prosanta Kumar Ghosh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 484.

 

Section 100 read with Transfer of Property Act, 1882 (as amended) Section 43 Not a proper judgment for reversal

 

Held; I find defendant No.3 set up a case of acquiring title through exhibit-C, that  is kabuliyat, which the Courts below found as invalid (on the basis of which exhibit-A was executed) and I find since exhibit-C has no leg to stand as it has been found by the courts below and also found the same is void document and there being no issue on the question of option provided under Section 43 of the Transfer of Property Act, I find the Court of appeal below misapplied this provision on the facts of the given case. Since it has been found plaintiff has been able to prove his title through exhibit-l(d) together with possession, I find the judgment and decree passed by the Court of appeal below on the facts of the given case is not sustainable in law. Although I find the judgment of the trial court is a rubbish one but I confirm the ultimate decision of the learned Munsif and decreed the suit.

 

Eunus Mallik & Ors Vs. Khaleda Begum & others 20  BLT (HCD) 75

 

Section-115

 

A Simple suit for permanent injunction -The plaintiffs could not prove their settlement and also could not show that the Bhawal Court of Wards Estate had authority to settle the suit land in the face of the notifications Ext.A-A(2). The courts below also did not take into consideration the board fact that the salami receipts produced by the plaintiffs are private documents and these require strict proof for being admitted in evidence. -We are of the view that the courts below committed error of law occasioning failure of justice in decreeing the plaintiffs' suit and this requires interference by this Court.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh Vs. Abdur Rahman & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 107.

 

Section -115 Adverse Possession vide the decision reported in 7DLR 94

 

As it appears the High Court Division discharged the Rule holding that there are serious contradiction in the evidence of P.Ws. as regard possession of the plaintiff in the suit land and all the P.Ws. also remained silent as to the genuineness of the unregistered Heba deed dated 19.6.1948 and on the other hand S.A. record in respect of the major portion of the suit land is in the name of the defendant No. 1 on the basis of un-registered Heba deed and other deed and further the defendant No.l has filed S.A. records marked as exhibits Kha to Kha (8) and also filed 26 dakhilas marked as exhibits Uma to Uma (29) and the above S.A. records and rent receipts manifestly indicate the prima facie possession of the defendant No.l in the suit jotes and further the defendant No.l sold 2.65 acres of land to Abdur Rahim and 7 others who are also in possession of their respective land. Moreover the defendant No.l adducing 5 witnesses has succeeded in proving his title on the basis of unregistered Heba deed dated 19.6.48 which appears to be genuine and which was impounded under section 35 of the Stamp Act and was taken into evidence under section 90 of the Evidence Act. However the claim of the defendant No.l as regard schedule Ka and Kha to the effect that he acquired the same from his mother Maheronnessa by virtue of oral gift dated 15.12.1973 has not been substantiated as the defendant No.l, failed to prove the oral gift by the evidence of D.W.5 who deposed that he did not see the mother of defendant No. 1 both the trial court as well as the appellate court below also concurrently found that the oral gift dated 15.12.73 has not been proved. But since the possession of the defendant No.l has been proved for more than 12.

 

years, he is entitled to get title even on the basis of invalid title thought the defendant No.l did not specifically claim title by adverse possession vide the decision reported in 7 DLR 94.-There is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

Nurjahan Begum Vs. Nur Rahman & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 300.

 

Section -115 Concurrent findings over the Points in issues

 

It appears that according to the plaintiff one Abdul Mannan was the owner of the suit land. The plaintiffs claim their .26 decimals of land from C.S. Dag No.310 C.S. Khatian, exhibit 2, stands in the name of Ram Chandra Shaha and others. There is no document to show that the C.S. recorded tenants made transfer of the suit land in favour of the plaintiffs or their predecessors-in-interest in any way. The plaintiffs also claimed that Abdul Mannan filed O.C. Suit No.25 of 1954 for recovery of khas possession and the suit was decreed in his favour and the plaintiffs purchased the suit land subsequently from Abdul Mannan by virtue of a deed, exhibit-3(ga). The Courts below found that there is no document on record to show that Abdul Mannan got the suit land from C.S. recorded tenants and there is no basis of preparation of S.A. record in the name of the plaintiff and Sokiruddin. The Courts below found that the plaintiffs and Sokiruddin. The Courts below found that the plaintiffs and their predecessor acquired no valid title on the suit land and there was no legal footing in support of preparation of the S.A. or R.S. record and the plaintiffs could not show any dakhila in their favour -The decisions of both the Courts below, being based on facts, circumstances and evidence on record and there being concurrent findings over the points in issues and there being found no error of law or fact in passing the impugned judgment, I am of the opinion that the impugned judgments and decrees do not warrant any interference by this Court.

 

Md. Sohrab Ali & Ors Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 41I.

 

Section-115

 

The Court of appeal has considered evidences of the witnesses and on consideration of those of plaintiff witness Nos.l, 2, 3, 4 and 5, the Court of appeal came to the specific finding that the plaintiff could not prove their prima facie title and conclusive possession in the suit land. This being a finding of fact, this Court sitting in revisional jurisdiction cannot interfere in this finding and as such the Title Suit No.l of 1996, a suit for permanent injunction on the finding to the effect that plaintiff could not prove title and conclusive possession over the suit land cannot be decreed and the Court of appeal rightly dismissed the said Suit No.l of 1996 there is nothing to interfere in the said judgment and decree passed by the court of appeal, and as such it is affirmed.

 

Kazi Md. Sultan Ahmed Vs. Titama Bibi & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 17

 

Section-115 Not a proper judgment of reversal

 

From the order sheet of the lower Court's record it appears that plaintiffs examined 2 P.Ws and the defendant No.l cross-examined them. After closer of the plaintiff witness the defendant No.l did not examine any witness nor adduce any documentary evidence. Yet he participated in the hearing of the argument of the suit. The defendant No. 1 did not avail the opportunity to adduce evidence in support of his case and now after delivery of the judgment and decree if the suit is sent back on remand to the trial Court for fresh trial giving chance to the defendant No.l to adduce evidence it will give him an indulgence to fill up the lacuna. As the defendant No.l was negligent in bringing his evidence, I am of the view that the impugned judgment and decree passed by the learned judge of the appellate Court is not well founded both in law as well as in the facts and circumstances of the case.

 

Azam Ali & Anr Vs Akram AH & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 273.

 

Section-115

 

Specific performance of contract The trial Court and the Court of appeal concurrently held   that  the  bainapatra  in question is not a genuine one and as the execution of the same was not proved and the High Court Division concurred with the findings of the Courts below on this point. Moreover, all the course in on voice stated that passing of consideration money was also not proved -we are of the view that the High     Court     Division     upon     correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Nurun Nahar Khan Vs. Md. Mahbub Rahman (Mohon) & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 176.

 

Section 115

 

The opposite party No.l as plaintiff instituted Title Suit No.31 of 2002 before the Court of Joint District Judge, seeking a decree for two declarations one is that the judgment and decree in Title Suit No.54 of 1998 passed by the Artha Rin Adalat are illegal, collusive, fraudulent and not binding upon the plaintiff. In the said suit the defendant No.l entered appearance upon filing an application under Order 7 Rule 11 of Code Civil Procedure praying for rejection of the plaint on the ground that the proceedings in Title Suit No.54 of 1998 is governed by Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and Section 6 of the said Ain is a legal bar in proceeding with Title Suit No.31 of 2002. -After hearing the parties the learned Court of Joint District Judge rejected the application for rejection of the plaint holding that the contents of the plaint are related with some disputed deeds and judgment and decree which can be decided only at the trial on taking evidence. - Held;

 

Per Mr. Sheikh Abdul Awal, J : If any party aggrieved by judgment and decree of the Artha Rin Adalat he may prefer appeal against the same as per specific provisions of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain and in case of ex-parte decree, the judgment debtor may prefer an application under section 19 of the Artha Rin Ain, 2003 for setting-aside the ex-parte decree upon deposit of certain amount as per the said provisions of law. - I am inclined  to  hold   that   the   learned  Joint District Judge seriously erred in view in passing    the    impugned    order    without j properly applying his judicial mind into the I facts and circumstances of the case and law f bearing on the subject and the same has I resulted in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice. In any event I this is not a case in which the Court of Joint District Judge or the Court of District Judge established under the Civil Court Acts has jurisdiction to grant the relief asked for by the plaintiff.

 

Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd. Vs Md. Salauddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 244.

 

Per Mr. M. Moazzam Husain, J : I am of the opinion that the opposite party No.l, before  being  proved   as   such,   is   not  a 'judgment debtor' as contemplated under the 1 Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003: By the same token, the suit filed by him questioning the applicability of the same cannot be said to be barred by the ouster clause of the Ain for the precise reason that on the event of his success in his suit the decree passed against him will turn into a nullity and no 'decree' passed under the Act.

 

Arab Bangladesh Bank Ltd.Vs Md. Salauddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 244.

 

Section-115 Concurrent finding of fact

 

Both the Courts below misreading and on non consideration of the material evidence held that the plaintiff failed to prove his possession in the suit land which are contrary to evidence and dismissed the suit illegally which can not be sustained in law.

 

Khitisli Chandra Sutradhar Vs Nirmal Chandra Sutradhar & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 219.

 

Section-115

 

Plaintiff acquired right, title and interest in the suit land by adverse possession as he had been possessing the suit land since 10.12,1973 pursuant to agreement for sale of the suit land. The plaintiff had/has been possessing the suit land on the basis of the bainapatra dated 10,12.1973, exhibit-!, executed by its real owner, the defendant No. 1, Nirmal Chandra Satradhar adversely for more than statutory period of 12 years since 10.12.1973 and thus perfected his title against the defendant No. 1 by such possession.

 

Khitish Chandra Sutradhar Vs Nirmal Chandra Sutradhar & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 219.

 

Section -115

 

The suit land was once a river but by the passage of time the same is converted as agricultural land as contended by the learned Counsel for the opposite parties - relied on judgment and order passed in Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal No.355 of 2005.

 

Held; In the present case, the nature and character of the suit land has been changed and the Government also treated the same as cultivable land which is apparent from Khas Khatian No.l prepared in the name of the Government and considering the true state of affairs the Government leased out the same to the plaintiffs earlier. But on an application filed by the present petitioners who are local persons and enemical to the plaintiffs the leasing authority cancelled the lease without hearing the plaintiffs which is arbitrary and violation of the principles of natural justice.

 

Mahmuda Begum & Ors Vs. Md. Ashraful Islam20 BLT (HCD) 412.

 

1494

Constitution of Bangladesh 1972

Citation: 4, MLR (1999) (AD) 316

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Constitution of Bangladesh

Delivery Date: 2018-04-25

Constitution of Bangladesh 1972

 

Article 102- Scope of interference in service matters—Article 29- Equality of opportunity of employment—

 

Mere preparation of list of some persons for appointment to certain posts does not create any vested right enforceable in law. But when on the basis of certain statutory backing and Government decision, list is prepared of certain persons for appointment/absorption to certain posts and some of them are appointed and some are left out, the left out writ petitioners in the circumstances can certainly invoke the writ jurisdiction for intervention on ground of discrimination.

 

Government of Bangladesh represented by Secretary Ministry of Establishment, and others Vs. Md. Jahangir Hossain and others 4, MLR (1999) (AD) 316.

1495

Contract Act, 1872

Citation: 17 BLT (AD) 98, 20 BLT (AD) 108

Case Year: 1872

Subject: Contract

Delivery Date: 2018-07-11

Contract Act, 1872

 

Offer and Acceptance

 

Held; We are of the view that in case the seller insists on delivery to the buyer a quantity of goods less than he contracted to sell, the buyer has got the right to reject them and claim refund of the money paid by him to the seller. In the instant case the seller failed to show that he was ready to deliver to the buyer the quantity/quality of the goods in good condition contracted to be delivered and in fact there is default by the seller and in such view Of the matter there is no legal reason to authorize the seller to forfeit the good money paid by the buyer and as such the action of the buyer in the present case in forfeiting the money of the plaintiff cannot stand in the eye of law.

 

National Bank Ltd. Vs. Pragati Industries Ltd. 17 BLT (AD) 98

 

Section –23

 

The Word 'public policy' The word 'public policy' is not easy to define but may include any injustice, oppression, restraint of liberty, commerce and natural or legal right, whatever tends to the obstruction of justice or to the violation of the statute and whatever against good morals when made the object of a contract and therefore void and not susceptible of enforcement.

 

World Tel Bangladesh Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 108.

1496

Court Fees Act, 1870

 

 

Section-8(c)

It appears from the written statement that the contesting defendants took the objection in their written statements that the suit has not been properly valued but no such issue was framed by the trial court, the defendant did not bring it to the notice of the trial court that an issue should be framed as to the valuation of the suit — in revision, cannot be allowed to raise an objection as to valuation of the suit because they slept over the matter after raising the same objection in their written statement. [Para - 18]

Sananda Mohan Barua & Ors. Vs. Niranjan Proshad Barua & Ors 4 BLT (HCD)-187

1497

Customs Act, 1969

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD ) 379, 20 BLT (AD) 60, 20 BLT (AD) 31, 20 BLT (HCD) 425, 21 BLT (HCD) 538, 19 BLT (HCD) 211, 21 BLT (AD) 240

Case Year: 1969

Subject: Customs

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Customs Act, 1969

 

Section 2(b) "appropriate officer"

 

From the adjudication order, it appears that the coast guards authority in its letter dated 20.6.2007 stated that after seizure of the oil tanker namely "O.T. NEW STAR" Mr. Munir Chowdhury, Magistrate, First Class, Chittagong Port, examined the same in the laboratory of Padma Oil Co. Ltd. On examination it is found that the seized furnace oil was pure furnace oil. Based on such examination report the said Mr. Munir Chowdhury awarded a fine of Tk.50,000/-each to the Chief Engineer and the Captain of the mothervessel -Mr. Munir Chowdhury is not an appropriate officer under the Customs Act rather he is the Magistrate of Chittagong Port completely, a different authority. As such the ex-parte examination report has got no legal basis.

 

Md. Rafiqul Islam & Anr Vs Customs, Excise and VAT, Appellate Tribunal & Anr 17 BLT (HCD ) 379.

 

Section 2(s) read with 156(1)(8) Admittedly,

 

diesel oil/dirty furnace oil are not prohibited or restricted items. To attract the definition of the smuggling it must be proved that the items found in the oil tanker were prohibited items by notification in the official gazette. It is well settled principle of law that to bring the charge of smuggling under section 156(1 )(8) of the Customs Act, the Customs Authority must show that the items are prohibited items in Bangladesh and there should also be smuggling under section 2(s) of the Customs Act, 1969. In the present case, as it appears that no single item of smuggled goods were found in the seized oil tanker.

 

Md. Rafiqul Islam & Anr Vs Customs, Excise and VAT, Appellate Tribunal & Anr 17 BLT (HCD) 379.

 

Customs Act, 1969 (as amended) Section- 18 read with Section -19

 

Section 18 of the Customs Act speaks of a rate of duty which could be upto 100% or value on that but section 19 speaks of exemption as the Government deem fit proper in the public interest and in that view of the matter these two sections do not control each other.

 

Commissioner of Customs Vs, Cab Express (BD) Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 60.

 

Section -19 & Section - 20

 

General power to exempt any goods from customs  duties exception   in   exceptional circumstances

 

The High Court Division held that then only difference between Hannan's case 42 DLR(AD) 167 and the instant case are that in Hannan's case there were special circumstances which were was narrated and in the present cases, no such circumstances were narrated but it is found from the materials on record that the government has exercised the discretion entrusted upon it under section 20 of the Customs Act whereas in Hannan's case exemption was made under section 19 of the Act which is a general power of exemption by the authority and not a special power of the authority as in the present case.-Held; We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record and the law applicable, arrived at a correct decision and accordingly the decision does not call for any interference.

 

M/s. R.M. Corporation Ltd. Vs. Customs, Excise and VAT Appellate Tribunal & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 31

 

Section 25(1) read with Customs Valuation (Fixing Price of Imported Goods) Rules, 2000 Section - 23(2) read with Pre-shipment Inspection Rules, 2012; Section 22(4)

 

Held; Applying the relevant provisions of both the PS I Rules and the Valuation Rules read with those of the Act relied upon by the Petitioner, and given the evidently arbitrary assessment of the CRF valuation, this Court finds that as mandated in law the Respondents shall have to reevaluate the valuation of the Goods under Rule 22(3). Given this Court's satisfaction that as warranted in the facts and circumstances the Customs Authority can presently indeed arrive at a final decision as to the valuation of the Goods applying the standards and principles as elaborately enunciated above, there is found no justifiable ground to Order instead a mere provisional assessment of the Goods. This Court, accordingly, directs the Customs Authority to strictly so proceed, thereby, necessarily allowing the Petitioner to pay the Customs duties as assessed by the Respondents under Rule 23(2) in accordance with the Valuation Rules read in the context of Section 25(1) and (2) of the Act and on the basis of the declared/invoice/transaction value by way of final assessment.

 

Transcom Cables Limited Vs. Commissioner of Customs, & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 425.

 

Section-25(3) read with Customs

 

Valuation Rules, 2000 Rule-5 read with Rule 2 (Ga) (Ga) The words "tariff value" and "minimum value" used in section 25 (3) of the Customs Act and the lowest value of identical gods as mentioned in rule 5 read with rule 2 (GaGa) of the Customs Valuation Rules have different meanings in different contexts. In the present case we do not find any wrong in levying the customs duties on the basis of lowest value of identical goods as provided in the Customs Valuation Rules, when no notification was made under section 25 (3) of the Customs Act.

 

Mohammad Elias -Vs- The Commissioner of Customs & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 538.

 

Section-47

 

Vessel is liable to discharge the cargo if permission to break bulk cargo is obtained irrespective of tin.' arrest order.

 

Whatever be the reason stated by the learned Advocate the actual facts remain that the said part discharge has been made under the provision of the customs Act 1969. Although the vessel is now under arrest yet the vessel will be liable to discharge the entire cargo in accordance with the Provisions of Customs Act 1969 since no breaking of bulk is allowed without the permission of Customs Authority under Section 47 of the Customs Act 1969. Since the vessel obtained the permission for breaking the bulk it became liable to discharge the entire cargo as mandated by the Customs Act 1969. But as the plaintiff has not yet submitted the original shipping documents, the plaintiff will not be entitled to get the delivery of the said consignment till the plaintiff submits the original copy of the shipping documents.

 

L.M.J. International Ltd. India Vs M.V. BK ACE & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 211.

 

Section 73

 

"Discharge" of Cargo is nothing but "unloading" the same in the port

 

Although the provision speaks of 'may' but the comprehensive reading of the other provision regarding discharge of cargo indicates that it is a mandatory provision that after obtaining permission for bulk breaking, the cargo must be unloaded within a specified period. The term "discharge" used in the Customs Act 1969 is nothing but "unloading" of the cargo into the classified area of the Port.

 

L.M.J. International Ltd. India Vs M.V. BK ACE & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 211.

 

Declaration of Rio Principle-10

 

The United Nations Conference on Environment and Development was of the view that one of the fundamental prerequisites for the achievement of sustainable development was broad public participation in decision making. Furthermore, the Conference recognized, in the specific context of environment, "the need for new forms of participation" and "the need of individuals, groups and organizations to participate in environmental impact assessment procedures and to know about the participation in (pertinent) decisions". The Conference implicitly linked the notion of real participation in the right of access to information by nothing that "Individuals, groups and organizations should have access to information relevant to environment and development held by national authorities, including information on products and activities that have or are likely to have a significant impact on the environment, and information   on   environmental   protection measures". The link between participation and   information   can   also   be   found   in Principle 10 of the Declaration of Rio.

 

Metro Makers & Developers Ltd Vs. BELA 21 BLT (AD) 240.

1498

Dhaka Electric Authority Act, 1990

Citation: 19 BLT (AD) 178, 18 BLT (HCD) 71, 18 BLT (AD) 329

Case Year: 1990

Subject: Dhaka Electric Authority

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Dhaka Electric Authority Act, 1990

 

Section-21 read with Dhaka Electric Supply Authority (Amended) Ordinance, 2008 Section-2(3) (gha) read with Surplus Public Servants Absorption Ordinance, 1985

 

Writ petitioner filed the writ Petition with prayer for direction, not to issue further letters of appointment prior to absorption of the surplus officials and stuffs of Dhaka Electric Supply Authority -High Court Division made the Rule absolute directing the DPDC authority to consider and dispose of the pending representations of the petitioners as per provisions of relevant laws as expeditiously as possible preferably within 60 days from the date of receipt of the judgment and order -Held; Having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case and the provision of section 21 of the Dhaka Electric Authority Act, 1990, as amended by the Dhaka Electric Supply Authority Amendment Ordinance, 2008, as well as the provisions of the Surplus Public Servant Absorption Ordinance 1985, we do not find any illegality or infirmity in the impugned judgment and order passed by the High Court Division.

 

Dhaka Power Distribution Comp. Ltd & Anr Vs. Md. Borhanuddin Bhuiyan & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 178.

 

Doctrine of Merger

 

Whether the order of discharged for default of High Court Division has been merged with the order of the Appellate Division as has been dismissed as not being pressed.

 

Consequence of Non Prosecution -Held; As the petition for leave to appeal has not been disposed on merit so it could not be said that the order of discharged for default of the High Court Division has been combined and united with the order of the Appellate Division. This Division still have jurisdiction to consider the application for restoration. All the remedies are creature of statute. It shall be available to an aggrieved party so long the same is not found to be barred by any law. Here, in this case the petitioner simply prayed for leave to prefer appeal before the Appellate Division but finally the said prayer has not been pressed and their Lordships of the Appellate Division did not make any comment regarding the propriety of the order of discharged for default so it cannot be said that order of discharged has been merged in the order of the Appellate Division.

 

Farhad Hossain Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 71.

 

Doctrine of Necessity –Condonation

 

In respect of condonation made by the High Court Division, the following modification is made and condonations are made as under:

 

(a)  all executive acts, things and deeds done and actions taken during the period from 15th August   1975  to 9th April,   1979 which are past and closed;

 

(b)  the actions not derogatory to the rights of the citizens;

 

(c)  all acts during that period which tend to advance or promote the welfare of the people;

 

(d)  all routine works done during the above period which even the lawful government could have done.

 

(e) (i) the Proclamation dated 8th November, 1975 so far it relates to omitting Part VIA of the Constitution;

 

(ii) the Proclamations (Amendment) Order 1977 (Proclamations Order No. 1 of 1977) relating to Article 6 of the Constitution.

 

(iii) the Second Proclamation (Seventh Amendment) Order, 1976 (Second Procla­mation Order No. .IV of 1976) and the Second Proclamation (Tenth Amendment) Order, 1977 (Second Proclamation Order No. 1 of 1977) so far it relates to amendment of English text of Article 44 of the Constitution;

 

(iv) the Second Proclamation (Fifteenth Amendment) Order, 1978 (Second Procla­mation Order No.IV of 1978) so far it relates to substituting Bengali text of Article 44;

 

(v) The Second Proclamation (Tenth Amendment) Order, 1977 (Second Procla­mation Order No. 1 of 1977) so far it relates to inserting Clauses (2), (3), (4), (5), (6) and (7) of Article 96 i.e. provisions relating to Supreme Judicial Council and also clause (1) of Article 102 of the Constitution, and

 

(f) all acts and legislative measures which are in accordance with, or could have been made under the original Constitution.

 

Khondker Delwar Hossain & Ors Vs. Bangladesh Italian Marble Works Ltd. & Ors. 18 BLT (AD) 329.

1499

Emergency Requisition of Property Act 1948

Citation: 17 BLT (AD) 339, 17 BLT (AD) 118

Case Year: 1948

Subject: Emergency Requisition of Property

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Emergency Requisition of Property Act 1948

 

Section -5(7)

The notification of the final acquisition of the said suit property in the official gazette has been delayed

 

Final gazette Notification under section 5(7) of the Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948 in respect of the suit premises has already been made on 18lh March, 1993 and as such the right, title and interest if any of the previous owner had extinguished and the property absolutely vested in the Government as contended by the learned Deputy Attorney General -Held; In the facts circumstances of the case and in view of the fact that final Gazette Notification under section 5(7) of the Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948 had already been made in 1993. In our view the judgment of the High Court Division requires interference by us.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Rabia Khatoon Ors 17 BLT (AD) 339.

 

Section-8B

 

In a de-requisitioned proceeding of a requisitioned property before delivery of possession was taken by the requisitioning authority, the delivery of possession of the released property is not necessary to make the order of release effective -We find substance in the submissions of the learned Deputy Attorney General that the survey report dated 02.06.1988 Annexure-E, order sheet of Miscellaneous Case No.2 of 1993 Annexure-J, order for depositing money Anenexure-F and the release order Annexure-D have not been properly considered in the review case. We also find substance in her submission that possession of the writ petitioner's requisitioned property had not been taken over by the authority and the same had been de­requisitioned at the initial stage under section 8B of the (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948.

 

 Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Mr. Sultana Ferdous Ara Khanam 17 BLT (AD) 118.

1500

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965

Citation: 21 BLT (AD) 125, 19 BLT (HCD) 05, 21 BLT (AD) 130, 19 BLT (HCD) 568, 20 BLT (HCD) 471, 18 BLT (AD) 497, 19 BLT (HCD) 327, 21 BLT (HCD) 433, 17 BLT (AD) 45, 18 BLT (HCD) 295, 17 BLT (HCD) 450, 21 BLT (HCD) 03, 21 BLT (HCD) 58, 20 BLT (HCD) 554, 20 BLT (

Case Year: 1965

Subject: Employment of Labour (Standing Orders)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965

 

Section 25(l)(b)

 

The High Court Division observed that the Labour Court found that the first party (the petitioner before us) was not able to prove that his termination was due to his trade union activities or that he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Union or that he was connected with the trade union activates. The High Court Division further observed that in the judgment by the Labour Court, the Chairman stated that he had discussed the case with the members and had considered their written opinions. The High Court Division also observed that from the deposition of PW.l it appeared that the petitioner was a member of the trade union in 1991 but he could not prove that he was either office bearer or executive member of any trade union after 1991. Therefore, it could not be said that the petitioner was terminated from service because of trade union activities. - We find that the High Court Division passed the impugned judgment upon proper consideration of the facts and circumstances and upon correct appreciation of the evidence and materials on record.

 

S. M. Kamaluddin Vs. Chairman, First Labour Court & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 125

 

Evidence Act, 1872 Section-45

 

The expert's opinion is not conclusive evidence but expert's opinion enables the Court to come to a satisfactory conclusion, though the said opinion in not binding upon the Court.

 

Monowara Begum & Ors Vs Hasmater Nessa & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 05.

 

Section – 45

 

An application for comparison of the disputed thumb impression in question - allowed the prayer exparte

 

The main issue in controversy between the parties being the genuineness of the deed of gift, the thumb impressions appearing therein should be examined by an expert for the purpose of enabling the Court effectually and completely to adjudicate upon and settle all the questions involved in the suit. Though the High Court Division allowed the prayer exparte, the defendant having challenged the said order in the appellate forum, we are of the view that whatever error the High Court Division has committed in allowing the prayer exparte has been cured by availing the appeal before this Division. As the examination of the disputed thumb impression is necessary for the purpose of resolving all controversies involve in the suit between the parties, we are of the view that such exparte order has occasioned no failure of justice.

 

Kabir Ahmed Vs. Korban Alt & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 130.

 

Section-45 read with section 73 Comparison of the thumb impression

 

The Court below without assigning any reason as to the question of consecutive expert's opinion or the legal strength of expert's opinion abruptly arrived at a finding that in the facts and circumstances of the case expert's opinion is not enough to disbelieve the plaintiff-Bank's case. The Court is required to take into account that in the modern world science has been developing very much day by day and it is also need of the day to detect the truth by applying modern technology. In this case highest team of CID in order to detect the genuineness of thumb impressions on the alleged documents examined the thumb impressions on the alleged documents with the admitted thumb impressions of the appellant (defendant No. 3) by applying scientific method and submitted two consecutive reports dated 19.11.1988 and 12.7.1990 respectively stating the thumb impressions on alleged documents were not in the hand of the defendant-Nur Alam. Therefore, our view is that the trial Court committed wrong in discarding the G.D. entries (Exhibit-A) as well as opinion of the hand writing experts (Exhibit-Ga & Ga-1). In the facts and circumstances of the case the trial Court ought to have believed the opinion of the hand writing experts.

 

Noor Alam Vs. Sonali Bank & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 568.

 

Sections 45, 47, 67 & Section 73 Identity of the handwriting or signature of a person

 

Held; In the instant case when it is the duty of the plaintiffs to prove the identity and genuineness of the signatures of defendant Nos.1-2 on the alleged document, the plaintiffs may avail of any of the method as enumerated Sections 45, 47, 67 & Section 73. They cannot be forced by the defendants to resort to any particular method of proving the alleged signature.

 

Debashish Chakrabarty & Anr Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 471.

 

Section-73 Report of the finger Print expert

 

The case of Jaspal Singh, Vs. State of Punjab, reported in AIR 1979 SC 1708 wherein Indian Supreme Court held that the science of identifying thumb impression is an exact science and does not admit of any mistake or doubt. We endorse the aforesaid view.

 

Nanda Rani Mondal & Anr Vs. Md. Abdus Sukur & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 497.

 

Section-73 Report of expert alone does not prove the case of either party.

 

It is well settled that report of an expert on finger print is a mere piece of evidence like other evidence as may be brought on record which the Court shall take into consideration while deciding an issue in a suit. Report of expert alone does not prove the case of either party. The cardinal principle of law is that parties must prove their respective case by legal evidence.

 

Jiban Krishna Sarker Vs Jogesh Chandra Sarker 19 BLT (HCD) 327.

 

Section-73

 

Whether expert's opinion is conclusive evidence to a court.

 

The proposition of law is by now well settled that the expert's opinion is not a conclusive evidence which enables the Court to come to a satisfactory conclusion, though the said opinion is not binding upon the Court. The Court itself can compare any signature or LTI of any concerned person under section 73 of the Evidence Act and come to a decision in accordance with law.

 

Bimol Rosario Vs. Barbara Risario & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 433

 

Section -74

 

The High Court Division held that certified copies of the kabuliyats, the originals of which were not called for nor produced were admissible in evidence as public documents. We are constrained to observe that the findings of the High Court Division are not at all based on the materials on record regarding title and possession of the plaintiffs in the suit land and the findings of the High Court Division that the certified copies of the kabuliyats without calling for the originals or the volume from the office of the Registrar is admissible in evidence is not the correct proposition of law.

 

Abdul Quddus Matabbar Vs. YousufAli Bayati &Ors 17 BLT (AD) 45.

 

Section-92

 

The proviso to section 92 of the Evidence Act 1872 clearly mandates that the party who claimed to vary the assertion of a registered documents may do so through either another registered documents or through such cogent evidence of the contemporary period that the same can be believed by Court of law otherwise no evidence will be allowed to be adduced to vary the assertion of a registered document by any oral assertion. To put the common sense to play if the assertion made in the registered documents is allowed to be varied after 70 years through flimsy oral assertion, the entire purpose of registration Act will be nagutory.

 

Hashen AH & Ors Vs Suruj Ali & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 295.

 

Section -101

 

The petitioner filed application for exemption from production of P.W.3 and his cross examination which was not disposed of. In view of circumstances, it is difficult to accept the evidence of P.W.3.

 

Kanchan Bala Rani Vs Sreemati Gita Rani Sarker & Anr 17 BLT (HCD) 450.

 

Section -101 Burden of proof

 

In the present case the plaintiff-petitioner as a citizen of the then Pakistan left this country in the year 1964 and was residing in India for a particular period and returned to Bangladesh after Liberation in the year 1972. He obtained Bangladeshi passport from the Government of Bangladesh in the year 1988. - Held; In view of the facts and circumstances of the case I have the reason to inclined such a view that it is settled in our court that to every adult person the law assigns a domicile which is called the domicile of origin and which remains attached to him until a pew and different domicile takes its place. There is absolutely nothing on the record to show that the accused respondent ever became an Indian citizen in substitution of his domicile of origin. Therefore, the domicile of origin remains attached to him. - relied on 32 DLR (HCD) 160.

 

Jnanendra Nath Barai Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 03.

 

Sections -101 & 102 Onus

 

Primarily onus, of course lies in the civil proceeding upon the plaintiff and in this case the primary onus has been discharged satisfactorily by the plaintiff, then onus has been shifted upon the defendants to prove their particular fact that the signatures of the defendant no.3 were extorted or forged but this onus they failed to prove by adducing any evidence and consequently the evidence adduced by the plaintiff as to the execution of bainapatro (Exhibit-1) stands.

 

Most. Renu Begum Vs. Khandoker Enamul Mowla & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 58.

 

Section -101 & 103

 

Treating the suit property as Enemy or Vested and Non-resident Property
