The High Court Division observed that a man could rise by capacity and merit; therefore, the High Court division found that the above contention could not hold good. -The findings arrived at and the decision made by the High Court Division having been made on proper appreciation of law and fact do not call for interference.

 

Paresh Chandra Biswas Vs. Shree Shree Shashan Kalimata Idol & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 339.

 

Hindu Law

Debuttar Property

 

In the instant case, we are of the farm view that by executing a Kabuliyat by Shebait of deity in the name of Paresh Narayan Choudhury was never settled as permanent Raiyat. Shebait can not extinguish or alienate permanently the property of Deity in other words Debuttar property and as such, claiming the Deity's property permanently in pursuance of unilateral Kabuliyat Ext.3 can not be considered as legal insturment. Therefore, including so called record of rights and all further transfer regarding Rent Sale, compromise of Execution Rent Case, settlement of sub-raiyat by Paresh and Naresh and others and thereafter purchase by Nesar Hossain was beyond the provision of law and without lawful authority and jurisdiction. Therefore, in pursuance of such unlawful authority and papers transferred by Nesar Hossain in the name of the plaintiff does not create any legal and lawful authority to have the right, title and possession over Ka schedule land.

 

Syed Jamshed  Hussain  Choudhury Vs Govt.  of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 303.

 

Hindu Law

'Widow's estate' -right of enjoyment

 

A Hindu Widow takes only a limited estate in the property of her deceased husband, inherited by her. The estate taken by her in such property is called "widow's estate" or "woman's estate" —a widow shall have a right of enjoyment of her husband's property, during her life time but shall have to right to transfer or encumber the property in any way, and after her death, the property shall go to the heirs of her husband, and not to her own heirs, The injunctions contained in other Texts require the widow to enjoy with moderation and lead a life of austerity, and in that sense, she has not even a life interest. On the other hand, she is not a tenant for life, but the properly is vested in her and she is the owner of the property, subject to certain restrictions. She has the right to alienate the property absolutely for what is known as "legal necessity', namely, for payment of husband's debts, for performance of acts which conduce to the spiritual welfare of the husband, for discharging obligations of her husband, for her own maintenance which is also an obligation of the husband and for the preservation of the estate.

 

Hazi Md. Nazim Hossain & Ors Vs Hafiz Ullah & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Hindu Women's Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance Act, 1946 Section – 2

 

According to Hindu Law, a Hindu wife is inseparable from her husband and they are obliged to live together as husband and wife till last day of their life. Any deviation of their relationship and conduct due to the behavior of the husband makes the husband liable to bear the consequences to the right accrued to the wife under the marriage.

 

Gopal Chandra Vs. Mitali Rani Chandra 20 BLT (AD) 279.

 

Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, 1937 Section-3(l)

Whether A Hindu widow governed Dayavaga School of Hindu Law inherit agricultural land from her husband

 

A  Hindu widow's  right  in   respect  of property left by her husband must  be applied indiscriminately -relied on 34 DLR Page-178

 

Putul Biswas - Vs- Krishnapada Mondal & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 564.

1504

Hindu Personal Law

Citation: 2BLT (AD)-9, 6BLT (AD)-131, 5BLT(AD)-283, 6BLT (AD)-251, 4BLT (AD)-139, 7BLT (AD)-12, 9BLT (AD)-211, 10BLT (AD)-150, 7BLT (HCD)-131, 9BLT (HCD)-290,16 BLT (AD)94, 9BLT(HCD)-131, 7BLT (HCD)-80, 13 BLT (AD)36, 7BLT (AD)-240, 7 BLT (AD)-366.

Subject: Hindu Personal Law

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Hindu Personal Law

Section-480

(a) Contention raised as to prohibition on the adoption of a daughter’s son by a Hindu father, a Vaishya not a Sudra being void abinition, whether principle of factum valet is applicable to this case.

S. K. Chowdhury & Ors. Vs. S. K. Chowdhury & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-9

 

 

(b) Hindu Law—Section 480(3)— Probation on adopting a daughter’s son— objections to the adoption raised on the first time after 87 years rejected —whether a defence cannot be based by limitation in case of adoption.

S.K Chowdhury & Ors. Vs. S. I Chowdhury & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-9

Section-205

Reversionary heirs—defendants Patani Sundari Dassaya had life interest in the suit land, alienation of the suit land to the transferee Shibnath is valid during the life time of the transferor Patani Sundari Dassaya and the same will not be binding upon the reversionary heirs after her death, in the meantime the protection of the property the reversionary heirs can perused other legal remedies if occasion arises for the same.

Sharashibala Sarker & Ors Vs. Patani Sundari Dassaya & Anr. 6BLT (AD)-131

Hindu Personal Law on Marriage

Requisites of a valid Hindu Marriage — there was a marriage ceremony between the parties in the temple of the deity kali in presence of many persons — It is obvious that nuptial rites in Hindu Shastra are so complicated that an exact observance of their details is not easy and is beyond the comprehension of the ordinary participants or the attendants of the ceremony. But once the celebration of a marriage in fact is established there shall be a presumption of there being a marriage in law and observance of the essential ceremonies.

Utpal Kanti Das Vs. Manju Rani Das 5BLT(AD)-283

Hindu Law on Will

Proof of will—The long delay, for probate— Admittedly, except P.W. I no one was examined among the 8 attesting witnesses to prove attestation of the alleged will and, no explanation was given for their non— examination even though the law required that at least two attesting witnesses each of whom saw the testator sign or affix his mark should be examined by the pro-founder of the will. The long delay of 15 years in filing the application for probate was not explained. The alleged will was found not to be physically genuine.

Sree Bhagirat Barman & Anr. Vs Sree Haricharan Barman 6BLT (AD)-251

Hindu Widow’s Estate

A widow residing at the residence of her deceased husband cannot be termed as acquiring property adverse possession.

Mohammod Shamsul Hague Vs. Haran Chandra Dey 4BLT (AD)-139

Hindu Law

Principle of Hindu Law—In respect of Deity

A Deity has also right of its own to have a suit instituted or defended by a next friend. In case of family Deity, even a worshipper other than the Shebayet or members of the family in a proper case may apply to the court for being appointed as the next friend to protect the interest of the Deity and in such a case a duty is cast upon the court to examine as to whether if such worshipper if so appointed the interest of the Deity would be adequately protected.

Falguni Majumder Vs. Mokbul Hossain Biswas & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-12

Hindu Law on Religious and Charitable Trust

Whether any person other than a shebait can prosecute a suit as a next friend of the deity.

In the instant case, most of the shebaits have already left the country or have since died. A few who are in this country are dormant and Hindu Personal Law have not been taking any interest in the cause Bengal School of the deity and play its next friend, in the circumstances Pradip Kumar Chakraborty who is admittedly a Puja and a worshipper of the deity and has offered himself to act as next friend of the deity can by no means be precluded from representing the deity as such.

Sri Sri Dasha Bhuja Mata Vs. Jamila Khatun Bibi & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-211

Hindu Personal Law

Legal necessity - recital in the instance case one transaction by Exhibit-B, where transfer is challenged after lapse of considerable long time then recital in the document being of long past can legally be considered, in the light of observation in the case reported in AIR 1916 P.C. 110. genuine and the court may taking the recital along with the circumstances go for making its decision as to validity of the deed.

Jitendra Nail, Mistry vs. Abdul Maleke Howlader & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-150

Hindu Personal Law

Legal and valid adoption

There must be physical act of giving and receiving, is absolutely essential to the validity of an adoption.

Bela Rani Saha & Ors Vs. Gopal Chandra Saha. 7BLT (HCD)-131

Condition for taking an adoption

Dayabhag School of Hindu Law — conditions to be fulfilled for taking an adoption-_A wife cannot adopt a son to her husband during her husband’s lifetime except with his express consent.

Bela Rani Saha & Ors Vs. Gopal Chandra Saha 9BLT (HCD)-131

Hindu Personal Law

Bengal School

Whether as sisters they could inherit lawfully the estate left by their brother.

Section 25 of Mullas Principles of Hindu Law says according to the Bengal School there are only five females who can succeed as heirs to a male, namely 1. Widow 2. Daughter, 3. Mother 4. Fathers mother and 5. Fathers fathers mother. Three more were added to the list by the Hindu Law of inheritance (Amendment) Act, 1992, namely, the Sons daughter, daughters daughter and sister. Section 88 of the same Book provides the order of Succession among Sapindas. There is no mention of sister. Absence of sister there only to indicate the heirs in whose presence, a sister is excluded. Section 88 does not take away the right of a sister as recognized under section 25. Under section 25 sisters are entitled to inherit the estate of her brother.

Md. Abdur Rahman Mondal Vs. Sreemoti Renu Bala  Barman & ors. 9BLT (HCD)-290

Hindu Personal Law

Debutter —Proof of dedication

High Court Division observed that in the instant suit, the plaintiffs save and except stating that the dedication was made orally failed to adduce any evidence to prove that the suit property was dedicated to Deity; it is the case of the plaintiffs that dedication was made in the year 1956 and so this dedication is not so old to suggest that no materials could be available —we are of the view that the High Court Division, on proper consideration of the evidence and the materials on record arrived at the correct decision.

Probir Kumar Basak Chowdhury Vs. Thana Nirbahi Officer & Ors 16 BLT (AD)94

 

Evidence — Legal and valid adoption

The Court of appeal below relied upon Ext.Ka, an affidavit alleged to have executed by Mrinalini on 17.07.1975 ext-Kha, an application before the village court, ext-ga’ an application under Section 107 cr. P.C. filed by the plaintiff Grija Mohon Saha in the Criminal Court,. ext ‘Gha’ a school leaving certificate of the defendant and ext-‘Uma’ the voter list, as the reliable evidence for a legal adoption — Held: those documents as relied by the court of appeal cannot be the basis for deciding whether the defendant the adopted son of Mrinalini or of Grija

Mohon Saha,

Bela Rani Saha & Ors Vs. Gopal Chandra Saha. 9BLT(HCD)-131

Hindu Women Rights to the Property Act, 1937 Section-3

The suit property was inherited by plaintiff and defendant No.1 from Haridash Roy Chowdhury. Plaintiff is the widow of Haridash Roy Chowdhury and defendant No. 1 is her step son—the plaintiff is entitled to partition, even though she has only life interest in the property left behind by her husband.

Bina Roy Chowdhury Vs. Amullya Roy Chowdhury & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-80

Hindu Law In Dayabhag Law

Admittedly, plaintiffs father and uncle were in joint mess and there was no partition amongst themselves as co-sharers. According to Dayabhag Law, father can dispose of ancestral property plaintiffs uncle being in joint family can also dispose of his ancestral by sale, gift and will or otherwise.

Srimati Aroti Rani Paul. Vs Sree Sudarshan Kumar Paul & Ors. 13 BLT (AD)36

Imposition of Cost

We find from the judgments of the High Court Division that seizure of gold ornaments from a citizen of Bangladesh is not authorised by customs law and there is no breach of any prohibition or restriction of Customs Act. The High Court Division found the seizure of gold ornaments to be mala fide and illegal and as such we do not like to consider the question of imposition of costs in the facts of the present case. Every public official must act within the four corners of law.

Collector of Customs Vs. Shammi Ahmed & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-240

Interest of Public Revenue

Customs duty—Personal guarantee—Held: We have, inter alia, observed that personal guarantee is a very weak and uncertain security which should be avoided in the best interest of public revenue.

Commissioner of Customs & Ors Vs. SARC Enterprise 7 BLT (AD)-366.

 

1505

House Building Finance Corporation, 1973

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 567, 18 BLT (HCD) 116, 20 BLT (HCD) 452, 20 BLT (HCD) 449, 19 BLT (AD) 163, 20 BLT (HCD) 99, 20 BLT (HCD) 452, 19 BLT (HCD) 148, 20 BLT (AD) 01, 18 BLT (HCD) 210, 18 BLT (AD) 282, 17 BLT (HCD) 416, 18 BLT (HCD) 127, 20 BLT (AD) 64, 18 BLT (

Case Year: 1973

Subject: House Building Finance Corporation

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

House Building Finance Corporation, 1973

(P.O. 7 of 1973)

 

Article 27

 

In the judgment of 49 DLR (AD) 80 it is evident that for coming to the decision that the word '"stf^" used in section 5(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 refers to suit and the proceedings under Article 27 of P.O. 7 of 1973 are not suits their lordships did not at all base on the 4th schedule of the Constitution, rather taking into consideration the requirements of a suit and also the nature of a proceeding under Article 27 of P.O. 7 of 1973 and also taking into consideration the provisio to Section 5(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 their lordships formed their independent opinion that the word "^Mt" used in section 5(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 refers to suit only and the proceeding under Article 27 of P.O. 7 of 1973 is not a suit and as such cannot be transferred to Artha Rin Adalat as per Section 9 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and that Artha Rin Adalat can try suit only and not may proceeding under Article 27 of P.O. 7 of 1973 - So, obviously the transfer of the Miscellaneous Case No. 16 of 1989 filed by the respondent No.2 Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation under Article 27 of P.O. 7 of 1973 to the Artha Rin Adalat, Narayangonj as per Section 9 of the Artha Rin Adalat Rin, 1990 and the disposal of the same by that Adalat have been illegal and therefore the decree passed in that Case by the Artha Rin Adalat, Narayangonj is without jurisdiction and as such a nullity.

 

Shahabuddin Ahmed -Vs- Joint District Judge & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 567.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section-2(ga) read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 ; Order-7 Rule-11

 

The nature of transaction between the petitioner-bank and respondent No.2 is completely a business and commercial transaction between the two schedule banks and not related to recovery of debt and the same cannot be treated as "loan as defined in section 2(ga) of the Ain, 2003 and the Artha Rin Adalat travailed beyond its jurisdiction in entertaining such suit as the Adalat has got no jurisdiction to deal with the matter other than to recovery of debt (*M) does not appear to be without substance as contended by the petitioner's council -Held; we are inclined to direct the Artha Rin Adalat to decide the points upon framing issues as to whether the amount claimed by the plaintiff-bank against the defendant-bank does come within the definition of loan (^M) as provided in section 2(ga) of the Ain, 2003 and the suit is barred by the law of limitation.

 

The City Bank Ltd. Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Anr 18  BLT (HCD) 116.

 

Section-4 Whether the Artha Wrin Adalat has jurisdiction to entertain any claim of House Building Finance Corporation

 

 

House Building Finance Corporation has its own provisions for realisation of loan under Article 27 of President Order 7 of 1972 and jurisdiction has been exclusively given to District Judge as such for realising its loans only the District Judge has jurisdiction, no other court, Artha Wrin Adalat being a subordinate court to District Judge has no jurisdiction to entertain any claim of House Building Finance Corporation.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section -4

 

It is an admitted fact that decree holder Janata Bank is a financial institute within the meaning of Section 2 of Artha Wrin Adalat Ain, 2003, Act VIII of 2003 and this Ain provides realisation of decreetal amount, as such, the execution case, as per provision of law, ought to be filed before Artha Wrin Adalat, not before Joint District Judge. It may be, as per sub-Section 4 of the Ain, Joint District Judge constitute Artha Wrin Adalat, but unless there be a notification through gazette, Joint District Judge can not act as Artha Wrin Adalat.

 

Nirman International Ltd. & Anr Vs. Janata Bank 20 BLT (HCD) 449.

 

Section-6

 

As it appears the High Court Division rejected the writ petition summarily holding that on or about 25.3.2007 Agrani Bank instituted Arlha Rin Suit No.22 of 2007 against the petitioner for recovery of its dues and the contents of the writ petition shows that the petitioner has not yet appeared in the said suit and that the said suit was instituted under a special law for recovery of the dues of the bank and the Rule Nisi is still pending for hearing and the subject matter of the rule appears to relate to renewal of loan facilities along with interest-free block loan money by installments subject to certain conditions and in the circumstances, the above writ petition, intended to stifle a suit lawfully instituted in Artha Rin Adalat, is wholly misconceived and also not bone fide and the order of status quo passed in aforesaid Rule cannot be deemed to restrain Agrani Bank from instituting and/or proceeding with the suit against the petitioner since no person, natural or artificial, can be injected or prohibited from suing another person, natural or artificial in a competent court of law and consequently this writ petition is summarily rejected—We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

Qamruzzaman Shah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 163.

 

Section 6(4) read with Section 19(6)

 

Held-In our view in both situations the case of the plaintiff must be considered on merit, even if he is absent. For such consideration, section 6(4) comes in aid of the court enabling it to consider the plaint, affidavit and the documents. However if the defendant is present his case is also to be considered in the either of the two modes of disposal, namely, by way of production of formal evidence through witness, or under section 6(4) i.e. without examination of witnesses. But if the defendant is also absent, it would be unfair to consider only the case of the absentee plaintiff and not of the absentee defendant. In our view, the case of both the parties should be considered, and not of the plaintiff alone.

 

Md. Enayetur Rahman & Ors Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 99.

 

Section 7

 

The   Court   must   examine   the   Process Server as Court witness

 

In the instant case, as we see, not only the money but also the land together with the building petitioners are loosing by stroke of pen of the learned Judge, as such, when the law is harsh then the learned Judge should be cautious before passing any judgment taking away life and property of an individual as to whether the litigant was aware of the proceeding and whether he was given proper opportunity to place his case. Whether summons were served or not it is the process server who could satisfy the court as such, before passing an exparte decree, since the law is harsh, the court must examine the process server as court witness. Law demand that before taking everything of a litigant and put him on the road, at least, from the judgment it could gather that before drawing the last blade at least court is justify that all the required procedure of law have been satisfactorily complied with. When the law is harsh the principle of natural justice will have to follow as an abandoned caution i.e. the Court acted in equity, in honesty and rightly.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors   20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section -7 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Order-5 Rule-20

 

After issuing of summons from the court if it is not served within 15 days or service return not received within 15 days, then on the matter of service of summons court is to take recourse of procedure of Rule 20 of Order V of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors 20  BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section-7 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-5 Rule-19

 

On a reading of the judgment and decree passed ex-parte against this judgment debtors we find that learned Judge did not consider whether the summons were served satisfactorily or not. It is to be borne in mind that Ain, 2003 is harsh law giving no chance to a loanee to do anything if it is found that he is a defaulting party. In the instant case, as we see, not only the money but also the land together with the building petitioners are loosing by stroke of pen of the learned Judge, as such, when the law is harsh then the learned Judge should be cautious before passing any judgment taking away life and property of an individual as to whether the litigant was aware of the proceeding and whether he was given proper opportunity to place his case.- Whether summons were served or not it is the process server who could satisfy the court as such, before passing an exparte decree, since the law is harsh, the court must examine the process server as court witness. Law demand that before taking everything of a litigant and put him on the road, at least, from the judgment it could gather that before drawing the last blade at least court is justify that all the required procedure of law have been satisfactorily complied with. When the law is harsh the principle of natural justice will have to follow as an abandoned caution i.e. the Court acted in equity, in honesty and rightly.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs Sonali Bank Ltd. & 0rs 19 BLT (HCD) 148.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003, (As amended) Section-7 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 ; Order-5 Rule-20

 

Held; Let it be known to all concerned if not already known that summons of a suit ought to he served, generally through process server and alternatively through registered post and as a last resort, through publication of notice/summons in the new papers.-Besides these steps would ensure due diligence in the service of summons from the office of the Court upon the defendants.

 

Sonali Bank Ltd. & Ors Vs. Prime Global Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 01.

 

Section-8

 

In the event of failure of the borrower to repay the loan the bank may proceed against both the borrower as well as the guarantor in accordance with the provisions of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 for recovery of the loan.

 

Md. Mojibul Hoque Vs Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 210.

 

Section -8(1) read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Order-1 Rule 10(2) Whether a Share holder of a Company is a necessary Party

 

A Suit under the Provisions of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 -A company incorporated under the Companies Act is a juristic person. A share-holder is not the owner of the company or its assets. The company itself owns its properties. A share-holder is only entitled to the dividends, if declared. On winding up however, after payment of its debts, he is entitled to participate in the distribution of its assets. The liability of a share-holder, whether he is the Chairman of the Board of Directors, or a director, is only to the extent of the face value of the shares he holds, nothing more than that. But if he guarantees repayment of the loan, enjoyed by the company or mortgages his property to the creditor, to ensure repayment of the loan by the company, then on the failure of the company to make such repayment, he becomes liable, not as a share-holder but as a guarantor or mortgagor or both as the case may be.

 

Mrs. Bakul Akter Vs. Bangladesh & ors 18 BLT (AD) 282.

 

Section -8(2) read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-11 Rule-14

 

It appears that the learned Judge, Artha Rin Adalat, by his order dated 25.02.2009, had already directed the plaintiff to file the documents as mentioned in the application dated 1.1.2009 but has not yet been fully complied with although the plaintiff is obliged to do so. If the plaintiff fails to comply, the learned Judge is to take appropriate measure in this respect in accordance with the provision of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 read with the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Mir Rashed AH Ahmed Vs Artha Rin Adalat, Dhaka & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 416.

 

Section-8(3)(4)(5) read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-11 Rule-14 Suit under provisions of Artha Rin Adalat, 2003

 

The plaintiff in order to get the decree has to come to the court with clean hands and as per order 11 Rule 14 of the Civil Procedure Code and under section 8(3), (4) and (5) the plaintiff is under obligation to file the original documents on the basis of which the decree is sought from the court. The Court will consider whether the plaintiff has complied with the provision of law and if the court finds that the plaintiff is avoiding to file the documents before the court in that case the court will certainly give direction upon the plaintiff as contemplated under the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and Civil Procedure Code failing which the court shall pass necessary order against the plaintiff for withholding the deeds/documents. The Court will not make any distinction whoever is the plaintiff.

 

Md. Shahrul Amin Colder Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 127.

 

Section 12

 

It appears that along with the mortgage of the property, securing the loan liable liability enjoyed the leave petitioner; a registered power of attorney has also been given in favour of the lending investment company authorizing it to sell the mortgaged property, to realize its due money. Apart from that Section 12 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 authorizes any lending bank to sell the mortgaged property without any intervention of any Court for adjustment of its due money from the borrower and then to proceed, in accordance with law, for realization of the balance amount, if any.

 

Md. Tariqul Islam Tareque Vs. Islamic Finance & Investment Ltd. & Anr 20 BLT (AD) 64.

 

Section-12(8)

 

As per  Section   12(8)  of the  Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and proviso thereof, which provided that in case of an auction sale held illegally or with irregularity, the same cannot be challenged. However, owner may sue the bank concern of any loss, if suffered because of such illegal or irregular auction sale.

 

Banesa Bibi Vs. The Senior Vic-President & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 507.

 

Section-19

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain imposes two preconditions on filing an application against the ex-parte decree of the Artha Rin Adalat. One of such preconditions is that 10% of the decreetal amount as security must be deposited and then the application must be filed within 30 days from the date of knowledge of the ex-parte decree. It is found in this case the present opposite parties preferred the revisional application against the ex-parte judgment and decree before the learned District Judge, Dhaka without depositing any amount in compliance with the provision of section 19 of the Ain, 2003. Since the defendant-judgment debtors had not deposited 10% of the decreetal amount for preferring the application or revision against the judgment and decree of the Artha Rin Adalat, in the eye of law the application / revision was incompetent and not maintainable.

 

Agrani Bank Vs. Mrs. Lutfunnahar Begum & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 453.

 

Section-20

 

Whether a Title Suit is maintainable to challenge the veracity, legality and propriety of a decree Passed by Aurtha Rin Adalat on the ground of fraud.

 

Held; There are two distinct opinions on question of law for filing of suit by aggrieved 3'd party against decree, either contested or exparte and there is divergent of opinion regarding the jurisdiction of civil court in challenging the decree obtained in Aurtha Rin Adalat. It is the case of plaintiffs that decree was obtained by practicing fraud then why the plaintiffs shall pay, at present 10% of decreetal amount, for challenging the decree which obtained by practicing fraud under section 32 of the Ain. The civil court under Section 9 of Civil Procedure Code has jurisdiction to try all suit/case of civil nature, as such, if the decree under challenge be tainted with fraud then why the plaintiff shall be over burden with compulsory payment of 10% of the decreetal amount as per Section 32 of the Ain. It is now become a practice on the banking side that without satisfying or verifying the title of the mortgage deed, Bank disbursed loan to the applicant like nine pins and put the 3rd party like present one in extreme danger. On the facts of the given case we are of the view that since Aurtha Rin Adalat Ain, being special law, learned Subordinate Jude was totally on wrong forum in entertaining Other Suit No. 146 of 2004 which not within his jurisdiction. We are of the view that if Aurtha Rin Adalat passed a decree it can be challenged within the four corner of the Ain itself. The question raised is of great public importance as such although we allowed the appeal but giving certificate to the plaintiff to settle the dispute finally before the Appellate Division.

 

Janata Bank Vs. Md. Sekandar & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 450.

 

Section -20 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Section -2(2) Decree

 

Judgment debtor took Tk. 3,00,0007= from decree holder Sonal Bank on 6.4.1988 and the last date for repayment of the loan was on 23.4.2003, i.e. for a period of 5 years. The judgment debtor petitioner took loan of Tk. 6 lacs from proforma defendant No. 3, Bangladesh House Building Corporation on 25.4.1984 to be repaid within 25 years which would expire on 25.4.2009.— This decree as we see is not tenable in law as the loan of Sonali Bank was to be paid in 5 years and that of House Building Finance Corporation in 25 years as such the loan of House Building Finance Corporation can not and should not be included in the instant suit for repayment.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors   20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section – 21 An application under Section 21 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 filed by the defendant with a prayer to dispose of the matter by A.D.R

 

Held; It is the Judge who is at liberty to dissolve the matter by settlement conference if both the parties so desire.

 

Radiant Garments Ltd. & Anr Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 159.

 

Section 26 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order XXI rule 83

 

Held; in our view Order XXI Rule 83 of the Code does not conflict with any of the provisions of the Ain. Therefore, we do not find any difficulty to hold that Order XXI Rule 83 of the Code will be applicable in an execution proceeding under the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003.

 

Major (Retd.) Rafiq Hasan Faruq Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 29.

 

Section-28

 

In the instant case in our hand the decree was passed on 29.8.2002 and as per section 28(1) execution case ought to be filed within 28.2.2003 but we find it was filed on 27.10.2003. If we give benefit of taking certified copy, then it appears that application for certified copy was filed on 27.1.2003 i.e. almost after 5 months, i.e. beyond the period for filing application for certified copy, which was obtained on 12.4.2003. Even from 12.4.2003 i.e. date of obtaining certified copy, the execution case was filed beyond period of limitation as 180"h day expired on 11.10.2003 but execution case was filed even thereafter on 21.10.2003 and legally it is more than 14 months from the date of ex-parte decree. As per provision section 28 of Ain, 2003, the court should dismissed the execution case and as per sub-section 3, from the date of dismissal, decree holder could file the decree for execution within l(one) year thereafter. But nothing has so far been done lawfully and it stands the execution case as filed was filed beyond the period of limitation but the learned Judge executed the decree through execution case and the property was sold which is totally in violation of special law. We find the entire proceeding of execution case is barred by limitation and without jurisdiction as such, from the date of filing of the execution case upto selling of the property in auction, entirely was done without jurisdiction, illegally, malafide and arbitrarily with a motive.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section-28

 

The execution case was filed beyond the period of limitation but the learned Judge executed the decree through execution case and the property was sold which is totally in violation of special law. We find the entire proceeding of execution case is barred by limitation and without jurisdiction as such, from the date of filing of the execution case upto selling of the property in auction, entirely was done without jurisdiction, illegally, malafide and arbitrarily with a motive. We find that execution case has filed illegally and no auction could be held on this execution proceeding.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs Sonali Bank Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT(HCD)148.

 

Section -28 read with Limitation Act, 1908 Article -182 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Section-48

 

Admittedly the decree in question was passed on 14.7.1984 and thereafter the 1st execution case was filed on 26.11.1984. This 1s' execution case was dismissed for default on 3.10.1992 and thereafter the execution case in question i.e. the 2nd execution case was filed on 8.2.1999. -the execution case in question has not been filed within the time prescribed in Article 182 of the Limitation Act and in section 48 of the Code of Civil Procedure. So, in this circumstances without any further discussion it may be said that the execution case in question being hopelessly barred by limitation is unlawful.

 

A.B.M. Ashrafullah Vs Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 343.

 

Section-28(3)

 

It appears from the record that the first execution case was disposed of on 4.8.2005 and the second execution case was filed on 1.11.2006 i.e clearly after expiry of one year from disposal of the first execution case. Section 28 (3) of the Ain provides a special limitation of one year for filing of the second execution case, and the limitation would start from the date of disposal of the first execution case. In view of the above quoted law of special limitation, the execution case in question is clearly barred by limitation. Since the execution case is illegal, the order passed therein issuing warrant of arrest against the petitioner is also illegal and as such the petitioner cannot be termed as a fugitive.

 

Mirza Ahsan Habib Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Anr  21 BLT (HCD) 370.

 

Section-28 read with Section 29 and Section-49(3)

 

High Court Division holding that the decree as passed in the suit directing payment of the decreetal amount in four equal installments within one year without mentioning any time-frame as to the mode of payment of the installments and thus holding that the period of limitation for filing execution case will commence from the date of expiry of one year is not proper. -Held; Since in the decree no specific date has been mentioned for payment of the installments and the judgment debtor were allowed to make the payment of the decreetal amount in installments, which is in fact a facility given to the judgment debtor to make the payment of the decreetal amount in part, instead of making the 'payment of the decreetal amount at a time, and there being no mention of specific dates for payment of the installments the judgment debtors were allowed to make the payment of the decreetal amount within one year in four installments and thus the mode of payment installments was made flexible. In the premises, in the instant case, we are of the view that the reasons given by the High Court Division, are in accordance with law and therefore no interference is called for.

 

M/S MM. Steel Ltd & Anr Vs. The Judge, First Artha Rin Adalat, & Anr 19 BLT (AD) 184.

 

Section-28 read with Section-60 The provisions of Section 48 of the Code of Civil Procedure is applicable in the instant case.

 

It appears that the instant Execution Case arises out the judgment and decree passed on 23.04.1991 and that the 1st execution case was registered as Execution Case No.37 of 1993 and thereafter two others Execution Cases being Execution Case Nos.12 of 1997 and 73 of 2000 were filed and in course of time those was dismissed and thereafter on 25.08.2003 the last Execution Case being Artha Rin Decree Case No.220 of 2003 was filed which has been renumbered as Artha Decree Case No.58 of 2004 filed in the Court of Artha Rin Adalat, Comilla. Section 48 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that where an application for execution of a decree is required to be filed, fresh application presented after expiration of 12 years is not maintainable. In the instant case it appears that the last Execution Case was filed beyond 12 years from the date of the decree in that the decree was passed on 23.04.1991 and the last Artha Decree Case No.220 of 2003 was filed on 25.08.2003, which thus show that the case has been filed after morethan 12 years and 4 months from the date of the decree. Thus it is hopelessly time barred. It also appears that the last Execution Case has been filed after the promulgation of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and as per Section 60 of the said Act any pending proceeding is to be proceeded with under the Provision of new Act and Section 28 of the said Act provides the limitation for execution case under the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and the maximum period of limitation of 6 years provided such execution case filed within one year from the disposal of the previous execution case filed under the said Act. In the instant case the provision of Section 28 cannot be applied inasmuch as the limitation of 6 years expired prior to promulgation of new Act, 2003. Be that as it may since the execution case has been filled after more than 12 years Section-48 of Code Civil Procedure is of no help.

 

Janata Bank Ltd.Vs. Gulneara Begum & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 170.

 

Section-29 Whether the limitation for filing an execution case would run during the time given in a decree

 

In the instant case, Artha Rin Suit was decreed exparte on 22.3.2005 and it was signed on 29.3.2005 giving 60 (sixty) days time to the judgment debtors to pay off the decretal amount in favour of the decree holder-bank (vide annexe:A-2 to the writ petition). In view of section 29 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, limitation of filing the application for execution of the decree in the present case, would run after expiry of 60 (sixty) days from 29.3.2005. Admittedly the present execution case was filed on 27.10.2005 and on calculation of limitation it appears to have been filed within 180 days after expiry of 60 (sixty) days from passing the decree. Therefore we do not find any substance in the submission of the learned Advocate for the petitioner on limitation.

 

Md. Nasurullah Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 492.

 

Section-31

 

The Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 does not empower the Artha Rin Adalat to pass an order to stay the proceedings of the execution case whatsoever.

 

M/S. Udayan Board Mills & Anr Vs Janata Bank & Anr 18 BLT (HCD) 266.

 

Section 32

 

Admittedly the property as described in the schedule of the plaint was sold in auction pursuant to the judgment and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat in Artha Rin Suit No.771 of 2004 -The 3rd party/petitioners have/had enough scope to file an application before the Artha Rin Adalat by way of filing an objection under section 32 of the Ain, 2003 against the execution of a decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat relating to the property.

 

Promoda Sundari Sen Kalyan Trust Vs. Momtaz Zafar Ahmed & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 355.

 

Section-32

 

The requirement of depositing 25% of decreetal amount is mandatory since the consequence of not depositing 25% of decreetal amount is stipulated in the said section 32 of the said Act to the effect that the said application shall be rejected.

 

Shamsuddin Ahmed & Ors Vs The City Bank Ltd. & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 296.

 

Section 32(2) Whether a third party is required to deposit any amount as required under provisions of section 32(2) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain.

 

The opposite party No. 1 being a third party and his property being plot No.4 of Block B of Shamoli Housing Estate was never mortgaged to Bank and thus is not the subject matter of Artha Rin Execution Case No. 1167 of 2003 and thus third party-petitioner is not required to deposit any amount as required under section 32(2) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003.

 

Syed Jobayer Hossen Vs Mary Janet Radrigues 19 BLT (HCD) 300.

 

Section-33

 

In the instant case, it appears that the auction of the concerned property of the petitioners was not sold in auction in pursuance of a decree or order as envisaged under Section 33 of the Ain but the auction was made prior to filing of the suit in pursuance to Sub­section 1 of section 12 of the Ain, as such, under Sub-section 4 of Section 12, the provisions of Section 33 are not mandatory.

 

Mrs. Zinnatul Ara & Ors Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 454.

 

Section-33

 

We have carefully examined the provisions of section 33 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 together with the decision reported in 15 BLT 425, it appears to us that unless the possession of the property is handed over to the auction purchasers, the execution case may not be finally disposed of.

 

Promoda Sundari Sen Kalyan Trust,Vs. Momtaz Zafar Ahmed & Ors  19 BLT (HCD) 355.

 

Section-33

 

On a reading of this section it is clear that 15 days notice is required before holding auction. It also appears that notice as to holding of auction is to be affixed in the Notice Board of the court and also at the locality notified by beat of drums. But nothing on record showing compliance of the provisions of this section. It appears that, auction was held not in accordance with law, as such, we are of the view that sale pursuance to this auction notice was done illegally.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors   20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section -33(5) Relating to confirmation of auction sale

 

Once an auction sale is complete no relief is available against such auction sale but the mortgagee may proceed against the mortgagor bank for any compensation, if it is proved that there was illegality in the auction sale.

 

Sonali Bank Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 84.

 

Section -33(7)

 

Section 33(5) of the Ain, 2003 provides that after due compliance of sub sections (1) (2)(3) and (4) of section 33 of the Ain, 2003 if it is not possible to sale the mortgaged property in auction, then the right and possession of the mortgaged property will be vested upon the bank. Consequently at the instance of the bank the Adalat rightly by exercising power conferred under section 33(7) of the Ain 2003 passed an order conferring title of the petitioner's mortgaged property upon the bank and directed to issue a certificate to that effect.

 

Mst. Setara Begum Vs Al-Arafah Islami Bank Ltd. & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 503.

 

Section-34 Natural Justice

 

The requirement of natural justice depends on the facts and circumstance of a case, the nature of inquiry, the rules under which the Court or Tribunal is acting, the subject matter that is being dealt with and many other aspects. In the present case the petitioner being a defaulter, loanee was sued upon under a special law and after service of summons the suit was decreed exparte against him. On subsequent commencement of the execution proceedings, a notice under section, 30 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain was also served upon him and an attempt was made to sell the property, that was given as collateral against the loan. Under the circumstance, the writ petitioner was supposed to know the legal consequence of the execution proceedings. In such a case no more notice to show cause was necessary before issuance of warrant of arrest against him, for compliance of natural justice.

 

Md. ArifGaffar Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 584.

 

Section -34(2)

 

whether the Provisions of civil imprisonment as laid down in section 34(2) of the Ain 2003 is applicable in respect of the substituted heirs of mortgagor or guarantor. On close analysis of the Provisions of section 34 (2) of the Ain 2003, we find that the substituted heirs of the principal debtors enjoy the right and privilege contemplated in the aforesaid provisions. The legislature promulgated Arlho rin Adalat Ain 2003 (Act VIII of 2003) for speed recovery of debts form the defaulting borrowers. The intention of the legislature is also to protect the right of substituted heirs of the principal debtors. Although such protection was not expressly provided in respect of the substituted heirs of mortgagor or guarantor in section 34(2) of the Ain 2003, but from the combined reading of the Ain 2003 as a whole, we find that the intention of the legislature is also to protect the right of the substituted heirs of mortgagor and guarantor. Therefore, we hold that the Provisions of section 34(2) of the Ain 2003 are squarely applicable in respect of the substituted heirs of mortgagor and guarantor.

 

Md. Akramuzzaman @ Babu Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 496.

 

Section-34(9)

 

Held; It appears that an attempt to sell the mortgaged property was made before disposal of the Miscellaneous Case under Order XXI rule 58 of the Code of Civil Procedure. But after allowing the Miscellaneous Case and amendment of the schedule of the Execution Case, no subsequent step whatsoever was taken to sell the remaining portion of the mortgaged property. Under the circumstances, we hold that the decreeholder bank was required to take step afresh for selling the mortgaged property after amendment of the schedule of the execution case, failing which, it cannot be said that section 34(9) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 was complied with.

 

Arun Kumar Sutradhar & Anr Vs. Joint District Judge & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 489.

 

Section-37(l) Whether the Provisions of Section 37(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 is mandatory

 

The 2nd Artha Rin Execution Case No.90 of 2008 was filed on 23.1.2008 while the warrant of arrest was issued on 1.3.2009 beyond the statutory period of limitation 150 days. Section 37 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 provides that an Artha Rin Execution Case shall have to be disposed of ithin 150 days. -Held; section 37(1) of the Ain, 2003, though is a part of Special Law but the same having not provided with for any consequence, is to be treated as directory and not mandatory.

 

Md. Abdus Soblian Vs Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 203.

 

Section -41 read with Limitation Act, 1908

 

Held; we are of the view that the petitioner bank may file any appeal without depositing any money but within 30 (thirty) days as prescribed and admittedly the appeal has been filed beyond the prescribed period of 30 (thirty) days. The Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 being special law and the limitation for preferring appeal having been provided by the special law, the provisions of Limitation Act, is not available.

 

Rupali Bank Ltd. Vs Md. Hamayet Uddin & Anr 17 BLT (HCD) 60.

 

Section-41 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-21 Rule-90

 

Since the judgment debtors did not challenge the decree rather they want to maintain the decree and prayed for setting aside the auction sale so that they can maintain their property, it is our considered view that, 50% of decreetal amount is not required to be filed as required under section 41 of the Act.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs Sonali Bank Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 148.

 

Section-41 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Order-21 Rule-90

 

In the instant case, it appears that, judgment debtor petitioners did not challenge the decree rather they want to maintain the decree but they have challenge the auction proceeding. The appeal is from an order passed on an application filed under Order XXI Rule 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure. When a decree has been passed, exparte or contested, the judgment debtor can challenge the decree by filing an appeal and as per law he must deposit 50% of the decreetal amount. But, when the judgment debtor challenge the auction sale keeping the decree in tact and want to maintain the decree then he is not required to deposit 50% of the decreetal amount as the judgment debtors are not aggrieved by the decree. Since the judgment debtors did not challenge the decree rather they want to maintain the decree and prayed for setting aside the auction sale so that they can maintain their property, it is our considered view that, 50% of decreetal amount is not required to be filed as required under section 41 of the Act.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs. Sonali Bank Ltd & Ors   20 BLT (HCD) 452.

 

Section - 41 read with Section – 26 Whether auction purchaser is not the one contemplated under Section 41(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain.

 

Held; the procedure for filing an appeal under this provision has been restricted to the decree holder or the judgment debtor and the use of expressions "WR W can not be extended to a third party who has accrued an interest or right in the subject matter of the decreetal property after passing of the decree who is not a party to the proceedings of the suit.

 

Advance Sweater Industry Ltd. Vs. Mohiuzzaman Chowdhury & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 17.

 

Section 41 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order 21 Rule 89

 

Held; In case of passing an order or decree in a Artha Rin suit, if the decreetal amount is up to Tk.50,00,0007-, an appeal has been provided before the learned District Judge. But in case of an appeal other than the one provided in Section 41, as per provisions of the Civil Courts Act the District Judge has pecuniary jurisdiction to entertain an appeal against judgment and order of the learned Joint District Judge of a suit or proceeding which does not exceed Tk.5,00,000/-Since the third party petitioner filed the application under Order 21 Rule 89 which having been allowed, an appeal is maintainable under Order 43 Rule l(j).

 

Advance Sweater Industry Ltd. Vs. Mohiuzzaman Chowdhury & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 17.

 

Section-44A(l) read with Civil Courts Act, 1887 Section-18 read with General Clauses Act, 1897

 

Section-3(15)

 

The word "District Court" as used in section 44A(1) is primarily to be interpreted with reference to the definition of the " District Court" as given in section 2(4) of the Code. On consideration of the plain meaning of "Principal" as given in the Oxford Dictionary read with section 24 of the Code; and section 3(15) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 we are of the opinion that the "District Court" referred to in section 44A(1 ) of the Code means the Court of the District Judge under section 3(1) of the Act and no other Court though under section 18 of the Act concurrent jurisdiction had been given to the District Judge and the Joint District Judge in respect of all original suits cognizable by Civil Courts. Therefore, under section 44A(1) of the Code certified copy of the decree in question is to be filed only in the Court of the District Judge and in no other Court.

 

AL-Arafah Islami Bank Ltd. Vs. M/S . Nobel Enterprise 19 BLT (HCD) 463.

 

Section-44A(l) and Section 39(2) Execution of a foreign decree

 

Admittedly the decree-holder under section 44A(1) of the Code filed the certified copy in the Court of District Judge and ultimately it was transferred to Court of Joint District Judge for execution. After combined reading of the aforesaid provisions particularly sections 44A(1) and 39(2) of the Code, we are of the view that the joint District Judge has the jurisdiction to execute the foreign decree whose certified copy was filed in the Court of District Judge and subsequently transferred to him.

 

AL-AraJah Islami Bank Ltd. Vs. M/S . Nobel Enterprise 19 BLT (HCD) 463.

 

Section-47(3)

 

Artha Rin Adalat below by its impugned order holding that the provision of section 47 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 is not applicable in the case inasmuch as in this case the suit was decreed ex-parte vide ex-parte order and decree dated 4.10.2003 (decree singed on 13.10.2003) and the final decree was drawn up on 01.01.2004, that is, long before the provision of section 47(3) came into force—Held; On a perusal of the said order together with the provisions of section 47 of the Ain, 2003, it appears that sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 47 of the Ain, 2003 has put an embargo on a filing suit claiming interest more than 200% of the loan granted and sub-section (3) of section 47 of the Ain, 2003 has made this embargo affective from one year after coming of this Ain, 2003 into force, that is, from 1st May, 2004. Our, view is therefore, that the Artha Rin Adalat rightly on assigning sound reason rejected the application under section 47 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 by Us order No. 16 dated 17.10.2004.

 

Agrani Bank Vs. Mrs. Lutfunnahar Begum & Ors   19 BLT (HCD) 453.

 

Section-57 There is alternative remedy

 

The appellants filed their application dated 04.02.2008 for setting aside the sale under section 57 of the Artha Wrin Adalat Ain, 2003. Such application under section 57 of the Artha Wrin Adalat Ain is not maintainable. Section 57 of the said Ain confirms the inherent power of the court. Section 57 of the said Ain is not any enabling provision for setting aside of sale. Section 57 of the said Ain reiterates the provision of section 151 of CPC, which just confirms the inherent power of court. Inherent power of the court cannot be exercise when there is specific provision in CPC and other law.

 

Shamsuddin Ahmed & Ors Vs The City Bank Ltd. & Ors 21 BLT(HCD)296.

 

Section-57 Application for exemption of interest and deposit the remaining Principal amount

 

Petitioner had taken loan amounting to Taka 65,0007= only and already paid off Taka 30,0007= in favour of the bank. Because of his illness and unbearable hardship he could not adjust the remaining loan. Meanwhile the Head Office of Sonali Bank Ltd. adopted a policy to exempt interest to the defaulting borrowers of particular categories and communicated its decision to all concerned by a circular dated 24.3.2010. Since the petitioner fell within the set category, he filed an application on 15.4.2010 to the executing Court for exemption of interest and deposit the remaining principle amount (vide annexe-C to the writ petition). The executing Court by its order dated 15.4.2010 rejected the said application. —Held; Since the petitioner had filed his application before the executing Court on 15.4.2010 i.e within 31.12.2010 on service of a copy upon the learned Advocate for the decree holder-bank, and the prescribed time for taking/giving exemption of interest has expired during pendency of the Rule, the petitioner should be allowed to file an application afresh to the respondent-bank, and the bank should also dispose of the same within the scope of circular dated 24.3.2010.

 

Aslam Khan Vs. Artha Rin Adalat, & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 483.

 

Section-57 An application for release of the auctioned property on Payment of the decreetal money

 

Held; the learned Judge of the executing Court allowed the judgment debtor to deposit the decretal amount beyond the scope of law and created a false hope in his mind that he may get back his property. Such an illegal order of the executing Court would not create any right for redemption of the mortgaged property in favour of the judgment debtor. This is a well settled principle of law that after confirmation of sale of any mortgaged property in due process of law, the mortgagor loses his all rights and interest over the property.

 

Md. Nasurullah Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 492.

 

Section-57 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Section-152

 

The learned judge as a matter of fact did not dispose of the application, filed before him on merit. Although the petitioner had claimed to have paid some amount out of the decreetal amount of money but the Artha Rin Adalat did not dispose of the said application on merit -Held; we feel it proper to direct the learned Artha Rin Adalat, Second Court, Bagerhat to dispose of the application under section 152 of the of the Code of Civil Procedure read with section 57 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 filed by the petitioner on 18.6.2005 on merit giving a chance to the decree holder to convert the same if he is so advised, within 4(four) weeks from the date of receipt of this order.

 

Abdul Wahab Moral Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT(HCD)120.

 

Section -57 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order -1 Rule -10

 

High Court Division hold that the contention of the learned advocate of the petitioner that having the first charge over the mortgaged property the petitioner is a necessary party in the subsequent suit filed by the respondent No. 2, is not tenable in the respondent No.2 and to adjudicate this issue the presence of the petitioner is not necessary at all and the petitioner can make prayer to the Artha Rin Adalat concerned at proper stage for satisfaction of its decreetal amount first from the proceeds of the sole of the mortgaged properties in question and the Artha Rin Adalat concerned at proper stage for satisfaction of its excretal amount first from the proceeds of the sole of the concerned may consider that prayer under section 57 of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003. -Held we are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

The City Bank Limited Vs. Judge, Artha Rin Adalat & Ors  17 BLT (AD) 209.

 

Section-57 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-1 Rule-10 Not an issue as to infavour of the applicant

 

The learned Artha Rin Adidat, after hearing, by judgment and order dated 18.6.2007, rejected the above application for addition of party holding that the responi lent Nos. 3 and 4 did not take any loan from the petitioner and the petitioner is also not a guarantor against the loans so taken and so the petitioner is not a necessary party in the above suit and further in the above suit it is not an issue as to in favour of which bank the respondent No.3 mortgaged the land in question as security and if mortgaged when and the main issue in the above suit is whether the petitioner will get Tk.1,11,2626/-from the respondent No.4 and further the respondent No.2 will get decree only to the extent of claim as they may prove and accordingly in the above suit there is no scope to decide the claim of the petitioner. Being aggrieved the petitioner moved the High Court Division in writ jurisdiction and after hearing the High Court Division summarily rejected the writ petition holding that the contention of the learned advocate of the petitioner that having the first charge over the mortgaged property the petitioner is a necessary party in the subsequent suit filed by the respondent No.2, is not tenable in the eye of law as in the subsequent suit the only issue for adjudication is whether the respondent No.4 owes any money to the respondent No.2 and to adjudicate this issue the presence of the petitioner is not necessary at all and the petitioner can make prayer to the Artha Rin Adalat concerned at proper stage for satisfaction of its decreetal amount first from the proceeds_ of the sole of the mortgaged properties in question and the Artha Rin Adalat concerned may consider that prayer under section 57 of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 -We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a coirect decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

The City Bank Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 78.

 

Section - 57 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order XXI Rule 83

 

The Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 specially the provisions regarding execution under chapter VI of the Ain and found that Order XXI rule 83 of the Civil Procedure Code does not conflict with any of the provisions of the Ain. Therefore, we do not find any difficulty to hold that Order XXI rule 83 of the Civil Procedure Code will be applicable in an execution proceeding under the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003.

 

SDS Dairy Limited Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 15.

 

Section-60

 

The Suit was instituted on 03.04.03 and on 25.10.05 the leave Petitioner filed the leave petitioner filed an application under Sections 12(2) and 57 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 praying for a direction upon the plaintiff-bank for sale of the pledged goods and to adjust the claim amount with the sale proceeds of the pledged goods and fix the actual claim amount and that the Artha Rin Adalat by its order No.44 dated 25.10.2005 rejected the application observing that examination of the witnesses are being in progress and that the provision for sale of the pledge goods before filing of the suit was not in the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and the said provision has been provided in Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and that the suit has been filed prior to promulgation of Artha Rin Adalat, 2003 and thus there is no bar in proceeding with the suit without sale of the edged goods and adjustment of the sale proceeds thereof with the claim amount in the suit. -Held on consideration of the facts and circumstances of the learned Advocate as well as provision of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 particularly Section 12(2) and 12(6) read with Sections 57 sod 60 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and the reasonings given by the Artha Rin Adalat as appearing in impugned order, we are of the view that the High Court Division has correctly interpreted the law and passed the order in accordance with law, which do not call for any interference.

 

M/S. United Leather International Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors  17 BLT (AD) 204.

 

1506

House Rent Control Act, 1991

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD) 508

Case Year: 1991

Subject: House Rent Control

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

House Rent Control Act, 1991

 

Section -27 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Order 7 Rule -ll(d)

 

The proceeding under House Rent Control Act, 1991 is a summary one. The application under the said Act can not be termed as a plaint. What a plaint should contain has been provided by Order VII Rule 11 of the Code. Order VII Rule 11 of the Code prescribed the circumstances when a plaint would be liable to be rejected. In the cause title of the application of the said case, I find provisions of Sections 13 and 28 and relief is prayed for under section 27 of House Rent Control Act, 1991 have been invoked. In such circumstance the application of the said case is not a plaint. The application of the petitioner made under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejection of such application is wholly misconceived.

 

Md. Mainul Haque Bhuyan Vs Md. Akkas Miah 17 BLT (HCD) 508.

1507

Human Rights and Environmental Law

Citation: 21 BLT (AD) 240

Subject: Human Rights and Environmental Law

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Human Rights and Environmental Law

 

(i) The human rights system should be strengthened by the incorporation of environmental concerns, enabling the expansions of the scope of human rights protection and generation of concrete solutions for cases of abuses;

 

(ii) Human rights and environmental law are two distinct, independent spheres of rights;

 

(iii) The environment and human rights are inextricably linked-the serious impact of a degraded environment on human health have to be adjusted in our policies and cultural practices to reflect understanding;

 

(iv) Human rights and human dignity within its broader social, economic and cultural context by contributing to those who are actively engaged in the environmental, conservation and public health areas should be protected.

 

Metro Makers & Developers Ltd Vs. BELA 21 BLT (AD) 240.

1508

Income Tax Ordinance, 1984

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD) 217

Case Year: 1984

Subject: Income Tax

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Income Tax Ordinance, 1984

 

Section -160(1) read with Section 35(3)

 

In the  instant  case,   it  appears  that  the assessee applicant, a Bank Company filed return under Section 75 with the audited statement of accounts and thus complied with the requirement of Section 35(3) of the Ordinance and in the assessment order there is no finding whatsoever that the method of accounting employed by the assessee applicant is not regularly employed or that the method is such that true income of the assessee applicant can not be properly deduced therefrom. Thus, in the absence of any such finding by the DCT the authority was not at all authorized by law to reject the accounts of the assessee. The Tribunal totally ignored the legal aspect of the case. So where the provision of law of Section 35(3) of ITO, 1984 is clear that without pointing out any defect whatsoever in respect of the audited accounts or without recording any findings relating to method of, accounting the DCT shall not make any order of disallowance.

 

One Bank Ltd. Vs. The Commissioner of Taxes 17 BLT (HCD) 217.

1509

Inland Shipping Ordinance, 1976

Citation: 17BLD(AD)136, 22 BLD(AD)1O.

Subject: Inland Shipping

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Inland Shipping Ordinance, 1976

 

Section—52

Section 52 of the Shipping Ordinance, 1976 gives special powers to the Marine Court notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure to try any case under Chapter 1V for shipping casualties. The Marine Court exercises its jurisdiction as a criminal Court and it can award compensation. An order to pay compensation shall have the effect of a Civil Court decree and sub-section 3 of section 52 only speaks that it is recoverable as if it is a decree of a civil Court.

Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Corporation Vs Al-Falah Shipping Lines Ltd. and others, 17BLD(AD)136

Ref: Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Corporation Vs. Nazma Transport Company. 45 DLR 152.

 

Section—54

Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority (Time and Fare Table Approval) Rules 1970

RuIe—15(i)(c)

As this Rule empowers the Authority in giving direction to an owner to ply his vessel on any route as per timetable approved temporarily in his favour in the public interest and in such case the Authority may waive the requirements of any or all the Rules, the noncompliance of certain Rules will not make the timetable illegal and without lawful authority.

Sirajul Hoque and others p. Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority and others, 22 BLD(AD)1O.

 

1510

INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ORDINANCE, 1961

Citation: 4 BL D(HCD)309, 12BLD (HCD)79

Case Year: 1961

Subject: INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ORDINANCE, 1961 (XXXIII of 1961)

 

Section—30

Removal from Service of a teacher of a secondary school—Whether can be removed without drawing up a proceeding against him?— The law contemplates a proceeding for removal of a teacher and if there is a proceeding, it needs be initiated and conducted in accordance with the provisions of law, namely that in the proceeding drawn against him, he must be given a reasonable opportunity of controvert the allegations made against him and be allowed to lead evidence in support of his case and if that is not done, the proceeding would be coram non jaundice.

Sardar Ahmed Ali Vs. G.M. All Baksha and others, 4 BL D(HCD)309

 

Section—39(2)

Boards power—The Board has power to make any regulation for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Ordinance generally though some particular subjects are enumerated in section 39(2), which are not exhaustive. Moreover section 39(2)(ii) empowers the Board to frame regulations for granting and withholding of certificates.

Although no regulations for withdrawing certificate, in particular, has been framed, the Board is not powerless if unfair means is found to have been adopted and it is detected after the result is published and the certificate is granted as the law has given it the power to do so.The Board is the sole authority to maintain and preserve discipline to hold examination properly and to take action in accordance with the relevant Ordinance and the concurred Regulations after holding enquiry where necessary. Such proceeding is domestic and administrative one and is not judicial or quasi-judicial proceeding and as such the Code of Civil Procedure or the Evidence Act has no application thereto and the Enquiry Committee is under no obligation to allow the student concerned to cross-examine any witness.

It is sufficient if the student is given opportunity of being heard and to explain his case against the allegation on which the proposed punishment is based.

Kazi Nafiul Majid Vs. The Secretary and Higher Secondary Education Board, Jessore and others, 12BLD (HCD)79

Ref: A.I.R. 1961 (All) 301; A.I.R. 1948 (Jammu and Kashmir) 40—Cited.

 

1511

Law Reforms Ordinance, 1984

Citation: 20 BLT (AD) 23, 18 BLT (HCD) 62

Case Year: 1984

Subject: Law Reforms

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Law Reforms Ordinance, 1984

 

Section-6

 

An 'owner' must be an owner in the legal sense in his own lawful right.

 

The High Court Division having found that in the instant case the predecessor of the petitioners purchased the case land and constructed his house thereon but the prayer of the defendant-respondent for pre-emption of the said land was allowed by the learned Munsif (now Assistant Judge) which was affirmed upto the Appellate Division and consequently, the petitioners lost their ownership of the suit land and so they are no longer "owners' of their homestead and as such they do not come within the ambit of section 6 of the Ordinance. -We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Abdul Hai & Anr Vs. Chan Banu Bibi 20 BLT (AD) 23.

 

Law on pre-emption

Principle of waiver, estoppel and acquiescence

 

Held; In a case of pre-emption, mere offer to purchase and denial thereto will not be sufficient to establish that the pre-emptor's claim of pre-emption will be barred by principle of waiver, acquiescence and estoppel and there must be some fact as to the pre-emptors dealing in the sell procedure in question so that the prudent man can arrive at the decision that in future the person i.e. the pre-emptor will not claim his statutory right of pre-emption in the matter of the sale in question or when it becomes clear that the pre-emptor is in loco parent is with the pre-emptee and he plays a definite part in bringing about the disputed transfer, the principles of waiver acquiescence and estoppel will come in full play and the pre-emptor will loose his right of pre-emption by his lapses.

 

Rais Ali & Ors. Vs. Mst. Hajera Khatun & Ors 18  BLT (HCD) 62.

 

1512

Limitation Act, 1908

Citation: 19 BLT (HCD) 01, 17 BLT (HCD) 203, 17 BLT (HCD) 360, 21 BLT (AD) 150, 21 BLT (HCD) 216, 21 BLT (HCD) 531, 20 BLT (HCD) 131, 21 BLT (HCD) 179, 21 BLT (HCD) 01, 20 BLT (AD) 282, 18 BLT (HCD) 196, 21 BLT (AD) 192, 21 BLT (HCD) 336, 17 BLT (AD) 78

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Limitation

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Limitation Act, 1908

 

Suit for recovery of money

 

If the defendants fail to make payment within the stipulated time, the plaintiff is required to file the suit for recovery of the outstanding loan with interest within a period of three years from the date of expiry of the last date of payment of installments as per exhibit-'Cha'. The last date for payment expired on 30th June 1973 and the period of limitation reckoned from that date which expired on 30lh June 1976. Therefore, the plaintiffs claim for recovery of money is hopelessly barred by limitation.

 

Agrani Bank Ltd. Vs Habib Oil Mills (Bangladesh) Limited & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 01

 

Section -5

 

It is a settled principle of law that a litigant should not suffer for negligence of the tadbirkar or the lawyer as on them the litigant has to depend. A party wishing to take advantage of section 5 of the Limitation Act, 1908 must satisfy the court that it had not been negligent or had been prosecuting the case with due diligence and care. Excusing delay has to be approached from the point of view of the petitioner's conduct.

 

Goutom Mudi & Ors Vs. Moron Mudi & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 203

 

Section -5 Delay of 1428 days

 

In the instant case the petitioners were fully depended on their tadbirkar and for his negligence the said delay of 1428 days was caused in preferring the civil revision against the impugned judgment and decree. It appears to me that the delay caused was not for the fault of the petitioners rather it Was due to tadbirkar of the petitioners. For that reasons the petitioners should not suffer inasmuch as the door of justice should not shut out to them. The petitioners instituted the suit for declaration of title and recovery of khas possession and accordingly they should get a chance to agitate their grievance before this court.

 

Goutom Mudi & Ors Vs. Moron Mudi & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 203

 

Section -5

Revisional application -The delay of 1155 days

 

There is a long standing practice that a revisional application is to be filed within the period of 90 days prescribed by law for appeal and that this Court may in its discretion entertain an application made for condonation of delay in a suitable case where there is no negligence or laches on the part of the petitioner.

 

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs Engineer M.M. Shawkat Alt &Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 360

 

Section-5

 

Leave was barred by 68 days -The appellants Advocate Mr. Abu Backkar entrusted his clerk Md. Abdur Razzaq to check up the fortnightly and the daily cause lists which was his usual duty but unfortunately the said Abdur Razzaq missed the case in the list. Consequently the Criminal Revision was heard by the High Court Division in the absence of the Appellants Advocate and that the Rule was discharged on 5.8.74. The appellants came to know of the disposal of the Rule from their surety Mr Mohan Kanti Ghose, Advocate, Judge's Court, Chittagong on 7.11.74 who received a notice from the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Chittagong on the same date for producing in Court in obedience to the direction of the High Court Division. Prior to that date the appellants had no knowledge of the disposal of the Rule as contended by the learned Counsel for the appellants.

 

Held; Having gone through the application for condonation of the delay and heard the learned Counsel who was very frank in his explanation we were inclined to take a lenient view, in the special facts and circumstances of the case, for the delay which was not due to any fault of the appellants but was due to carelessness and irresponsibility on the part of the Advocate's clerk and the Advocate upon whom trust and responsibility were reposed. Accordingly, the delay was condoned.

 

Abul Hossain & Anr Vs. Farrok Ahmed & Anr 21 BLT (AD) 150.

 

Section- 5

 

Due to the official formalities required to be observed in different Government machineries there is a delay of 843 days to file revisional application which is bonafied and unintentional -The delay of 843 days in filing the revisional application under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil procedure is hereby condoned -relied on 21 DLR 910 and 1986 BLD (AD) 180.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Md. Ataur Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 216.

 

Section-5

 

Application for condonation of delay of 843 days to file revisional case by the Government

 

Due to the official formalities required to be observed in different Government machineries there is a delay of 843 days to file this revisional application which is bonafide and unintentional and if the aforesaid delay of 843 days is not condoned the petitioners will suffer irreparable loss and injury as contended by the petitioner's counsel -Held; In view of the submissions made by the learned Assistant Attorney General in support of his application for condonation of delay has got merit and deserves consideration, relied on 21 DLR page-910 & 1986 BLD(AD)180.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh -Vs- Md. Ataur Rahman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 531.

 

Section - 5 read with Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation Order, 1973 (P.O. No.VII of

1973); Article 27(10)

 

Whether an application under Section 5 of the Limitation Act is maintainable in an appeal under the provisions of House Building Finance Corporation Order, 1973

 

No doubt the Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation Order, i 973 is a special enactment but only for being a special enactment it can not be said that the applicability of the Limitation Act is prohibited in filling appeals under this Order. -We are of the view that in the enactment where there is no prohibition for entertaining any application filed under the provision of the Limitation Act is made, the court can condone the delay in filing appeals entertaining the application for condonation of delay under the provision of the Limitation Act.

 

Laila Begum & Anr Vs. House Building Finance Corporation & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 131.

 

Section-5 read with Section-14

 

Delay of 2050 days in filing the appeal against the Order passed in Arbitration Case—for filing of an appeal from an award of arbitrator a time limit has been made under Section 7(f) of (Emergency) Requisition of property Act, read with Rule 9(16) of (Emergency) Requisition of Property Rules, 1948.

 

Held; In the instant case we find the award was passed by the Arbitrator and appeal there from lies to the High Court Division and there is a special limitation provided under (Emergency) Requisition of Property Rules, 1948, for preferring appeal, that is 60 days and relying on the decision reported in 43 DLR (AD)28, we are of the view that there being a special limitation provided in the law, we are unable to condone the delay and admit the appeal as prayed for in the rule.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. A.Y. Mashiuzzaman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 179.

 

Section -14

 

With due diligence another civil proceeding

 

The facts revealed shows the petitioner is misled by wrong advice. It is quite clear from the chronological happenings of the case that petitioner was always prosecuting with due diligence another civil proceeding with the same cause of action. The wording in Section 14 of the Limitation Act is not only "from defect of jurisdiction" but also "or other cause of a like nature". The case in hand comes within the later wordings of Section 14 of the Act. All the facts of the case if taken into a narrow campus than it is seen that petitioner honestly in good faith, in due case and attention for relief travel from pillar to post in whatever forum as was advised render the Court to apply provision of Section 14 of the Limitation Act.

 

Abdur Rashid Akanda Vs. Md. Raisuddin & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 01.
