Section - 14 read with Section - 29(2) with The Local Government (Upazilla Parishad) Ordinance, 2008 Section - 13(4) with The Local Section - 65(3)

 

Evidently, the High Court Division was not correct in coming to the finding that the Local Government (Upazilla Parishad) Ordinance, 2008 and the Local Government (Upazilla Parishad) Rules, 2008 being special laws and the period of limitation prescribed under section 13(4) of the Ordinance and Rules 65(3) being different from that prescribed in the Limitation Act, any proceeding thereunder is excluded from the operation of Section 29(2) read with section 14 or from any other provisions of the Limitation Act, and therefore, the benefit of Section 14 or any other provisions of Limitation Act is not available in computing the period of limitation in filing any election tribunal case or election appeal therefrom and thus in holding that the election appeal filed before the Election Appellate Tribunal was barred by limitation. We make it clear again that the provisions contained in sections 4, 9-18 and 22 of the Limitation Act are applicable in determining the period of limitation prescribed by any special law for filing any suit, appeal or application where such special law does not expressly exclude the applicability of the provisions of these sections of the Limitation Act. The remaining provisions of the Limitation Act shall not apply in any proceeding under any special law.

 

Abdul Waltab Sheikh Vs. Md. Kamal Hossain & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 282.

 

Article-44

 

In order to challenge a transfer of the property of the minor by the guardian, the minor can file a suit within 3 years of his attaining majority.

 

Most. Alom Taj begum & Ors Vs Sree Nimai Chandra Roy 18 BLT (HCD) 196.

 

Article-113

 

9/2 years had elapsed from the time of contract till the filling of the suit

 

In our view the period of limitation was never crossed as the action of the Vendor from time to time effectively gave a new lease,of life to the agreement -In the facts of the instant case it is clear that, although it was stipulated in the agreement that the contract for sale should be completed within a period of one year, the breach of such condition was sanctioned by the payment of the liquidated damages in the sum of Tk.5,00,000/-. Therefore, time was definitely not of the essence of the contract. It must also be noted that the one month's ultimatum is an unilateral stipulation and it cannot be said that the Purchaser agreed to it. Even if the period of one month from 8.7.93 is taken to be the basis for performance of the agreement, then failure on the part of the Purchaser to conclude the sale in that period makes the agreement voidable. Even if at that stage time became of the essence of the contract, it is apparent that the Vendor did not take any action on or after 8.8.93 to cancel the agreement. On the contrary, her acceptance of Tk.15,00,000/-of the consideration money on 15.02.94 has negated the aspect of time being of the essence of the contract and effectively extended the period of limitation. Moreover, according to section 55 of the Contract Act( if it was the intention of the parties that the time should not be of the essence then the contract does not become voidable, but the promisee becomes entitled to receive compensation. Hence, it is our view that the Vendor is only entitled to receive compensation for the delay in performance of the agreement by the Purchaser.

 

Mahua Khair Vs. Amena Begum All Ispahani 21 BLT (AD) 192

 

Article 113 read with Transfer of Property Act, 1882 Section-53A

Held; As it has been noticed already in the present case the plaintiff-opposite parties entered into bainapatra (Ext.l & Ext.6) to purchase the suit land and got delivery of possession of the suit land immediately after execution of the bainapatra in their favour. The provisions of section 53A of the Transfer of Property Act have created a bar against enforcement of any right of the transferor in respect of the property in question which he would have apart from the agreement. In view of the provisions of section 53A of the Act the vendor or his successors in-interest are prevented frpm dealing with the property provided the vendee has performed his part of the contract and in pursuance thereof has taken possession of some immovable property. I, therefore, find there is a good deal of substance in the contentions raised by Mr. Abul Kalam Mainuddin, the learned Advocate for the opposite parties that in the facts and circumstance of the case the present Plaintiff-opposite parties are entitled to protect there own possession by invoking the provisions of section 53 A of the Transfer of Property Act and by instituting a suit as has been done in the present case and thus the provision of section 113 of the Limitation Act has no manner of application in the present case

 

Ayesha Khatun Vs Nasiruddin Ahmed & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 336

 

Article-164

 

Miscellaneous case for restoration of the original file -Trial Court Dismissed the Miscellaneous case holding that the same is barred by limitation -Held; The High Court Division did not meet the reasonings of the trial Court and also did not consider that the miscellaneous case is barred by limitation on the ground of not filing the miscellaneous case within 30 days from date of the knowledge of original defendant i.e. on 12.12,1983. It further appears that the appellant though sufficiently established about the service of summons of the execution case upon the respondent No.l, the High Court Division, without considering the provision of Article 164 of the Limitation Act allowed Miscellaneous Appeal No.613 of 1991 setting aside the ex-parte decree. So the judgment and order of the High Court Division can not be sustained;

 

Abdus Samad Khan Vs. Sree Dulal Chandra & Anr 17 BLT (AD) 78.

1513

Local Government (Pourashava) Act, 2010

Citation: 21 BLT (AD) 332, 19 BLT (AD) 17

Case Year: 2010

Subject: Local Government (Pourashava)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Local Government (Pourashava) Act, 2010

 

Section-31(2) read with Section-32

 

Held; an order once takes effect, it cannot be stayed.  If an order of suspension takes effect, it cannot be stayed till the same is finally disposed of on merit,

 

Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Sarwar Kamal 21 BLT (AD) 332

 

Section-31(3)

 

Held; It should be noted that an order once takes effect, it cannot be stayed. If an order of suspension takes effect, it cannot be stayed till the same is finally disposed of on merit.

 

Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Sarwar Kamal 19 BLT (AD) 17.

1514

Local Government (Pourashava) Election Rules, 2010

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 422.

Case Year: 2010

Subject: Local Government (Pourashava) Election

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Local Government (Pourashava)

Election Rules, 2010

 

 

Rule-61(3)

Ad-interim order of the Election Tribunal

 

Held; Rule 61(3) provides the final decision of the Election Tribunal after taking evidence of the parties and after conclusion trial. The adintcrim order passed by the Election Tribunal is not same as stated above. The final decision passed after conclusion of trial is appealable under order XLIII rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure and as such it is revisable under section 115(2) or 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Md. Aminul Haque Vs. Md. Abdul Quddus Mollah & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 422.

1515

Local Government (Upazilla Parishad) Ordinance, 2008

Citation: 18 BLT (HCD) 289

Case Year: 2008

Subject: Local Government (Upazilla Parishad)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Local Government (Upazilla

Parishad) Ordinance, 2008

 

Section-13(4)

 

The world connotes that a final order passed after conclusion of trial of the case and not any order passed during trial.

 

S.  M.  Ahsan  Kabir  Vs  Election  Appellate Tribunal & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 289.

1516

Mohammedan Law on Marriage

Citation: 20 BLT (AD) 143, 17 BLT (HCD) 22

Subject: Mohammedan Law on Marriage

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Mohammedan Law on Marriage

 

Whether non-registration of the marriage under Mohammedan Law makes the marriage illegal or irregular or non-existent

 

A doctrine of Muslim Marriage - Held; The recognized custom of all sects are that a marriage is solemnized by a person conversant with the requirements of the law who is designated for the occasion, the Kazi. Two other persons, formally appointed for the purpose, act on behalf of the contracting parties, and the terms are usually embodied in a deed of marriage called 'Kabin-nama'. Under the Sunni law what is required more is that a declaration should precede the  acceptance, in order to demonstrate conclusively the intention of the parties. A marriage contracted without witnesses is invalid. But a marriage contracted at a place where compliance with it is impracticable, the marriage would not be void on that ground. Where it is possible to obtain testimony, and the ceremony of marriage has gone through without the presence of witnesses to attest its performance, it may be declared to be invalid. The condition of testimony, therefore, is not so essential that it can not be dispensed with. Once the marriage is consummated and the parties have cohabited, the contractual defect is removed; and the marriage is declared to be legitimate.

 

Mst. Momtaz Begum Vs. Anowar Hossain 20 BLT (AD) 143

 

up by her father in his own residence since her age 3 months when the parents become separated from each other and the father appears to be careful about the education of his daughter and even today the daughter appears happy with the company of her father. In such situation I hold the view that the daughter Amena Begum will remain under the custody of her father as usual, but the father should allow Mst. Ratna Begum (the mother) to see her daughter on the occasions convenient to both of them and the father will also allow the mother to present any goods which will not be detrimental to the mental and physical health of the daughter and to develop her character.

 

Md. Nurul Huda Moulavi Vs Most. Ratna Begum and Ors.  17 BLT (HCD) 22

1517

Mohammedan Law, Wakfs

Citation: 20 BLT (AD) 143

Subject: Mohammedan Law, Wakfs

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Mohammedan Law, Wakfs

 

Section - 156 (D.F. MuIIa) Wakf by immemorial user

 

Held; though the previous Khatian of the land was recorded to be "Peer's Dargabari" but the land at present appears to be nal land duly cultivated by the plaintiff. The nature and character of the suit land having been changed and the Government also treated the same as cultivable land and considering the true state of affairs leased out the same to the plaintiff on permanent basis. - There is no substance in this application for interference with the impugned judgment.

 

Md. Nafaruddin Mollah Vs. Md, Serajuddin Khan & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 143

1518

Money Laundering Protirodh Ain, 2009

Citation: 19 BLT (AD) 104,

Case Year: 2009

Subject: Money Laundering Protirodh

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Money Laundering Protirodh Ain, 2009

 

Section 2 & 4(2) read with Money Laundering Prevention Act, 2002 Sections-2 & 13 read with General Clauses Act, 1897; Section-6

 

In the instant case the alleged offence was disclosed under the provisions of Section 2 (>) (W) (Wf) of the Ain of 2002 but there was no pending case or proceeding under the Ain of 2002 when the said Ain of 2002 or the Ordinance of 2008 was repealed. Rather the FIR was lodged under Sections 2 and 4(2) of the Ain of 2009 on 26.10.2009 long after the repeal of the Ain of 2002 by the Ordinance of 2008 and also after the enactment of the Ain of 2009 on 24.02.2009. It appears that according to the FIR occurrence took place from 01.01.2003 to 31.05.2007 when the Ain of 2002 was in operation. The Ain of 2009 was given retrospective effect from 15.04.2008 when the Ain of 2002 was repealed by the promulgation of the Ordinance of 2008. The facts and circumstances of the instant case is very unique in its nature wherein an offence committed under the repealed Ain of 2002 and the FIR was lodged much long after the repeal of the said Ain when the Ain of 2009 came into effect with the intervening Ordinance of 2008 which had already been repealed before the lodging of the FIR— since the alleged offences were committed during the operation of the Ain of 2002, the punishment for the said offence as provided under Chapter IV of the said Ain be applicable. Therefore, there is no bar to hold trial of the petitioner under provisions of the ACC Act, 2004 for the commission of the offence alleged to have been committed under the Ain of 2002 and the question of prejudice does not arise at all. The case be treated as one instituted under the Ain of 2002.

 

Tarique Rahman Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 104

1519

Municipal Corporation (Tax) Rules, 1986

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 367

Case Year: 1986

Subject: Municipal Corporation (Tax)

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Municipal Corporation (Tax)

Rules, 1986

Rule 7 (13)

 

Whether the decision of the appellate authority is final.

 

The Dhaka City Corporation, respondent No. 1 is bound to accept the decision of the appellate authority, namely Additional Deputy Commissioner (General) Dhaka Division, Dhaka and is equally bound to accept the Municipal tax as decided by the appellate body. The Dhaka City Corporation is hereby directed to accept the Municipal Tax from the petitioner in accordance with the decision of the appellate authority.

 

Minnat-E-Mowla & Anr Vs Dhaka City Corporation & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 367.

1520

Muslim Family Law

Citation: 20 BLT (AD) 173.

Subject: Muslim Family Law

Delivery Date: 2018-07-12

Muslim Family Law

 

Custody of a Minor girl Admittedly the daughter has been brought Presumption of jointness of family in the Muslim Law

 

We are of the view that the High Court Division was not in error in not interfering with the finding of the lower appellate Court as to nature and character" of the auction sale and the purchase made in the name of the wife of the defendant No.l. This fact clearly demonstrates that the auction was not genuine, rather it was intended to deprive the minors, that is, the Plaintiff Nos. 1 and 2. It is seen from the judgment of the lower appellate Court that no attempt was made by the defendants to show that the defendant No.2 i.e. wife of the defendant No.l had independent source of income and that she purchased the land put to auction owned by the plaintiff Nos. 1 and 2, who were the co-sharers, with her own money. Since it has been established that on the death of father of the plaintiff Nos. 1 and 2 as well as defendant No.l i.e. the sons of Faiz Uddin Sheikh, the defendant No. 1 was looking after the property left by the father of the plaintiffs and the defendant No. 1 and in that background it was observed by the lower appellate Court that after the death of Faizuddin Shiekh e.i. father of the plaintiff Nos. 1 and 2 and the defendant No.l they were not in separate mess rather in one mess and the income of the property left by Faizuddin Sheikh was in the common fund of the plaintiffs and the defendant No.l. In the background of discussions made hereinbefore we are of the view there is no reason to take exception to the observation of the lower appellate Court as to jointness of the Muslim family since the said observation is supported by the fact brought on record by the parties, particularly the plaintiffs. It may be mentioned there may not be presumption of jointness of family in the Muslim Law, but the fact has been established that after the death of Faizuddin Sheikh, father of the plaintiffs and defendant No.l, the members of Faizuddin family was in one mess and the income of the property left by Faizuddin was in the common fund of the plaintiffs and the defendant No.l and in the background of the said fact the lower appellate Court observed that by the money of the joint fund of the plaintiffs and the defendant No. 1 the auction purchase was made. It was not established that the defendant No.2 had any independent source of income or she had money from known source and by that money the land put to auction was purchased by her or the defendant No.2, wife of defendant No.l made auction purchase by the money earned by her.

 

Tarn Miah Sheikh & Ors Vs. Alek Sheikh & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 173.

1521

Muslim Marriage and Divorces (Registration) Act, 1974

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 105

Case Year: 1974

Subject: Muslim Marriage and Divorces (Registration)

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Muslim Marriage and Divorces

 (Registration) Act, 1974

 

Section- 4 read with Muslim Marriage and Divorces (Registration) Rule, 1975

 

Rule - 5A Direction to issue licence on regular basis

 

In view of Rule 5A if a Nikah Registrar acts for at least three years on temporary basis then subject to Rule 10 he will be eligible to be licenced on regular basis. Since the petitioner was appointed on 27.1.2004 by the respondent No.l and he successfully performed his functions. Hence the petitioner is entitled to have a permanent Nikah Registrar licence under Rule 5A.

 

Md. Nazrul Islam Talukder Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 105.

 

1522

Muslim Marriages and Divorces Registration Rules, 1975

Citation: 8 BLC 34, 10 BLC (AD) 134, 9 BLC (AD) 248

Case Year: 1975

Subject: Muslim Marriages and Divorces Registration

Delivery Date: 2018-05-20

Muslim Marriages and Divorces

Registration Rules, 1975

 

Rules 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 18, 19 & 34—

 

Petitioner has challenged the second proviso to section 4 of the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Act, 1974 and the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Rules, 1975 particularly Rules 3, 4 and 10 and the order dated 3-2-2000 appointing respondent No. 6 as Nikah registrar for three Unions of his Nikah Registration area and also to strike down the second proviso to section 4 of Act No. LII of 1974 and the Rules framed thereunder.

 

The existing Rules of 1975 is inept, in cohesive, inadequate, ambiguous and ineffective having tendency to pick and choose policy, arbitrariness, absurdities and require to be remodeled and redrafted in the given situation and demand of time with sound thought and modern look with reference to Articles 10, 28(2) 29(2) 27, 31 and 40 of the Constitution and the warrant of Procedure. Thus the Muslim Marriages and Divorces (Registration) Rule, 1975 is struck down being unconstitutional.

 

Ruhul Mannan Helali. vs Bangladesh 8 BLC 349.

 

Rules 4, 5 and 10—

 

The Government is empowered to extend, curtail or otherwise alter the area of jurisdiction of a Nikah Registry subject to the maximum area provided in the Rules.

 

Kazi Imamuddin Bhuiya vs Government of Bangladesh and others 10 BLC (AD) 134.

 

Rule 10—

 

On the establishment of the Gafargaon Municipality the area which was previously a part of No. 4 Saltia Union Parishad became the area of the Gafargaon Municipality. The appointment of the appellant as Nikah Registrar was in respect of new area which had no reference to or connection with the area wherein the respondent 1 is acting as Nikah Registrar. The appellant has been appointed as Nikah Registrar of the area of the newly established Municipality. No area of the respondent 1 wherein he is acting as Nikah Registrar after the formation of the Gafargaon Municipality has been curtailed.

 

Saiful Islam (Md) vs Md Abdur Rahim and other 9 BLC (AD) 248.

1523

Negotiable Instrument Act (Amended) 2006

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD) 325

Case Year: 2006

Subject: Negotiable Instrument

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Negotiable Instrument Act

(Amended) 2006

Section -138 A

 

On perusal of section 138A of the Act as amended on 09.02.2006 and on consideration of the whole enactment, it appears to us that the Negotiable Instrument Act being a procedural law, there is no bar in giving its effect retrospectively and more so by the Act there is no difference in awarding sentence if any upon the accused.

 

Jahid Faisal & Anr Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 325.

1524

Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949

Citation: 17 BLT (AD) 75,

Case Year: 1949

Subject: Non-Agricultural Tenancy

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949

 

Section-24

 

It is the uniform view that character/nature of  particular   land   is   to   be   determined keeping in view the purpose for which tenancy was created or that settlement was made or that purpose for which lease was taken. It is also the uniform view that the land within the municipal area is pre-emptable under section 24 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act.

 

Abdul Khaleque Vs. Abdul Noor & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 75.

 

Section-24 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950; Section-96

 

Since the land sought to be pre-empted is admittedly in the rural area and that it having not been established that the settlement of the land sought to be preempted was taken for the purpose other than agricultural purpose we are of the view that the High Court Division was not in error in discharging the Rule which was obtained against the judgment of the appellate Court dismissing the Miscellaneous case filed under section 24 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act upon arriving at the finding that the land sought to be pre-empted is agricultural land.

 

Abdul Khaleque Vs. Abdul Noor & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 75.

1525

Non Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1950

Citation: 19 BLT (AD) 238

Case Year: 1950

Subject: Non Agricultural Tenancy

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Non Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1950

 

Section-24

 

A particular land though situated in the rural area, can be classified as non-agricultural land, because it depends upon the nature of the holding.

 

Abdul Shahid Chowdhury & Anr Vs. Kazi Khurshed AH & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 238.

1526

Partition Suit, 1893

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 276, 17 BLT (HCD) 470, 17 BLT (HCD) 01

Case Year: 1893

Subject: Partition Suit

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Partition Suit, 1893

 

Simple Partition –Maintainability

 

In a suit for partition the Court will no doubt consider the title of the plaintiff to the suit land in some details. In this case I have already noticed that the title of the plaintiffs predecessors/vendors to the partible property is not clear, the suit for simple partition is not maintainable without declaration of title.

 

Ibrahim Alt Vs Alhaj Md. Nazim Vddin Akhter & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 276.

 

Section-4

 

The very purpose of Section 4 is to protect and preserve the sentiment of the co-sharers and attachment to their ancestral property and also preserve the privacy of the members of the undivided family.

 

Sreemati Sobita Rani Bonik Vs Sree Gouranga Prasad Acharjee & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 470.

 

Section-4 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-9 rule-9(1) read with Limitation Act, 1905

Article -120

 

It is an admitted legal position that there is no limitation for filing a suit for partition and unless there is a total ouster of the right of a co-sharer from the ejmali property he shall be deemed to be in ejmali possession of the properties sought to be partitioned, if not partitioned earlier by metes and bounds. It need not be discussed by wasting so many pages that the cause of action for filing a suit for partition arises when the other co-sharer or co-sharers refuse the plaintiff to give his due share from the ejmali property. And the cause of action for filing a suit for partition being continuing and recurring it shall continue unless the other co-sharers give the plaintiff his due share partitioning the suit land by metes and bounds.

 

Hormuz Sikder & Ors Vs Ayub All Sikder & Ors  17 BLT (HCD) 01.

1527

Power of Attorney Act, 1882

Citation: 21 BLT (AD) 144, 21 BLT (HCD) 303

Case Year: 1882

Subject: Power of Attorney

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Power of Attorney Act, 1882

 

Presumption-onus of proof

 

Whether the High Court has erred in rejecting the defendants' contention that the lease and the kabala dated 16-1-56 (which, he conceded, no doubt constituted a single transaction of sale) were executed by Abu Mohammad Kasem without authority, since the power of attorney in the latter's favour could not be brought on record.

 

Held; In view of the presumption attached to the said endorsements, it was for the defendants to prove that Abu Mohammad Kasem was not Sarat Shahi's constituted attorney. Mr. Behter AH could not dispute that the defendants made no attempt to discharge this onus.

 

Md. Shahed Faruque Vs. Mst. Matiunnessa Khatun & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 144.

 

 

Power of Attorney

 

On scrutiny of the power of attorney exhibit 28 it further reveals that one Nesar Hossain executed the same in favour of (a) Faizul Haque (b) Syed Mokarram Hossain (c) Sree Sushil Kumar Roy (d) Mazed Ali (e) Syed Jamshed Hossain Chowdhury. However, from the exhibit 16 deed in question it is crystal clear that out of 5 Attornee's only Mr. Sushil Kumar executed the alledged deed dated 28.8.65, not only that on scrutiny it further divulged from the power of attorney exhibit 28 that there is no schedule in the power of attorney regarding any land as described in the schedule of the suit as well in exhibit 16. So, we find that although the Court below in its judgment did not discuss on the merit about right and title of the plaintiff in respect of schedule Kha and Ga of the Other Suit No. 8 of 2003 but from the above discussions and considering the plaintiffs title deed exhibit 16 it manifest that the plaintiff has failed to prove his title by producing successive title deed as has been claimed in the plaint which was executed by Sushil Kumar Roy is nothing but a deed without sanction of law as because in the power of attorney there is no schedule of the land as described in exhibit 16, the alleged deed of the plaintiff. So, we can safely hold that the plaintiff has failed to prove his plaint case in respect of not only Ka schedule land but also Kha and Ga schedule land by producing valid documentary evidence.

 

Syed Jamshed Hussain Choudhury Vs Govt of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 303.

1528

Powers of Attorney Act, 1882

Citation: 20 BLT (HCD) 162

Case Year: 1882

Subject: Powers of Attorney

Delivery Date: 2018-08-01

Powers of Attorney Act, 1882

[Act No. VII of 1882]

 

Section – 2

 

The petitioners have challenged the Gazette Notifications through writ petition No.3210 of 2001 in respect of the land of plot Nos. 15, 35, 36, 41, 57, 79, 84, 117 and 17. The petitioners have instituted the instant writ petition through their constituted power of attorneys, namely M. A. Awal and Sudhir Chandra Sarker. On perusal of the power of attorney (Annexure-A) it appears that the petitioners did not execute power in respect of the land recorded in plot No.57. In that view of the matter our considered opinion is that the petition in respect of the land recorded in plot No.57 does not deserve any consideration   in   connection   with   W.   P. No.3210of2001.

 

Mongol Chandra Sarker & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh 20 BLT (HCD) 162.

 

1529

Practice and Procedure

Citation: 17 BLT (AD) 21, 17 BLT (AD) 26., 17 BLT (AD) 231, 17 BLT (HCD) 209, 17 BLT (HCD) 386, 18 BLT (AD) 266, 18 BLT (HCD) 51, 18 BLT (HCD) 62, 18 BLT (HCD) 80, 18 BLT (HCD) 83, 18 BLT (HCD) 123, 18 BLT (HCD) 127, 18 BLT (HCD) 188, 18 BLT (HCD) 194, 18 BLT (HCD

Subject: Practice and Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-07-31

Practice and Procedure

 

Plea of defect of Party

 

It appears that both the trial Court and the appellate Court concurrently held that the plaintiffs have title and possession in the suit land and they were subsequently dispossessed but the trial Court dismissed the suit on the ground of defect of party but the appellate Court did not agree with the trial court on this point and held that the suit is not bad for defect of Party. -The High Court Division further held that the plea of defect of party is to be raised at the earliest stage of the suit. Otherwise such plea should be deemed to have been waived. Accordingly, the High Court Division held that the suit was not bad for defect of parties. -Held; we are of the view that the High Court Division upon correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Gazi Rafiqul Islam @ Manzu Vs. Mosharaf Hossain & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 21.

 

 

Application for restoration of the Rule

 

[The Rule was discharged for default on 10.01.2007 for non-compliance of Court's order for taking steps for engaging new Advocate as the Advocate earlier engaged died. It is on record that after the death of engaged Advocate, a notice in From N-10 was served upon the petitioner but the Tadbirkar Mr. Joydev Chandra Saha not take any step as he was suffering from blood pressure. -The High Court Division opined that in the application for restoration it was asserted that the tadkbirker Mr. Joydev Chandra Saha had been bed ridden for about six months and as such, he could not come to Dhaka to take necessary steps after service of notice in From N-10 upon the petitioners. But this assertion does not hold good in that the petitioners slept over the matter even after expiry of six months on the ground of alleged illness the Tadbirkar. -Held; we are of view that the High Court Division upon correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Joy Dev Saha & Anr Vs. Haridas Saha & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 26.

 

Practice and Procedure

Violation of Principle of natural justice

 

The principle of natural justice is to be observed in a proceeding affecting a person or property or other rights of parties concerned. Accordingly, the Court, thus, always adds rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice in the exercise of power under the Constitution and other concerned laws of the land and invariably interferes in case of absence of any prior notice and a failure to provide any chance of hearing and thus always interferes with such order passed thereunder for any such violation of principle of natural justice.

 

Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Idrisur Rahman & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 231.

 

A deed if not acted upon the period of limitation of such deed cannot be considered to shut down legitimate claim of a claimcnt.

 

Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Nawab All & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 209.

 

Practice and Procedure

Meaning of Article 94(2) of the Constitution

 

The honorable Chief Justice of Bangladesh is a person designata and the term Supreme Court of Bangladesh shall always include the honorable Chief Justice of Bangladesh and all other Judges of the Supreme Court within the meaning of Article 94(2) of the Constitution to constitute the Full Court.

 

Sontosh Kumer Saha Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

A Division Bench can always differ with the decision and opinion passed by another Division Bench of the High Court Division of Bangladesh Supreme Court as it has the concurrent jurisdiction.

 

Sontosh Kumer Saha Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

After noticing that the writ petitioner is a fugitive from justice, the learned Judges directed the writ petitioner to surrender before the Court on before 18lh January, 2009 but by the same time, by a subsequent order dated 11"' January, 2009, directed the law enforcing agencies not to apprehended the petitioner or to harass him before that date, but in the next order on 18lh January, 2009, they observed that the writ petitioner surrendered before them on 11th January, 2009. This observation is self contra directory with their earlier order dated lllh January, 2009. Nothing was mentioned in this order that the learned Judges of the High Court Division accepted the appearance of the writ respondent, rather he was directed to surrender "in any court of law till 18.1.2009". - Held; This sort of orders of the learned Judges of the High Court Division sitting in the highest Court of the Country, are deprecated. If the Judges of the highest Court ignore the established principles of law, such exercise of powers in such circumstances would be deleterious to judicial discipline and in that event, the administration of criminal justice will be jeopardized. Accordingly this sort of practice disapproved.

 

Anti-Corruption Vs. Dr. H.B.M. Iqbal Alamgir &Ors. 18 BLT (AD) 266.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Brajangana had been acted as shebait for certain period and being in such position, she could appoint her successor but she did not appoint her successor and in that view of the matter, when she left the premises without exercising her power, the office of the shebait had automatically reverted to the plaintiff who is the only heir of the founder and such aspect of the case had not been noticed by the trial Court. The view of this court finds support in the case of Radha Nath Mukherjee Vs. Saktipada Mukherjee, (1936)58. All.

 

Deities Vs. Biresh Ranjan Dhar & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 51.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

In the instant case, the pre-emptee has claimed that offer was made to the pre-emptors to purchase the lands before the sale but the pre-emptors denied. There is nothing on record that the pre-emptors took active part in the transaction of sale of the lands in question when the seller sold the lands to the pre-emptees - in the instant case there is no evidence that in the matter of transaction of the lands in question by the impugned deed the pre-emptors took any active role.

 

Rais Ali & Ors. Vs. Mst. Hajera Khatun & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 62.

 

Practice & Procedure

 

Cause of Action in Title Suit For the ascertainment of the cause of action the Court is required to read the plaint in its entirety-relied upon

 

56 DLR (AD) 210 Abdul Aziz Vs Md. Anisur Rahman Babul & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 80.

 

Practice & Procedure

 

The principles enunciated by the Appellate Division in the case reported in 4 MLR (AD) 257 (Judgment delivered on 5lh January, 1998) cited on behalf of the accused petitioner though has not been taken into notice in the latte decision reported in 6 MLR (AD) 297 (judgment delivered on 4lh July, 2001) yet it is a settled proposition of law that the later decision of the Apex Court will prevail over its earlier decision.

 

Ruhul Amin Babul Vs The State & Art 18 BLT (HCD) 83.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Whether Partial Partition is maintainable

 

Question of hotch Potch -Held; Partial Partition is maintainable and it will not fail for non conclusion of plot No.296,297 and 300 since the plaintiffs' and the defendants' claims are confined only to plot No.298 and 299 and that they have no interest in plot No.296, 297 and 300. It may be noted that the defendants could not also show that for nort inclusion of said 3 plots the defendants or any of the parties in the suit will be prejudiced. Thus I am of the opinion that the suit as framed is also maintainable.

 

Mst. Saleha Begum & Anr Vs Md. Mizaniir Rahman & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 123.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Artha Rin Suit -Court's discretion Power

 

It has been found from the order No.36 that the learned Judge directed the plaintiff to file the document in court but by order 41 the court has exempted the plaintiff from filing the remaining documents in court which appears to us the derogatory to his own order.

 

Md. Shahrul Amin Colder Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 127.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

If the Government wants to stop the Petitioner from leaving the country, then it must start a specific criminal case against him and get a custodial order by a court of law under the laws of the land.

 

Atlanta Delawar Hossain Sayedee Vs Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 188.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

The Executing Court can not go behind the decree or claim in Execution Case and it has no jurisdiction to amend or modified decreetal amount or interest or legal expenditure.

 

House Building Finance Corp. Vs Mst. Amena Begum 18 BLT (HCD) 194.

 

Practice & Procedure Consent by the Parties

 

Our Appellate Division consistently held that the jurisdiction of Courts is created by statutes and that it can neither be conferred nor taken away by agreement or concession of parties to the litigation or of their lawyers.

 

Smith Co-Generation (Bangladesh) Pvt. Ltd. Vs Bangladesh & Anr 18 BLT (HCD) 261.

 

Practice and Procedure

Establish right of receiving the Rastrio Sammani Bhata

 

It is well settled principle of law that once the privilege is given that cannot be taken away without due process of law and this principle is applicable in this case as no opportunity was afforded to the petitioners before curtailing the opportunity that is the stopping  of the  state  honorarium  to  the petitioners.

 

Md.   Bazlur Rahman   &   Ors Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 279.

 

Practice & Procedure

 

The decree passed by the appellate court below as affirmed by the revisional court shall be binding upon the contesting defendants as well as upon the plaintiffs and the application filed by the petitioner of the miscellaneous case in any way shall not affect the decree so far as it relates to the contesting defendants and the plaintiffs.

 

Hafizuddin & Ors Vs Md. Idris Mia & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 308.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

When an interim Order of stay should be 'be stay'

 

In the instant case, the operation of the impugned memo dated 20.10.10, placing the petitioner under suspension, was stayed by the High Court Division, after it was effective 4 days earlier. -Under such circumstances, let the operation of the interim order of stay passed by the High Court Division on 24.01.2010 in Writ Petition No. 8558 of 2010, be stayed till disposal of the writ petition, pending before the High Court Division.

 

Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Sarwar Kamal 19 BLT (AD) 17.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Waiting for'90 minutes

 

Since the learned Advocate for the petitioner neither placed nor pressed the Civil Petition for the last 90 minutes inspite of our best endeavours and repeated requests, we have no other alternative but to dismiss the said Civil Petition for leave to appeal as not being pressed.

 

Begum Khaleda Zia Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 14.

 

Practice and Procedure Connected application

 

The Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal is dismissed as not being pressed. The connected application for mandatory injunction/status-quo would follow the result of the Civil Petition. It is accordingly rejected.

 

Begum Khaleda Zia Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 14.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

As is expected of an Advocate The learned Advocate for the appellant placed before the Court available reported cases in different law journals, without hesitation, deciding either way, whether a Revenue Officer disposing of the mutation application is a Court or not or in other words as to the question whether a Revenue Officer disposing of an application for mutation acts as a Court or not and ultimately having had noticed the decision reported in 55 DLR(AD) 125 submitted that he feels difficulty to proceed with the appeal. The learned Advocate by submitting so has acted in a manner as is expected of an Advocate appearing before the highest Court of the country.

 

Most. Sahera Khatun & Ors Vs. Abdur Rahim Sk. & Anr  19 BLT (AD) 21.

 

Practice and Procedure Setting aside the ex-parte decree

 

Law is now settled that a separate suit can be filed for setting aside the ex-parte decree on the ground of fraud practiced in obtaining the said ex-parte decree upon misleading the Court or preventing the defendant from placing his case before the Court.

 

Govt of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Osimuddin 19 BLT (AD) 119.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Whether transfer document is necessary, after the suit decreed on the basis of solemana

 

Since the sons of alleged benamder Srish Bhattacharjee filed solenama in Title Suit No. 102 of 1958 brought by Baidyanath for a declaration that Srish Bhattacharjee is benamder and the suit having been decreed on compromise on the basis of solenama filed by Dhiren and Biren, sons of Srish Bhattacharjee, in our view, no transfer document is necessary in favour of Baidyanath by Dhiren and Biren.

 

Khandoker Ansar Ahmed & Ors Vs. A.T.M. Monsur Ali Mallik & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 129.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Since the laws are special laws having provide for special remedies as such case or suit of one jurisdiction can not be heard and disposed of by another jurisdiction because in that case one of the jurisdiction become disqualified and subordinate to the other jurisdiction which can not be done or it is not the intents of the legislature. One special law can not be subordinate to other subordinate law. When there is conflict of law then it will be decided on the basis of the law under which the suit or proceeding initiated. It may be further said cases under Bankruptcy Act are proceeding where cases under Artha Rin Adalat Ain are suits.

 

I.F.I.C. Bank Ltd Vs Eknabin and Co. & Ors (Civil) 19 BLT (HCD) 34.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Whether in a suit for specific performance of a contract possession is not relevant

 

Appellant Division of the Hon'ble Supreme Court of Bangladesh held that in the suit for specific performance of contract only point for consideration is whether the unregistered deed of sale is genuine document or not and if it is found to be genuine document the suit of the plaintiff should succeed.

 

Sultan Miah Vs Mst. Roksana Begum & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 37.

 

Practice and Procedure

Records rights standing in the name of a Hindu Widow

 

It is a settled position of law that a widow as a limited heir is not a mere tenant-for-life, but is owner of the property inherited by her, subject to certain restrictions on alienation. The whole estate is vested in her for life and she represents it completely and her position is that of an owner. So long as she is alive no one has a vested interest in the succession. It is similar in incidents to an absolute estate. As long as a Hindu woman is found in possession of a piece of land either taken by her as life estate or as absolute interest she remains to be the owner of the land. In the circumstances, preparation of record of rights in her name remains to be a matter of course. It has nothing to do with the nature of her title to the land, limited or absolute. Nor such record of rights per se raises any presumption in favour of stridhana.

 

Motiur Rahman Bahadur Vs Hemanta Kumar Skill 19 BLT (HCD) 78.

 

Practice and Procedure Stridhana

 

Record of rights standing in the name of a Hindu widow, even if found to have been prepared in her name during lifetime of her husband, does not ipso facto raise any presumption in favour of stridhana.

 

Motiur Rahman Bahadur Vs Hemanta Kumar 19 BLT (HCD) 78.

 

Practice and Procedure

Adverse Possession

 

Adverse possession must be actual, visible, exclusive, hostile, notorious and confined during the time necessary to create a bar under a statute of limitations and it must be adequate in continuity, publicity and extent.

 

Md. Waseq Ullah & Ors Vs Razia Khatun & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 194.

 

Practice and Procedure

Whether arbitration miscellaneous proceeding is a civil matter or not.

 

Held; the Arbitration Miscellaneous Case is, no doubt, a civil proceeding.

 

Shahnawaz Akhand Vs. The State & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 349.

 

Practice and Procedure

Suit for specific performance of contract

 

It appears from the judgment that the learned Judge acted in emotion rather judiciallv in decreeing the suit. Since there is no baina then what is to be performed by defendanat No.l. Learned Judge found defendant No. I acted mischievously as such, decree should be passed. If that be so, then on exhibit-1 which, as it appears to be a money receipt, plaintiff ought to file a suit for recovery of money, not a suit for specific performance of a contract.

 

Roshanally Mohamed Hajri & Anr Vs A.K.M. Zakir Hossain & Anr  19 BLT (HCD) 318.

 

Practice & Procedure

 

It is reported that there is only one Joint District Judge at Nilphamary as such we have no option but to withdraw the suits i.e. Other Class Suit No.26 of 2003 and Other Class Suit No.4 of 2006 from the Court of Mr. Abdur Rashid Miah, Joint District Judge, 1M Court. Nilphamari and place it at the disposal of the learned District Judge, Nilphamary for dealing the same in accordance with law.

 

Md. Enamul Haque Vs. Md. Ekramul Hague &Ors   19 BLT (HCD) 383.

 

Practice and Procedure

Requirement of suit for Causing Damages

 

In a suit for causing losses or damages, the plaintiff is required to give specific instance of damages suffered by him and the exact loss caused to him for which the defendant is liable to be called upon to answer his demand which is lacking in the present case. Furthermore, on a careful perusal oi" the averments of the plaint, it appears to us that the nature of allegations as brought against the defendant-petitioner for causing loss amounting to Tk. 1,56,569.38 to the plaintiff-opposite party do not constitute the cause of action for filing the instant money suit.

 

Md. Azizul Haque Vs Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd 19 BLT (HCD) 306.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Responsibility of forgery - suppressing the fact It appears that the petitioner earlier filed Writ Petition No.5284 of 2007 against the refusal to extend the period of the governing body of the said Madrasha by the Madrasha Board which fact has not been stated in the instant writ petition. It furthei' appears that the photocopy of the Memorandum of Association of the said foundation, which has been annexed with the writ petition, does not tally with the original copy of the said Memorandum of Association, as sent from the office of the Registrar of Societies i.e. Registrar of Joint Stock Company and Firms which clearly proves that the photocopy of the same is a forged document. The consequence of submitting false document before the highest court is a serious offence to be dealt with appropriate manner. Although the responsibility of such forgery cannot be denied by the learned Advocate of the defaulting party, yet by taking a lenient view of the matter, considering the age of the learned Advocates except making a note of caution against them.

 

Allhaj Qayum Reza Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 251.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Small Causes Courts cannot restored to possession of any tenant dispossessed or thrown out of suit premises by execution of decree.

 

Mrs.  Rezia Sultan & Anr Vs.  Md.  Haroon Malik & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 339.

 

Practice and Procedure antedated

 

On critical analysis of the evidence on record we find that one Shamsul Haq purchased 3(three) stamps bearing Nos.32373 to 32375 each at price of Tk.1.500/- from Comilla Treasury on 29.03.1982, and the same were used by defendant Nos.2, 3 and 5. We further find that one Lakhi Ahmed purchased stamp bearing No. 12327 on 15.04.1982 from the Comilla Treasury which were used by defendant No.4. It appears that the stamps used for four kabalas were purchased prior to it's execution dated i.e. on 21.04.1982. So, the same cannot be regarded as antedated comparing with that of the kabala deed dated 23.04.1982 of the plaintiff.

 

Mokbul Ahmed Mia & Ors Vs. M. Golam Mostafa & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 417.

 

Practice and Procedure

"an after - thought'"

 

The impugned  judgment and decree was passed on 26.11.2000 and decree was signed on 30.11.2000 in Title Suit No. 107 of 2000. The present appellant-petitioner, Additional Deputy Commissioner (Revenue), Dhaka, who was a contesting defendant in the suit applied for the certified copy on 19.6.2002, about 2 years after the impugned decree and the certified copy was made ready and delivered on 29.6.2002 and this was informed to the petitioner on 25.7.2002 and in filing the appeal, there was a delay of 599 days - there is absolutely no explanation for obtaining the certified copy after about 2 years after the suit was decreed. Subsequently the matter appeared in the list for hearing on 3.8.2006 when another Division Bench allowed the opposite party to file a reply to the supplementary affidavit filed by the petitioner. In the said supplementary affidavit attempt has been made to explain the delay in filing the application for certified copy, which is an after-thought. - The statement made in the supplementary affidavit appears to be an attempt to fill up the lacuna in the application for condonation of delay and we are not inclined to accept such explanation.

 

A.D.C. (Rev.) Dhaka Vs. Sree Prosanta Kumar Ghosh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 484.

 

Practice and Procedure

Proper exercise of jurisdiction

 

It is indeed unfortunate that the Court of appeal below in deciding the appeal dealt with some unnecessary facts and observed that as per evidence on record the Government is the real owner of the suit land giving a go­by to the old registered deeds of the plaintiff-opposite party No.l though the said observation of the appellate Court below is nobody's case. This is not only illegal but also not a proper exercise of jurisdiction vested in the Court inasmuch as the Court should record the findings on all points raised and should not decide any question which does not arise from the pleadings or unnecessary.

 

Saidur Rahman & Anr Vs. Haji Ameer All & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 568.

 

Practice & Procedure Unhealthy observation

 

Prof. Muhammad Yunus is a noble laureate. He is a respectable person not only in Bangladesh but all over the world. He was initially appointed as Managing Director of Grameen Bank by the Government and subsequently the Board reappointed him with prior approval of the Bangladesh Bank. Under such circumstances, the observations of the High Court Division that "a 'squatter' or a 'trespasser' or a 'usurper' can not maintain a writ petition under Article 102" are totally uncalled for in this case and the petitioner was illegally compared with litigants like "squatter, trespasser, usurper". Prof. Muhammad Yunus is .neither a 'squatter' nor a 'trespasser' or a 'usurper' of Grameen Bank in any sense. Rather he is the person on whose ideas and innovative projects for extending collateral free small loans to the rural people, the Bank has been established and it has achieved the prestigious noble prize as a recognition of its phenomenal success. Therefore, the unnecessary observations as quoted above are totally derogatory which are hereby expunged. It is hoped that the High Court Division should be cautious in future in making any unhealthy observation against any litigant who has come to Court for justice and not for seeking derogatory remarks instead.

 

Prof. Muhammad Yunus Vs. Rahima Begum & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 103.

 

Practice & Procedure

The fountain source of all

 

Judges administer justice. In order to do justice, the first and foremost expectation from them is to be just. This expectation itself is the fountain source of all that can be put in the realm of canons of judicial ethics. A Judge can not have any pre-disposed state of mind. His judgment would not be actuated by concerns of private interests or considerations. He has to be decisive. His every action and every word-spoken or written, must show and reflect correctly that he holds the office as a public trust and he is determined to strive continuously to enhance and maintain the people's confidence in the judicial system. Learning, personality, manners and stature in the judicial functioning matter. A Judge is as much respected as he respects the law, justice, equity and good conscience, and above all serves and seen to serve the cause of justice. It is desirable that the High Court Division should not use such unsophisticated words against a respectable person like Prof. Muhammad Yunus. The language of the Court should be dignified and the findings should confine to the issues involved in the matter.

 

Prof. Muhammad Yunus Vs. Rahima Begum & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 103.

 

Practice & Procedure

Lawyers are an important limb in the administration of justice

 

Lawyers are an important limb in the administration of justice. Their duty to the cause of justice is even superior. Their first obligation is to assist the Courts to the best of their ability so that justice can be done, so much so that only the legal profession is deservingly called a learned profession. It has high standards to keep abreast. That is why the profession commands respect. A lawyer's advanced education, training, knowledge and skill in the field of law, apart from his duty to the client, are the attributes to his tradition in the practice of law. Instances are not rare to find where lawyers in their over-zealousness to protect the interest of their clients have chosen to go over-board to the extent of submitting misleading facts and law.

 

Prof. Muhammad Yunus Vs. Rahima Begum & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 103.

 

Practice and Procedure No fault of the petitioner

 

The petitioner was vigilant very much in pursuing his claim to the property in question and he took right step in filing the revision application before the High Court Division and the revision was really maintainable but unfortunately the Rule in the Civil Revision was discharged as being not pressed on the observation made by the learned Judge of the Single Bench. -Be that as it may since the petitioner filed the writ petition under misconception of law on the observation made by the learned Judge of the Single Bench as stated hereinbefore, he cannot be subjected to suffering for no fault of his own and the revision application filed by him deserve to be disposed of on merit.

 

Md. Golzar Hossain, Adv. Vs. Janata Bank 21 BLT (AD) 168.

 

Practice and Procedure Custody of a Minor

 

Matters such as custody must always remain fluid since change in circumstances may at any time require the terms of the custody of the child to be varied upon a fresh application in order to comply with the age-old principle that the welfare of the child is a paramount consideration and in modern parlance "the best interests of the child" must be given due consideration.

 

AnikaAli Vs. Rezwanul Ahsan 21 BLT (AD) 185

 

Practice and Procedure

A third party as receiver of the joint property

 

The trial Court passed an order inducting a third party as receiver of the joint property of the family which goes against the cardinal principle of management of the property of a family.

 

Most. Vmme Shaheda Akhter Rina & Ors Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman & Ors   21 BLT (AD) 180.

 

Practice and procedure

Whether delay in disposed of the suit is a ground for appointment of receiver

 

Delay in disposal of the suit cannot at all be a ground for appointment of a receiver in respect of the suit land.

 

Most. Umme Shaheda Akhter Rina & Ors Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman & Ors   21 BLT (AD) 180.

 

Practice and Procedure

How to write a Judicial Order

 

Admittedly the trial Court allowed the application for amendment by a cryptic and slipshod order. A judicial order devoid of reasoning causes error of law but mere error of law cannot be a ground for interference unless it has occasioned failure of justice. While exercising any discretion under Order VI Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure the court is required to assign its reasons so that when the order is called in question, the higher Court may be in position to see that there has been application of mind by the Court concerned and that it is aware of the principles involved in the exercise of its discretion.

 

Md. Akram All Pk. & Ors Vs. Md. Yasin Ali & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 175.

 

Practice and Procedure

Effect of pendency of Writ Petition No.494 of 2007 and the order of interim injunction passed therein

 

Held; Though the appellant is a bank loan defaulter within the meaning of section 5 ka ka of the Bank Companies Act, 1991 read with clause (m) of the proviso to Article 12(1), RPO and its Explanation-V, he could not be designated as bank loan defaulter till the question of defaulter reaches finality in Writ Petition No.491 of 2007 in which an order of injunction was passed.

 

Md. Abul Kashem Vs. Major General Mahmudul Hasan (Rtd.) & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 209.

 

Practice and Procedure

 

Final decree vs. Preliminary decree It is settle principle that the execution court cannot   go   behind   the   decree.   So   the execution    court    does    not    have    any jurisdiction to take into consideration of any thing stated in preliminary decree.

 

Shamsuddin Ahmed & Ors Vs The City Bank Ltd. & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 296.

 

Practice and Procedure

Whether empowering the Pourashava Mayor to pass an Order regarding title of the parties during pendency of a Title Appeal in between the same parties

 

Held; Drawing my attention to the Pourashava Ordinance, Mr. Moudud Ahmed argues that there is no law empowering the Mayor to decide title of a party during pendency of a suit between the parties. On a query by me, the learned Advocate for the opposite parties finds it difficult to refute this branch of argument of Mr. Moudud Ahmed.

 

Nurul Haque Vs. Mohammad Shamsul Haque & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 456.

1530

President Order 1972

Citation: 19 BLT (HCD) 148, 19 BLT (HCD) 31

Case Year: 1972

Subject: President Order

Delivery Date: 2018-07-31

President Order No.7 of 1972

 

Article-27

 

House Building Finance Corporation has its own provisions for realisation of loan under Article 27 of President Order 7 of 1972 and jurisdiction has been exclusively given to District Judge as such for realising its loans only the District Judge has jurisdiction, no other court, Artha Rin Adalat being a subordinate court to District Judge has no jurisdiction to entertain any claim of House Building Finance Corporation.

 

Dr. Md. Asadullah & Anr Vs Sonali Bank Ltd. & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 148.

 

 

President Order 98 of 1972

 

Article-4

 

In the case of society, Government may relax the ceiling. In the case in our hand the plaintiff is a registered society as such the plaintiff is fallen within the category of Article 4 of P.O. 98 of 1972.

 

Debishahar Agriculture Ltd. Vs Govt. of Bangladesh 19 BLT (HCD) 31.

 

1531

Private Degree College Teachers Service Regulations, 1994

Citation: 20 BLT (HGD) 565

Case Year: 1994

Subject: Private Degree College Teachers Service

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Private Degree College Teachers

Service Regulations, 1994

 

Rule – 4

 

Belated stage - cause, being afraid of the then ruling party

 

Held; It appears that the decision for-appointment of the respondent No.3 as Principal was made by the Governing Body of the College, which is the proper authority, and since the petitioners have nothing to be afraid of at the present in view of the change in the Political arena of the country and the government, they may now move the Governing Body of the college for proper relief in accordance with law.

 

Md. Abdul Mannan & Ors Vs. Ministry of Education & Ors 20 BLT (HGD) 565.

1532

Private University Act, 2010

Citation: 20 BLT (AD) 156

Case Year: 2010

Subject: Private University

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Private University Act, 2010

 

Sections 3, 6, 7 and 13

 

On perusal of the various provisions of the Ain, 2010 particularly sections 3, 6, 7 and 13, it appears that it is the Government and the University Grants Commission which enjoy the exclusive domain to give approval for the establishment of the Private University at any place in Bangladesh and whether in exercise of their power under the provisions of the Ain, 2010 they can accord permission for establishing independent outer campuses is a matter to be decided by them and since the said two authorities have not taken any decision in the matter, we do not consider it proper and advisable to make any comment of our own in the matter, because such comment may jeopardize the discretion given to exercise of power by the said two statutory authorities under the Ain, 2010. We are of the view that writ- respondent Nos.l and 2 should be allowed to exercise their wisdom in taking decision on the prayer made by the petitioner for establishing outer campuses at Chittagong and Rajshahi in accordance with the provisions of the Ain, 2010 without any interference by this Court. At the same time, we do not approve of the action of the respondents in sitting over the applications of the petitioner so long though they had every right to decide the applications in either way. In the context, we find the observations made by the High Court Division that in the meantime, the petitioner has fulfilled the criteria and also complied with the conditions as mandated in provisio to section 3(5) and sub-section (9) of section 6 of the Ain, 2010 and as such it is entitled to have "permission of independent campus of Rajshahi and Chittagong" indiscreet. When the High Court Division gave direction upon the writ-respondents to consider the case of the petitioner with regard to the opening of independent campuses at Chittagong and Rajshahi in accordance with law, it should not have made any comment as to merit to the entitlement of the petitioner to get approval of establishing the outer campuses at Rajshahi and Chittagong. Furthermore, when the learned Advocate for the petitioner did not press the first part of the Rule as to the shutting down of the outer campuses and as per own statements of the petitioner approval to establish outer campuses of the University at Rajshahi and Chittagong was not given by the concerned writ- respondents, the High Court Division was totally wrong in allowing the order of stay of operation of the impugned order passed earlier to continue till the appropriate decision is taken by the respondents, because by such order of stay in fact the petitioner has been allowed to continue with its academic activities in the unapproved campuses at Rajshahi and Chittagong nullifying the impugned order as well as the provisions of the Ain, 2010.

 

University Grants Commission Anr. Vs. UITS & Anr 20 BLT (AD) 156.

1533

Registration Act, 1908

Citation: 21 BLT(AD) 229, 18 BLT (HCD) 17, 21 BLT (AD) 337, 20 BLT (HCD) 417, 21 BLT (AD) 209

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Registration

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Registration Act, 1908 (As Amend by Act 25 of 2004)

 

Section-17B read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 (As Amended by Act 27 of 2004); Section-21A

 

Agreement dated 02.01.2000 Shows that the consideration of Tk.2,34,00,000/- out of which Tk. 78,00,000/- was paid in advance with a further commitment to pay the rest of the amount by 31.12.07 -moot question is that whether court can direct to pay the balance amount before the expiry of 31.12.07

 

Held; It will not be out of place to mention that plaintiffpetitioner was required to deposit the balance amount in terms of agreement on or before 31.12.2007 but till now he has not deposited the same though he filed the suit for equitable relief in the form of the Specific Performance of Contract. However since both the trial court and the High Court Division are on the same view relating to deposit of the balance amount at the time of filing of the suit for Specific Performance of Contract under section 21 A of the Specific Relief Act we find no illegality or infirmity therein which deserves our interference.

 

Ayurvedia Pharmacy (Dhaka) Ltd. Vs. Mohammad Ali & Ors 21 BLT(AD) 229.

 

Section-28 Ineffective and lacks of jurisdiction

 

The lands of the instant exchange deed belongs to Chandina Sub-Registry office and as such the deed ought to have been registered in Chandina Sub-Registry office. But it has been registered at Joint Sub-Registry office, Comilla which had no legal authority to register it. As such the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioner that any party of that deed is not entitled to raise any question as to its validity is not sustainable in law because the deed in question has not been registered containing the properties did not exist or was fictitious or insignificant or was not intended to be conveyed rather the facts remains that Joint Sub-Registry office, Comilla was not authorized to register the deed with the properties mentioned in the deed. In the instant case the deed itself has become void.

 

Kazi Md. Sultan Ahmed Vs. Titama Bibi & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 17.

 

Section 28

 

Deed in question was registered before the amendment - the suit land is situated within the jurisdiction of different Sub-Registry Office

 

Admittedly, the lands said to have been transferred by the impugned deed fell within the jurisdiction of another Sub-Registry Office - High Court Division make the rule absolute on the ground "Section 28 of the Registration Act speaks that document which affects immovable property shall be presented for registration in the office of Sub-Registrar within whose Sub-District the whole or some portion of the property to which such document relates is situated. In the present case it is found that the land which was included in the impugned sale deed was not within the jurisdiction of Palong Sub-Registry Office. It is a settled principle that where no part of property to which document relates is situated within the jurisdiction of a Sub-Registrar, the Sub-Registry has no jurisdiction to registrar the document, and registration if executed will be fraud. In a case of fraud, the question of limitation will run from the date of knowledge and not from the date of execution of the disputed document. In the present case it appears that the plaintiff filed the suit within the statutory period of limitation, which in the present case will run from the date of knowledge and not from the date of execution of the deed in question." -Held; The reasons assigned by the learned Single Judge are inconsonance with law and I find no illegality in the judgment of the High Court Division in interfering with the judgment of the Court of appeal below.

 

Joynal Abedin Vs. Ali Azam Saial & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 337.

 

Section – 47

 

A document that has been registered relates back to the date of its execution and when the question of title as between the two contestants claiming on the basis of successive documents executed by the self­same vendor must be determined with reference to the title to the later on the date of execution and not of registration. - In the instant case we find that the defendant No. 1 executed four kabalas on 21.04.1982 but the same were registered on 18.08.1982 but defendant's No. 1 executed and registered kabala in favour of plaintiff on 23.04.1982, so in our view the kabalas which were executed on 21.04.1982 by the defendant No.l in favour of defendant Nos.2-5 shall prevail.

 

Mokbul Ahmed Mia & Ors Vs. M. Golam Mostafa & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 417.

 

Admittedly, the appellant is the Managing Director of the loanee company, MAQ Enterprise Limited. So, according to the provision to section 5(Ga Ga) quoted before, the appellant in his capacity as a Director/Managing Director, falls within the purview of the definition given in section (GA Ga) for the purpose of deciding his status for the loan taken by his company.

 

Md. Abul Kashem Vs. Major General Mahmudul Hasan (Rtd.) & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 209.

1534

Registration Act (As amended), 2004

Citation: 19 BLT (HCD) 189

Case Year: 2004

Subject: Registration Act

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Registration Act (As amended), 2004

 

Sections-17A and 17B

 

A combined reading of those provisions show that after coming into force of this amendment, no party can enter into any contract for sale of any immovable property unless the contract for sale is registered before the Sub-Registrar and if the contract agreement is executed prior to coming of the section 17A, the parties to the contract shall within six months from the date of the amendment present the contract for sale for registration. Unless the said provisions are complied with, no cause of action for institution of a suit for specific performance or recession of the contract would lie.

 

Farah Naz & Ors Vs Mst. Mahbuba Hasnat Khan 19 BLT (HCD) 189.

1535

Registration (Amendment) Act, 2004

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 155

Case Year: 2004

Subject: Registration (Amendment)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Registration (Amendment) Act, 2004

 

17A and 17B read with Code of Civil Procedure Order VII Rule ll(d)

 

Plaintiff   instituted   the   suit  for   Specific Performance of a Contract on the basis of

unregistered contract for sale and also for declaration that sale deed N0.1324 dated 11.7.2006 and sate deed No.2056 dated 19.12.2006 executed in the name of the defendant Nos.2 and 3 are collusive, illegal, void and not binding upon the plaintiffs.

 

Held; Since the plaintiff did not act as per Section 17A and 17B of the Registration Act by registering the unregistered deed within 6(six) months from the promulgation of the aforesaid law, we find the instant suit is barred as per provision of existing law of the country. Since the suit is barred, the plaint is rejected as per provision of Order VII Rule 1 l(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Sree Mali Nioto Rani & Ors Vs. Azit Kumar Singh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 155.

1536

Small Causes Act, 1887

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD) 423, 20 BLT (HCD) 339, 20 BLT (AD) 222,

Case Year: 1887

Subject: Small Causes

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Small Causes Act, 1887

 

Section -25 Bonafide requirement

 

On assessment of the evidence on record, appears that PW-1, PW-2 and PW-3 all of them in their respective testimony stated that in order to develop the suit shop room amongst other rooms of the suit holding which were let out to other tenants the plaintiff obtained a plan from RAJUK. -Held Bonafide requirement of the premises in suit by the owner for his own use or for the purpose of construction of building is a matter exclusively with landlord but still then be is under legal obligation to prove that he needs the premises for his own use or for construction of building through the evidence of reliable witness. In this case I have already indicated that there are sufficient corroborative evidence both oral and documentary available on record to arrive at a finding that the plaintiff petitioner has been able to prove his bonafide requirement of the suit shop premises for purpose of multistoried building.

 

Khandaker Mahmud Hasan Vs Anjir Asma 17 BLT (HCD) 423.

 

Section 15 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order IX Rule 13

 

Suit for ejectment of ordinary ejectable monthly tenants, was filed in 1987 and that defendants were evicted from the suit premises on 5.11.1980 and the miscellaneous case was registered on 04.9.82

 

In the instant case as I find by execution of decree defendants were thrown out of the suit premises and when the miscellaneous case was filed, tenants were out of possession that means, decree of the suit or for the purpose the suit was filed has been satisfied and jurisdiction of Small Cause Courts has been totally ousted as a tenant can not fight any legal battle if he/she is out of possession as court cannot compelled the land lord to restore possession of an unwanted tenant.

 

Mrs. Rezia Sultan & Anr Vs. Md. Haroon Malik & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 339.

 

Section-25

 

In any view, the scope of the scrutiny under Section 25 of the Small Causes Courts Act is much wider and the revisional Court is permitted to reassess the evidence in the light of the pleadings of the parties and also may consider all other evidence on record and is not restricted in exercise of its revisional power as is limited under Section 115( 1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

 

Md. Nasiruddin Vs. Md. Mizanur Rahman 20 BLT (AD) 222.

1537

Specific Relief Act, 1877

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 522, 19 BLT (HCD) 427, 20 BLT (HCD) 574, 19 BLT (HCD) 318, 20 BLT (HCD) 532, 20 BLT (HCD) 471, 21 BLT (HCD) 515, 21 BLT (HCD) 411, 17 BLT (AD) 45, 17 BLT (HCD) 209, 18 BLT (AD) 311, 18 BLT (AD) 497, 19 HLT (AD) 180, 19 BLT (HCD) 194, 20 BL

Case Year: 1877

Subject: Specific Relief

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Specific Relief Act, 1877

 

Section-9

 

Thus in a suit under Section 9 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 it is only necessary to prove whether the plaintiff was in possession of the suit land and he was dispossessed by the defendant and to see whether the plaintiff has filed the suit within 6(six) months from the date of dispossession and, if these facts are proved, the plaintiff can get his possession restored. There is no necessity to adjudicate the title of the parties in this nature of suit.

 

Watt Ahmed -Vs- Monjur Kader & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 522.

 

Section-9 read with Section-42

 

RAJUK in collusion with the defendants demolished the structures constructed by the plaintiffs over the suit land.

 

Trial Court below decreed the suit—Held; True it is such a finding also not possible by the trial court unless the government and RAJUK are brought to the suit as defendants but the difficulty arises when there is a specific bar in bringing a suit under Section 9 of the Specific Relief Act against the government or any functionary thereunder, therefore, a suit in the present form merely for recovery of possession under Section 9 of the Specific Relief Act is not at all maintainable. Instead the plaintiffs are at liberty to bring a suit for recovery of khas possession upon declaration of their title over the suit land in a regular suit as contemplated under Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act and not otherwise, If they are so advised. In a summary proceeding under Section 9 of the Specific Relief Act the relief cannot be claimed by plaintiffs as they did in present suit more so the learned trial court over looked this position of law and decreed the suit by his impugned judgment and decree.

 

Nigar Hossain & Ors Vs. Ahmed Ali Nur & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 427.

 

Section 12 read with Registration Act, 1908

 

Section 32,72, 73 and 74 The learned trial Judge found the contract has been conducted as the learned Judge found its execution has been done, consideration money has been paid, no fraud has been committed and plaintiff proved his case, only registration of the Kabala requires to be done which on the findings of the learned Judge ought to be ordered which she did not on the reason that required formalities under Registration Act has not been exhausted by the plaintiff which the learned Judge done on misunderstanding of law, Section 32 of Registration Act direct the executants (defendant) to present the document for registration, Section 72 for filing appeal before the Registrar against an order passed by the Sub-Registrar refusing to register the deed, Section 73 relating application to Registrar where Sub- Registrar refused to register the deed on ground of denial of execution and Section 77 for filing suit against the order of refusal by Registrar. We do not understand how these sections of Registration Act attracts on the facts of the given the case. Moreover, it is not the case of defendant Bank. From an over all consideration of the facts of the instant case we have seen plaintiff successfully make out a case of actual performance of a contract and it has all the essential of a contract valid and binding in law in order to be enforceable in law.

 

Abdul Huq Vs. The Oriental Bank Ltd. & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 574.

 

Section-22 Judicial discretion

 

The contract must have the essentials of a contract and binding at law in order to be enforceable. Relief granted under section 22 of Specific Relief Act is a discretionary relief but such discretion is to be applied judicially. Judicial discretion means sound discretion guided by law i.e. it must not be arbitrary, vague or fanciful, but legal and regular.

 

Roshanally  Mohamed Hajri & Anr Vs A.K.M. Zakir Hossain & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 318.

 

Section – 22

 

Judicial discretion means sound discretion guided by law i.e. it must not be arbitrary, vague or fanciful, but legal and regular.

 

It appears from the deposition of the plaintiff that defendant No. 1 was not the actual owner of the entire land. It also appears that the possession of the suit land was not delivered to the plaintiff pursuant to the bainapatra. It also appears that suit land was transferred to defendant No. 1 before the suit was filed. It also appears in the suit plaintiff mentioned about 5 schedules but in the bainapatra no schedule of land was given. It also appears no title deed or documents were delivered to the plaintiff by defendant No. I. Moreover, the bainapatra Exbt.I in no imagination can be said to be a contract is it is signed by only the seller, nor by purchaser. Contract is agreement between two or more person enforceable by law. Agreement is mutual assent to do a thing. Contract or agreement can not be done by one person. In Exbt.I we have seen plaintiff did not sign it as such Exbt.I can not be said to be a contract to be enforceable in law. A bainapatra, contract or agreement is enforceable in law and decree can be passed when the bainapatra, contract or agreement is not cumbrous but legal and genuine. From the aforesaid discussions of the legal features of the case it is our considered view that Exbt.I is not a bainapatra, agreement or contract to be enforceable in law.

 

Roshanally Mohamed Harji & Anr Vs. A.K.M. Zakir Hossain  20 BLT (HCD) 532

 

Section - 22

In a suit for specific performance of a contract, the prime consideration is the bainapatra i.e. the agreement itself. If it is found that the bainapatra is executable then next, a decree must be awarded for execution and registration of the same. If thereby any ambiguity in executing the same, the court then lift its hands off to pass a decree.

 

Roshanally Mohamed Harji & Anr Vs. A.K.M. Zakir Hossain 20 BLT (HCD) 532.

 

Section 22 read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section 114(g)

 

Whether the signature on bainanama is forged To decree Specific Performance is discretionary

 

Held; Although D.W.I denied his signature and the signature of his brother Komol Chakrabarty on baina but it is a matter of surprise that Komol who was allegedly one of the executant did not come forward to deny his signature, without explanation. So the legal presumption would be had he been examined he would not have supported his brother's case. - the baina (Exht.I) executed by defendant Nos.1-2 in favour of plaintiff is genuine and specific performance of contract be enforced.

 

Debashish Chakrabarty & Anr Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 471

 

Section 31 Proper judgment of reversal

 

In the instant case the most important element is not at all proved. It is also not proved that the alleged talk of sale or offer of proposal to sale the property was really held between the parties and the alleged consideration or any amount of consideration was ever paid by the plaintiff or taken by the defendants in pursuance of the agreement. - I am constrained to hold such a view that the learned appellate court committed no misreading and non-reading of evidence and no illegality was done by which the impugned judgment and decree can be interfered with.

 

Md. Sultan Ahmed -Vs- Narayan Chandra Roy Ji Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 515.

 

Section-39

 

In a suit for Specific Performance of contract Held; we are of the view thai the trial Court rightly decreed the suit, but extraneous relief given that the deed in question in favour of defendant No.4, Md. Serajul Islam is cancelled which is superfluous however, the deed in question is voidable. Therefore, we are of the further view that above observation of the judgment be struck out.

 

Md. Serajul Islam Vs. Mrs. Hosneara Begum & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 411.

 

Section-42
