The trial court and the court of appeal held that the present suit is a simple suit for declaration of title in respect of 10.47 acres of land out of 13.14 acres of land is not maintainable, as from the evidence of P.Ws it is clear that the suit land is ejmali property and without a prayer for partition the suit is barred by section 42 of Specific Relief Act. -The High Court Division it appears reversed the findings of the appellate court and the trial court without adverting to the reasonings given by the court of appeal which is final court of fact. -Held; the impugned judgment is not a proper judgment of reversal. In this connection we also like to observe that the findings of the court of appeal on question of fact is binding upon the High Court Division unless it can be shown that those findings are perverse.

 

Abdul Quddus Matabbar Vs. YousufAli Bayati & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 45.

 

Section -42

 

Suit for declaration that deed of gift has been obtained fraudulently -when the donor or transferor acquired no title whatever deed of transfer, either by way of sale or by way of gift or, by way of will, cannot confer any title to a transferee or a donee.

 

Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Nawab All & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 209.

 

Section-42 Subject matter of the Suit is Shifting of the office of Union Parishad from its present site

to its new site.

 

It appears  that  the  site  selection   is  the business of the Government and relates to policy matter concerning the administration and the petitioner as plaintiff had no locus standi to challenge such a policy decision of the Government.

 

Md. Abdul Motaleb Sarker & Ors Vs. Md. Laskar All & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 311.

 

Section-42

 

Whether a suit for a simple declaration that the judgment and decree passed in T. S. No. 51 of 1997 is void without making a further prayer for declaration of title and confirmation of possession is not maintainable.

 

The appellant is defendant no. 1 in Title Suit No. 249 of 1998 which was instituted by the plaintiffs for declaration that the judgment and decree passed by the learned additional Assistant Judge, 3I(J Court, Dhaka in title Suit No. 51 of 1997 is void and is not binding on the plaintiffs. -Held; In view of the fact that deed dated 14.05.1969 was rightly held to be a forged one and not binding upon the plaintiff of Title Suit No. 51 of 1997, Bhashani Mondal, and that the court of appeal below rightly held that the plaintiff's possession was not proved, whereas, the defendant Bhashani Mondal's possession was already proved in the earlier Suit No.51 of 1997 and in the present suit, a suit for declaration simplicitor is not maintainable.

 

Nanda Rani Mondal & Anr Vs. Md. Abdus Sukur & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 497.

 

Section-42

 

Plaintiffs were not in exclusive possession Plaintiffs suit, praying for a decree for simple declaration of Title in the suit land -Trial Court dismissed the suit holding, amongst others, that the plaintiff No.2 by filing a compromise petition relinquished his claim on the suit land admitting the right, title and interest and possession of the defendant thereon and that possession of the defendant in the suit land has been admitted by the P.W. Nos.2 and 3 as evidenced from their respective depositions and thus the suit is barred under Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act for want of proper prayer for consequential relief in the suit -Appellate Court in reversing decree the suit and the High Court Division held that the lower appellate Court is absolutely wrong in reversing the judgment and decree of the trial Court as such the judgment and decree passed by the lower appellate Court is liable to be set aside -Held; The High Court Division correctly found that the appellate Court erred in not holding that the suit as framed and filed with a prayer for simple declaration is not maintainable in view of Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act since the defendants were found in possession.

 

Kulsum Vanu Bibi & Anr Vs. Abdul Jobbar Bhuiyan & Ors  19 HLT (AD) 180

 

Section-42

 

Judicial discretion

 

In a suit for specific performance of a contract, the prime consideration is the bainapatra i.e. the agreement itself. If it is found that the bainapatra is executable then next, a decree must be awarded for execution and registration of the same. If therebe any ambiguity in executing the same, the court then lift its hands off to pass a decree.

 

Roslutnally Mohamed Hajri & Anr Vs A.K.M. Zakir Hossain & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 318

 

Section-42

 

Claimed tide by adverse possession against government.

 

Plaintiff claim that he purchased the suit property orally as such he can not assert that he got title by adverse possession as title by adverse possession is to be claimed by a person whose title is to be perfected other than by virtue of a title deed or a contract to purchase. It is the case of the plaintiff that suit land was declared as enemy property. It is the case of the plaintiff that he mistakenly filed application for getting lease of the property on the advise of the employees of the vested property cell. The advise of the employees of the vested property may be mistakenly but since application was filed, for getting lease, it proved that he accepted the property as enemy property. Now he can not turned round and sought declaration of title by adverse possession against Bangladesh. The limitation for getting title by adverse possession against Government is 60 years uninterrupted possession. If it is assumed the case of the plaintiff that he entered into possession in 1952 from the original owners, but the suit having filed in 1990, as such he did not acquired title by adverse possession against principal defendant i.e. Government of Bangladesh.

 

Md. Waseq Ullah & Ors Vs Razia Khatun & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 194.

 

Section-42

 

In the instant case the plaintiffs claiming their right, title and interest only upon the Exht.l, save and except the said document they have no other supporting papers to show that after purchase the plaintiffs tried to pay rent and to get necessary right over the suit land. Furthermore, it has come to notice that the defendants predecessors possessed the suit land by purchasing the same in auction and the defendants also got possession over the same. On perusal of the documentary and oral evidence on record, the defendants, are found in possession as such the plaintiffs suit for declaration without having prayer for recovery of khas possession in the suit land, the suit is not maintainable in the present form. Having regard to the facts I am in agreement with the concurrent finding of facts arrived at by the Courts below.

 

Abdul Awal & Ors Vs. Abdul Hal & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 596

 

Section 42

 

Suit for mere declaration of title

 

The plaintiff has filed the suit-for declaration of title on assertion that he is in possession of the suit land and the recording of S.A. Khatian No.64 is wrong. Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act provides that a suit for mere declaration of any legal character or any right to property is maintainable. In view of the evidence of possession in favour of the plaintiff, the plaintiff need not ask for any further relief. In view of the matter, I am of the opinion that present suit for mere declaration is maintainable.

 

Most. Rafida Bewa Vs. Md. Abdul Gani & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 407.

 

Section 42

 

Admittedly plaintiffs are not in possession of the suit land Suit for simple declaration is not maintainable

 

Plaintiffs instituted the suit, praying for a decree for declaration that order dated 26.7.1993 passed by the Deputy Collector for cancellation of the Genuineness Certificate dated 29.4.1989 and the registered deed dated 20.5.1989 - Trial Court dismissed the suit, upon appeal, Appellate Court allowed the appeal and decreed the suit. - The defendant No.l, Deputy Collector after following all the necessary procedures passed the impugned order dated 26.7.1993 for cancellation of the Genuineness Certificate dated 29.4.1989 and the registered deed of transfer No.4398 dated 20.5.1989. Trial Court found that the plaintiffs could not prove their possession over the suit land. Thus the suit so instituted for a declaration that the impugned order dated 26.7.1993 passed by the defendant No.l was illegal, void and not binding upon the plaintiffs without seeking for declaration of title to and recovery of possession of the suit lands, is not maintainable under section 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877. Trial Court thus rightly found that the suit itself was not maintainable.

 

Jhaiya Barman & Ors Vs. Md. Khondoker Syedul Islam & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 344.

 

Section – 42

 

First requirements is to establish title in the suit land

 

The finding of the High Court Division is based on concurrent findings of facts and the plaintiffs failed to prove that the registered deed of gift No.2953 dated 26.3.1963 and consequent thereupon the registered sale deed No.146 dated 1.4.2000 are invalid documents. The plaintiffs also failed to prove their acquisition of title by inheritance in the suit land. We do not therefore find any substance in any of the submissions of the learned Counsel for the petitioner.

 

Sree Ashish Kumar Shaha Roy Vs. Al-Haj Md. Wasidul Islam & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 13.

 

Section - 42 read with Evidence Act, 1872; Section – 80

 

Held; On a perusal of Ext. (Kha) we find that the said application was filed jointly by three persons namely (I) Sachindra Chandra only heir of admitted owner (2) Rosomoy Chandra Nath and (3) Abdul Hasem against Taheruddin the auction purchaser, claimed by plaintiff side and that application was filed for setting aside of certificates sale took place in Certificate Case NO.188(S)/ 64-65 under section 23(2) of the Public Demand Recovery Act, 1913. Certified copy of that document was obtained as back as in the year 1974 while the instant suit was filed in the year 1997, therefore long before the institution of the instant suit those two Exts. namely (K) and (Kha) were collected from the side of the defendants and on perusal of the Ext. Kha we find a clear averment made thereih testifying the assertions made in the written statement filed by the defendants and the deposition of their witnesses made in the suit. Having given a look to those two documents with bear eyes those can not but be accepted as genuine ones and the question of fabrication of those documents for the purpose of the suit can not be raised al all. These arc genuine documents evidencing the official act canceling the auction sale held in Certificate Case No. 188/64-65 was done in due process. Since a presumption of genuineness of the said cancellation of auction sale is available under Section 80 of the Evidence Act and the said presumption has not at all be rebutted by the plaintiffs, therefore, we can safely accept the position that the sale though held in the year 1964 in favour of Taheruddin in Certificate Case No. 188/64-65 yet the same was subsequently set aside in a regular proceeding in Miscellaneous Case No.2/73-74 brought by the three persons including one who is the sole heir of admitted owner, therefore, we have no hesitation to arrive at a finding that the auction sale in favour of Taheruddin in connection with Certificate Case No. 188/64- 65 was set aside in a regular proceeding because of non .service of notice upon Sachindra the certificate debtor and after setting aside the sale in the proceeding as aforesaid the subsequent transfer from Taheruddin onwards up to the plaintiff have been rendered invalid, therefore, the question of declaration of title in their favour on the basis of their registered transfer deeds does not arise at all.

 

Nazir Ahmed & Ors Vs. Md. Fajal Ahmed & Ors 20 BLT (HCD ) 118.

 

Section-42 read with East Pakistan Hats and Bazars (Establishment and Acquisition) Amendment Act, 1966 (Act No.XII of 1967) Section-2(3)

 

Without Serving notice upon the owners of the Suit land

 

High Court Division held that the suit land was not liable to be forfeited since the said Bazar was neither established by the owners themselves nor with their consent and moreover, no notice of forfeiture was served upon the owners of the land before passing the order of forfeiture. -We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh Vs. Mariam Begum & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 01.

 

Section-42 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-7 Rule-3

 

Suit for Declaration of Title -High Court Division made the rule absolute mainly on the ground that the suit land is totally undemarcated and unspecified in the schedule of the plaint and a court shall not be able to pass an executable decree. -Held; we find no illegality in the judgment of the High Court Division since the lower appellate court has passed a decree over unspecified and undemarcated suit land which is not executable.

 

Aihulla Kumar Bairagi & Ors Vs. China Ran/an Biswas & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 118.

 

Section 42 read with Sonali Bank (Employees) Service Regulations, 1981 Regulation 13(2)

 

Suit for a declaration that the order of termination is void, illegal and without jurisdiction

 

Held; the learned Court during disposal of the original suit and appeal scrutinized the relevant provisions of law and assessed the evidence on record properly in its true perspective. It was also rightly held that on 29.08.1983 all concerned were awarded three months substantive salary instead of one month salary as termination benefit. In the instant case despite the defendant No.J issued the termination order even then there can not be any reason to believe or to hold that the defendant No.l was without jurisdiction or not empowered to issue such order inasmuch as the authority was conferred upon him through regular official process.

 

Md. Mosharraf Ali Khan Vs. A.G.M Sonali Bank, & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 51.

 

Section - 42 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order 1 Rule 9

 

Misconception of law

 

In the R.S. khatian the suit property has been recorded in the name of plaintiff deity, but in the remark column it has been noted as 'vested property' and for that noting while the concerned Tahsilder tried to lease out the property in favour of third party plaintiff's title to the suit properties has been clouded. To dispel that cloud plaintiff instituted the original suit for declaration of title.

 

Held; The learned trial court in his judgment and decree opined that the plaintiffs have successfully proved title in the disputed properties but for defect of parties they are not entitled to get the relief as prayed for. - it is a settle principle of law that the suit shall not fail for reason of mis-joinder and non­joinder of the parties. No suit can fail by reason merely of non-joinder of parties. Order 1 Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure makes this legal position clear. Apart from this on careful scrutiny over the case records it is evident that Abdul Latif and Elahi are not the necessary parties of the suit. As lessee under the defendant No.l their presence is not required for proper adjudication of the matter in dispute and it is within record that the defendant Government of Bangladesh is well within the plaint of the suit and they are contesting the case. The exhibited documents as it appears go to show that the rent receipts starts from Puthia Zomindari Estate upto the Government which has been duly marked as Exhibits 4-4(35) from the side of the plaintiffs. In view of the materials on record it is a glaring misconception of law as to onus probandi in a civil proceeding.

 

Sree Sree Radha Ballav Deb Thakur & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 84.

 

Section-54 read with (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948 Section-14A

 

It is well settled and recognized that in a Suit for Decree of Permanent Injunction title .of Party cannot be gone into and the same can be gone into incidentally and factum of possession is the paramount consideration in awarding Decree of Permanent for Plaintiff. The point has been finally Law at rest by series of Judicial decisions of Superior Courts of this Sub-continent. I, also, carefully considered evidence of P.W.s and DW 1 on possession and I do not find any reason and ground to hold contrary/different views taken by both Learned Assistant Judge and Learned Additional District Judge and I am in full agreement with decisions reached by both Judges on factum of Possession of Plaintiff Opposite Party No.l on Suit Property —From evidence of PWs and DW I and materials brought on record I am of this positive view that since Mandatory Provision contained in Sections 4, 5, 5B and 7 of The Act of 1948 had not been at all complied with, Requisition and Acquisition Proceeding in LA case No. 63 of 1959-196o and Requisition and Acquisition of suit property is absolutely illegal, void, without Jurisdiction and not at all binding upon Plaintiff-Opposite Party No. 1.

 

Bangladesh Railway Vs. Md. Sujaruddin & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 363.

 

State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section-10A

 

Admittedly the suit property is a Debuttar Property

 

According to the provisions of Section 10A of the said Act it is found that all Debuttar property must be managed, controlled and maintained in accordance with the aforementioned provisions of law. Here we must express our view that the 'Ka' schedule suit property of the present case admittedly was/is a Debuttar property since its inception which was correctly recorded in the name of Deity at the time of preparation of D.S. record of rights during the colonial regime of British showing Kumar Birendra Nath Roy Bahadur as Shebait who was the donor of the property. It further appears from the pleadings of the suit, from the recital of exhibit 3 and deposition of P.W.I herein he admitted that Ka schedule land was /is a Deity's property. It is further admitted facts that there is a temple with Deity and a big pond from which it is apparent that there was/is nothing cultivable and arable land. Ka schedule total land is occupied by the big pond, temple and Pathway of the temple, so how it would be settled for cultivation to a Raiyat which happened in this case. Since from the time of D.S, record of rights the Ka schedule land belonged to Deity as Debutlar property which never comes within the ambit of the settlement as per the provisions of the Bengal Tenancy Act or thereafter, by operation of law of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. -Moreso, the defendant Government including the period of the erstwhile East Pakistan Government have failed to produce any notification or assessment -roll in respect of the suit land which admittedly a debuttar property, hence, as per provisions of Section 10A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act 1950, unless Government take over the possession of the property as provided in the law none but only Deity is the owner and possessor of the Ka schedule land and as such, Shebait will act as representative of the Government.

 

Syed Jamshed Hussain Choudhury Vs Govl of People Republic of Bangladesh.

 

Section-24 read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section-115

 

The established principle of the law of pre­emption is such that the right of pre-emption would be barred in presence of acquiescence and estoppel. When the pre-emptors negotiates the sale under preemption or the facts are such that their acquiescence can be safety concluded, the doctrine of estoppel conies into full play. The very conduct of the pre-emptors would be a bar even though their application for preemption is a statutory right.

 

Bislinu Pada Sikder & Ors -Vs- Badiuzzaman & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 533.

 

Section-95 read with President's Order No.88 of 1972

 

Period of limitation for redemption Suit

 

Held; The High Court Division relying the case of Abu Bakkar vs. Nazi Ahmed reported in 34 DLR(AD) 237 held that the right of redemption shall accrue after 12 years from 1936, date of mortgage deed and the suit has been filed within a period of 60 years. Accordingly both the courts below committed a gross error of law in construing the President's Order No.88 of 1972 and in holding that the mortgage deed was executed in 1936 and section 95 of the State Acquisition of Tenancy Act was amended by promulgation of President's Order No.88 of 1972 with effect from 03.08.1972 and the transaction is a past and closed one, overlooking the vital fact that the mortgagor's right of redemption within a period of 60 years limitation has not been taken away by president's Order No.88 of 1972 rather by promulgating President's Order No.88 of 1972 a quick remedy has been made available to a raiyat but it did not in any way affect the long practised remedy of the right of redemption of mortgage by filing a suit within a period of 60 years from the date of accrual of the right of redemption. -We are of the view that the High Court Division upon correct assessment of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Md. Nasirullah & Ors Vs. Md. Ziauddin Khan & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 19.

 

Section-95 read with Limitation Act, 1908 Article-148

 

Whether deed of mortgage with a condition to repay and as failed to repay the loan the transaction was out and out a sale out past and closed

 

The transaction in the instant case under no circumstance can be termed as an out and sale. So, the plea of bar of past and closed transaction, as raised by the petitioner, does not applicable in the instant case inasmuch as once a mortgage always a mortgage — The transaction was a complete usufractuary mortgage and not an out and out sale and the plaintiffs being the heirs of the mortgagor have every right to redeem the mortgage by instituting the suit for redemption of mortgage under section 95 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. The suit is instituted on 15.2.1987, that is, well within the period of statutory period of limitation of 60 years under Article 148 of the Limitation Act, 1908 and hence the suit is quite maintainable.

 

Amena Ribi & Ors Vs. Abdul Hamid Sarder & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 537

 

Section -96

Ceased to be a co-sharer

 

Since it is found joma of the pre-emptor is split up by opening a new khalian No. 1852 (Exa.2), the pre-emptor can not be held to be a co-shearer to the case land and in that view of the matter also the pre-emptor is not entitled to pre-emption.

 

Sukur Ali & Anr Vs Md. Ashrafuzzaman & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 513

 

Section -96

 

Contiguous owner

 

In the instant case there are sufficient evidences on record to show that petitioner No. 1, Sukur Ali (husband of petitioner No. 2 Halima Begum) is a co-sharer as well as contiguous owner of the case land purchased the case land by his own money in the name of his wife petitioner No. 2 Halima Begum and none of the PWs deposed that petitioner No.2 Halima Begum is a stranger to the case land. The concurrent findings of both Courts below that the pre-emptee purchaser Halima Begum is out and out stranger to the case land which are, in fact, based on misinterpretation of laws and also contrary to the weight of evidence on record. -The trail Court as well as the appellate Court below failed to decide the vital aspect of this case that who is the stranger and who is not which resulted in the failure of justice.

 

 

Sukur Ali & Anr Vs Md. Ashrafuzzaman & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 513.

 

Section-96

 

It appears from the record that the respondents executed the kabala deed in the District Registry Office instead of Sub-registry Office presumptably to conceal the date of sale. While executing the kabala there was no local person. The respondents did not get served notice upon the cosharer including the pre-emptor which was imperative under the law. So, neither the pre-emptor nor his co-sharers was aware of the deed. It is also admitted by all the P.W.s that the appellants' knowledge of kabala date is only 04.10.1981 but the High Court Division might not have distrusted the finding of fact arrived at by the final Court of fact observing that the date of knowledge for the first on 04.10.1981 was not proved in preponderance of evidence losing sight of the considered evidence of all the P.W.s as to the date of knowledge of the pre-emptor on 04.10.1981. -With the above finding the appeal was allowed.

 

Kulsuma Begum & Ors Vs. Monowara Begum & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 310.

 

Pre-emption Petition was barred by limitation

 

It appears that the definite case of the pre-emptor is that he came to know about the transfer on 10.01.1997. The transfer in question is by sale deed dated 29.02.1992. Therefore, after about five years the pre-emptor petitioners came to the court with the plea that they came to know about the same on 10.01.1997 but in the petition there is no statement as when the purchaser demanded possession and whether anybody else was present at the time of such demand. The name of P.W.2 was not mentioned in the preemption petition. Therefore, the appellate court rightly disbelieved the story of knowledge of the petitioners from 10.01.1997 and the High Court Division affirmed the same.

 

M. Akbar Chowdhury Vs. Khalilur Rahman & Ors 8 BLT (AD) 314.

 

Section-96

 

Improvement Cost

 

The learned Advocate for the pre-emptee-petitioner is unable to dislodge the findings of the Appellate Court, the last Court of facts, save and except that after purchase, the petitioner made improvements on the land by erecting shops and houses which was noticed by the High Court Division. -Held; The petitioner-pre-emptee is entitled to the development cost of Tk. 10,0007.

 

Jahangir Alain Vs. Md. Joynal Abedin & Ors 18 BLT(AD) 305

 

Section -96 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Section-148

 

The Deposite not being made within time allowed.

 

The pre-emption law provides that four months time for filling an application for pre-emption from the date of knowledge and that any opposite party in the pre-emption case is permitted to file an application for adding him/her as an co-applicant with prayer for rateable pre-emption of the land within two months and is required to deposit the amount, as may be ordered, for, within the period allowed by the Court and such provision is mandatory inasmuch as this special provision of law provides special limitation and therefore the limitation as provided in the law itself shall prevail over the normal law of limitation.

 

Md. Chan Miah Vs. Md. Dabirul Islam Khan & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 462.

 

Section 96 read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section 102

 

Onus shifter on the pre-emptees

 

On perusal of the judgment of the High Court Division, it reveals that the High Court Division has categorically adverted to the evidence to the parties and held that the lower appellate Court considered the evidence of pre-emptor No.3 Abdur Rahman and P.Ws.2 and 3 who corroborated the pre-emptor and also considered the evidence of OPW Nos.l and 2 who proved that the purchaser did not take over the possession of the case land immediate after his purchase and that the seller remained in possession of the case land and drawn conclusion holding that the lower appellate Court correctly noticed that after the pre-emptors proved that they had no knowledge of the transfer in question prior to 01.09.1994, the onus shifted on the pre-emptees to prove that the pre-emptors had earlier knowledge of the transfer in question and that the pre-emptees in the present case failed to discharge their onus. - Upon over all security of the materials and the judgment and order of the High Court Division we find that the High Court Division affirmed of the judgment of the appellate Court on giving strong cogent reasons which calls for no interference by this Division.

 

Suratunnessa & Ors Vs. Nurjahan Bibi & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 74.

 

Section - 96 read with Evidence Act, 1872; Section -102

 

It appears from the record that the appellate Court below having found that the deed of re-conveyance executed and registered during pendency of the pre­emption case cannot defeat the right of pre-emption, has erroneously allowed the appeal rejecting the pre-emption case holding that the petitioner failed to prove that the market value of the case land was Tk.60,000.00 as mentioned in the impugned kabala which he found to be Tk.6,00,000.00 as claimed by the opposite parties. The specific case of the opposite party No.2 being that market value of the case land was Tk.6,00,000.00 but he took loan of Tk.60,000.00 from the opposite party No.l by giving the land mortgage to him, thus onus of proving the same was on him. But the Appellate Court below has committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice in shifting the onus of proof of the same upon the petitioner. The petitioner deposited the consideration amount as mentioned in the kabala in accordance with law with statutory deposit at the rate of 10%.

 

Alhaj Abdul Awal Ratan & Anr Vs. Abdul Mannan Mia & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 272.

1538

State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment) Act, 2006

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 152

Case Year: 2006

Subject: State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

State Acquisition and Tenancy

(Amendment) Act, 2006

 

Section- 96 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

 

Order VII Rule ll(d) Instant pre-emption case instituted by the pre-emptor dated on 10.6.2007 and claimed the case land as co-sharer by purchase, -Held; The instant case is under the new provisions of law of State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment) Act, 2006 which is barred by law since the pre-emptor is co-sharer by purchase not by inheritance. No application under Section 96(i)(a) shall lie unless the applicant is a co-sharer tenant in the holding by inheritance.

 

Md. Rafiqul Islam Vs. Md. Nasir Uddin & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 152.

1539

State Acquisition and Tenancy Rules, 1955

Citation: 20 BLT (HCD) 49

Case Year: 1955

Subject: State Acquisition and Tenancy

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

State Acquisition and Tenancy

Rules, 1955

 

Rule - 42A

 

Whether Director of Land Records and Surveys has authority to interfere with the judgment passed in appeal under Rule 31 of Tenancy Rules.

 

Settlement-Officer has already decided the appeal cases by exercising his power under Rule 31 and 42 of the Tenancy Rules. 1955. the Director of land records and surveys, has no right and authority to constitute a committee to rehear the appeal cases afresh without having any allegation of fraud in the entry of record-of-rights,

 

Emran Ahmed & Ors Vs. Govt, of Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 49.

1540

Succession Act, 1925

Citation: 17 BLT (HCD) 180

Case Year: 1925

Subject: Succession Act, 1925

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

Succession Act, 1925

[XXXIX of 1925]

 

Section -283 read with Limitation Act, 1908 Article-181

 

There is no limitation prescribed for the purpose of making application for granting probate under the Succession Act, 1925 and that Article 181 of the limitation Act 1908 is not attracted in case of application filed for granting of probate as contended by the learned counsel for the Appellant.

 

Held; The cause of action to apply for granting probate in the instant case accrues every clay, since the cause of action for an application for probate subsists every moment, so long as the 'will' remains unprobated and the properties exist and that for such application there is no period of limitation.

 

Tapash Poddar & Ors. Vs I'ritimoy Fodder & Ors  17 BLT (HCD) 180.

1541

Supreme Court of Bangladesh (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988

Citation: 12 BLC (AD) 193, 13 BLC (AD) 97

Case Year: 1988

Subject: Supreme Court of Bangladesh (Appellate Division)

Delivery Date: 2018-07-05

Supreme Court of Bangladesh (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988

 

Order XXVI—

 

The appellants have failed to make out any case calling for the review prayed for as none of the ingredients as spelt out in Order XLVII, rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure or Order XXVI, rule 1 of the Appellate Division Rules is present in this case to lay our hands to review the impugned judgment. In the instant case, there is no reasonable ground to justify the action of the respondent on the doctrine of necessity since the impuged order of detention of the respondent was made, according to the appellants, with the apprehension that somebody else (the students community threatening to move to Sena Bhaban) may endanger public order due to some utterances of the detenu and, as such, this Court in the impugned judgment found the order of detention to have been passed without lawful authority. The plea of doctrine of necessity is not warranted in the facts   and   circumstances.  

 

Bangladesh   vs Mostafizur Rahman 12 BLC (AD) 193.

 

Order XXVI rule I—(Per Justice Md Abdul Matin) :

 

In view of Article 105 of the Constitution read with review rules as per Supreme Court of Bangladesh, Appellate Division Rules, 1988 in Order XXVI, rule I interference can be made only on the ground of an error apparent on the face of the record. The scope of interference is very limited. Nonetheless, since in the instant case the error is apparent on the face of the record and in that view of the matter to limit the relief to reduction of sentence only is not enough.

 

The appellants enjoyed their freedom from 9-4-1996 when they were acquitted by the High Court Division and then they are released as per leave granting order dated 3-11-1996 and, therefore, ends of justice will be met if the two appellants are given the full relief by allowing the appeals as a whole maintaining the judgment of the High Court Division insofar as the appellants are concerned. Therefore, the appeals are allowed. Accordingly, the appellants are acquitted Order of the Court These appeals are allowed by majority judgment. The perod of sentence is reduced to 3 (three) years from 7(seven) years. The appellants are directed to surrender to serve out the sentence, if not already served out.

 

Khandker Zillul Bari vs State 13 BLC (AD) 97.

1542

The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 (Part-2)

Citation: 21 BLT (HCD) 142, 21 BLT(HCD)156, 21 BLT (HCD) 163, 21 BLT (HCD) 282, 21 BLT (HCD) 370, 21 BLT (HCD) 438, 21 BLT (HCD) 460, 21 BLT (HCD) 471, 21 BLT (HCD) 541, 21 BLT (HCD) 544, 17 BLT (HCD) 62, 18 BLT (HCD) 188, 19 BLT (HCD) 39, 17 BLT (HCD) 386, 19 BLT

Case Year: 1972

Subject: The Constitution

Delivery Date: 2018-07-11

The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972

 

 

Article – 102

 

Public Interest Litigation

 

The petitioner has espoused his personal cause as well as the cause of the coterie of Marine Engineers only. It is an indisputable fact that he dose not represent a vast multitude of down-trodden or oppressed or vulnerable or disadvantaged people. From a plain reading of the Writ Petition, it leads us to hold that in the grab of a PIL, he has come up therewith for his personal and group benefit. That being the position, we have no hesitation in holding that the Writ Petition is not a PIL.

 

Md. Arifur Rahman Vs. Ministry of Shipping & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 142.

 

Article – 102

 

Maintainability - Public interest litigation

 

Held; A Organization named Human Rights and Peace for Bangladesh (HRPB) challenging the step of the respondents to construct a road through the Azimpur Graveyard by destroying thousands of graves -The steps of the respondents to construct alleged connecting read through the Azimpur Graveyard by demolishing thousands of graves is hereby declared illegal and without any lawful authority and is of no legal effect. This type of project cannot be allowed to run in future also.

 

Human Rights & Peace for Bd. & Anr Vs. Dhaka City Corporation & Ors 21 BLT(HCD)156.

 

Article 102

 

The Execution Case was filed according to the provision of Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 Whether the Executing Court had jurisdiction to exercise power under Section 47(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003

 

It is admitted that the judgment debtor respondent Nos.2 and 3 paid Tk.9,00,041/-which includes the principal loan plus 200^ over the principal loan amount and the payment was accepted by the Artha Rin Adalat and disposed of the execution case with full satisfaction by the impugned order. The respondent Bank challenging the legality and propriety of the impugned order at first filed Civil Revision which was summarily dismissed and thereafter the bank filed appeal under Section 41 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and lost up to High Court Division in another civil revision and without resorting to higher forum by challenging the said order of the High Court Division has came up this Division again under writ jurisdiction under Article 102 of the Constitution, challenging the self same order. On the other hand the judgment-debtors with a good intention to pay the outstanding dues of the petitioner-bank already paid Tk.9,00,041/- which includes the principal loan plus 200% over the principal loan amount. - We are of the view that   the    instant    writ    petition    is    not maintainable.

 

Rupali Bank Ltd. Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 163.

 

Article-102

 

Motive to harass and humiliate the alleged detenue and also to her father

 

The Writ petitioner (the father in law of the alleged detenue) and the father of the detenue are next door neighbors. The alleged detenue categorically stated she has not been detained by her father and she wants to stay with him. Her appears to be made voluntarily and without being influenced by anyone. Both in her statement and in the G.D. the detenue raised some allegations against her in-laws including the petitioner -Considering the facts and circumstances stated we are of the view that the Rule is devoid of any merit and the alleged detenue Nur Nahar (kona) has not been illegally detained by her father.

 

Sheikh Abdul Mannan Vs Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 282.

 

Article-102

 

Whether the Petitioner cannot be termed as a fugitive

 

The term 'fugitive' disqualifying a person to get any relief from the Court is applicable for criminal proceedings. But the Artha Rin Suit is a clear and simple suit of civil nature and in execution of the decree passed therein the present execution case is also a proceeding of civil nature.Therefore a judgment-debtor against whom an warrant of arrest is pending in a case of civil nature, cannot be termed as a fugitive and the door of justice is not closed for him.

 

Mirza Ahsan Habib Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 370

 

Article-102

 

Whether Writ Petition lies for enforcing the leasehold rights

 

Bhola Pourashava is axiomatically a statutory emanation, not a private entrepreneur. Its statutory duties cover a wide range of areas, which include establishment of shopping complexes and demising the same to traders with a view to provide civic amentias to the dwellers. Hence the claim that the tenancy agreement under which the petitioners hold the shops are mere trading contracts are, but fallacious. They are surely contracts with statutory flavour and hence breach of these contracts attract judicial reviewability. These contract also attract what the Appellate Division termed as "severing action" in Sharping Matsajibi Samaboy Samity-v-Bangladesh 39 DLR (AD) 85. So the argument against maintainabili holds no water whatsoever.

 

Md. Monjurul Alam & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 438.

 

Article-102

 

Ten years after settlement Court's Judgment and order passed in settlement case, the Writ petitioner wanted to be a party and to have the matter heard again on merit -Court of Settlement rejected the same on the ground of limitation and not being a party in the case—sent back on remand

 

Held; In finding of the court of Settlement it appears that the case holding was originally belonged to one Hamidunnessa who gifted the said holding to her only son Hasibur Rahman Chowdhry in 1962. This Hasibur Rahman is the Petitioner in both the present writ petitions. The papers and documents submitted by the petitioner before the court cannot be considered by us, at this stage. As these are disputed by the respondents. At the same time keeping in fact the judgment and order dated 31.10.1993 passed by the Court of Settlement in Case No. 14 of 1991 we cannot jump to the Writ petition No. 6442 of 2008 and arrive at a decision. We have given our anxious thought and considering the facts and circumstances of the case it would be fair and just to all if the case is sent back on remand to the Court of Settlement which will come to a conclusion after giving, opportunities to parties to the produce evidence and give a verdict therunder on examining the papers and documents submitted by them.

 

Hasibur Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Chairman, lsl Court of Settlement & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 460

 

Article-102

 

Action was taken through the impugned notices in total disregard to the provisions of Mawhina Bliashani Science and Technology University Ain, 2001

 

The alleged claims, are not supported by any audit or accounts and in absence of any audited accounts such a claim is not maintainable. However, we are also of the view that on the basis of the complete audit of the accounts, if any, defalcation is proved against the petitioner, that may be realised in accordance with law. Since the present claims are not supported by any audited accounts, therefore the Rule deserves merit that the impugned demands were made without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Dr. Md. Khalilur Rahman Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors   21 BLT (HCD) 471

 

Article-102

 

Sought for direction upon the respondents to pay their arrear salaries

 

Held; Suspension from service is not a punishment and as such because of putting the petitioners on suspension, which did not culminate to any order of dismissal, they cannot be deprived of their salary.

 

Mrs. Shaheba Khatun -Vs- Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 541.

 

Article-102

 

The detenu's relationship with her parents had been increasingly tense and hostile over the years as they had subjected her to threats and acts of physical violence. The detenu has since 5.8.2008 to date been held captive against her will and under duress by respondent Nos.l and 2 aided by respondent No.3 thus debarring her from communicating with her friends or professional colleagues in the UK or Bangladesh.-Rule upon the private persons (parents of the detenue's)

 

The parents, of course, have the right to advise their children but they must not treat their children as their slaves who must have their freedoms particularly when they are adults. The parents must remember that they are not living in old ages, but in the twenty-first century where freedom of every human being irrespective of sex is universally recognized. The petitioner's liberty enshrined in the Constitution shall mean and include her right to make decision concerning her groom free of coercion, violence and discrimination -Held; The detenu was illegally detained by respondent Nos. 1 to 3 from 5.8.2008 to 14.12.2008 without any lawful authority and in an unlawful manner.

 

Dr. Shipra Chaudhury & Anr -Vs- Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 544.

 

Article 102 read with Article -21

 

The Petitioner has no locus standi

 

The petitioner is a Journalist, peace activists in Bangladesh and the Editor, Weekly Blitz. He brought this action to perform his public duty to protect present legal system as enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and as a citizen the petitioner has been aggrieved, by the publication of a report which is the result of an investigative journalism, by a National Daily namely Amader Shomoy of 28th September, 2006 by which it has brought to light

 

Article -102 read with Article-148(3)

 

The petitioners who administered justice for others definitely deserve the same yard stick for them to be treated equally under the Constitution. Under clause (1) of article 148 of the Constitution, the petitioners took oath before they entered upon the office of additional judges and under clause (3) of said article they deemed to have entered upon such office from the date of such oath for all purposes even after appointments as judges under article 95. Fresh oath meant for a judge appointed under article 95 would not invalidate the date of the petitioners entering upon their office after oath under article 148(1). Service of every judge of the Supreme Court is so treated and recorded with effect from the date of oath taken by them after appointment under article 98, not under Article 95.

 

Md. Shamsul Huda & Ors. Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 62.

 

Article-102 read with Article-95

 

Legitimate Expectation

 

The writ petitioners claimed that when they were appointed they had the impression that at the end of the initial period if the CJB had recommended for their confirmation as permanent Judges reflecting their assessment of satisfactory performance as Additional Judges, they would be appointed in the ordinary course. The Constitutional Jurisprudence on the subject of judicial appointments clearly indicate that if there is any reason why CJB's recommendations are not accepted then those reasons should be communicated to the CJB, and the matter should be resolved through further consultations giving due respect to the vie ,s of the CJB and the principle of independence of judiciary. This expectation of uie writ petitioners is fundamental and natural and there can not be any departure from the established practice being followed over thirty years.

 

Md. Shamsul Huda & Ors. Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 62.

 

Article -102 read with Article-36

 

The fact that the trial of war criminals is about to start and that the Petitioner is likely to be put on trial for war crimes during the liberation war of Bangladesh in 1971 is in our opinion totally insufficient to refrain the Petitioner from leaving the country .-Held if the Government is allowed to restrict a person from going abroad at its discretion simply because he is going to make propaganda against Government policy or because he may be required to stand trial at a future date, then Article 36 will become nugatory. This Court being the Guardian of the Constitution cannot condone such practice.

 

Allama Delawar Hossain Sayedee Vs Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 188.

 

Article-102 read with Article 83

 

Under art.83 not only the levy but also the collection of tax must be sanctioned by or under the authority of an Act of Parliament. The expression 'Levy' includes creation of liability realisation of tax. Not only a tax must be validly levied, its collection must also be in accordance with the Act of Parliament. Thus, when an Act of Parliament provides that a tax shall be collected in such manner as may be prescribed by rules, the tax cannot be collected until the rules are made. This article gives protection against arbitrary collection of tax. When an assessment is made in an arbitrary fashion, there is no collection of tax in accordance with an Act of Parliament. Apart from that the power of the Parliament in enacting legislations or ratification of certain action(s) is also subject to judicial review by the apex Country. If the Parliament enacts any law(s) inconsistent or ultra vires to the provision of the Constitution, the supreme law of the land, such enactment can also be interfered by the apex Court exercising the power conferred under Article 102 of the Constitution of the Republic.

 

S. Alam Steels Ltd. & Ors Vs Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 39.

 

Article 102 read with Article 116

 

The order passed by the President under Article 1 1 6 of the Constitution in respect of the control including the posting, promotion and grant to leave and discipline of persons employed in the judicial service and Magistrate exercising judicial function has the essence of law and as such challengeable under Article 102(2) of the Constitution on .the ground of Corum Non Judice, malafide and ultravires of the Constitution.

 

Sontosh Kumer Saha Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Article-102 read with Article-125

 

Whether the Writ Petition is maintainable against any step in the parliament Election process

 

In holding against the maintainability of the writ petition in election disputes the real and larger issue of completion of free and fair election with promptitude and functioning of elective bodies like parliament is of greater importance than settlement of private disputes. Moreover Article 125 of our Constitution provides that no election to the offices of President or to the Parliament shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as may be provided for by or under law made by the Parliament and in such view of the matter there is a complete ouster of jurisdiction in entertaining writ petition in the matter of election disputes except in cases of coram non- judice or malice in law.

 

Dr. Muhiuddin Khan Alamgir Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 191.

 

Article - 102 with Article 47(3) read with Bengal Jail Code Rule – 910

 

Whether any suspected accused under the International War Crimes Tribunal claim fundamental right guaranteed in Part HI of the Constitution of Bangladesh.

 

The High Court Division is of the view that the respondents are under trial prisoners in connection with different cases and on consideration of their social and political status, they can not be denied and/or deprived of their right or entitlement of benefits and status as per Jail Code. In arriving at such conclusion the High Court Division has taken into consideration Rule 910 of the Bengal Jail Code. - In view of the above, the High Court Division committed no illegality in directing the respondents to provide the petitioners Division-1 status under the Jail Code. There is no merit in this petition.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Abdul Quader Mollah & Anr (Civil) 20 BLT (AD)240.

 

Article 102 read with Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980 (Act No.VII of 1981) Section - 4

Jurisdiction of Administrative Tribunals

 

The writ-petitioner has challenged legality of the order dated 27.3.2001 giving current charge of the post of Chief Engineer and Ship Surveyor, Department of Shipping to the respondent No.5, but the same being the matter relating to condition of service the relief sought in the writ petition in respect of the said order dated 27.3.2001 was not available to him since the subject matter of the said order i.e. giving of current charge was the matter for adjudication by the Administrative Tribunal.

 

Md. Muinuddin Zulfiquer Vs. Ministry of Shipping & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 132.

 

Article-102 read with Administrative Tribunal Act, Section-6(l)

 

Whether the High Court Division is competent to entertain a Writ Petition on the view that the Administrative Tribunal has no power of granting ad-interim relief "and normal procedure by way of appeal will take long time by which time the mischief will be done"

 

In the instant case the Administrative Tribunal refused the prayer for ad-interim order restraining the authority from granting promotion to the Respondents. So the Respondent Nos.1-11 herein if were aggrieved by the order so passed by the Administrative Tribunal they were required as per provision of section 6(1) of the Administrative Tribunal Act to file appeal, if any, they would have thought fit. But instead of doing that they were not well ad­vised to file the writ petition seeking the \ relief identical to the relief sought in the Administrative Tribunal case with the sole object of having an ad-interim order restraining the authority from taking steps for the promotion of the Assistant Superintendent of Police to the post of Additional Superintendent of Police.

 

Khalilur Rahman Vs. Md. Kamrul Ahsan & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 486.

 

Article -102 read with Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004 Section-26 read with Anticorruption

Commission Rules; Rule-17

 

In the instant case, notice in Form 5 which was duly served, the notice as alleged though may not conform the wording "ws" and "'WS" mentioned in Section 26 of the Act and of the Rules as against the words as have been used in the notice, in our view the same has neither prejudiced the writ-petitioner nor has misled the writ-petitioner as pursuant to the said notice the writ-petitioner accordingly submitted the wealth statement before the writ-respondent. The notice in all other material particulars are in conformity with the provision of said Act and Rules and no misgiving as tu the provision of law or the petitioner as well was not in any way misled by such wordings used in the notice and as such, merely use of the words n the notice designed to asking the writ-petitioner to submit the wealth statement has in no way suffer from any infirmity or any illegality and as such, the notice is by no stretch of the imagination could be termed as illegal or contrary to the provision of the Act and the Rules to that effect. -We have no hesitation to hold that the notice issued in the case to the writ-petitioner is a valid one and the same was duly served upon the writ-petitioner who accordingly replied to the notice fully understanding the intended purpose and puiport of the same in relation to the provision of Section 26 of the ACC Act and Rule 17 of the ACC Rules and indeed at no point of time raised any kind of objection to the Authority as to the vagueness, or of being misleading nature or character, or as to legality or impropriety regarding the impugned notice excepting the belated objection in the writ petition filed as a measure of afterthought. In that view of the matter we find no substance in the contention that the notice is illegal and of no lawful authority.

 

Anti-corruption Commission & Ors Vs. Sheikh Hasina Wazed & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 08

 

Article - 102 read with Anti-Corruption Commission Rules, 2007 Rule 17(5) 'fugitive from justice' - malafide - question of invoking the writ jurisdiction

 

Held; Admittedly that there is no provision either in A.C.C. Act, 2004 and/or the ACC Rules, 2007 which empowers any Commander of RAB to issue or serve any notice or order asking any citizen to submit statement of his property. It appears that very initiation of the enquiry into the property of vthe writ-petitioners was, therefore, vitiated by such notice dated 25.02.2007. It appears that no order or notice was ever served upon writ-petitioner No.2 either under Section 26 or under Section 27 of the ACC Act, 2004 or Rule 15(X)(5) of the Emergency Power Rules, 2007 asking her to submit statement of her property, moveable and immovable. In the absence of any order or notice under aforesaid provisions of law, lodging of F.I.R. against her must be held to be unwarranted, uncalled for and male-fide. As there was no substantive offence in acceptance with law against respondent No.l there could not be any abetment of such offences, and as such, no allegation under Section 109 of the Penal Code could also be resorted to for bringing a charge of abetment against the writ-petitioner No.2.

 

Anti-Corruption Commission Vs. Md. Hasan & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 53.

 

Article-102 read with Arms Act, 1878 Section-18

 

In the case in hand before cancellation of the licence of the petitioner by the impugned order contained in Memo beingdated 07.03.2007 as referred to in the First Information report of Dhanmondi Police Station Case No.29 dated 8.3.2007 (Annexure-A to the writ petition) passed by the District Magistrate, Dhaka, respondent No.2 in violation of section 18 of . the Arms Act, 1878 read with rule 42 of the Arms Rules, 1924 and also in violation of the principles of natural justice and thus the same is liable to be declared to have been made and issued without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Nazmul Huda Vs Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 88.

 

Article -102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003; 33(2). Prayer for setting aside the auction   sale alleging that the price which was accepted was shocking low but the executing Court rejected the said prayer.

 

In Writ jurisdiction judgment debtor obtained rule and auction Purchaser by filing affidavit-in-opposition opposed the Rule while decree holder Bank supported the Rule -High Court Division disposing of the Rule directing the executing court for passing necessary order for setting aside the auction sale and for holding fresh auction of the mortgaged properties provided that the judgment debtor pay the auction purchaser, interest at the rate of 12%, on the amount of money which the auction purchaser deposited in the court with effect from the date of deposit -Held; High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

Mis International Trade Promotors Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 306

 

Article -102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section -34 (1)

 

Held; we have carefully examined the application under section 34 of the Ain, 2003, it appears that in the, application under section 34 of the Ain, 2003 for issuing warrant of arrest against the judgment debtors the concerned official authority of the Bank neither put his signature nor made any verification/affidavit thereto and therefore it cannot be said that the application in question was filed by the decree-holder-Bank as per provision of section 34(1) of the Ain, 2003 -warrant of arrest is hereby declared to have been made without lawful authority.

 

Sheikh Nazmul Hague Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 189.

 

Article -102 read with Artha Rin Adalat

 

Ain, 2003 Section -34(2) Whether   the   heirs   of the   Mortgagor  are exempted from civil imprisonment

By impugned order the learned Judge of the Adalat sentenced the petitioner to suffer civil imprisonment for a period of six months -it is well settled that the liability of the principal debtor is co-extensive with that of the guarantor or mortgagor. The creditor is at liberty to pursue either the principal debtor or guarantor or mortgagor according to his sweet will or realisation of his dues or he can proceed against both of them simultaneously. Moreover the liability of the principal debtor and his surety though arising under the same transaction are distinct -the impugned order is not just and proper pursuant to the implied intention of the legislature made in section 34(2) of the Ain 2003. Thus the Rule having merit succeeds. Md. Akramuzzaman & Babu Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 496.

 

Article 102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section 33(5)

 

Whether without delivery of possession, the execution case cannot be disposed of Held; It appears that the learned Judge has passed the order " but has not passed the order as contemplated under section 33(7). Consequently, the title and possession of the mortgaged property has not been vested in the decree holder and without vesting a property, the execution case cannot be disposed of.

 

Md. Salahuddin & Ors. Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 45.

 

Article-102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section-6(5)

 

It has been found from the notice that no mortgaged property of the borrower has been included in the auction notice dated 09.07.2009 published in Daily Amar Desh by Sonali Bank, in order to sell the mortgaged of the properties petitioners (Annexures B). Section 6(5) of the Artha Rin Ain clearly provides that the mortgage properties of the borrower requires to be sold first for the purpose of realization of the decreetal money but the properties of the borrower has not been included in the auction notice and as such, the learned Artha Rin Adalat Judge has violated the specific provision of law and thus acted without lawful authority. On the face of the order, it appears that the learned judge has committed an error of law and the order definitely has jeopardized the interest of the guarantor and as such, it appears to us the impugned order and the auction notice are not sustainable in law and the same is liable to be declared to have passed without lawful authority.

 

Md. Khalil Ullah & Ors Vs Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 69.

 

Article-102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003; Section-8

 

The petitioner being the director of the borrower Company, M/s SAAM Business (Pvt.) Ltd executed the Charge documents as guarantor in respect of the loan sanctioned by the respondent No.2, Agrani Bank infavour of the borrower company. In case of default in re-payment of loan money by the borrower, the mortgagor and the guarantor are equally liable. The petitioner resigned from the directorship of the Company and transferred his sJiares in the on 6.4,1995 without priuc iil of the respondent No.2 as required under leim No.2l(e) of the saner ion fetter dared 25jl.J9y3. By such resignation (he petitioner wjs not releciwil from ilie gitfli'ariior-r,hin by the respondent No 2, Agrani Bank Limited. Thus the petitioner is nor emitted lo be relieved fioni llie liability uf outstanding dues ol I lie said bonowci company.

 

Article-102 read wilh Artrisi Kin Adalat Ain,

 

b tttok litati by inftrtgitgiiig huge .vftafex uf various CainpOfliea -witfiimt t&king tiny step* iir Sett thi'St .ffwret, file Attaint ptifoted tin onlt'f flf warrant "J arrest/Civil iitlptis Qittrierit

Dr.   Mil. Abul Kalam   &   Aur Vs  Gvrt.  

 

Article- 102 read wiih Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section- J3(3)

 

Judgment parsed under se&ittn 13(3) of the Arflia Ritt Attain! Ain, 2003 Ir lias been evident from the Annexurc C. Ihe written statement that the petitioner noi aJmiited tho ehum of the plaintiff ra denied Ihe contending passing (he order irndtr section I3f1) ^^ l"c Ain appear.1. 10 have passed beyond Ihe stope of Ihe law. Since the defendant did not admit the claim of the plaintiff bank, the Artlia Rni Adalal no jurisdiction or power to dispose of the stii's at, per secfron M of Anha Riji Adjiat Ain. such the impugned judgments.  decree without jurisdiction and is or" no legal effect .

 

Artlia Kin Adalat Am, 2003 Section-33(5)

 

Whether an applicatw n for isstti/iff certificate nitlier waifm 33(5j iiflti? Arlfra /fin Ain, 2fHfJ without filing exectttian sail be mafniafnabti

 

ft appcai-s thai :In? decree- holder bank without taking any steps as per Chapter- V] of the Ain filod an application for gulling certificate diroctty in oricnuJ proceeding w per provision of Section 33(5) of the Artha Rin Ain, ?003. The Jaw provides that by instituting E\t:ifLitJOJi Ciise in Lime. In suuh view ol ifio matteertilicate of (ransfci the mo' Imaged for leafiziiig Ihe dccrei;)] dues is patcntJy unlawful.

 

Md, Joinaul Abedin Mimn Vn Joint District Judge & Or BLT (HCD) 277.

 

Article-102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section-34(9)

 

In the instant case, an attempt to sell the mortgaged property was made before disposal of the Miscellaneous Case under Order XXI rule 58 of the Code of Civil Procedure. But after allowing the Miscellaneous Case and amendment of the schedule of the Execution Case, no subsequent step whatsoever was taken to sell the remaining portion of the mortgaged property. Under the circumstances, we hold that the decree-holder bank was required to take step afresh for selling the mortgaged property after amendment of the schedule of the execution case, failing which, it cannot be said that section 34(9) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 was complied with. It is the cardinal principle of statute that any provision law, which takes away the man's freedom, should be construed strictly.

 

Arun Kumar Sutradhar & Anr Vs Bangladesh &Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 172.

 

Article - 102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section - 57 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 ; Order XXI Rule 83 Decree in Money Suit

 

Though the petitioner-company was a third party mortgagor, it was willing to pay the entire outstanding dues by adjustment from the sale proceeds, if it would be allowed to sell schedule-A property through private negotiation and enhance the sale proceeds -the executing Court rejected the same on the ground that the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 is a special law and there is no scope to give permission for selling the property under the provision of the Code of Civil Procedure -Held; Sub-rule (3) of rule 83 under Order XXI excludes mortgage decree from application of sub-rule (1) and (2) of the said Order, but since the decree before us is a simply money decree, Order XXI rule 83 (1)(2) of the Code would be applicable here.

 

SDS Dairy Limited Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 15.

 

Article -102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section 12(5) (ka)

 

In action of the respondent, for handing over the possession and control of the mortgaged property to the Financial Institution/Bank

 

Held; Section 12(5)(ka) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 - it is incumbent and mandatory on the part of the respondent Nos.l and 2 to appoint a Magistrate of First Class for handing over the possession and control of the mortgaged property to the Financial Institution/Bank when requested. In such circumstances, we are of the view that justice would be done if a direction be given upon the respondent Nos.l and 2 to take necessary steps in accordance with law.

 

Southeast Bank Ltd. Vs. District Magistrate, Chittagong & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 27.

 

Article-102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Sections 9(5) & 13(1)

 

Held; There is no doubt that the provision laid down in Section 13 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 has only empowered the learned Judge of the Court to dispose the matter but prior to invoke such jurisdiction the learned Judge is to comply other provisions laid down in Section 13(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003. Unfortunately relevant portion quoted from written statement cannot, at all, satisfy the Court to have a decision relating to the admission of the claim of the defendant-petitioner as contemplated in Section 9(5) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003. So the matter in issue is required to be adjudicated and determined with the help of document filed by the plaintiff including other evidence, adduced by the parties. - this case as has been made out does not come within the mischief of Section 13(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 and accordingly the decision taken by the Judge of the Artha Rin Adalat in order to dispose of the matter under Section 13(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 is absolutely illegal.

 

Radiant Garments Ltd. & Anr Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 159.

 

Article 102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section-34(l)

 

Issuing order of warrant of Arrest in a case under Artha Rin Adalat Ain,

 

Held; In the instant case, the application by which warrant of arrest was sought cannot be treated as an application in the eye of law since the same had not been signed by the official or authority of the bank neither the same had any verification. Simply it was filed by the concerned Advocate of the Respondent-Bank without following the procedure as observed above. -That being the position, the order impugned against should he declared to have been passed without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Marzan Abedin Vs. Artha Rin Adalat & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 184.

 

Article-102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Section-34(10)

 

Held; It is the cardinal principle of interpretation of statute that any provision of law, which takes away the man's freedom, should be construed strictly -the impugned order dated 26.5.2003 passed by the Aratha Rin Adalat, Comilla in Artha Decree Execution Case No. 44 of 1995 (arising out of Artha Rin Suit No. 182 of 1992) issuing warrant of arrest to put the writ petitioners in civil prison is hereby declared to have been passed without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Arun Kumar Sutradhar & Anr Vs. Joint District Judge & Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 489.

 

Article 102 read with Artha Rin Adalat Rin, 1990

 

Section 5(1) Since the writ petitioner did not raise any objection as to jurisdiction of the Artha Rin Adalat, rather accepted the decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat by filling a solenama, at execution stage the petitioner is now estopped from raising any question as to validity of the said decree as contended by the counsel of writ respondent No.3 auction-purchaser.

 

Held; But we are unable to accept this contention made by respondent No.3 action-purchaser, for, "Jurisdiction of courts is created by statutes; it can neither be conferred nor taken away by agreement or concession of parties to a litigation or of their lawyers" (vide 36 DLR (AD) at page 1). This petitioner though, at earlier stage, entered into an agreement with the decree-holder Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation having no knowledge about the legal position but subsequently, before the execution court, he, by filling an application, raised this question of jurisdiction and prayed for setting aside of the action-sale on that very ground also - the decree passed in Artha Rin Mortgaged Suit No. 152 of 1991 being without jurisdiction is a nullity and as such it is not executable. So, the whole proceeding of the Execution Case No.59 of 1994 started on the basis of that decree is illegal and consequently the auction sale of the mortgaged property in question also held in that execution case has been illegal.

 

Shahabuddin Ahmed -Vs- Joint District Judge &Anr 21 BLT (HCD) 567.

 

Article -102 read with Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance of the Bangladesh Water Development Board (Employees) Service Rules, 1982 Section -4

 

As it appears the High Court Division made the Rule absolute holding that the impugned order dated 28.4.2004 has been challenged by the writ petitioner on the ground that the officers and the staffs of the Board of Trustees cannot be treated as Finance Accounts and Audit Cadre under the Directorate of Finance of BWDB because the Board of Trustees has been created as per provisions of section 4 of the Government and Autonomous Body Corporation Employees Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance Ordinance 1982 and it has been given a separate entity and by dint of above Statute and so the employees of Board of Trustees has got their separate identity and cannot be considered as employees of ^srf^f Finance and Audit Accounts Cadre, and that before issuance of the impugned order dated 28.4.2004, similar order dated 3.3.1983 was issued by the respondent No.4 and then Ahmed Hossain (since deceased) filed Title Suit No.857 of 1985 seeking declaration that above order of amulgation is illegal and the above suit was decreed declaring that the said order dated 3.3.83 as illegal and void and on the basis of the said decree the respondent No.4, vide Memo dated 4.10.87, cancelled the earlier order dated 3.3.83 withdrawing the amalgamation but again, on the self same matter, the respondent No.4 issued the order dated 28.4.2004 disregarding the earlier verdict of the civil Court which manifestly being illegal and without any lawful authority, is liable to be struck down. -Held; we are of the view that the High Court Division  on  proper  consideration  of the materials on record arrived at a correct decision.

 

Bangladesh Water Development Board & Ors Vs. Md. Quamruzzaman 17 BLT (AD) 06.

 

Article-102 read with Bangladesh Abandoned Property (Control, manage and Disposal) Order, 1972 (P.O. No.16 of 1972)

 

The question of service or non-service of notice is a question of fact and determination thereof is required upon consideration of the evidence brought on record by the parties.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Anr Vs. Mrs. Rawshan Ara Begum & Anr 17 BLT (AD) 65.

 

Article 102 read with Bangladesh Bank Memo dated 07.10.1991

 

The High Court Division of hearing both sides made the rule absolute on the ground that the respondents had acquired a vested right on the basis of the Bangladesh Bank memo and the petitioner was estopped from denying the exemption of waiver of interest as proposed in the said memo. The High Court Division further directed the petitioner to allow the respondents waiver of 75% interest -Held, We do not find any illegality in the judgment of the High Court Division.

 

Sonali Bank Vs. Quaderia Publications and Products Ltd. & Ors. 17 BLT (AD) 148.

 

Article -102 read with BADC Employees Service Rules, 1990 Regulation -55(2) read with General Clauses Act, 1897; Section -21

 

In the instant case the vires of 55(2) though challenged the High Court Division declined to declare the regulation as ultra vires as the High Court Division thought it prudent to dispose of the case otherwise than by striking down the regulation. The approach of the High Court Division is appreciated because when a case can be decided without striking down the law but giving the relief to the petitioners that course is always better than striking down the law. In the instant case the High Court Division held that even Regulation 55(2) was not followed while terminating the services of the respondents and, therefore, the action of termination was declared illegal without striking down the regulation.

 

BADC & Ors Vs. Md. Shamsul Hague Mazumder & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 153.

 

Article -102 read with Bangladesh Petroleum Act, 1974 Section-4 read with Section-2(c)

"Petroleum operation"

 

The expression "Petroleum Operation" as found in section 4(2) and defined in section 2(e) of the said Act, 1974 has not stipulated for any kind of petroleum agreement with the Government or the Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation as a pre-condition to importing such Petroleum Product. But such agreement is required to be in place at the time and in course of exploration, extraction of the Petroleum Product, its development, exploitation, production, refining, processing or marketing. In other words, once the Petroleum product is found inside the country on import at the instance of any one except the Government or the Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation, Petroleum agreement is a condition precedent to dealing with such product. In the absence of any restriction imposed either in the Imports and Exports Control Act or in the Import Policy Order,-the Customs or the National Board of Revenue would not be competent to refuse clearance of any imported high speed diesel.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Q.C. Petroleum Limited & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 196.

 

Article -102 read with

 

Power to dismiss as an appointing authority

 

The Director General of was not empowered to discharge terminate any of the Class I and Class II employees can not be extended to the power to dismiss or terminate its employee, since the power to exercise penal provision of terminating ridesharing an employee rehires categorical empowerment either by the provision of law or service or regulations.

 

Md. Abdul Majid Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 518.

 

Article -102 read with Constitution of Bangladesh Muktijoddha Sangsad

 

Section-33 (gha) S.R.O. No. 217 dated 06.09.2007

 

The High Court Division held "Upon a careful reading to the said clause it appears to us that the impugned Ad-hoc Committee has been formed for an unlimited period which is nothing but malafide and illegal allowing the respondents for holding the office of the Bangladesh Muktijoddah Sangshad, Central Command Council and without arranging any election. This type of Ad-hoc Committee is not only contrary to the provision of Article 33(Gha) of the Constitution of Muktijoddah Sangshad but also contrary to the exixting law of the country." In such situation High Court Division had not alternative but to hold S.R.O. No.217 dated 06.09.2007 was issued with malafide intention and on violating the spirit of the Constitution of the Bangladesh Muktijoddah Sangshad, Central Command Council and also against the exixting law of the country -leave petition is dismissed.

 

Jatio Muktijoddah Council & Ors Vs. Bangladesh Muktijoddah Sangshad & Ors 18 BLT (AD) 306.

 

Article -102 read with Bangladesh (Freedom fighters) Welfare Foundation Order, 1972

 

Principle of Natural Justice -Administrative Proceeding

 

It has been noticed that before stopping the honorarium of the petitioners had not served any notice or asked them to show cause as to why the honorarium shall not be stopped. It appears further the petitioners were not given any fair opportunity of being heard and thus action stopping the honorarium is ex-facie violative of the principle of natural justice. Whatever action has been taken by way of stopping the state honorarium is without lawful authority and of no legal effect.

 

Md. Bazlur Rahman & Ors Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 279.

 

Article-102 read with Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act, 1995 (Act No.l of 1995) Section-5

Doctrine of the Public Trust

 

Government being the Executive wing of the State is also under an obligation to obey law, protect law and act in accordance with law made by the legislature and in no way the Government can violate the law— the state is Trustee of all natural resources and being a Trustee is under a legal duty to protect the natural resources -Held; The Director General of Environment, Bangladesh is directed to appoint a Director having its office at Cox's Bazar to protect the area which have been declared Ecologically Critical Area relating to Cox's Bazar Sea Beach by notification dated 19.4.1999 and is further directed to demarcate the Ecologically Critical Area putting pillar within 6 months from date of receipt of the order.

 

Public Trust Case 18 BLT (HCD) 323.

 

Article-102 read with Article-117(2) read with Bangladesh Service Rules Regulation No. 22 (IV) read with Rule 73

 

As it appears the High Court Division discharged the Rules relying on the case of Junnur Rahman vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha and others, reported in 51 DLR(AD) 116, Delwar Hossain Mia (Md) and another vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others, reported in 52 DLR(AD) 120, Shamsul Islam Khan vs. Secretary, Ministry of Communications, Roads and Highways, reported in 8 BLT(AD) 120 holding'that the Appellate Division in a series of cases has taken a consistent view that a person in the service of the Republic who intends to challenge the vires of a law on the ground of violation of fundamental right may seek his remedy under Article 102 of the Constitution but in all other cases he will seek remedy under Article 117(2) and that on the terms and the conditions of service the Administrative Tribunal possesses the exclusive jurisdiction to hear the dispute and that in the instant writ petitions the petitioners did not challenge the vires of any law on the ground of violation of their fundamental rights and the petitioners, being employees of Bangladesh bank, the Administrative Tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction to hear the dispute in relation to the impugned orders of suspension of the petitioners. The High Court Division also referred to -the case of Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh vs. S.M.
