Fariduddin reported in 21 BLD(AD) 155 wherein it was further held that when a person in the service of Bangladesh Bank is suspended he is to follow that order of suspension and if by the order of suspension any of the terms and conditions of service is violated his remedy lies before the Administrative Tribunal—We are of the view that the High Court Divisian-on-proper consideration of the materials on record and the law involved arrived at a correct decision and there is no illegality or infirmity in the above decision so as to call for any interference.

 

Shahadat Hossain Mina & Ors Vs. Governor, Bangladesh Bank & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 155.

 

Article-102 read with Building Construction Act, 1952 Section-3B(l)

 

Layout of the revised plan Held; The car parking space, reserved in the approval plan, is being occupied by the petitioners; as such no illegality is found to issue the impugned notice under section 3B(I) of the Building Construction Act, 1952.

 

Khondkar Mobarak Hossain & Ors Vs Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 174.

 

Article 102 read with Bank Companies Act, 1991 Section-45 read with Grameen Bank Ordinance, 1983; Section-14(l) read with General Clauses Act, 1897; Section-16

 

The Writ petitioner, aged 70, is the Managing Director of Grameen Bank, a body established under the Grameen Bank Ordinance, 1983. In 2006, the petitioner became the first Bangladeshi to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize jointly with Grameen Bank for their efforts to create economic and social development by extending loans without collaterals or guarantees to its borrowers by creating repayment responsibilities solely resting on individual borrowers who are organised into groups—the petitioner has been holding the post for about 10 years violating the statutory provisions of Sections 14 and 36 of the Ordinance and Regulation 50.1 of the Service Regulations, 1993. But it is a long established principle of law that there -ssfbe no estoppels or waiver against any statutory provisions. In this regard another long established principle of law is that where there is inherent illegality or lack of jurisdiction, mere lapse of time or even consent thereto cannot validate or confer jurisdiction to it—Under Sub-Section (l)(Ka) and Sub-Section (1 )(Gha) of the Section 45 of the Bank Companies Act, 1991 Bangladesh Bank enjoys the authority to pass any direction on all or any of the Bank-Companies in the public interest or for ensuring proper management of the Bank-Companies/ Company respectively, if it is so satisfied. Section 14(1) of the Ordinance contemplates that nobody can be appointed Managing Director of Grameen Bank without prior approval of Bangladesh Bank i.e. without prior approval of Bangladesh Bank nobody can hold the post of Managing Director of Grameen Bank. But it is unreasonable to say that if anybody is appointed or allowed to hold the post of the Managing Director without such prior approval, Bangladesh Bank has nothing to do but to be an onlooker. In order to maintain proper management, administrative discipline and rule of law and thereby to secure public interest, Bangladesh Bank certainly can pass necessary directions and take effective measures in exercise its powers under Section 45 of the Bank Companies Act, 1991 and Section 14(1) of the Ordinance preventing such unauthorised activities and not allowing to continue such holding of the post. Even as per Section 16 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, the power of Bangladesh Bank under Section 14(1) of the Ordinance to grant prior approval to the appointment of Managing Director also includes its power to withdraw such approval.

 

Professor Muhammad Yunus Vs Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 331.

 

Article -102 with Article 47(3) read with Bengal Jail Code Rule – 910

 

Whether any suspected accused under the International War Crimes Tribunal claim fundamental right guaranteed in Part III of the Constitution of Bangladesh.

 

The High Court Division is of the view that the respondents are under trial prisoners in connection with different cases and on consideration of their social and political status, they can not be denied and/or deprived of their right or entitlement of benefits and status as per Jail Code. In arriving at such conclusion the High Court Division has taken into consideration Rule 910 of the Bengal Jail Code. - In view of the above, the High Court Division committed no illegality in directing the respondents to provide the petitioners Division-1 status under the Jail Code. There is no merit in this petition.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Abdul Quader Mollah & Anr 20 BLT (AD) 240.

 

Article 102 read with Biman Bangladesh Airlines Limited

 

Without prefer appeal - Whether the termination letters issued by Bangladesh Biman Corporation and subsequently it has been converted into Biman Bangladesh Airlines Limited which is a public limited company against which application under Article 102 of the Constitution can be maintained.

 

The writ petitioners were terminated under Regulation 52(1) of the Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulation, 1979 and subsequently Bangladesh Biman Corporation has been converted into Biman Bangladesh Airlines Limited which was incorporated under the provision of the Companies Act, 1994 to take over the functions and works of erstwhile Bangladesh Biman Corporation - Held; In the instant case, Bangladesh Biman Corporation has been converted into a public limited company namely Biman Bangladesh Airlines Limited nevertheless it is directly under the control and supervision of the Government and as such its decisions and orders are amenable in writ jurisdiction. In the instant case the impugned orders of termination were passed prior to Bangladesh Biman Corporation was converted into a private limited company and the instant Rules relate to decisions at the time and as such the Rules are maintainable on that score as well.

 

Emran Ahmed & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 01.

 

Article 102 read with Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employee (Service) Regulations, 1979 Regulation 52(1) Legitimate expectation

 

Administrative arbitrary high handedness -even if the administrative authority has the right to exercise its power of termination of service of its employee, such power must not be exercised arbitrarily and whimsically but must be exercised fairly and reasonably. - In the instant case the employees of Biman have been working for the corporation for several years and they cannot be terminated from service suddenly by taking recourse to such a provision without assigning any reason. This clearly shows administrative arbitrary high handedness and cannot be justified simply on the plea that it is termination simpliciter and does not attract any stigma. -we are of the view that the petitioner's terminations from service were done unlawfully and without lawful authority.

 

Emran Ahmed & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 01.

 

Article -102 read with Bangladesh Abandoned Property (Taking Over Possession) Rules, 1972 Rule - 6(3) read with Abandoned Buildings (Supplementary Provisions) Ordinance, 1985; Section-5(l)(a)

Maintainability - locus standi

 

Held; The building was constructed as a residential building but simply letting out the same for alleged commercial purpose could not attract the provision regarding the commercial building under rule 6(3) of the Abandoned Property (Taking Over Possession) Rules, 1972 and the alleged purchase was of no avail to the petitioner and have not acquired any locus standi. Moreover, as the alleged purchase was made at a time when the property has already been declared abandoned and accordingly vested in the Government as abandoned property rendering the deed of transfer in favour of the petitioner as void and the alleged transferee have not acquired any interest in the abandoned property, as such, the appellant-petitioner has no locus standi to file the writ petition and thereby writ petition and consequently, this appeal at the instance of the alleged purchaser during the continuance of the property as abandoned is not maintainable.

 

Mohammad Abdul Alim Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 19.

 

Article-102 read with BCIC Employees Service Regulations, 1988 read with Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 "Pay Off

 

High Court Division held that the termination of the service of the writ- petitioner in the name of 'Pay Off was made without any lawful authority and thus has no legal effect. The Court further directed the respondents to reinstate the writ petitioners to their serviced on condition that they would refund the termination benefits paid to them. In coming to this finding the Court held that the service conditions of,the petitioners were being regulated under the BCIC Employees Service Regulation, 1988, there is no provision for such "Pay Off in the said Regulations. Held; It appears that the High Court Division while making the rule absolute directed the writ petitioners to return their entire benefits taken by them to the BCIC before their reinstatement. It further appears that the impugned orders in all the writ petitions have been declared to have been passed without lawful authority, but the High Court Division directed that the reinstatement shall be done only after return of the benefits taken by the employees to the BCIC. Such direction of the High Court Division does not suffer from any legal infirmity.

 

Md. Nazrul Islam & Ors Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 147.

 

Article-102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; Order-47 Rule-1

 

Review Petition Nos.4-6 of 1998 as against the judgment of the High Court Division in Writ Petition Nos.l 170-1172 of 1995 stating amongst others that valuable document i.e. notification No.901- Reqn dated February 14, 1950 made under section 5(7) of the (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948 (Act 13 of 1948) published in the Dhaka Gazette on February 23, 1950 at page 126 finally acquiring 31.46 acres of land (by correction of the notification, No.901 wherein total quantity of land was mentioned 29.77 acres) could not be gathered and discovered at the time of hearing of the writ petition and as such could not be placed before the Court and that the said Gazette Notification having been discovered the review petitions are being filed by the writ Respondent No.5 i.e. appellant herein. -The High Court Division while heard the review petitions observed that the petition for leave to appeal filed by the writ-Respondent No.5 against the judgment of the High Court Division in the writ petitions were dismissed on the ground of limitation and as such petitions for review of the judgment against which petitions for leave to appeal were filed but dismissed can not be entertained. The High Court Division also refused to entertain the review petition on the ground of delay and that because of absence of the explanation as to how the delay occurred. On the aforesaid findings rejected the review applications. -The fact of acquisition of 31.47 acres of land, which the writ-petitioner-Respondents claimed out side the acquired land, having been established by the Gazette Notification No.901-Reqn dated February 14, 1950 published in the Dhaka Gazette on February 23, 1950 and the Gazette Notification No.7068-Reqn dated August 15, 1951 the judgment passed in the aforesaid writ petitions was not sustainable in law and as such the High Court Division was in serious error in rejecting the review petitions.

 

Chairman, T&T Board, Vs. Md. Rafiqur Gaznavi & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 179.

 

Article 102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Section 11

 

The principle of res-judicata within the meaning of Section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is not applicable in the writ jurisdiction. Moreover, when the parties to the litigation, the issues in the adjudication, the property in question and, the cause of actions are same and the issues are finally disposed of by a competent court, the applicability of res-judicata comes into operation. But as this court finds that the Respondent No.2 the Registrar of Supreme Court was not a party in the earlier writ petition No.7316 of 2003, the issue brought in the instant writ petition as to the legality and propriety of the order of suspension and the departmental proceeding against the writ petition and non adjudication of the cause as brought in the said Writ Petition No.7316 of 2003, being apparent on the thee of the orders of that writ petition, this court finds that the question of res-judicata is immaterial within the meaning of Section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, so far the cause brought in the instant writ petition.

 

Sontosh Kumer Saha Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Article-102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Section-11

 

Whether the writ Petition is hit by the principle of resjudicate

 

On 28.03.1996 the constitution (Thirteenth Amendment) Act, 1996 (Act No.l of 1996) was promulgated. The Thirteenth Amendment was initially challenged in Writ Petition No. 1729 of 1996. That writ petition was summarily rejected on the ground that the provision of the impugned Act did not fall within the definition of alteration, substitution or repeal of any provision of the Constitution and as such it was not an amendment as contemplated under Article 142 of the Constitution. The selfsame Thirteenth Amendment was again challenged in Writ Petition No. 4112 of 1999 (the instant writ petition) contending that the said Act was ultra vires the Constitution.

 

 

Article-102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order-1 Rule-10(2)

The present Civil Appeal is having great public importance - The Writ Petitioner who diedduring pendency of the present appeal and the applicant is having the same grievance of writ petitioner.

 

Article - 102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order 41 Rule 23

 

Prayed for sending the case back on remand to the Court of Settlement so as to afford, an opportunity to consider the documents which are annexed by supplementary affidavit by the writ petitioner

 

It appears from an affidavit (Annexure-K to the writ petition) that the petitioner sworn in on 08.04.2001 wherein the petitioner categorically stated that on 10.8.2000 when the settlement case was heard the original deeds and documents were submitted to the Court of Settlement by a "Firisty" which have not been considered by the Court of Settlement. The LCR does not show that any such original deeds and documents were filed by way of firisty. It is to be mentioned here that the hearing was concluded on 10.8.2000  and the judgment was delivered on 15.01.2001 and during these five months between the date of hearing and the delivery of judgment  no  such  affidavit  has  been sworn in. The affidavit was sworn in on 08.4.2001   before filing of the instant writ petition. The petitioner has filed a supplementary affidavit before this Court annexing some photocopies of documents save and except the petitioner's purchase deed dated 10.11.1973. It clearly shows that the petitioner has failed to produce any original deed or documents in respect of the case holding. - The judgment and order passed by the Court of Settlement is hereby declared to have been passed legally lawfully and having its jurisdiction.

 

Aminur Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Settlement Court & Anr 20 BLT (HCD) 392.

 

Article -102 read with Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Order 41 Rule 24

 

Vacating the order of stay - an undertaking that all the petitioners will be given a shop in the proposed shopping complex at the ground floor with equal floor space

 

Held; Since the respondent No. 1 has given undertaking to allot shops in favour of each of the petitioners on the ground floor of the proposed shopping complex with equal floor space, we find that the order of stay should be vacated for the smooth construction of the development work.

 

S.M. Zahid Rezvi & Ors Vs. Magura Pourashava & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 16.

 

Article-102 read with Children Act, 1974 Section-2(j)

 

Place of safety

 

A place of safety is clearly defined in the Act itself and no mention is made to the effect that any prison will be a place of safety for any child. A child is defined within section 2(1) of the Children Act as any one below the age of 16. There is no provision within the Children Act or any other law which permits any judge to send a child during the pendency of a trial to be held in custody within any prison. — Children held in the prisons, whose age is below 16 years, are being held there illegally and without lawful authority and are to be removed from prison forthwith.

 

The State Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 376.

 

Article -102 read with Companies Act, 1994 (as amended) Section 397

 

Whether alleged forged resignation letter in the compliant petition went far beyond what Section 397 contemplates. A fortiori, the Court below also can not take the said alleged resignation letter into consideration.

 

Held; the alleged resignation letter, as mentioned in the Complaint Petition by the Registrar, shall not be taken into account by the Court below in considering whether an offence under Section 397 of the Act has been proved or not.

 

Tea Hung Packaging (BD) Ltd. & Ors Vs. Joint Stock Companies and Firms & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 487.

 

Article-102 read with Companies Act, 1994 Section-347

 

The Petitioner is entitled to get the certified copies of the Returns on payment of prescribed fees as provided in Section 347 of the Companies Act, 1994 and the respondant No.l is legally bound to provide the certified copies of the Returns on demand. But it appears that the respondant No.l refrained from issuing the certified copies of the Returns to the petitioner inspite of several request -In the facts and circumstances of the case the respondent No.l is liable to be directed to provide the petitioner with the certified copies of the Returns submitted by it.

 

Fareast Finance & Investment Ltd. Vs Joint Stock Companies and Firms & Anr 19 BLT (HCD) 209.

 

Article -102 read with Contract Act, 1872 (Act No.IX of 1872) Sections -4,5 & 73 Right of Legitimate expectation - prayer for executing the lease deed

 

The offer of the writ-respondent was accepted by the writ-petitioner. Consequently there was a concluded contract between the writ-respondent No.l and writ-petitioner -The fact of making repeated demands by the petitioner to the authority for executing the lease deed was not disputed. The High Court Division in the background of the facts brought on record by the writ- petitioner and the Respondent has observed "From the facts disclosed in the writ petition which the respondents did not deny, it is apparent that the petitioner has an legitimate expectation for having a registered lease deed and to that event the petitioner complied with all terms and conditions of the allotment letter (Annexure-B) and paid entire money in 1997. If the petitioner deposited this money in the Bank then he would get interest on this money. In the instant case we find respondents executed and registered lease deeds in respect of 3 other plots but the petitioner having been on the same footing was not getting a registered lease deed. It smells bad odour. We do not know what prevented the respondents from executing and registering the lease deed in favour of the petitioner when the respondents executed other lease deed of other 3 plots who are standing on the same footing with the petitioner. We find that the respondents acted malafide and whimsically in not registering the lease deed in favour of the petitioner. The ground for not registering the lease deed as it appears from the affidavits of respondent Nos.l and 3, that there is a dispute as to which Ministry of the land belonged. The affidavit of respondent No.l is something interesting wherein respondent No.l disclosed that some persons who are powerful then the Government were instrumental in allotting the plot of the Railway through Respondent No.l. What a surprising discloser by the Government. It is very ridiculous that respondent No.l on sworning affidavit (on 30.1.2001) disclosing this fact. However we are not entering into the merits and demerits of the affidavits filed by the respondents but we are of the opinion that whether the disputed property belonged to respondent No.l or respondent No.3, it is a dispute between two Ministry for which the petitioner a citizen should not suffer. The petitioner who has performed all the formalities as required under law of annexure-B and legitimately waited for having a lease deed from the Government should not suffer for inter Ministerial dispute. From the aforesaid facts of the case we find the petitioner has acquired a vested right for having a lease deed registered in respect of plot No.Ka(l) from respondent No.l." The High Court Division has also observed "On the Question of possession we find that the claim of respondent No.3 is far from truth as it is admitted by respondent No.l that the petitioner was given possession as back as on 9.10.95 (Annexure-D) and thereafter the petitioner by erecting and one storied structure displaying signboard continuing his business. This fact has not been denied by respondent Nos.l and 3. As such possession claimed by respondent No.3 is nothing but on papers." - On perusal of the judgment of the High Court Division we find that the contentions of the petitioner before this Court was addressed by the High Court Division making reference to the materials on record. The learned Advocate-on-record could not point out error in the judgment sought to be appealed calling for interference by this court.

 

Bangladesh Railway Vs. Abdul Huq & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 07.

 

Article-102 read with Customs Act, Section-81

Whether the encashment of Bank guarantee without final assessment in contrary to Section 81 of the Customs Act.

 

Section 81(2) of the Customs Act categorically says that the final assessment is to be made within 150 working days from the date of release of the goods on the basis of provisional assessment and since more than 180 days have passed after provisional assessment made on 17.5.2005, the Customs authority under no circumstances can ask for encashment of the bank buarantee. Thus, since the respondents failed to obtain an expert opinion and since the respondents failed to assess the goods finally within 150 working days from the date of provisional assessment the order for encashment of the bank guarantee by the impugned letter is illegal and without lawful authority.

 

Nasir Glass Industries Ltd. Vs. National Board of Revenue & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 242.

 

Article - 102 read with Customs Act, 1969; Section - 196B

 

Not maintainable

 

The High Court Division held that in the instant case the petitioner's having failed to get relief from the highest authority of the respondent No.2 after exhausting all the forums of appeal, revision and review as prescribed in Customs Act, 1969, cannot get any relief under Article 102 as they were given a fair deal by the authority in accordance with law.-Held; We are of the view that the High Court Division on proper consideration of the materials on record and the law applicable, arrived at a correct decision and accordingly the decision does not call for any interference.

 

M/s. R.M. Corporation Ltd. Vs. Customs, Excise & VAT Appellate Tribunal & Ors 20 BLT (AD )31.

 

Article - 102 read with Customs Act, 1969 (as amended) Section -193

 

Maintainability

 

In the instant case, pursuant to SRO No.56 dated 16.3.1999 the importer made all arrangement for import of the specified of taxicab as per specification detailed in SRO applying with the terms and conditions thereto allowing them a right to get the consignment in question cleared on payment of specified duty at 7.5 percent as allowed by the said notification, prevalent at the time when the Letters of Credit were opened complying with the terms and condition specified therein. The petitioners alleged that their vested right cannot be taken away by subsequent SRO No. 158 dated 12.6.2003 which not only deprived them of their right but also illegal and malafide. Upon arrival of the consignment at the customs frontier the importer submitted the Bills of Entry but the customs authority instead of assessing the same on the basis of SRO No.56 dated 16.3.1999 assessed the customs duty at the rate 15% on the basis of impugned SRO No. 158 dated 12.6.2003 on the plea ihai section 30 the Customs Act provides that (he rate of duty applicable to any imported goods shall be rate of duty prevailing on llic date of the filing of the Bills of Entry for clearance of the import in question. --Held; since no disputed question of fact need he gone into and that only interpretation of certain provision of law as to the applicability of the same in a admitted given situation being the efficacious remedy, the importer could avail the writ jurisdiction for speedy and adequate remedy in order to release their goods instead of restoring to section 193 of the Customs Act.

 

Commissioner of Customs Vs. Cab Express (BD) Ltd & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 60.

 

Article-102 read with Customs Act, 1969 (As Amended); Section-25(7)

 

In the instant case in order to challenged vires only

The appellant has impugned the notification in SRO N0.214Ain/93/1527 /Sulkla dated 28.10.1993 fixing tariff value in respect of his import in question, subject-matter of letter of credit opened on 18.4.1994 and 19.5.1994 respectively. Thus the appellants prior to opening of the letters of credit were aware of the notification fixing tariff value for the imports and to their own volition, knowing fully well about the prevalent tariff value opened the letters of credit and thus have acquiesced the tariff value in respect of the imports. The notification though could be challenged being in violative of any law and legal right in the appropriate forum but in (he instant case in order to challenged vires only of the same, resort could be had lo writ jurisdiction for a declaration that the notification as has been passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. Thus the appellants as a businessman was aware of the notification and prior to the initiation of any step for importation of the import has not challenged the same to be illegal or to have been passed without any lawful authority but imported the goods acquiescing the notification, for which acquisscence may also be inferred under the circumstances which may operate as well an estoppel by conduct. Though there is no estoppel against law but in the facts and circumstances of the case we have already found that the notification does not suffer from any legal infirmity i.e. no law or any legal right has been violated and the notification has been issued in accordance with law.

 

Mahfizul Hoque & Ors Vs. Collector of Customs, Chittagong & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 182.

 

Article -102 read with Rule-4 (l)(Kha)

 

The petitioner is a Mukti Jodda Bahumukhi Samabaya Samity -we find that the Corporation in exercise of power conferred under section 159 and 97(3) of Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983 promulgated wherein section 4 provides for proportion of allotment of shops in each public markets, under corporation. -Held; petitioner-'s Samity is entitled to get allotment of shops from the reserved quota of Mayor.

 

Muktijoddha Bahumukhi Samabaya Samity. Vs  Govt.  of  Bangladesh & Ors 17  BLT (HCD) 184.

 

Article - 102 read with Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983 Section 125

 

Maintenance or administration of the graveyard — the construction of link road does not come within the work maintenance and administration of the graveyard as contemplated in Section 125 of the Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983

 

In no way any graveyard can be allowed to be used for other purpose even like construction of public road. It is absolutely against the statutory provisions of law as contemplated in Section 125 of the Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983. The Map filed by the respondent, the Dhaka City Corporation, clearly speaks that the proposed road construction work will go lo destroy thousands of existing grave including the grave of martyrs which cannot be allowed to be done for alleged public benefit. So, the Dhaka City Corporation has rightly considered the public sentiment and has stopped the work of the Contractor which should not be interfered with. The action taken by the Dhaka City Corporation to stop the construction work should not be withdrawn in any future occasion. In fact, keeping the provisions of law as contemplated in Section 125 of the Ordinance, 1983 alive Dhaka City Corporation has got no authority to undertake such a project of construction of a road through graveyard for the cause of any one's benefit.

 

Human Rights & Peace for Bd. & Anr Vs. Dhaka City Corporation & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 156.

 

Article-102 read with Employment Notification No.25318 dated 21.06.2009

 

The petitioner is the son of a freedom fighter and according to Government Circulars, a Ward of a freedom fighter is legally-entitled to be appointed in the employment of the Government department in reserve quota of 30% kept for the freedom fighters and in their absence their Wards. The petitioner, a ward of freedom fighter as per term No. 13 of the Employment Notice No. 25318 dated 21.6.2009 (Annexure-B to the writ petition) applied for appointment to the vacant post of Health Assistant for Kamolnagar Upazilla, Lakhmipur District in the reserve quota of 30% kept for the freedom fighters and in their absence their wards as per Government Circular as contended by the learned counsel for the petitioner -Held; It appears that for recruitment in the Government Department/ Autonomous Bodies Semi-autonomous Bodies the quota of 30% reserved for the freedom fighters and in their absence their wards must have to be ensured. From the result sheet (Annexure-El) it appears the petitioner qualified for appointment as Health Assistant for Kamolnagar Upazilla, Lakhmipur District and thus he ought to have been considered for appointment by the respondents.

 

M. Reas Uddin Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 240.

 

Article - 102 read with Environment Conservation Act, 1995

 

Public interest litigation - to protect the environment and the water body known as Gulshan-Mohakhali Lake.

 

So far as the subjects lakes are concerned, the respondent No.2 has not deflected the allegation, aspersions and assertions contained therein. This respondent, has through it's pleading on the contrary, tacitly admitted these. This respondent is in full concord with the allegation that Gulshan-Mahakhali-Banani, and Gulshan-Baridhara Lakes have been facing incogitant intrusions from grabbers and polluters without respite, as a result of which the garbage and waste deposition are drying up the lake. Plots are being created by filling parts of the lakes, something which are being done by the authorities them selves. They have failed to take steps to hold back those out there to fill in the lakes. The authorities have not demarcated the lakes, no walkways have been paved, no sewage system exists in the area - we are in no qualm to arrive at the inevitable conclusion that the petitioners have succeeded to substantiate their case with a visibly high preponderance, making the Rule absolute.

 

Omar Sadat & Anr Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 19

 

Article - 102 read with Environmental Preservation Act, 1995 ; Section -14

 

Interpretation of Law - without prefer appeal, writ petition is maintainable.

 

The impugned order of assessment of damage and penalizing the petitioner without giving him any opportunity of being heard is violative of the principles of audi alteram partem. The order of the respondent No.2 charge with the duty of complying with natural justice in the exercise of power before restricting the fundamental right of a citizen is void ab-initio and of no legal efficacy. Since the question of interpretation of law is involved in the instant petition so this petition is maintainable.

 

R.F. Properties Ltd. & Ors Vs. Dept. of Environment & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 34.

 

Article-102 read with Enemy Property Ordinance (Ordinance No.l of 1965)

 

Colourable assumption of law

 

The High Court Division, held that the inactions of the writ-respondents tantamount to abetment to such unauthorized possession of the case property by the illegal occupants; that alleged enlistment, if any, of the case property in 1997 as vested property by the writ-respondents is a clear violation of the provisions of law and colourful exercise of power. It is evident that the V.P. case in question was started in 1997 and before that time there was no occasion to treat the case property as a vested property. In the absence of any legal basis the exercise of powers by the writ-respondents to treat the case property as vested property in 1997 does not only tantamount to illegal exercise of power by colourable assumption of law but also amounts total disregard shown to the rights of the writ-petitioner which is obviously malafide and without jurisdiction. —The enlistment of any property after 1974 as vested property as illegal and without lawful Authority as the law of enemy property became inoperative and no property could be declared as enemy property after the repeal of Ordinance No.l of 1965 on 23.03.1974.

 

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Dhaka Memon Anjuman 20  BLT (AD) 07.

 

Article - 102 read with East Bengal (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948; Section 5(l)(a) read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section - 114(e)

 

Whether the Notice had been served in accordance with law

Held; In the case of Bangladesh and another Vs. Fazle Karim reported in 42 DLR (AD) Page 91, it has been observed by their Lordships of the Appellate Division that the presumption of service of public notice for acquisition of property being an official act, a presumption is available under the Evidence Act that it has been regularly performed unless the contrary is proved. Section 114(e) of the Evidence Act, provided that the Court may presume that the judicial and official acts have been regularly performed. Where once making of an order under a statute has been proved, there may well be a presumption that it was duly made as required by law. Once the publication of the orders in the official Gazette are established the process of publications should be presumed to have been considered sufficient. Since the proceedings took place long ago the same must be presumed to be regular. Similarly, where the report states that symbolical possession is delivered, there is a presumption as to formalities having been complied with. Irregularity is not to be presumed, but a party alleging it may prove it. The writ petitioners did not take any step to rebut the presumption.

 

Mongol Chandra Sarker & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh 20 BLT (HCD) 162.

 

Article 102 read with Easement Act, 1882

 

Since the respondents took substantial sums of money, we will imply in the lease agreement a term to the effect that the tenancy would not abruptly be terminated. Under that principle rights have definitely accrued to all the petitioners. In addition a right has also vested in the petitioners pursuant to Easement Act. 1882. In view of the right the petitioners have as stated above, the respondents have no power to evict the petitioners in the pretext of the need to demolish the building and reconstruction of the same. If the respondents desire to build a new complex that has to be in full agreement with all the petitioners. However, it will be to the petitioners' benefit to have a new building and from that point of view it is expected that the petitioners will agree to the demolition of the old one and construction of a new one. However, that must be arrived at in consensus between the petitioners and the respondents. In the proposed new building, if the respondents want to construct any such building, the petitioners must be accommodated in the floors which they presently occupy in the old building. Obviously the value of the premises in the new building will be enhanced. So the respondents and the petitioners must agree to a value when they will be accommodated in the new building. That can possibly the best done if the value of the present building is first assessed and the value of the new premises in the new building is compared. In other word, the petitioner must be accommodated in a space which shall represent the present value of their present occupation. In conspectus, the petitioners can not and, must not be placed in inv disadvantageous situation.

 

Md. Monjurul Alain  Or Vs. Corf of Bangladesh & Ors 21 1UJII('D)438.

 

Article - 102 road with Fajil and Kami Madrasha Affiliation Rules, 2006-07 Rule 11.2

 

Approving the Special Type of Governing Body of the Madrasha.

 

As it appears from the original copy of   the Memorandum    of   Association    that   the Madrasha named Hazi Ehsan Mohammad Karigori Kamil Madrasha has not been taken over by the said Hazi Ehsan Lajiba Sharif Parama Foundation, Rule 11.2 of the Fajil and Kamil Madrasha Affiliated Rules, 2006- 07 has no manner of application to the said Madrasha and accordingly the Registrar, Islamic University, Kushtia, has lawfully refrained from approving the Special Type of Governing Body of the said Madrasha as sent by the petitioner.

 

Alhaj Qayum Reza Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 251.

 

Article 102 read with High Court Division Rules, 1860 Rule 3(d)

 

Any proposal for the degradation or suspension of Assistant Judge, Senior Assistant Judges and the Joint District Judges and any proposal for dismissal from service of the judicial officers must be placed before General Administration Committee (G. A, Committee) of the High Court Division of the Bangladesh Supreme Court for recommendation and all such recommendations made by the G. A. Committee must be placed before the Full Court of the High Court Division for finality -The petitioner was placed under suspension with the initiation of two disciplinary proceeding against him without compliance of the mandatory provision of rule 3(d) Chapter 1 Part 1 of the High Court Division Rules, which required the placement of such proposal for suspension and initiation of disciplinary proceeding before the General Administration Committee and then to the Full Court of the High Court Division and as such the same have been made and initiated without lawful authority.

 

Sontosh Kumer Saha Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 386.

 

Article -102 read with Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 Section-152(2)

 

It appears that the instant Certificate Case was initiated for Execution of the order passed by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes. The petitioner who is the assessee filed an appeal under section 152(2) Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 before the Settlement Commission which is yet to decide the matter on merit. In the meantime the General Certificate Officer proceeded under P.D.R. Act to realize the amount assessed by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes. The petitioner filed an application for adjournment but the same was rejected. -Held; The proceeding of Certificate Case No.26 of 2002-2003 is stayed till final decision passed by the Taxes Settlement of Commission in accordance with law.

 

Dr. S.M. Eunus Ali Vs General Certificate Officer & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 121.

 

Article-102 read with Jatiya Biswabiddalaya Karmachari (Srinkhhala-O-Appeal) Sangbidhi

 

Sangbidhi-8

 

It appears that the authority took up the case of the respondent like a permanent staff and proceeded against her under Sangbidhi-8 of the Jatiya Biswabiddalaya Karmachari (Srinkkhala-O-Appeal) Sangbidi. But she was not given any reasonable opportunity to defend herself. The authority without giving any chance to the respondent to be present at the time of examining the witnesses or without giving her any chance to cross-examine the witness and without issuing any 2nd show cause notice along with inquiry report, passed the order of termination with stigma and therefore, the order suffers from gross illegalities and passed in violation of the principles of natural justice. But if there by any fault with her she may be dealt with in accordance with law.

 

National University & Ors Vs. Begum Sultana Razia 17  BLT (AD) 190.

 

Article 102 read with Local Government (Union Parishads) Act 2009; Section-75

 

As the resolution has been communicated to the Upazilla Nirbahi Officer as per provisions of section 75 of the Act, so it was the duty of the respondent No. 4, Upozilla Nirbahi Officer to take steps as per provisions of the said law but inspite of Notice Demanding Justice he did not take any step and thereby he failed to comply with his statutory duties to deal with the matter in accordance with law. Section 75 of the Act as quoted above clearly provided that the Government can cancel or stay the resolution of the Parishad after due compliance of the provisions of sub-section (2) of section 75 of the Act -it would be just and proper to direct the respondent No. 4 to take action as per provisions of Section 75 of the Local Government (Union Parishads) Act, 2009 on basis of the resolution dated 20.12.2009 as communicated to him.

 

Asia Khatun & Ors Vs The Election Commission & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 11.

 

Article-102 read with Local Government (Municipality) Election Rules, 2010 Rule 39(2)

 

In the instant case, the writ petitioner was declared elected defeating his nearest rival candidate the respondent No. 7. The respondent No. 7 filed election petition before the Election Tribunal for declaration that he is the elected Mayor and result declaring the petitioner as Mayor is void. - The respondent no. 7 adduced 10 witnesses in support of his case. On the other hand, the petitioner adduced 9 witnesses. At that stage, the respondent No.7 filed application for recounting the votes of all centres. The election Tribunal allowed that application. Election Appellate Tribunal affirmed that order.

 

Held; Prayer for recount in term of Rule 39(2) of the Local Government (Municipality) Election Rules, 2010 was not made by or on behalf of any of the contesting candidates including the respondent No.7 before the Presiding Officer of any of Polling Station which they would ordinarily have made if there was any truth in the pleas canvassed by the respondent No.7 in his election petition and application for recounting. - The evidence adduced by the respondent No.7 are unreliable. No definite particulars have been given in the application for inspection as to the illegalities, irregularities or improper counting of votes. A recount will not be granted as a matter of right but only on the basis of evidence of good grounds for believing that there has been a mistake in counting. The reasons are that such an order affects the secrecy of ballots which is under the law is not to be lightly disturbed. The secrecy of ballot is sacrosanct and shall not be permitted to be violated and merely for asking or on vague and indefinite allegations or averments of general nature. Our view is that the averments made in the petition and the material brought on record by the respondent No.7 did not make out a case of recount. The allegations of irregularity or improper counting of ballots have not been pleaded adequately and specifically and the evidence adduced by the election petitioner regarding improper counting of ballots each of the Polling Centres are insufficient and the allegations are not at all proved. Both the Tribunals acted unlawfully in passing the order of inspection and recounting the ballot papers inasmuch as the respondent No.7 failed to establish the factual foundation of it by adducing sufficient evidence bringing specific allegation of improper counting of each of the Polling Centres. - Rule is made absolute.

 

Md. Afzal Hossain Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 66.

 

Article 102 read with Local Government (Upazilla Parishad) Ordinance, 2008; Rule - 47

Post election dispute

 

The High Court Division held that the irregularities and illegalities though not raised on the polling day yet can be resolved by the Election Commission in exercise of its supervisory and plenary power under Rule 93 of the Rules, 2009 inasmuch as election process starts with the publication of the election schedule and culminates with the publication of the election result in the official gazette. The High Court Division further noticed that before publication of result in the official gazette under Rule 47 of the Rules, 2008 the Election Commission in exercise of its plenary and supervisory power can act upon the post election dispute and after publication of the election result in the official gazette election dispute, if any shall have to be resolved by the election commission before the election tribunal set up under the law. - Held; In the above facts and circumstances, we are of the view that the High Court Division having considered all the materials on record and the submissions advanced on behalf of both the parties arrived at a correct decision which does not require, any interference by this Court.

 

Ataur Rahman Vs. Election Commission & Ors 20 BLT (AD) 99.

 

Article - 102 read with Marine Fisheries Ordinance, 1983 Sections 8 and 9 read with Marine

Fisheries Rules, 1983 Rules 3, 4, 5, 6 & 7 read with Merchant Shipping Ordinance, 1983; Sections 18 and 388

 

Whether prior approval/permission is required from the Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock to issue license and registration certificate

 

In the instant case, the trawlers originally belonged to the Government and the petitioners' purchased the said trawlers by auction and after obtaining possession, invested huge amount of money to make fit for catching fish from the deep sea and installed all kinds of equipments therein with an expectation to obtain registration and license and hence the petitioners' applied for license and registration to the concerned authority. - Concerned authority refused to grant registration and license on the ground that prior to issuance license and registration, an approval from the Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock would be needed. - Held; Upon over all scrutiny of the entire materials, along with the law and decisions, we find substance in the submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioners to the effect that no prior permission is required to issue license and registration certificate under the law. Rather it is the statutory duty of the functionaries to act in accordance with the provision of law and in this case the respondents having rejected the application for license and registration on the plea of taking prior permission from the Government have acted without lawful authority.

 

Md. Haidar Ali & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 20  BLT (HCD) 400.

 

1543

The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 (Part-3)

Citation: 19 BLT (AD) 104, 19 BLT (HCD) 19, 17 BLT (HCD) 365, 18 BLT (HCD) 188, 20 BLT (HCD) 59, 20 BLT (HCD) 329, 20 BLT (HCD) 425, 20 BLT (HCD) 84, 21 BLT (HCD) 177, 19 BLT (AD) 189,

Case Year: 1972

Subject: The Constitution

Delivery Date: 2018-07-11

The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972

 

ArticIe-102 read with Money Laundering Prevention Act, 2002 Section-2 and Section-13

 

Writ   petition   is   misconceived   and   is   not maintainable

 

Admittedly the alleged offences had been committed during the period from 01.01.2003 to 31.05.2007 but the FIR was lodged as late as on 26.10.2009 under the provisions of the Ain of 2009 which saved only the proceedings pending under the provisions of the Money Laundering Protirodh Ordinance 2008 (the "Ordinance of 2008") and the said Ordinance saved only the proceedings pending under the provisions of the Ain of 2002—after filing the charge-sheet fixed for taking cognizance but before taking cognizance the petitioner move the High Court Division under Article 102 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the initiation and continuation of the proceeding ACC G.R. Case under section 2 and 4(2) of the Money Laundering Protirodh Ain, 2009— Held; the writ petition "is misconceived one and not maintainable since vires of no law has been challenged. Secondly, the provision of Sub Article (1) of Article 35 of the Constitution will not be attracted since the offence as well as its punishment, if any, would be dealt with under the Ain of 2002. Thirdly, from a clear reading of the FIR, Investigation Report and other materials on record, a prima-facie case under Sections 2 and Section 13 of the Ain of 2002 has been disclosed and the prosecution may proceed in accordance with law, if so advised.

 

Tarique Rahman Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 104.

 

Regulation 39(l)(Ka)

 

The nomination of the respondant No.4 as President of the Ad-hoc Committee of the said school was accorded by the 'Board' rather by the Chairman, the respondant No.2 himself nominated as apparent from the impugned order dated 6.1.2010 (Annexure-M to the writ petition) which is contrary to regulation 39(1)(ka) of the Regulations, 2009. -Held; is liable to be declared to have been made and issued illegally, without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Al-haj Abdul Kader Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 19.

 

Article-102 read with The Primary schools (Taking over) Act, 1974 Section -3

 

Writ Petitioners became the government Servant as government Primary School Teachers since all the Primary school teachers functioning as Private Primary school were taken over by the government under the provisions of section 3 of Act No.8 of 1974 as contended by the learned Counsel of the Petitioners

 

Held; The petitioner admittedly was the functioning teacher of the primary school turned into a government servant as government primary school teacher. Therefore the petitioners were elegible for appointment in the government primary school as they were taken over through the provision of law.

 

Md. Shahjahan All & Ors Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 365.

 

Article-102 read with Pre-Shipment Inspection Rules, 2002 Rule-22(4)

 

In the instant case, it appears that the respondents neither followed the provisions laid down in the PSI Rules, 2002, nor the Valuation Rules, 2000, in proposing the assessment by giving load rather, it appears that though the petitioner submitted the Bill of Entry with relevant documents on 24.1.2006 but the respondents failed to take any decision till 7.3.2006. Moreover, in spite of clear direction given under Rule 22(4) of the PSI Rules, 2002, the respondents did not take any steps to release the goods by taking Bank Guarantee for the differential amount of duties and taxes on their demanded value, even after written representation dated 7.3.2006 by the petitioner. Such activities of the concern assessing authority is nothing but harassment to the petitioner and also disregard to the relevant provisions of law which are binding on the customs authority.

 

Marif Hossain Chowdhury Vs The Commissioner of Customs & ors 17 BLT (HCD) 420.

 

Article-102 read with President's Order No.149 of 1972 Article -2 and 28 read with President's

Order No. 27 of 1972 Article 4(1) and 10(A)

 

Held; The High Court Division found that the industrial concern M/S Eastern Tubes Limited which was incorporated in Bangladesh and more than 51 % shares were held by the petitioners of the writ petition though found to be absent from the Country but could not be allegedly found by the Government that they were nationals of a Country which were not at war with Bangladesh at the relevant time and their shares are not liable to be treated as abandoned and accordingly declared the letter dated 27.05.1987 for retention on 51% shares with the corporation was issued without any lawful authority and is of no legal effect and accordingly the same is liable to be released in favour of the writ petition after "ascertaining the shares on proper verification of shares of M/S Eastern Tubes Limited only in favour of the writ petitioner"—We do not find any -reason to interfere with the impugned judgment and hence the three appeals are dismissed without any order as to cost.

 

Arif A. Shekha & Ors Vs. Ministry of Industries & Anr 19 BLT (AD) 91.

 

Article-102 read with Passport Order, 1973

 

Passport authority must act bonafide and comply with all requirements of law

 

As provided in Bangladesh Passport Order, 1973 a citizen's passport may be impounded by the concerned authority in certain circumstances and in such situation the person concerned will be prevented from travelling abroad. In such situation, however, the passport authority must act bonafide and comply with all requirements of law failing which the restriction order will become void and unlawful.

 

Allama Delawar Hossain Sayedee Vs Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 188.

 

Article-102 read with Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974

 

Section-9(2) Whether orders of forced retirement is violative under Articles 27 and 31 of the Constitution.

 

The petitioners were retired allegedly on ground of Public interest -High Court Division held that a person any may be put on retirement for his age, but he cannot put on retirement with a stigma or blame as it made in the instant case -Held; it appears that the High Court Division has rightly passed the impugned order on detailed discussion holding the view that application of Section 9(2) of the Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 was not based on fact and the reasoning given by the High Court Division in making the Rules absolute in part, do not call for any interference. Thus we do not find any substances in the application.

 

Bangladesh Vs. Goutam Kumar Sana & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 169.

 

Article - 102 read with Public Servants (Retirement) (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No.V of 2010)

Section 4A

 

In the present case it appears from the materials on record that the petitioner was recognized as Mazibnagar employee by the government and subsequently she was absorbed in the service of the Republic and in the meantime, her service was rendered up to 57 years of age by entering the service of the Republic as a freedom fighter. So it is not required by law for such public servant to have certificate or identity, as a freedom fighter to be verified by the Ministry of Liberation War Affairs as the proviso exempts such public servant from such verification.

 

Mrs. Shahanara Begum Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 59.

 

Article - 102 read with Printing Presses and Publications (Declaration and Registration) Act, 1973 Section -7 read with Section - 9(3) (b) Writ of Mandamus- cancellation of declaration

 

Admittedly, the respective weekly newspaper namely "Saptahik Dak" could not be printed and published for 6(six) months by the writ petitioner because of the extenuating circumstances prevailing at the relevant period, for, he was detained in custody pursuant to the order of the Task Force on 18.04.2007. Ultimately, he was released from jail custody on 14.05.2009 pursuant to the order so had been passed by this Court. - In view of the said provision of section 7, the writ petitioner has option to make subscribe a fresh declaration as such he is at liberty to make the said prayer for afresh declaration of the respective newspaper namely "iMfl^5 'M ^W" within a period of 30(thirty) days and the respondents concern on receipt of the application is hereby directed to dispose of the same in accordance with law considering the facts and circumstances of the case.

 

Ad. Taimur Alam Khandakar Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 329.

 

Article - 102 read with Pre-shipment Inspection Rules, 2012 Section 22(4)

 

Held; This Court has found upon full satisfaction that in the facts and circumstances both the Respondent No. 7 PSI Agent and the Respondent No. 4 Assistant Commissioner have acted in flagrant violation of mandatorily applicable principles and standards of valuation. The arbitrariness evident in their actions is manifested in the fact that the law in this case is marked more by its breach than in its compliance. In reiteration this Court declarers that the Customs Authority in particular acted most illegally and arbitrarily by failing to comply with Rule 22(3) and not undertaking reassessment of valuation for levying appropriate Customs duties on the Goods. That failure is compounded further by the failure to accept a bank guarantee to secure a release of the Goods when at all material times it could readily be confirmed from the data available at the time of  assessment of duties that the CRF value is indeed not the correct "transaction value". -the above assessment of the Goods covered under L/C number 074211010387 dated 20.11.2011 lying under B/E No. C 3489 dated 9.1.2012 on the basis of CRF No. BV11 Iff862 dated 14.12.2011 valuation at a higher inflated rate ignoring the "transaction value" has indeed been done without lawful authority and is to be deemed to be of no legal effect.

 

Transcom Cables Limited Vs. Commissioner of Customs, & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 425.

 

Article 102 read with Public Corporation Management and Co­ordination (Amendment) Act, 1994 [Act NO.XVIII of 1994] Sections -2(e) and 14A Substantive right - age of retirement of a worker

 

The petitioner being a "Security Guard" definitely falls within the said category, for the nature and character of his duties and functions do not fall in the capacity of the managerial, administrative, supervisory or solely in clerical capacity -In that view of the matter, the petitioner is entitled to serve in the respective Mill till the age of 60 years.

 

Abul Hashem Doptari Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 182.

 

Article - 102 read with Penal Code, 1860; Section -154 read with Police Regulations of Bengal, 1861;

 

Regulation-252

 

High hand ness and misuse of power by the respective police officer

 

In the instant case, a Sub-Inspector of Police (respondent No.3) in the grab issued the notice upon the petitioner under section 154 of the Penal Code read with Regulation 252 of the Police Regulations, Bengal restraining the petitioner from enjoying the land in question by directing him to stop further construction on the case land and also to maintain status-quo - there is no existence of the criterions for invoking power by the respondent No.3 under Section 154 of the Penal Code read with regulation 252. This type of high-hand ness and misuse of power by the respective police officer must not be overlooked and the Superintendent of Police must take note of it - impugned notice declared to have been issued without lawful authority and hence, of no legal effect. The respondent No.3 is to pay costs of Tk.50,000/- to the petitioner within 60(sixty) days from the date of receiving the copy of this judgment and order.

 

Md. Kodor Ali Vs. Additional Deputy Commissioner & ors 20 BLT (HCD) 84.

 

Article 102 read with (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948 Section-8

 

A direction upon the respondents practically for release and restoring possession of a piece of land

 

Held; There is no dispute about the decision of the Government for release of the land in question, which was taken at the highest level. But even after the return of the compensation in pursuance of the aforesaid letter dated 03.01.91 why the Deputy. Commissioner did not take any steps for release of the land is not understood. We find no justification for keeping the release of the land from requisition pending so long - Respondent Nos.2 and 4 are hereby directed to issue a formal order of release from requisition and restore possession of the requisitioned land to the petitioners under Section 8 of the Act as prayed for within a period of 30 days of receipt of this order, positively.

 

A.Y. Mashiuzzaman & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (HCD) 177.

 

Article-102 read with Regulation, 2009 Regulation-38(2) and 39(l)(Ka)(Kha)

 

Cancellation of the Ad-hoc Governing Body and the appointment of new ad-hoc governing body for the Uttara High School and College

 

It appears from the appointment of the first Ad-hoc Governing Body and the second Ad-hoc Governing Body that the first Ad-hoc Governing Body has been made in accordance with law and following the provisions of the Regulations, 2009 but the second Ad-hoc Governing Body appears to have been made without following the provisions of the Regulations 2009 and that only change in the Ad-hoc Governing Bodies is in respect of the Post of President and the remaining three members of the Ad-hoc Governing Bodies were same and it further appears that the 2nd Ad-hoc Governing Body was appointed at the interference of the Ministry of Home Affairs, which is unwarranted -the President of the 2nd Ad-hoc Governing Body was not nominated by the Board, as required by the Regulation, 2009 and thus was exfacie an illegal appointment.

 

Bangladesh Vs. Md. Moazzem Hossain Bhuiyan & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 189.

 

Article-102 read with Red Crescent Order, 1973 Article- 9(b)(l)

 

There is no provision in the said Order entitling the President of the Red Crescent Society to extend the period by one year of its ad-hoc committee by one year and of its Chairman by two years, instead Article

9(b)(l) specifically provides that if for any reasons the general election could not be held the President shall appoint an ad-hoc committee or Managing Board to exercise the powers and perform functions for such Committee or Board for a period of 3 months and Article 9 (3) provides that an Ad-hoc Committee or Managing Board shall hold the general election within 3 months from the date of appointment of the Ad-hoc Committee or Board.

 

A.F.M. Obaidur Rahman & Ors Vs. Md. Asgar Ali & Ors 19 BLT (AD) 34

 

Article 102 read with

 

Held; the Election Commission being a constitutional body its satisfaction not according registration to the petitioner as a political party cannot be substituted by the satisfaction of this Court.

 

D P Vs. Election Commission & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 12.

 

Article - 102 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Rules, 1955 Rule – 42

 

Whether a notice issued for rehearing/ reconsideration of the appeal cases by the Settlement- Officer (Respondent No. 3) who passed the judgment and order under Rule 31 of the Tenancy Rules beyond the jurisdiction.

 

Held-respondent No. 3 has no jurisdiction to issue the impugned notice in consequence of above-order as the constitution of a committee and issuance of notice thereof is beyond the scope of Rules as contemplated in the Tenancy Rules, 1955- the impugned order dated 08.7.2002 passed by respondent No. 2 constituting a committee to rehear Appeal Case Nos.31335 of 2001, 31336 of 2001 and 41105 of 2001 and the notice dated 14.7.2002 issued by respondent No.3 for rehearing of above 3 cases on 24.07.2002 are declared to have been passed without lawful authority having no legal effect.

 

Emran Ahmed & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 20 BLT (HCD) 49.

 

Article 102 read with 2008, (Ordinance No.XXVII of 2008)

 

Whether the Ordinance No.XXVH of 2008 is ultra vires of the Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh

 

Held; The impugned Ordinance is ultra vires the Constitution on the reasons : Firstly, the Ordinance was promulgated on 8 June 2008, much beyond the tenure of 90 (ninety) days of the Non-Party Care-taker Government, established under the provisions of the Constitution (Thirteenth Amendment) Act, 1996, consequently, without jurisdiction being made by an illegitimate Government, as such, void ab inilio. However, the normal functions of the Government and other Constitutional Institutions were not illegal being condoned in the Thirteenth Amendment Case. Secondly, the Ordinance had nothing to do with the holding of the general election of members of Parliament, rather, contained a policy decision of the Government, as such, violative of Article 58D(1) of the Constitution.

 

Monzur Ahmed Bhuiyan & Ors Vs, Adilur Rahman Khan & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 97.

 

Article 102 read with Shipping (Engineer and Ship Surveyor of Inland Ships) Recruitment Rules, 1980

 

Whether the substituted Schedule of the Recruitment Rules of 1980 by the SRO No.39-Law/86 dated 23"' January, 1986 is the violation of the Articles 27 and 29(1) of the Constitution.

 

High Court Division held that amendment made in 1986 in the Rule of 1980 was not made to favour any body or to deprive any body in any respect and as such the amendment can not be considered malafide and writ-petitioner has no reason to challenge the amendment of the schedule of the Department of Shipping (Engineer and Ship Surveyor of Inland Ships) Recruitment Rules, 1980. - Held; High Court Division was quite correct in holding that amendment of the schedule of Department of Shipping (Engineer and Ship Surveyor of Inland Ships) Recruitment Rules, 1980 was not made to favour anybody or to deprive anybody.

 

Md. Muinuddin Zulfiquer Vs. Ministry of Shipping & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 132.

 

Article-102 read with Samabaya Samity Ain, 2001 Section-50(4)

 

As Arbitrator issued award setting aside the Election in Dispute Case

 

The petitioner without exhausting the forum available under sub section (4) of section 50 of the Ain, 2001 filed the instant Writ Petition. Therefore, the present Writ Petition is premature and, as such, it is not maintainable.

 

Md. Faruque Hossain Sumon Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 73.

 

Article -102 read with Stamp Act, 1899 Section-18

 

Locus Standi - the power of attorney executed outside Bangladesh, attested by Notary Public of that country and authenticated by Bangladesh High Commission in that country has a presumption of validity and that presumption not having been rebutted and the original owners are the aggrieved parties and not their attorney in that the attorney filed the writ petition for enforcement of his own authority to act as attorney and therefore, he is an aggrieved party within the meaning of Article 102 of the Constitution as contended by the Counsel of the Petitioner -The petitioner has no locus standi to file this writ petition in his own name as he is a mere attorney of the original owners as contended by the counsel of the Respondents -Held; we find sufficient force in the submission of the learned Counsel for the respondents and do not consider that the High Court Division committed any error of law for our interference.

 

Sitesh Bhattacharya Vs. Govt: of Bangladesh &Ors 17 BLT (AD) 115.

 

Article -102 read with Provisions of the SRO No.l80-Ain/99 dated 1.7.1999

 

Refusing tax exemption to the Petitioner

 

Mere Keeping 10% of the total number of beds for the poor is not enough. The spirit of the provision is that the 10% of the poor patients out of the total number of beds in the hospital, have actually to .be treated completely free of charges, in order to attract the application of the aforesaid provision, allowing exemption of tax. S.T.S. Holdings Limited Vs National Board of Revenue & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 574.

 

Article 102 read with

 

The High Court Division co mmitted no error of law in holding that Bidhimala 2002 does not apply in case of the respondent No. 5 of the writ petition. It is further held that reservation of 75% posts of the law and justice wing and the post of Secretary of the Ministry of Law is reserved for the judicial officers as provided for by Bidhimala 2002 to be read with Rules of 1998 for the Drafting Wing and Nitimala 2001 and the writ respondent No.5 has no authority to hold the post of Secretary-in-charge of that Ministry. We further hold that he has no authority to hold any other posts other than the post of the Additional Secretary, Drafting Wing and his present holding of the pqst of Secretary is without any lawful authority.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Aftabuddin & Anr 18 BLT (AD) 284.

 

Article-102 read with Tariff Schedule and Rules of BPDB Clause-7.1

 

It is not denied that the petitioner's business was inspected by the Executive Engineer and it was duly categorized in the category C "small industry" and to change him from category C to category E "Commercial" would certainly require a notice to be issued and an opportunity to the petitioner to show cause if he so wishes -Held; we find that the respondents have changed the category of use of electricity for the petitioner's business without any show cause notice which is illegal and without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.

 

Alhaj Md. Golam Masum Sarker Vs. PDB & Ors 19 BLT (HCD) 607.

 

Article-102 read with Union Parishad Ordinance, 1983; Section-19

 

The Delimitation Officer acted outside his terms of reference in issuing public Notice for hearing objections for naming the two proposed Unions. The matter of hearing objections was completed by the Upazila Nirbahi Officer, Galachipa vide his public Notice dated 17.9.2002 much earlier that is on 26.9.2002 following which the Deputy Commissioner, Patuakhali directed the Delimitation officer as per provisions of section 19 of the Union parished ordinance, 1983 to delimit the area of the said two Unions namely Bakulbaria and Kalagachia Unions as well as the territorial limits of the Thana with the said area. His act of hearing objections on the name of the Unions and there after changing the name of Kalagachia Union to Kallayan Kalash Union appears to have been done in excess of his jurisdiction and the subsequent naming of the said Unions as notified in the gazette published dated 30.1.2003 as Kallayan Kalash Union appears to have been done illegally and without lawful authority.

 

Shoeb Ahmed Masud Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 18 BLT (HCD) 77.

 

Article-102 read with Value Added Tax Act, 1991 Sections-59 and 67 read with Value Added Tax Rules, 1991; Rule-12

 

Claim for release of the Bank Guarantee

 

It appears that the predecessor of the petitioner company did not raise any objection against the outstanding arrear VAT liability demanded by the respondent authority as contained in Annexure-El on the ground of non-compliance of procedure of the VAT Act before making the demand. In the circumstances of the case after submission of the Bank Guarantee No.l01TS1241LG07 dated 07.05.2007 for Tk.2,75,42,815.02 supported by an unconditional undertaking by all the directors of the petitioner company against the outstanding VAT liability of Tk.2,75,42,815.02 the claim for release of the Bank Guarantee is not tenable in law. However, the petitioner company can claim refund of any mistaken payment or excessive payment in respect of VAT turnover tax or any other dues if any to the respondent

authority as envisaged in Section 67 of the VAT Act.

 

Nuvista Pharma Ltd. Vs. The Chairman & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 330.

 

Article -102 read with Valued Added Tax Act, 1991 Section-9(2)

 

Under section 9(2) of the VAT Act the authority can direct to adjust but without giving chance of hearing cannot directly cancel the rebate obtained and accordingly adjust the current account register. Here we find that the authority by Annexure-'B' directly cancelled the rebate obtained and adjusted the current Account Register which is not in accordance with law. This aspect was not considered by the Tribunal as such the impugned order of the Tribunal is without any lawful authority.

 

M/s.Partex Beverage Vs Govt: of Bangladesh & Ors 17 BLT (HCD) 321.

 

Article-102 (2)

 

The High Court Division while exercising its jurisdiction under Article 102(2) of the Constitution in respect of the judgment of a tribunal or in other words exercises its jurisdiction in certiorari is certainly not acting as a Court to appeal and to re-assess the evidence and finally to arrive at a view different from the tribunal in the absence of arriving at a finding that the view taken by the tribunal in the background of the materials noticed by it is not legally tenable or logically not well founded.

 

Govt: of Bangladesh & Anr Vs. Mrs. Rawshan Ara Begum & Anr 17 BLT (AD) 65.

 

Article-102(2)

 

Certiorari—'equally efficacious'

 

The  words   'no  other equally  efficacious remedy is provided by law'  appearing in clause (2) of Article 102 is very pertinent as well as important because that is the precondition for exercising the power of the High Court Division to issue the writ in the nature of certiorari. It should be noted in this connection that no word of the Constitution can be ignored and must be given due weight and importance to its meaning. As such, before issuing any such order the High Court Division must be satisfied that 'no other equally efficacious remedy' is available. But it must also be noted that the available remedy, is not mere efficacious, it must also be 'equally efficacious'. If the High Court Division is satisfied that the available remedy is only efficacious but not equally efficacious, then in exercise of its discretion may issue necessary orders, depending on the facts and circumstances of the case in hand.

 

Siddique Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 23.

 

Article -102(2)(1)

 

A court of law has no power to give effect to any right not recognised by law. It is not the function of a court of justice to enforce or give effect to moral obligations which do not carry with them the legal or equitable rights. -In this view of the legal position, the Full Bench has committed illegality in directing the Government for appointment of the 10(ten) Additional Judges as permanent Judges of the High Court Division on the ground that the recommendation of the Chief Justice has primacy and the illegality has further been compounded due to the fact that the gap of 5-6 years between the act of non-appointment by the executive government and the direction of the Special Bench of the High Court Division by the impugned judgment has been treated as special leave without pay inasmuch as it is in utter violation of the provisions of the Supreme Court Judges (Leave, Pension and , Privileges) Ordinance. 1982.

 

Bangladesh & Ors Vs. Md. Idrisur Rahman & Ors 17 BLT (AD) 231.

 

Article - 102(2)(a)(ii)

 

As per Mr. Justice Mohammad Anwarul Haque; On perusal of the recital of the application it is clear that 195 Prisoners of War, the alleged perpetrators of the crime against humanity; were not under the custody of Bangladesh at the time of the agreement, rather they were under the custody of India and they were handed over to Pakistan to protect the better interest of the country under a peace agreement and now after lapse of 36 years that can not be declared illegal by invoking writ jurisdiction, which is absolutely unrealistic and absurd, rather it is clearly a product of ulterior motive. Moreover publication of list of 3 (three) million martyrs and an auxiliary force are also an unrealistic and absurd proposition, which no court should entertain in any form. - hence it is summarily rejected.

 

 

As per Mr. Justice Sayed Abu Kowser Md. Dabirush Shan; I have examined the writ petition and heard the submission of both the learned Counsel for the petitioner and respondents, I find substance and force in the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner hence let a Rule Nisi be issued.

 

As per Mr. Justice Muhammad human Ali; It is unfortunate that the learned advocate sought fit to file the instant writ petition in the same words as the previous one in spite of the fact that the earlier writ petition with the exact same facts, grounds and prayer was rejected summarily. This has caused unnecessary expense and wastage of valuable Court time. -In the facts and circumstances    above,    the    instant    writ petition is rejected summarily.

 

Wing Commander M. Hamidullah  BP  Vs. Bangladesh & Ors  20 BLT (HCD) 324.

 

Article-102(2)(a)(ii)

 

Challenging the legality of Section 3 of the Constitution  Amendment) Act, 1986

 

On comparison of Section 2 of the Constitution (Fifth Amendment) Act, 1979, with Section 3 of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1986, it would appear that the purpose of both the provisions are same. Both the provisions were enacted to give validity and legitimacy to the Martial Law Proclamations, Regulations, Orders, Instructions etc. and all kinds of proceedings, functions and transactions made thereunder. Section 3 of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1986, is however, more elaborate than the earlier Section 2 of the Constitution (Fifth Amendment) Act, 1979. But by both the enactments, the Martial Law Proclamations, Proclamation Orders, Chief Martial Law Administrator's Orders, Martial Law Regulations, Martial Law Orders, Martial Law Instructions, Ordinances and all other laws made during the periods of Martial Law from 1975 to 1979 and from 1982 to 1986, were sought to be ratified and confirmed and declared to be validly made respectively by the Second and Third Parliament of Bangladesh. The purpose in both the cases is to give legitimacy to the illegal and unconstitutional acts of the Martial Law Authorities and its vassals -Since the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1986, is similar to that of the Constitution (Fifth Amendment) Act, 1979, we need not discuss and repeat all those points all over again, rather, we agree, accept and uphold what were decided in the Fifth Amendment case.

 

Siddique Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 21 BLT (AD) 23.

 

Article 102(2)(a)(ii) read with Anti-Corruption Commission Rules, 2007 Rule 15(2)

 

Admittedly the writ petitioner was a fugitive from justice on the date he moved the writ petition.-The initiation of the criminal proceeding against the writ petitioner being violative of Rule 15(2) of the Anti-Corruption Commission Rules, 2007, all subsequent steps taken in the proceedings including the conviction and sentence are vitiated, and thus, the writ petitioner having no other alternative remedy invoked his fundamental rights in writ jurisdiction, in which, the High Court Division on being satisfied, exercised its jurisdiction irrespective of the fact that the Special Judge issued a process, but in an illegal proceeding as contended by the learned Counsel for the writ petitioner.

 

Held; In our opinion, the mailer does not relate to jurisdiction but to one of propriety, principles and established practice. In our country, it is obligatory to submit to the due process of law who seeks the interference on revision of a judicial order. The rule of law depends upon definite principles and binding precedent, which together make for certainty, uniformity and predictability. These in turn provide the foundation of fairness injustice delivery system.

 

Anti-Corruption Vs. Dr. H.B.M. Iqbal Alamgir & Ors. 18 BLT (AD) 266.

 

Article-102(2)(a)(ii) Read with Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 Section 561A

 

Orders of Conviction and sentence passed in martial law Courts The inherent power of the High Court Division under section 561A of the Code can only be invoked if the proceedings are under the provisions of the Code. It does not provide any relief if the trials are not conducted under the provisions of the Code. Since the convictions were made by the various Martial Law Courts, illegally constituted under the Martial Law Proclamations and Regulations and not under the Code, the inherent power of the High Court Division under the provisions of section 561 A, cannot be invoked.
